HEADLINE: Whitman's Budget Reflects State's Boom

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
With growth in the economy and state revenue outstripping nearly every projection, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will propose a budget for 2001 that amounts to an across-the-board loosening of the state's fiscal belt, including a record $1.1 billion for transportation and other capital programs, $760 million more in relief for taxpayers and aid to schools and towns, and hundreds of millions more for colleges and needy hospitals, her closest advisers said today.
Spending would rise 8.9 percent, to $21.2 billion, compared with the governor's 2000 budget, the advisers said. And borrowing, a frequent target for Mrs. Whitman's critics, would continue to grow. But even if the New Jersey economy begins to cool slightly, the state's receipts would rise fast enough to provide another huge surplus at year's end, they said: $850 million, or about 4 percent of expenditures. 
 The governor is to unveil the details of her budget on Monday, but her chief counsel, Rick Mroz, and the state treasurer, Roland M. Machold, briefed reporters.
Mr. Mroz stressed that $10 billion, or half the budget, was devoted to aid for school districts and municipalities and to direct property tax relief to taxpayers. "Providing the largest package of property tax relief in our history means that citizens, not the government, get to decide how their hard-earned dollars are spent," he said.
The new spending programs, the advisers said, include a panoply of modest initiatives, like $10 million toward an eventual $200 million fund to help cultural groups raise capital, and the hiring of 640 new state workers -- among them 70 state troopers, and enough guards to open two new juvenile detention wards to alleviate crowding.
Also announced today were a series of changes to New Jersey Best, a program that helps families save for a child's college education. Annual charges would drop to $5 from $15 and the management fee would be cut to 0.5 percent of assets from 1 percent, younger participants would be able to invest more in riskier equities and the maximum scholarships would rise to $1,500 from $500.
One area of higher spending likely to underwhelm the recipients is $30 million for smoking prevention and cessation programs, to be set aside from an expected $471 million from the nationwide settlement of tobacco-industry litigation. An antismoking coalition has pushed for $76 million in such programs, comparable to what Florida spends.
In her speech on Monday, Governor Whitman is expected to detail a $10 billion school construction program that could rely on another $200 million from the tobacco settlement to pay for debt service.
An additional $100 million from the settlement, officials said, would pay for FamilyCare, a new initiative to reduce the number of adults who lack health insurance, estimated at 950,000. With other state money, matching federal funds and payments by workers and employers, that program could reach $206 million and provide coverage for 125,000 of the so-called working poor, who are not covered by Medicaid but cannot afford insurance.
New Jersey's financially troubled hospital industry would get a much-needed $80 million from FamilyCare. But that could pale next to another $549 million in new aid that officials said the state's 81 hospitals could expect next year, from several sources. Hospitals that provide free care to the most indigent patients would get a one-time federal reimbursement of $365 million, and an extra $30 million from the state. Hospitals that lost money from the failure of HIP Health Plan of New Jersey Inc. would receive $54 million from a state bailout package negotiated last week, and the state is expecting that improved documentation by hospitals of their treatment of Medicare patients would produce an increase of $100 million in federal reimbursements.
The governor's advisers also confirmed today that Governor Whitman had agreed to refinance the state's depleted Transportation Trust Fund to pay for $1 billion in road and bridge projects each year, using $750 million in bonds and $250 million in capital appropriations. The deal with legislative leaders would mean an increase of $221 million in spending from the state's general revenues, and an increase of $580 million in borrowing.
Mr. Machold, the treasurer, said the state's economic boom showed every sign of lasting for at least another year. Nonetheless, he said, the state's forecasts constitute a slight ratcheting down of revenue expectations from a year ago: growth in sales tax receipts is predicted to be 7.5 percent in the coming year, down from the 10.5 percent increase that was envisioned in the budget adopted last July.
The surplus originally projected for the current budget year, which ends in June, was $783 million, but it is now expected to top $1.1 billion. That cushion allowed officials writing the 2001 budget to include $326 million more in spending than they expect the state to receive in taxes. Even so, the new budget includes a projected surplus in June 2001 of $850 million.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Dims His View of Russia's Future

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The Clinton administration's top policy maker on Russia, in his annual assessment of where that country is headed, has presented a more wary review this time, even hinting at the possible return of some Soviet habits.
The policy official, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, said in a speech at Oxford University in England on Friday that the war in Chechnya and the transfer of power to Acting President Vladimir V. Putin raised the question of how the resurgence of Russian nationalism would assert itself. 
 One consistent theme about Mr. Putin, among many inconsistencies, Mr. Talbott said, is his desire "to see Russia regain its strength, its sense of national pride and purpose."
"In and of itself, that goal is not only understandable, its achievement is indispensable," Mr. Talbott said. "It all depends on how Russia defines strength, how it defines security. Will it do so in today's terms, or yesterday's -- in terms that are proving successful elsewhere, or in terms that have already proved disastrous for Russia under Soviet rule?"
Mr. Talbott then raised another issue: "Will Russia recognize that in an age of global -- and regional -- interdependence, the porousness of borders is a necessity out of which a viable state must make a virtue? Or will it fall back into the habit of treating this and other facts of life as a vulnerability to be neutralized or -- that most Soviet of all verbs -- to be liquidated?"
He also pondered, but did not give a conclusion on, whether Russia would understand that in Chechnya, "indiscriminate aerial attacks, forced movement of populations and civilian roundups" are the work of a "weak and desperate state, not a strong and clearheaded one."
The speech was more skeptical than an address the deputy secretary gave at Stanford University in 1997. Then, he said that Russia "may have turned the tide -- it may be on the brink of a breakthrough." It was also more downbeat than a second speech he gave at Stanford in 1998, titled The Case for Strategic Patience in a Time of Troubles.
But while Mr. Talbott, who has been criticized in some quarters as a Russophile, chose a sterner tone than he has used in the past, his speech was far less critical of Moscow than an essay in the current issue of The New York Review of Books by Sergei Kovalev, a Russian human rights campaigner who is a member of the Russian Parliament.
Mr. Kovalev predicted that Mr. Putin would build "an authoritarian-police regime that will preserve the formal characteristics of democracy, and will most likely try to carry out reforms leading to a market economy."
"Life will not be sweet for Russia's fledgling civil society," he said.
Mr. Talbott only elliptically dealt with Mr. Putin's embrace of the Communists in the Parliament this week, which resulted in a walkout of pro-democratic factions.
"We can speculate together -- and that's all we can do at this point -- on exactly what he's up to in his recent parliamentary maneuvers," Mr. Talbott said.
Addressing Russia's war against rebels in Chechnya, Mr. Talbott said the military campaign is a "gruesome reminder of how hard it is for Russia to break free of its own past." He blamed the reformist government in Moscow in 1992 and 1993 and the governments after the 1994-96 Chechnya war for leaving Chechnya to its own devices, thus fueling the appetite for total independence in the republic.

HEADLINE: Grandmothers Cite Family Values in Effort to Take Cuban Boy Home

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
There is no Disney World in Cuba. But in Cuba, the grandmothers of Elian Gonzalez say, there are the boy's father and a family that loves him, the familiar streets where he played and the school where his first-grade classmates have kept his chair empty, awaiting his return.
It is the world, the women said, that the 6-year-old boy most needs to recover from the accident that killed his mother last November as they and others tried to make their way to the United States in a boat that capsized and that left Elian clinging to an inner tube at sea for two days before he was rescued. 
 "We're not politicians," Maria Mariela Quintana, 51, Elian's paternal grandmother, said in an interview early Saturday morning. "What we want is the well-being of the child."
"If they're human," she said, referring to the relatives in Miami who are blocking Elian's return to Cuba, "we beg them to think about the child's well-being too."
Mrs. Quintana and Raquel Rodriguez, 51, Elian's maternal grandmother, arrived in New York City on Friday to present a united front against the Florida relatives who have taken care of the boy since the Nov. 25 accident. The relatives, a brother of Elian's paternal grandfather and other members of the father's side of the family, have argued that Elian would have a better life in the United States than in a socialist state. The great-uncle, Lazaro Gonzalez, filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday challenging the Immigration and Naturalization Service's decision Jan. 4 to return the boy to Cuba.
This is the first time anyone from Elian's family in Cuba -- which in addition to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, includes both sets of grandparents -- has come to the United States to press the father's custody claim. The women flew from Havana in a private plane chartered by the National Council of Churches, an association of 35 Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations that favors the reunification of the child with his father.
The women flew to Washington on Saturday for a meeting with Attorney General Janet Reno and Doris Meissner, commissioner of the immigration service. The grandmothers were to return to New York, where they are staying in the home of Joan Brown Campbell, the church council's general secretary. They said the purpose of the trip was to enlist the help of American officials to retrieve their grandson.
Ms. Reno and Ms. Meissner said after meeting with the grandmothers that they would seek an early resolution to the matter in federal court.
"We maintain that the law recognizes the unique relationship between parent and child," Ms. Reno and Ms. Meissner said in a statement, "and that family reunification has long been a cornerstone of both American immigration law and I.N.S. practice."
Earlier, speaking in Spanish in Ms. Brown Campbell's living room, the grandmothers made their case forcefully, becoming tearful as they talked about their grandson.
"I don't know why they want the child to stay here after the trauma he's been through," Mrs. Quintana said. "They are not close relatives."
Mrs. Quintana, a secretary for the Ministry of Justice in Cuba, said she brought with her legal papers empowering her to represent her son. She said the father stayed behind fearing he would meet more hostility than the women.
Elian's family dispute has escalated into a political tug-of-war as the government of Fidel Castro and Cuban-American organizations have seized on the case to reiterate their spite for each other in speeches and demonstrations. In the meantime, the grandmothers said they had been counting the days since Nov. 19, when they last saw Elian. After he and his mother, Elizabet Brotons Rodriguez, vanished, a co-worker of the mother told the family she had left for the United States.
"We went crazy," Mrs. Quintana said. "His father punched the walls, screaming and crying.
"They had been married for 13 years," Mrs. Quintana said of Elian's parents, "and she had had seven miscarriages. Both of them were obsessed with Elian. They and us. We have all raised him and spoiled him."
The grandmothers said Elian's mother told no one of the plans, and Ms. Rodriguez insisted her daughter was coerced into the risky journey across the Straits of Florida by the man she had lived with. Her daughter's boyfriend, Ms. Rodriguez said, controlled her to the point that he persuaded her to move out of her parents' home.
For days, the women said, the family was worried sick until they heard news of the accident that killed 11 people (including the boyfriend of Elian's mother) and of the rescue of a boy. They rushed to call relatives in Miami and urged them to take a picture of Elian to the hospital where they had taken the survivor.
But the joy of finding out that Elian had been saved turned to dismay as the great-uncles moved to prevent the child's return. Ms. Rodriguez bristled at assertions in Miami that her daughter would have wanted Elian to stay in the United States.
"None of them knew her," Ms. Rodriguez said. "How can they know what she thought?"
Elian's parents divorced three years ago -- and Mr. Gonzalez remarried and now has another son, who is 4 months old -- but the couple's relationship was close, "like a brother and sister," Mrs. Quintana said. Elian slept at his father's home part of the week, she said.
Both parents had government tourism jobs -- she as a hotel maid, he, still, as a hotel doorman and bartender -- and their access to dollars ensured that the family did not suffer the economic hardship of many others in Cuba, the women said. Asked whether she at any point had debated the decision to press for the boy's return, Mrs. Quintana asked: "Why stay in the United States if all his family is in Cuba? In Cuba he doesn't lack for anything."
The women said they had been unable to reach Elian, who has been taken to Disney World and showered with gifts by his American relatives and others.
After losing her only daughter, Ms. Rodriguez said, she wants to recover her only grandson. She said she was receiving psychiatric treatment in Cuba to cope with the family loss.
"I don't have her but I have him," she said. "But I don't have him."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Seeks to Link Bradley to the Reagan Era

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore sought today to link his Democratic opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, with what he said was a negative direction that President Ronald Reagan took the country in the 1980's.
Mr. Gore noted that Mr. Bradley has said he wanted to model his leadership style after that of Mr. Reagan, who focused on just a few big issues. Mr. Gore then recounted several matters that he said Mr. Reagan had ignored, allowing a quadrupling of the national debt, a rise in AIDS cases and an increase in unemployment, implying that a Bradley presidency would have the same disastrous consequences. 
 "By contrast, in the last seven and a half years, President Clinton and I have not turned our backs or turned away from any of the major fights that were important to the American people," Mr. Gore declared to 1,000 people at a rally at a campus field house here.
Mr. Gore has premised much of his newfound strength in the Democratic primary on being a fighter, and he has faulted Mr. Bradley for "quitting" the Senate, which he retired from in 1996.
Mr. Gore's portrayal of himself as a fighter, in contrast to Mr. Bradley as a quitter, has become the central theme of his campaign.
He hammered it today in a busy day of bus rides and plane trips across north-central Iowa to rally voters for Monday's Iowa caucuses. He campaigned in Fort Dodge with his wife, Tipper, and was joined here by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts.
While casting Mr. Bradley as a man of limited vision, Mr. Gore cast himself as caring about a range of issues and offered voters a veritable grab-bag of priorities.
As Mr. Gore said in Fort Dodge: "My expectations would be not to focus on just one issue but to keep on fighting for all of your interests against every challenge that the American people face, and move our people forward by focusing on health care and education, child care and Medicare, cleaning up the environment and keeping our economy strong. We need to keep our prosperity going, and we need to lift up the working people of the United States of America."
In discussing other topics, Mr. Gore called for more money for research into cancer and diabetes, spoke out against discrimination against gays and railed against striker-replacement laws.

HEADLINE: 'Senator Hillary' Is Bait in Mayor's Plea for Cash Across U.S.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
Thousands of conservatives across the country have been receiving frequent fund-raising letters in recent months from a newfound pen pal back East. "Does Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sound good to you?" begins one, and if that scenario does not make the recipients wince and lunge for their checkbooks, another is soon presented.
"Most political observers," the letter warns, "believe that Hillary Clinton is merely using this race as a steppingstone to even higher office." 
 The letters are signed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mrs. Clinton's probable opponent in the New York Senate contest, and they have been very successful at coaxing political contributions. Mr. Giuliani's campaign announced last week that it had collected $12 million in 1999, by far a record for the year before a Senate election.
While Mr. Giuliani is hoping that his accomplishments as mayor will convince voters that he deserves to go to Washington, he is discovering that when it comes to amassing a treasury, an equally formidable asset is Mrs. Clinton, otherwise known in these letters as "leader of the ultra left-wing Democrats," "darling of the left-wing elite" and "champion of every left-wing cause you can imagine." Not to mention purveyor of "radical schemes for the future."
Some conservative groups began using Mrs. Clinton's probable candidacy as a direct-mail fund-raising vehicle nearly a year ago, but the Giuliani campaign started only last June, and the strategy promptly proved to be a bonanza. The mayor's advisers say 40 percent of the donations collected by the campaign originate from direct mail, while the rest come through fund-raising events.
The advisers decline to say what percentage of the direct-mail donations are from outside of New York, but they acknowledge that it is significant. So even as Mr. Giuliani tars Mrs. Clinton as a carpetbagger with no ties to New York, his own campaign is thriving from out-of-state money.
Mrs. Clinton's advisers describe the language in the letters as outlandish, saying the mayor is collecting political money by pandering to arch-conservatives out of touch with the views of most New Yorkers. The mayor's advisers respond that people support him largely because of his record, and say Mrs. Clinton's supporters have made vitriolic attacks on him that she has not denounced.
Most Senate candidates seek donations through mass mailings. They rarely harvest much money out of state. What it takes is a polarizing figure like Mrs. Clinton or, on the other side, Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who is the bete noire of liberals.
In fact, it is very probable that anyone running against Mrs. Clinton would be flooded with donations from across the nation, political consultants say. When Mr. Giuliani ran for re-election in 1997, he did little, if any, direct-mail fund-raising. About 85 percent of the money he took in was donated by New Yorkers.
Seeking to learn how to press the right partisan buttons, the Giuliani Senate campaign has retained Richard A. Viguerie, who is considered a mastermind of conservative direct-mail solicitations and has turned demonizing the Clintons into a standard appeal.
Mr. Viguerie, who helped draft the Giuliani fund-raising letters, has worked for Senator Helms, Patrick J. Buchanan and others with far more conservative views on abortion and other social issues than the mayor.
Mr. Viguerie spearheaded the direct-mail operation in 1994 for Oliver L. North, the Iran-contra figure who set a record for fund-raising in a Senate race by a nonincumbent. Mr. North, a Virginia Republican, collected $21 million in his losing bid to unseat Senator Charles Robb. It is likely that Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Clinton will each collect more, in what could be the most expensive Senate race ever.
The Giuliani campaign has also bought lists of potential contributors from a company that offers "Anti-Clinton Republican Revolutionaries," "Dole Supporters" and "Capitalist Contributors."
New Yorkers will generally not receive these letters. The Giuliani campaign is mounting something of a two-pronged direct-mail effort. In writing to New Yorkers, the campaign is mindful that even Republicans in the state have not been as hostile to President and Mrs. Clinton as their brethren elsewhere.
The New York letters dwell more on the mayor's record on such issues as crime, welfare and the economy and often note his ties to New York. There are fewer references to the "left-wing" ideology of Mrs. Clinton.
"As someone who has lived in New York most of my life and understands the needs and concerns of the people," he writes, "I think I'll have a very powerful advantage as I take my message to the voters."
Mrs. Clinton's campaign, which has raised $8 million, has also undertaken a strenuous direct-mail effort outside of New York, and her celebrity has no doubt helped her to raise far more than a first-time candidate would otherwise be expected to collect. But because Mr. Giuliani does not evoke such passionate feelings outside New York, the Clinton campaign has not tried to construct its appeals around the mayor.
The Clinton campaign's appeals generally do not refer to Mr. Giuliani, instead denouncing attacks by unnamed opponents. "They can launch an anti-Hillary Web site," she wrote in a recent letter. "They can use their limitless war chests to run negative television ads. They can publish mean-spirited books and press releases. But they can never stop me for standing up for what I believe in."
Mrs. Clinton's advisers said they had expected that Mr. Giuliani would try to capitalize on antipathy toward Mrs. Clinton nationally, conceding that among some conservatives, she was even more unpopular than her husband. But, they said, they were taken aback by the language in some of the letters sent by the Giuliani campaign.
"These fund-raising letters are filled with vicious attacks against Hillary," said Howard Wolfson, a spokesman for the Clinton campaign. "They sound like they were written by Jesse Helms or Rush Limbaugh. It's clear that the mayor is working very hard to cozy up to the far right."
Bruce J. Teitelbaum, the mayor's campaign manager and an architect of his direct-mail strategy, said such criticism was hypocritical. He said some of Mrs. Clinton's supporters had publicly insulted Mr. Giuliani, without any protests from her.
"Gimme a break," Mr. Teitelbaum said. "For the past six months, Mrs. Clinton's surrogates have been bashing the mayor in the most pejorative terms -- that includes James Carville, who referred to the mayor's supporters as goons and thugs."
Mr. Teitelbaum disputed comments from Mrs. Clinton's advisers that the mayor was tapping into a "network of right-wing donors."
"When are they going to stop claiming everything is a result of a vast right-wing conspiracy?" Mr. Teitelbaum said.
Political consultants marveled at the response to the mailings. Most campaigns lose money on their first round of letters because the donations -- from generally 1 or 2 percent of recipients -- total less than the costs of the lists and other items.
But the campaigns often make money on subsequent mailings because they focus on those who gave in the first round.
But Mr. Giuliani's campaign began earning money on its first round of mailings, officials said. By the end of 1999, it had accumulated a list of 90,000 donors, most of whom could be expected to donate more.
"The ideal situation is running against a polarizing candidate who is known nationally," said Kieran Mahoney, a Republican consultant not involved in the Senate race. "Suddenly, instead of being able to raise money in the district or state, your universe is anybody who is alive. In all likelihood, Giuliani has only scratched the surface."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CANDIDATE;
Bradley's Long Day Ends on a High Note

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Jan. 22

 BODY:
After more than a week of strategic setbacks, sinking poll numbers and negative news coverage, former Senator Bill Bradley received a welcome lift tonight when he picked up the endorsement of Iowa's largest newspaper on the eve of this state's caucuses, the first event of the presidential primary season.
In an editorial that appears on Sunday, The Des Moines Register describes Mr. Bradley as a visionary leader "whose ideas and approach to governing most closely match the needs" of the rapidly changing times. "There is a fundamental decency about him that would bode well for healing the festering partisan wounds that have produced virtual stalemate in our national government," the editorial continues. 
 The editorial notes that choosing between Mr. Bradley and his lone rival for the Democratic nomination, Vice President Al Gore, was difficult, describing Mr. Gore as a "sharp" and "exceptionally" well-prepared candidate.
For Mr. Bradley, the endorsement could not have arrived sooner. In recent days, new polls have shown him falling further behind Mr. Gore, he disclosed that he had suffered four bouts of irregular heartbeats since late December and his honorary campaign chairman in Iowa died.
The announcement came at the end of a long day of campaigning through eastern Iowa where Mr. Bradley hammered at his pledge to spread prosperity to people who have not benefited from the nation's roaring economy.
"It's about time all of us got on this prosperity train," Mr. Bradley told 150 people at a school in Maquoketa, arguing that "the politics of plenty" made it possible for government to do more to help low-income people.
Though he tried to avoid mentioning Mr. Gore by name, Mr. Bradley repeatedly drew implicit contrasts with the vice president, suggesting that he would be a more confident, visionary leader than Mr. Gore. Throughout the campaign, Mr. Bradley has asserted that his proposals to restrict gun ownership, expand health care and reduce poverty were more sweeping than Mr. Gore's.
"I look out there and I say, 'What's at stake here in this election?' " Mr. Bradley said. "It's whether we're going to do something big or whether we're going to nibble around the edges. If you want to nibble around the edges, I'm not your guy."
In the afternoon, Gov. Tom Vilsack, a popular first-term Democrat, appeared with Mr. Bradley before a boisterous crowd of 300 people at an event promoting campaign finance reform in Dubuque. Mr. Vilsack is officially neutral in the race, but his wife and many of his aides have endorsed Mr. Gore.
Earlier in the day during a news conference, Mr. Bradley was asked if he thought his campaign had missed opportunities in Iowa, where he has matched the vice president in spending but trails him badly in polls. Mr. Bradley said no.
"I know I will leave here with the knowledge that we have run a strong campaign," he said. "I was never somebody who after a game would wake up in the middle of the night wondering what could have happened."
In Clinton and Maquoketa, Mr. Bradley received warmed greetings from crowds of 100 to 200 people, but the audiences were swollen by scores of volunteers from other states who cannot vote here, including a group of about 40 students from Wheaton College in Illinois who were helping the Bradley campaign in Iowa as part of political science project.
In recent days, some of Mr. Bradley's own supporters have been critical of his campaign. On Friday in Davenport, for instance, Bill Gluba, a volunteer for Mr. Bradley, complained that the campaign had spent too much money on commercials in Iowa -- $1.5 million -- and not enough on get-out-the-vote operations.

HEADLINE: Going Public Amid Sharks;
Insurers Look at Stocks As a Means of Survival

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
FOR the insurance companies of America, the sluggish cash cows of the financial world, the new century is dawning with a jarring Darwinian message: Either buy up your rivals or risk being swallowed yourself.
Now that Congress has done away with Depression-era barriers that fenced off banking, insurance and securities underwriting as separate businesses, almost everyone in the field, from giant American banks and brokerage houses to the financial powers of Europe, is looking for merger partners or takeover targets in a scramble to get bigger, chasing the dream of greater market share and, through economies of scale, greater profits. 
 Any combination now seems possible. But the insurance companies, with their huge stores of investable cash reserves, battalions of agents and flocks of customers, are seen as the choicest prizes. Because of their lumbering performance and relatively small size, they are particularly vulnerable.
"It is getting down to the eaters and the eatees," said David F. D'Alessandro, president and chief operations officer of the John Hancock Mutual Insurance Company in Boston. "I go to industry meetings and I see everyone eyeing everyone else, thinking, 'What would it be like to work for that guy? Would I want him working for me?' "
Like several of its biggest rivals, John Hancock is racing to throw off a crucial handicap: its mutual structure. On Thursday, Hancock will go public, converting from a company owned by policyholders to one owned by its stockholders. A few weeks later, Metropolitan Life plans to go public, and Prudential is also working on a conversion expected for later this year or early in 2001.
The executives who run these giant mutual insurers see conversion to stock ownership as crucial for their continued survival.
Without stock to use in mergers and takeovers, or options to attract and reward vital executives, companies with a mutual structure are seen as increasingly powerless to compete in a new financial services arena without boundaries.
But the offerings are not likely to excite investors the way initial public offerings usually do. Even with John Hancock's vaunted brand name, the company's shares are expected to open near book value and languish there, and Met Life can expect a similar reception.
Even so, once the offering is complete, Mr. D'Alessandro, who will become chief executive of John Hancock in June, is expected to dive into the thick of the buying as he tries to bulk up his company as a defense against takeover from the banks and other bigger, richer players.
Analysts say Metropolitan Life will be forced into the same sort of defensive strategy, gobbling up whatever companies it can to increase earnings and keep the other big fish from getting their jaws around it.
In such a headlong race for size, deals are being contemplated that may not be perfect fits and may not even follow good economic logic, at least for the companies: Naturally, creating megacorporations means more money and power for the people making the moves.
Evidence is still lacking that what America wants most is one-stop shopping on financial matters, the rationale behind many suggested bank-insurer and broker-insurer combinations. Most past efforts to construct financial services "supermarkets," notably by American Express and by Sears, Roebuck, did not last long.
BUT one company seems to be pulling it off, attracting would-be emulators from all points of the compass: the melding of banking, insurance and brokerage services under the banner of Citigroup. The creation of Citigroup has made its co-chief executive and one of its principal architects, Sanford I. Weill, the toast of the town.
"Everybody looks at Sandy Weill and goes, 'I want to be him,' " said Alice Schroeder, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc., "Frankly," she said, "being the C.E.O. of a great big huge company is more important than being the C.E.O. of a smaller company. And you get paid more. You might even get your picture on a magazine cover."
The wholesale consolidation of insurance and other financial businesses will be much less fun for those on lower rungs of the ladder. For one thing, thousands of jobs will be destroyed. Indeed, a driving force in taking over an insurance company is the buyer's conviction that it can be operated more efficiently. The idea is to run the back offices of both companies with roughly the staff of one, while piling on more sales people, more customers and more investment capital.
If the track record of banking mergers is any guide, another consequence of consolidation will be deterioration in customer service, as ever more dealings with the public are shunted to automated systems. Though a case can be made that heightened competition among giants in banking or securities brokerage has led to lower prices for some customers, insurance rates could instead be driven up, as mutual insurers, created and managed specifically to provide low-cost insurance, are converted into shareholder-owned businesses with profit as their main objective.
Any "surplus" generated by a mutual company was supposed to be returned to policyholders as dividends, effectively lowering the net cost of insurance; shareholders will expect profits to be plowed back into continued growth or used to buy back shares instead, while policyholders get just enough insurance benefits to stay ahead of the competition.
Over the next few years, the insurance industry is likely to resemble the oceanic food chain. The nimblest and most aggressive of the small insurers will gobble up slower and smaller rivals. Bigger insurers will probably swallow them, and others nearer their own size. At the top of the chain, huge financial conglomerates like Citigroup, G.E. Capital and the giant banks, brokerage firms and mutual funds are expected to devour many of the biggest insurers.
THE predators who may be eyeing the bigger fish in American insurance most avidly are the giant European insurance and banking companies. The world's two largest insurers, Allianz of Germany and AXA of France, already have substantial holdings in the United States; so do ING Group and Aegon from the Netherlands and Fortis of Belgium.
"The big European companies have made no secret that they plan to move into the United States in a bigger way," said Jeff Sawyer, who is in charge of insurance at Deloitte Consulting in New York. And their market capitalizations are large enough to make swallowing a major American acquisition feasible: investors value Allianz at about $85 billion, and AXA at $45 billion.
The best cross-industry merger fit may be between big retail banks and life insurers. Both are fundamentally in the investment business, and bank branches and insurance agents can readily sell each other's products. (In limited ways some already do.)
And it is easy to see similar advantages in a combination between property and casualty insurers on the one hand and consumer credit companies like mortgage lenders and auto-finance houses on the other.
Some banks, like Wells Fargo, have already expressed interest in owning insurance companies. Others, pointing to a history of insurance companies' tending to be less profitable than banks, say they may be better off with marketing agreements, earning fees from selling insurance but avoiding the heavy lifting of underwriting operations.
That reasoning sounds like a smoke screen to some analysts. "The insurance companies are a great fit for the banks," said Andrew S. Kligerman, an insurance analyst at Schroder & Company, which sold its investment banking and research units to Citigroup just last week. "But why should the banks broadcast their interest? Why not tell people, 'We're not interested,' and continue to see the insurance stocks trade at low multiples and get them cheap? The life companies are sitting ducks."
Two brokerage houses, Merrill Lynch and PaineWebber, already own small insurance companies, as does Fidelity Investments, the big mutual fund company. "Why not leverage that with the expertise and scale of a bigger insurer, and get some real bang out of those operations?" Mr. Kligerman said.
IMAGINING deals in the other direction, with insurers acquiring banks, is harder. As much as some insurance executives might want to get into the banking business, it seems unlikely that they will have the muscle to start out with a flourish by buying a big bank. "Banks have, on average, returns on equity in the high teens and low 20's," said Jon Boscia, chief executive of the Lincoln National Group, a life insurance and annuities company with a stock market value of about $7 billion. "That gives the banks high price-earnings multiples that make it virtually impossible for most insurance companies, with substantially lower price-earnings multiples, to be buyers."
Several insurers are easing into banking by obtaining thrift charters. Among them are State Farm, the big auto and home insurer, and American International Group, the most international of the big American insurers and one of the few with the financial strength to contemplate a bank takeover.
However the merger dance with the banks and brokerage houses plays out, the pace of evolution within the insurance business is only going to quicken. There are simply too many insurance companies, and many have been run too complacently for too long.
Mr. Sawyer sees the cross hairs of the big insurers coming to rest on a "killing zone" in the marketplace: high quality mid-cap insurance companies with market values up to about $10 billion. These are companies that are big enough to be worthwhile acquisitions but are too small to afford heavy spending for computer technology that might catapult their earnings and share prices, or to bulk up rapidly with acquisitions to fend off the barracudas.
One example is Allmerica Financial, a Worcester, Mass., insurer whose market capitalization is now about $2.5 billion. Though it sells homeowners and auto insurance, it is best known for its life and annuity products and its success in selling through financial planning seminars. Another company often mentioned in the same breath is Reliastar Financial of Minneapolis, which specializes in life insurance and annuities, also sold through seminars, and has a stock market value of $2.7 billion.
"These companies would be a good fit and be easily affordable for a Met or a Pru," said Colin Devine, an insurance analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. But a hungry insurer would have to move swiftly: Allmerica or Reliastar would also be just right for a Merrill Lynch or a Wells Fargo, Mr. Devine said.
The American General Corporation, a Texas-based life insurer with a market value of about $14 billion that has itself grown rapidly with a string of recent acquisitions, and two life insurers in the $6 billion to $7 billion range, Jefferson-Pilot and Lincoln National, are also considered likely takeover targets.
Some analysts see Lincoln National as meshing neatly with a brokerage house like Charles Schwab & Company. "Lincoln National is excellent at asset management, estate planning and retirement sales, which is just what Schwab needs as its customers get older," Mr. Devine said. T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore mutual fund company, might be another possible buyer, he said.
But the action will not be limited to the "killing zone." Some of the most famous names in insurance are being sized up for takeover, especially in the auto and homeowners businesses, where higher-than-expected operating expenses have driven down share prices. The stock of one stellar name, Allstate, has been trading at about $24 a share, down from $41 a year ago and just a bit above book value. Two of its rivals, Progressive and Safeco, have also become vulnerable as their share prices have declined to little more than book value.
Metropolitan Life, which has a growing auto and homeowners division, and A.I.G. are regarded as potential buyers of Allstate. Wall Street analysts also speculate that Warren E. Buffett might want to meld Allstate with Geico, his discount auto insurer. But Ms. Schroeder of PaineWebber, who has become a specialist on Mr. Buffett, said she thought Mr. Buffett would prefer to expand in auto insurance by achieving internal growth with Geico.
Hartford Financial Services, which does a big business in auto, homeowners and commercial insurance and is the parent of Hartford Life, the leading seller of variable annuities, turns up on many handicappers' target lists these days; again, Met Life and A.I.G. are mentioned as buyers that would find Hartford a good fit.
THREE mid-sized commercial insurers with substantial capital surpluses -- the Reliance Group, Fremont General and Frontier Insurance Group -- are also trading at depressed prices. And the trend extends to reinsurers, which sell backup coverage to insurance companies. Two Bermuda-based reinsurers, ACE Ltd. and XL Capital, have begun providing insurance that is akin to bonds, and some analysts say they would be a natural acquisition for investment banking houses like Goldman, Sachs & Company, Lehman Brothers or Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. All three firms already have units that put together packages of bonds that function like insurance.
For all their size, industry leaders like John Hancock, Metropolitan and Prudential have as much reason to worry about being acquired as any of their smaller brethren. They are sleeping giants that own some of the best-known brand names in the country but have been sheltered from relentless pressure for profit growth. Policyholders, who see themselves as customers rather than collective owners of their companies, rarely ask for details of a company's performance as long as they are confident the money will be there to pay claims. So the return on equity for these companies has been, by the standards of publicly traded companies, appallingly low, sometimes as little as 3 or 4 percent, one-fifth or one-sixth that posted by healthy banks.
NOW all that will change, as the siren of the bull market beckons all three giants to cast off mutual ownership and its comforts and protections. The big question is whether they will have enough time to execute their acquisition and growth plans before someone makes a move on them.
Aware of the danger of an immediate feeding frenzy, and the sweeping layoffs and economic dislocation that might result, regulators in the home states -- Massachusetts, New York and New Jersey -- of the three big companies have thrown up barriers to takeover for at least two or three years after they go public. Still, "they will be very susceptible to acquisition if they don't come out of the protected period cruising at a higher level of returns," Mr. Sawyer said.
When mutual insurers convert to stock ownership, their accumulated profits must by law be divided among the mutual policyholders, which can feel like a windfall, though technically it was their money all along. The bigger winners are the executives of the companies, who after an initial waiting period can begin paying themselves millions in bonuses through stock options, which did not exist when the companies were mutuals.
The companies argue that mutual ownership, by denying them the ability to issue stock, hamstrings their efforts to make acquisitions, finance investments in new technology and attract and retain top talent, dooming them to wither away on the sidelines while nimbler competitors offer cheaper, better insurance products.
But those sentiments are not unanimous among mutual companies. A few believe they can prosper while sticking to the old structure, whipping themselves into stock company-like efficiency and buying as many other companies as they can with cash. They are betting that the coming turmoil in the insurance business will be repellant to some customers.
"We think that when people see all this instability, they'll wish they could go back to the old days," said Sy Sternberg, chief executive of the New York Life Insurance Company. "And we'll be the old days -- the same policy, the same company with the same name, not a subsidiary of some big American or European conglomerate."
Instability there will certainly be. "Within the next five years," said Mr. Sawyer of Deloitte Consulting, "you are going to see a dramatically smaller number of American insurance companies. I would have a lot of sleepless nights if I were an insurance company executive."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Drug-Maker Mergers Shake the Office Market

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE worldwide pharmaceutical industry has been in a dizzying dance of mergers and acquisitions, changes that are having direct effects on New Jersey, headquarters for several of the giant drug companies.
The reconfiguration of the space needs has, most real-estate industry analysts and commercial brokers interviewed said, been mostly positive for the New Jersey commercial market. And when the music finally stops, they said, they expect that the industry changes will mean that more office space will be absorbed by the industry than will be vacated by it. 
 Consider these examples. Late last year Aventis, the giant drug maker formed from the marriage of Hoechst Marion Roussel and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, announced it would put its North American headquarters in two buildings, totaling 620,000 square feet, now being built in Bridgewater, consolidating operations now in Kansas City, Mo., and Collegeville, Pa.
Until the new buildings are ready next year, Aventis Pharmaceuticals has leased a 340,000-square-foot building in Parsippany that had stood empty since it was completed at the end of 1998.
Late last year, Novartis -- formed in 1997 by the merger of Ciba-Geigy's pharmaceutical division and Sandoz Pharmaceutical Corporation -- put up for sale the 1.7-million-square-foot former Ciba-Geigy research and office campus on 88 acres at Morris Avenue and River Road in Summit. Novartis will stay in at least 400,000 square feet in some of the buildings for several years, while it constructs new ones at its East Hanover headquarters.
Other companies are expanding. Late last year Merck built a 322,000-square-foot office building at its 189-acre Rahway complex and is constructing a 220,000-square-foot office building on 520 acres it recently purchased adjacent to its 535-acre world headquarters in Readington Township.
And Schering-Plough, based in Madison, is constructing a 100,000-square-foot building at its Kenilworth campus and a 200,000-square-foot building at its Union complex.
Drug companies have been through this dance before. The difference this time "is the intensity and size of the mergers and acquisitions," said Hemant Shah, an independent stock analyst in Warren who tracks the pharmaceutical industry.
"They must develop new products, which requires a tremendous investment, and still deliver a 15 percent gain in earnings," he said, adding that mergers enable companies "to find the savings they need."
With the merger frenzy expected to continue, so will the space shuffling. Other companies involved in the intricate process are Warner-Lambert of Morris Plains, Manhattan-based Pfizer, American Home Products, based in Madison; Pharmacia & Upjohn, based in Peapack-Gladstone; Cincinatti-based Procter & Gamble and the Monsanto Company of St. Louis.
For now, Mr. Shah said, "New Jersey has not been a big space loser and may well come out a winner in all this."
COMMERCIAL brokers and state officials added that what has kept and will keep New Jersey attractive are its skilled workforce, biotechnology centers, universities, chemical companies and ports and airports. The key reason, they added, is that pharmaceutical firms want to rub elbows with others in the same business.
New Jersey, which is home to 191 drug companies, leads the nation in pharmaceutical jobs, which state figures put at 45,000 and industry data records at 57,000. Those firms spent $1.2 billion in capital improvements, including the construction and renovation of buildings, in 1998, according to the HealthCare Institute of New Jersey, a nonprofit trade group in New Brunswick.
"All indications are that the industry's commitment to research and development in the state will continue," said Rebecca Perkins, a spokeswoman for the HealthCare Institute.
The consolidations, like those in the past, will mean some job losses. But with the announcement earlier this month of the impending merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, there has been speculation that the giant new company will have a presence in the state, bringing many new jobs.
Moreover, new biotechnology companies are expected to be created, adding still more jobs.
The impact on the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market has been mostly positive said Thomas V. Giannone, senior managing director at the Edison office of Julien J. Studley, the national commercial tenant brokerage. His firm reports that in the last two years pharmaceutical firms leased 1.5 million square feet of space in blocks of 20,000 square feet or more, which represented 12 percent of 12.2 million square feet leased in the New Jersey region in that time.
Large drug companies typically prefer to own space, Mr. Giannone said. But, he added, their appetite for leased space increased to meet their need to make rapid moves.
Christopher E. Kinum, a principal at the Garibaldi Group, Corfac International brokerage in Chatham, added that while some companies were taking shorter five-year leases they were consolidating in New Jersey, where they have made significant investments in research and development centers, "anchoring them to the state."
THAT, along with the state's strong economy, added Andrew J. Merin, senior director of the Financial Services Group at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, has helped absorb space, spur new construction and prod rents upward.
According to his company's 1999 year-end report the total office vacancy rate dropped 0.8 percentage points to 11 percent from the previous year.
Despite the addition of 2.7 million square feet of new Class A space, the brokerage reported, the vacancy rate for last year dropped 0.1 percent from the previous year's 8.5 percent.
At the same time, annual average asking rents rose to $22.77 a square foot from $21.22, with the rent for Class A space -- generally the most modern and best-located buildings, which is most in demand -- rising from $26.57 to $28.50, the brokerage reported. It also estimates that 3.6 million square feet will be added over the next 18 months.
The building for Aventis will house up to 1,300 workers in the company's commercial operations, including sales and marketing and administrative support, which are being relocated from Kansas City and Pennsylvania.
The buildings will be developed by SJP Properties of Parsippany at its Somerset Corporate Center, at the intersection of Routes 202/206 and 22 and Interstates 287 and 78 in Bridgewater.
"We chose New Jersey because we wanted a stronger presence along with other major pharmaceutical companies, and the Bridgewater site because it's near our global research and development center, which will increase our efficiency," said Charles F. Rouse, spokesman for Aventis Pharmaceuticals. He said plans also called for expanding the existing Bridgewater building, which is three miles south along Route 202/ 206.
The first of the two new 310,000-square-foot buildings is under way and will be com-pleted by the first quarter of 2001, with completion of its twin to follow three months later, said Mr. Rouse. Because it "wanted to get the business going quickly," he said his company would start moving into the existing 340,000-square-foot building it leased in Parsippany through the middle of this year. That building also was built by SJP Properties.
Mr. Kinum said that with Aventis taking over 900,000 square feet of space there was less space on the market, which could encourage some developers to start new buildings.
One is Gale & Wentworth, of Florham Park, which has started a 131,000-square-foot building, the first at its Mountainview Corporate Center, off I-78 in Basking Ridge in Somerset County.
The center, which the company is developing with J.P. Morgan, eventually could have a total of 820,000 square feet in six buildings.
"While not the direct impetus, you can't build on 78 without being aware of the presence of drug companies, like Pharmacia," said Mark Yaeger, president of the Commercial Group at Gale & Wentworth.
To be sure, drug companies have given back some office as well as research and development space, and the potential separate mergers involving Warner-Lambert and Pharmacia remain open questions. But Mr. Giannone, of Julien Studley, said, and other brokers agreed, that the space that has been returned has been absorbed. They expect the leasing to continue, particularly for research and development space, which is scarce.
Novartis's Summit campus includes nearly a million square feet of research and development space at the back of the site. At a time when drug companies "are in a race and the name of the game is research," the site, which is one of the largest to become available in northern New Jersey, represents an opportunity, said Mr. Merin, of Cushman & Wakefield, which is marketing the property. Today, he added, it takes three years to build a single laboratory.
But, Mr. Merin said, the future of the front portion of the site is to replace the mostly older office buildings with up to 700,000 square feet of new Class A space -- or a mix of such office space and a hotel.

HEADLINE: Why Decry the Wealth Gap?

BYLINE: By W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm; W. Michael Cox, chief economist of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, and Richard Alm are co-authors of "Myths of Rich and Poor."

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
The economic expansion that began in 1991 will soon become the longest in our history, yet last week Americans may have been distracted by two reports reminding them of a widening gap between the rich and poor.
The Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and the Economic Policy Institute, two liberal research groups, put out a state-by-state breakdown of Census Bureau data, which found nine states (led by New York) in which the richest 20 percent of households now earn at least 11 times the income of the poorest 20 percent. This indicated a much sharper disparity between the top and bottom than existed two decades ago. 
 Then the Federal Reserve Bank released its latest survey of consumer finances. It showed that the average net worth of families earning less than $10,000 a year had fallen by $6,600 over the past three years, while households earning more than $100,000 a year had seen their wealth jump by more than $300,000.
Our response is: So what?
Few of us should be surprised -- or threatened -- by statistics on inequality. Some Americans believe the more equality the better, but the fact is that the distribution of income and wealth isn't arbitrary. It emerges from broad trends in the economy and is a byproduct of a decade that created 17 million jobs and added 20 percent to median household net worth.
The unstated implication of the state-by-state report was that the states where income disparities are lower are somehow "fairer" than the states with high disparities. But the truth is that among communities, states and regions, income and wealth will vary for many reasons, several of them unavoidable and laudable.
Consider, for example, that income varies with education. According to census data, high school dropouts in the work force earn an average of $26,207, while workers with a professional degree average $127,499. Census figures show that many of the states with the widest income gaps have greater diversity in education levels than states with smaller income gaps. Twenty-six percent of those over the age of 24 in New York -- the state with the greatest income disparity -- have at least a bachelor's degree, whereas in Indiana, which was among the seven states with the lowest income disparity, only 16 percent do. Should we be lamenting that so many New Yorkers went to college?
Another non-nefarious cause of increasing income disparity may be our ever-higher immigration rates. Immigrants tend to cluster in low- and high-income groups. Thus it is no surprise that in the seven most unequal states -- New York, Arizona, New Mexico, Louisiana, California, Rhode Island and Texas -- about 13 percent of the population is foreign-born (in California, it's 25 percent). Among the seven states with the smallest income disparities, the immigrant population is only 3.8 percent.
The shift away from manufacturing is also a factor. Service workers span the gamut from hotel maids to brain surgeons, while the pay range is generally narrower in the manufacturing sector. States that are industrial tend to have more equal distributions of income. Data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that about 10 percent of workers in Arizona, Louisiana and New York have manufacturing jobs, whereas in more equal states like Indiana and Wisconsin the figure is 23 percent.
Also, in the seven states with the greatest income inequality, more than 80 percent of the population lives in or near metropolitan areas. In states with the most equality, only about half does. If we were to turn back the clock 100 years and again become a largely rural nation, we might not see such large income disparities, but that's because America's cities are our engines of wealth and offer greater prospects for those who succeed.
And what of the poorest Americans' loss of ground compared to the richest, as reported by the Fed? The apostles of equality consider the rising inequality kindling for social unrest. But while that would be true if most workers on the bottom rungs were trapped there for generations, America isn't a caste society, and studies that track individuals' incomes over time show that Americans have a remarkable ability to propel themselves upward.
A 17-year study of lifetime earnings by the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas found that only 5 percent of people in the economy's lowest 20 percent failed to move to a higher income group. In a similar study by the Treasury Department covering 1979 to 1988, 86 percent of Americans in the bottom fifth of income earners improved their status.
Inequality is not inequity. Artificial efforts to try to curb wealth gaps invariably do more harm than good. Heavier taxation might narrow the division between rich and poor, but it would be a hollow triumph if it stifled the economy. What Americans ought to care most about is maintaining our growth, not the red herring of gaps in income and wealth.

HEADLINE: Media;
Time and Fortune play catch up -- ever so carefully -- on the AOL-Time Warner deal.

BYLINE: By Alex Kuczynski 

 BODY:
IT was around cocktail hour on the Sunday night before Time Warner and America Online announced the big deal that Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc., heard the news.
Mr. Pearlstine said he was first surprised, and then daunted by the frustrating task of covering the news after he had just put all of his magazines to bed. "Fortune had closed 48 hours earlier and Time had closed 24 hours earlier," he said last week. "We were left playing catch up." 
 Catching up was only part of the problem. The coverage of the deal by Time and Fortune would be the first test of how the enormous new company would cover itself in its own pages. In the end, Time and Fortune covered the deal -- a barely adolescent new-media giant swallowing up their old-media parent company -- much like the punch line to that old joke about canoodling porcupines: very carefully.
"There's a a balancing act when you cover yourself," Mr. Pearlstine said. "There's no perfect way around it. There's conflict. There's potential for conflict. What did you know as a journalist and what did you know as a business partner? In the end, you just sit down and write in a way that does not violate corporate confidences."
The crew of newsweeklies mostly hewed to the AOL-as-winner line, and emphasized AOL's chairman, Stephen M. Case over Time Warner's chairman, Gerald M. Levin.
Newsweek, weighing in with 25 pages of coverage (compared with Time's 15 pages), styled Mr. Case as a latter-day Charles Foster Kane, a median titan for the next century. Its coverage included a solidly skeptical essay about both company's stock prices by the economic correspondent Allan Sloan.
In 10 pages of coverage, Business Week posed America Online as the clear winner in the deal, and also criticized AOL stock as volatile. Business Week showcased Robert W. Pittman and Mr. Case on its cover, in a mock magazine design brandishing the letters AOL in the typeface of Time magazine's logo. U.S. News & World Report and Newsweek, which is owned by the Washington Post Company, both ran lengthy profiles of Mr. Case.
"Levin is a smart guy and a good businessman," Mark Whitaker, the editor of Newsweek, said. "But his is the story of a skilled corporate insider. Compare that to the former Pizza Hut salesman who by his early 40's has taken a start-up company in 10 years to be so powerful that it can buy the biggest media and entertainment company in the world. That's a better profile for our readers, frankly."
Only Time magazine featured Mr. Levin along with Mr. Case on its cover and paired the two in a dual profile. Entertainment Weekly, another publication of Time Inc., featured a caricature of Mr. Case as a macho groom, Mr. Levin as a bride in drag and Ted Turner as a leering bridesmaid. On its cover this week, Fortune features William H. Gates and Mr. Case, in two separate stories for the issue that arrives on newsstands today.
Time's cover article, by Daniel Okrent -- who had been involved in previous Time Inc. Internet forays and knew most of the players in the deal on a first-name basis -- was an insider's account of the deal, and was tough about the company's sorry performance in developing an Internet strategy.
In the dual profile, while largely laudatory of Mr. Levin, Time also pointed out his "half a dozen spectacularly costly crashes," like the now-defunct TV-Cable Week. And two columns, by Michael Kinsley and Victor Navasky, examined the pros and cons of media concentration, respectively. Newsweek went with just one view on this subject, a critical one, by the Jonathan Alter.
Stephen B. Shepard, the editor in chief of Business Week, which is owned by McGraw-Hill, said that despite the fact he felt there was some added pressure to feature Mr. Levin on the Time cover, Time's coverage was fair. "Look, they used the word 'dinosaur' to refer to Time Warner, so I don't think they can be accused of going easy on themselves," he said.
But there was no lack of hand-wringing during the reporting process. One Time staff member sent an e-mail to colleagues warning them that the company's management would probably prefer the deal to be referred to in print as a merger, not an acquisition.
"There was no pressure from Time Warner to refer to it as one thing or another," Mr. Pearlstine said. "But if I said, 'look, here are the arguments for why it's a merger, not a purchase,' there is a risk that someone thinks I am laying down an edict."
Fortune's coverage painted AOL as the dominant partner in the deal. It began with a two-page editor's note defending the ability of Time Inc. magazines to report on the new landscape, pointing out such recent examples as Sports Illustrated's interview with John Rocker, the Atlanta Braves player, in which the pitcher painted himself as a xenophobe; the Braves are owned by Time Warner.
Carol J. Loomis wrote an article critical of the new company's ability to earn any money for investors saying that the market capitalization on AOL Time Warner would have to reach $2.4 trillion (from her estimate for the company currently which is $290 billion) to give an annual return of 15 percent. She compared the task to "pushing a boulder up an Alp."
John Huey, Fortune's managing editor, said: "I think we have the hardest time covering it. Those two companies operate at the white-hot center of what we care about as a magazine." But, he added, more concern went into the reporting for a positive story about Time Warner the magazine ran in 1998.
Mr. Huey said he overheard mention of the deal as he was flying from his home in Georgia to work in New York that Monday morning. "I overheard two people on the airplane and they had heard it on the radio," he said. "So that's how plugged in I am."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
DOW VS. NASDAQ: As technology stocks outperform again, it's the smaller players that are doing the heavy lifting.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THESE are blue days for blue chip owners, but they're great days if your money is in small technology stocks.
Last week was a bad one for the Dow Jones industrial average, the index that has long been identified with blue chip stocks. 
 But the technology-saturated Nasdaq composite index had its best week ever relative to the Dow. The Nasdaq rose 4.2 percent last week to yet another closing high, with gains in every trading session, while the Dow fell 4 percent as it declined each day.
That outperformance -- with the Nasdaq doing 8.2 percentage points better than the Dow -- far exceeded the Nasdaq's previous record for outperformance over a week. That margin, 4.8 percentage points, was set in the week ended Nov. 5.
Last week's divergence reflects continued speculation in small technology stocks at a time when rising interest rates have hurt many stocks -- including the bigger, bluer-chip technology stocks.
For instance, Intel and Microsoft, the Nasdaq-listed technology issues that were added to the Dow's 30 component stocks last year, were among the 23 Dow stocks that lost ground last week. And the other two most-active Nasdaq stocks last week, MCI WorldCom and Dell Computer, also lost ground. Together, those four stocks account for 20 percent of the Nasdaq composite index, but their decline did not stop that index from having a strong week.
The latest speculation in small technology stocks extends beyond Internet isues, but it is concentrated on companies that are often small and unprofitable.
There is nothing new in the Nasdaq's soaring, of course; it has doubled over the last 13 months. But the fact that smaller stocks are leading the way is a bit of a change.
The Russell 2,000 -- an index that includes the stocks that rank from 1,001 to 3,000 in market capitalization in the United States and is the most widely followed index of small stocks -- rose 5.2 percent last week, better than the Nasdaq, which is dominated by large technology stocks. Compare that to 1999, when the Nasdaq composite rose more than 80 percent for the year, while the Russell was up less than 20 percent.
In the past, huge margins of outperformance by Nasdaq over the Dow have usually -- but not always -- come at a time when the momentum of the Nasdaq composite was likely to continue. As calculated by Bloomberg Financial Markets and going back to the Nasdaq's creation in 1971, of the 10 previous cases when the Nasdaq composite outperformed the Dow by at least four percentage points during a week, on eight occasions the Nasdaq composite outperformed the Dow over the subsequent four weeks.
Perhaps more important, the Nasdaq composite registered gains in seven of those eight cases.
The most notable exception came slightly less than a year ago. In the week ended Jan. 29, 1999, the Nasdaq leaped 7.1 percent, vastly outperforming the Dow, which gained 2.6 percent. Over the next four weeks, though, the Dow slipped only a bit while the Nasdaq fell 8.1 percent. Technology stocks, which had led the move up, also led the move down.
On the other hand, the most recent big outperformance for the Nasdaq over the Dow, prior to last week -- the week of Nov. 5, noted above, when the Nasdaq rose 4.6 percent and the Dow slipped a bit -- served as a signal that the current Nasdaq surge was under way. It was the third week in a row that the Nasdaq rose at least 3 percent, and it did not have a week with a gain of less than 2 percent for the rest of 1999.
A drop of 4.6 percent occurred in the first week of this year, but the Nasdaq has more than made up for that decline by rising more than 4 percent in each of the two subsequent weeks.
All told, since Oct. 15 -- a period of 14 weeks -- the Nasdaq composite has risen 55 percent, while the Dow has gained 12 percent and the Russell 2,000 is up 29 percent.

Autobytel to Sells Cars Directly Over Internet
Autobytel, the Internet car-buying service, plans to announce today that it will act as a car broker by selling cars directly over the Internet.
The announcement at the annual convention of car dealers in Orlando comes on the heels of Friday's news that Amazon.com would get into the online car-selling business by taking a 5 percent stake in Greenlight.com, and is part of a broader scramble by high-flying Internet companies to get into the business of selling cars and car parts. HEADLINE: Jean MacArthur, General's Widow, Dies at 101

BYLINE: By ENID NEMY 

 BODY:
Jean MacArthur, the widow of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who remained at her husband's side through the darkest days of World War II and was often introduced by him as "my finest soldier," died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 101.
Throughout their 27-year marriage, the couple, who met when she was 36 and he was nearly 20 years older than her and was the survivor of an earlier unhappy marriage, maintained an old-fashioned formality. Mrs. MacArthur addressed her husband in the presence of others as "the general." He called her "ma'am" and in his later years, confided that she was his "constant friend, sweetheart and devoted support." 
 Mrs. MacArthur, whom William Manchester, the MacArthur biographer, described as "a poem of womanhood," married General MacArthur in New York in 1937. They had met two years previously when he was a fellow passenger on the S.S. President Hoover, en route to the Philippines to assume his duties as military adviser to the government there. Later, he became the supreme allied commander in the Southwest Pacific, waged the campaign against Japan and accepted the surrender of Japanese forces in 1945 in Tokyo Bay aboard the U.S.S. Missouri.
When the war ended, he oversaw the occupation of Japan as supreme commander of allied forces in Japan. After North Korean forces invaded South Korea, he also became supreme commander of the United Nations forces in Korea until April 1951, when, in a dispute over the prosecution of the war, he was relieved of both commands by President Harry S. Truman. He returned to America and a hero's welcome and became chairman of Remington Rand and then of the Sperry Rand Corporation. He died in 1964.
Mrs. MacArthur displayed an indomitable spirit and determination in the face of wartime trials.
After the Japanese invaded the Philippines, it was decided to abandon Manila in 1942 and move the government to the island of Corregidor. Mrs. MacArthur packed a few necessities and, as she was leaving the apartment, she passed a cabinet containing the decorations awarded to her husband. She removed the medals from their cases, wrapped them in a towel and made room for them in her suitcase by discarding some of her own clothes.
Later, when the military situation on Corregidor rapidly deteriorated, the general informed her that President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines had offered her and their young son, Arthur, passage to Australia. "We have drunk from the same cup; we three shall stay together," she replied. The MacArthurs and their 4-year-old son lived in an underground bunker during months of bombardment before agreeing to evacuation on President Franklin D. Roosevelt's orders.
Mrs. MacArthur, the former Jean Marie Faircloth, was born in Nashville on Dec. 28, 1898. Her father, Edward C. Faircloth, was a banker and businessman. She was 8 when her parents divorced and her mother, a native of Murfreesboro, Tenn., took her young daughter and her two sons, Cameron and Frederick, back to her birthplace.
The head of the Murfreesboro household was her grandfather, Capt. Richard Beard, a Confederate veteran, and Mrs. MacArthur was raised in a home where a Confederate uniform was a badge of honor.
Fellow members of the Daughters of the American Revolution recalled that "every time Jean Faircloth heard a Fourth of July firecracker go off, she jumped to attention and saluted." Young men were advised that "if you want to win Jean Marie, you better get a uniform."
Mrs. Faircloth married again in 1907 and there were two children of that marriage to Frederick Smith -- Harvard Smith and Donna Angeline Smith.
Mrs. MacArthur was educated at Ward-Belmont College in Nashville and at Soule College in Murfreesboro, from which she graduated.
As a young girl, she had not been close to her father, but as he grew older and wealthier, he frequently took her on trips and cruises with him. When he died, he left her a substantial fortune, and she used it to travel extensively, visiting friends in Manila, cruising in Europe and taking her half-sister on a South American cruise and her half-brother on a three-month round-the-world cruise.
A vivacious woman with meticulous manners, Mrs. MacArthur took seriously the social duties connected with her husband's position, both in the military and later in private life. After his death, she refused to bask in reflected fame, leading a quiet social life within a select circle of well-known New Yorkers. She pursued her interests in fashion, theater and opera.
Friends recalled that on one occasion at the Metropolitan Opera, she paused as she walked down the aisle to make sure that the plaque bearing her name was still attached to an orchestra seat. "I paid $1,000 for it," she said.
She also worked on behalf of several civic and philanthropic activities, and was honorary chairman of the board of the Gen. Douglas MacArthur Foundation in Norfolk, Va. In 1990, at age 91, with her friend Barbara Bush at her side, she cut the ribbon opening the research center of the MacArthur Memorial in Norfolk, where her husband is buried.
Mrs. MacArthur received the distinguished public service award from the Department of Defense in 1984, and in 1988, President Ronald Reagan presented her with the Medal of Freedom, the highest award given a civilian in peacetime, for her patriotic service to the nation. The government of the Philippines honored her in 1993 with its Legion of Merit medal. She was one of the few private citizens to receive a visit from the Emperor and Empress of Japan during their trip to the United States in 1994.
One of her favorite stories when she reached the last decade of her life was about her conversation with the driver as she was bouncing around in a New York City taxi. "I'm 90 years old," she said. "Can you go a bit slower please?"
"I'm sorry, Mrs. MacArthur," the driver said. "I remember you from the Philippines and how you bounced around in the jeeps there and it didn't bother you."
Her intimate friends also recalled that although she would order a martini "to be social" when dining out, she had earlier briefed the waiters and bartenders in her favorite restaurants on what that really meant. A martini glass filled with water and decorated with a lemon twist would be brought to her, and she would smile appreciatively as she sipped.
She is survived by her son, Arthur, of New York City, and her half-sister, Angie McCarthy, of Murfreesboro, said Col. William J. Davis, executive director of the MacArthur Foundation in Norfolk.
Mrs. MacArthur will be buried beside her husband at the MacArthur Memorial in Norfolk after a private service for her on Wednesday, Colonel Davis said.
