HEADLINE: Long Island Case Sheds Light On Animal-Mutilation Videos

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG

DATELINE: ISLIP TERRACE, N.Y.

 BODY:
When law enforcement officials searched the bedroom of a 27-year-old in this Long Island suburb one night in 1998, it was not the collection of a half-dozen semiautomatic rifles and shotguns that most unnerved them. Nor was it the poster of a Nazi storm trooper.
What stunned them, they said, were the fish tank full of mice, a pair of high heels coated with dried blood and the contents of 71 animal-mutilation videos with titles like "Vanessa's Frog Stomp" and "Debby the Destructor." 
 In one videotape, officials said, a woman's foot impaled a writhing frog with a stiletto heel. In another, a woman's hand reached down to burn a mouse with a cigarette. "In all my years on the job, I've never seen anything this sick before, this depraved," said Roy Gross of the Suffolk County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which charged the man, Thomas Capriola, with animal cruelty.
The suspect, now 29, was investigated after his ex-girlfriend called Mr. Gross's agency to say she had helped Mr. Capriola produce the videos. A trial date for the misdemeanor charge has not been set. But the case, along with a similar one in Los Angeles scheduled to go to court today, is calling attention to a subculture of animal-mutilation videos that prompted Congress to pass a law banning the sale of such films.
"We believe that these charges ultimately have very little merit to them," said Mr. Capriola's lawyer, Paul Gianelli. His client has pleaded not guilty.
But the authorities say Mr. Capriola was a maker of so-called crush videos, which cater to a male sexual fetish in which viewers become aroused by watching women, usually in high heels, stomp on small animals. Mr. Capriola, they say, filmed female friends as they killed hundreds of small animals, then sold the videos and bloodied high heels through a Web site called "Crush Goddess" and classified ads in pornographic magazines.
Crush films and videos have been made since the 1950's, but only in the last five years or so have they emerged from the underground, as advertisements for them have spread from pornographic magazines to the Internet. The Humane Society of the United States has counted about 2,000 titles since it began its monitoring in 1997. They sell for $30 to $300 each.
The videos' increased visibility has even extended to television, where "NYPD Blue" and "The Practice" have featured subplots about crush fetishists. Meanwhile, animal rights advocates have staged protests and lobbied Congress.
Richard C. Richards, a philosophy professor at California State Polytechnic University in Pomona who has studied perversions, said about 1,000 American men have the crush fetish. "I think it's wrong to demonize these things," he said. "These people won't stop. They can't. Very few of them want to."
Artwork from Pompeii shows the crush fetish may have existed as far back as ancient Rome, Mr. Richards said. But modern technology has allowed crush videomakers to sell their products on the Internet.
The law Congress passed in November makes it a federal offense to create or distribute "a depiction of animal cruelty" for "commercial gain," with penalties ranging from a fine to five years in prison. Exceptions are made for "educational" and "artistic" works. "We tried to get to the folks who are distributing these things," said Representative Elton Gallegly, a Republican from Ventura County, Calif., who introduced the bill. "Let's face it. It is an economic-driven activity."
But both Mr. Capriola and Gary Lynn Thomason, the defendant in the Los Angeles County crush video case, will not be tried under the new federal law because they were arrested before it passed. Mr. Thomason has pleaded not guilty to misdemeanor charges of animal cruelty.
Mr. Capriola's lawyer, Mr. Gianelli, has asked the judge to dismiss the case against his client on several counts, including lack of evidence and technicalities related to the search warrant, according to court records. He said Mr. Capriola would not talk about the case.If convicted, Mr. Capriola could face up to one year in jail.
Alongside the seized tapes, officials said, they found shipping records to hundreds of individuals. "If you want to go on a diet, these videos are the way to go," Mr. Gross said. "You'll lose 20 pounds after watching one of these."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Supreme Court Ruling on Campaign Contribution Limits

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding Missouri's limits on campaign contributions. The vote in the case, Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, was 6 to 3. Justice David H. Souter wrote the majority opinion. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote a dissent, as did Justice Anthony M. Kennedy. 
FROM THE DECISION
By Justice Souter
The principal issues in this case are whether Buckley v. Valeo is authority for state limits on contributions to state political candidates and whether the federal limits approved in Buckley, with or without adjustment for inflation, define the scope of permissible state limitations today. We hold Buckley to be authority for comparable state regulation, which need not be pegged to Buckley's dollars.
In 1994, the Legislature of Missouri enacted Senate Bill 650 to restrict the permissible amounts of contributions to candidates for state office. . . . Before the statute became effective, however, Missouri voters approved a ballot initiative with even stricter contribution limits, effective immediately. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit then held the initiative's contribution limits unconstitutional under the First Amendment. . . .
The appeals court treated Missouri's claim of a compelling interest "in avoiding the corruption or the perception of corruption brought about when candidates for elective office accept large campaign contributions" as insufficient by itself to satisfy strict scrutiny. . . .
The court thought that the only evidence presented by the state, an affidavit from the co-chairman of the State Legislature's Interim Joint Committee on Campaign Finance Reform when the statute was passed, was inadequate to raise a genuine issue of material fact about the state's alleged interest in limiting campaign contributions. . . . Given the large number of states that limit political contributions, we granted certiorari to review the congruence of the Eighth Circuit's decision with Buckley. We reverse.
The matters raised in Buckley v. Valeo . . . included claims that federal campaign finance legislation infringed speech and association guarantees of the First Amendment and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth.
The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, as amended by the Federal Election Campaign Act Amendments of 1974, limited (and still limits) contributions by individuals to any single candidate for federal office to $1,000 per election . . . Until Buckley struck it down, the law also placed a $1,000 annual ceiling on independent expenditures linked to specific candidates . . . We found violations of the First Amendment in the expenditure regulations, but held the contribution restrictions constitutional. . . .
We then, however, drew a line between expenditures and contributions, treating expenditure restrictions as direct restraints on speech, which nonetheless suffered little direct effect from contribution limits . . . We thus said, in effect, that limiting contributions left communication significantly unimpaired.
In speaking of "improper influence" and "opportunities for abuse" in addition to "quid pro quo arrangements," we recognized a concern not confined to bribery of public officials, but extending to the broader threat from politicians too compliant with the wishes of large contributors.
These were the obvious points behind our recognition that the Congress could constitutionally address the power of money "to influence governmental action" in ways less "blatant and specific than bribery." In defending its own statute, Missouri espouses those same interests of preventing corruption and the appearance of it that flows from munificent campaign contributions. Even without the authority of Buckley, there would be no serious question about the legitimacy of the interests claimed, which, after all, underlie bribery and anti-gratuity statutes. . . . Leave the perception of impropriety unanswered, and the cynical assumption that large donors call the tune could jeopardize the willingness of voters to take part in democratic governance. Democracy works "only if the people have faith in those who govern, and that faith is bound to be shattered when high officials and their appointees engage in activities which arouse suspicions of malfeasance and corruption."
Although respondents neither challenge the legitimacy of these objectives nor call for any reconsideration of Buckley, they take the state to task, as the court of appeals did, for failing to justify the invocation of those interests with empirical evidence of actually corrupt practices or of a perception among Missouri voters that unrestricted contributions must have been exerting a covertly corrosive influence. The state statute is not void, however, for want of evidence. . . .
Buckley demonstrates that the dangers of large, corrupt contributions and the suspicion that large contributions are corrupt are neither novel nor implausible. . . .
There might, of course, be need for a more extensive evidentiary documentation if petitioners had made any showing of their own to cast doubt on the apparent implications of Buckley's evidence and the record here, but the closest respondents come to challenging these conclusions is their invocation of academic studies said to indicate that large contributions to public officials or candidates do not actually result in changes in candidates' positions.
Given the conflict among these publications, and the absence of any reason to think that public perception has been influenced by the studies cited by respondents, there is little reason to doubt that sometimes large contributions will work actual corruption of our political system, and no reason to question the existence of a corresponding suspicion among voters. . . .
In Buckley, we specifically rejected the contention that $1,000, or any other amount, was a constitutional minimum below which legislatures could not regulate. As indicated above, we referred instead to the outer limits of contribution regulation by asking whether there was any showing that the limits were so low as to impede the ability of candidates to "amass the resources necessary for effective advocacy."
We asked, in other words, whether the contribution limitation was so radical in effect as to render political association ineffective, drive the sound of a candidate's voice below the level of notice. . . .
There is no reason in logic or evidence to doubt the sufficiency of Buckley to govern this case in support of the Missouri statute. The judgment of the court of appeals is, accordingly, reversed, and the case is remanded for proceedings consistent with this opinion.
It is so ordered.
 
FROM THE DISSENT
By Justice Thomas
In the process of ratifying Missouri's sweeping repression of political speech, the court today adopts the analytic fallacies of our flawed decision in Buckley v. Valeo. . . . Unfortunately, the court is not content to merely adhere to erroneous precedent. Under the guise of applying Buckley, the court proceeds to weaken the already enfeebled constitutional protection that Buckley afforded campaign contributions. . . .
Our decision in Buckley was in error, and I would overrule it. I would subject campaign contribution limitations to strict scrutiny, under which Missouri's contribution limits are patently unconstitutional. I begin with a proposition that ought to be unassailable: Political speech is the primary object of First Amendment protection.
The founders sought to protect the rights of individuals to engage in political speech because a self-governing people depends upon the free exchange of political information. And that free exchange should receive the most protection when it matters the most during campaigns for elective office. . . . I do not start with these foundational principles because the court openly disagrees with them. I start with them because the court today abandons them. For nearly half a century, this court has extended First Amendment protection to a multitude of forms of "speech," such as making false defamatory statements, filing lawsuits, dancing nude, exhibiting drive-in movies with nudity, burning flags and wearing military uniforms. . . . In light of the many cases of this sort, today's decision is a most curious anomaly.
In my view, the Constitution leaves it entirely up to citizens and candidates to determine who shall speak, the means they will use and the amount of speech sufficient to inform and persuade. Buckley's ratification of the government's attempt to wrest this fundamental right from citizens was error.
 
FROM THE DISSENT
By Justice Kennedy
The court's decision has lasting consequences for political speech in the course of elections, the speech upon which democracy depends. Yet in defining the controlling standard of review and applying it to the urgent claim presented, the court seems almost indifferent. Its analysis would not be acceptable for the routine case of a single protester with a hand-scrawled sign . . . or a driver who taped over the motto on his license plate because he disagreed with its message. . . .
The plain fact is that the compromise the court invented in Buckley set the stage for a new kind of speech to enter the political system. It is covert speech. The court has forced a substantial amount of political speech underground, as contributors and candidates devise ever more elaborate methods of avoiding contribution limits, limits which take no account of rising campaign costs.
To defend its extension of Buckley to present times, the court, of course, recites the dangers of corruption, or the appearance of corruption, when an interested person contributes money to a candidate. What the court does not do is examine and defend the substitute it has encouraged, covert speech funded by unlimited soft money. In my view that system creates dangers greater than the one it has replaced.
Among the facts the court declines to take into account is the emergence of cyberspace communication by which political contributions can be reported almost simultaneously with payment. The public can then judge for itself whether the candidate or the officeholder has so overstepped that we no longer trust him or her to make a detached and neutral judgment. . . .
I would overrule Buckley and then free Congress or state legislatures to attempt some new reform, if, based upon their own considered view of the First Amendment, it is possible to do so. Until any re-examination takes place, however, the existing distortion of speech caused by the half-way house we created in Buckley ought to be eliminated.

HEADLINE: Car Dealers' Driveway Blues;
Pushing for a Crackdown on Sales Done Directly Online

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Jan. 24

 BODY:
Internet companies that sell cars directly to consumers are encountering stiff opposition from auto dealers, who are using their influence in state legislatures and with state regulators to protect their businesses.
Car dealers, meeting here at their annual convention, are worried that they are being undercut or bypassed entirely by the new services. They are also afraid that automakers might sell cars on the Internet themselves or through the new Internet services. So the dealers have begun pushing restrictive laws through state legislatures to prevent this and have encouraged state regulators to crack down. 
 But consumer advocates say that extra competition would be good for customers. Indeed, state regulators say the only complaints they have been receiving about the services have been from dealers, not consumers. There is mixed evidence on whether consumers save money buying cars online.
Because of state franchise laws and manufacturers' policies, Internet services must buy cars from dealers, not directly from manufacturers. Paying two markups, one for the dealer and one for the Internet company, is a burden on consumers that does not exist for many other forms of electronic commerce. This erodes price advantages Internet companies may have.
The federal government has left the regulation of auto retailing to the states, leaving potential gaps in regulation for deals that cross state lines, said state regulators from across the nation, who convened at a hotel near the dealers' convention for meetings over the last four days.
"You could buy a car from a Mississippi dealer who has his Web site in Iowa and delivers a car in Idaho -- who has jurisdiction?" asked T. Rex Green, Idaho's supervisor of dealer investigations. "I can't justify to my taxpayers running all the way to Mississippi to chase someone."
Dealers have already used their political muscle over the last 12 months to persuade lawmakers in nine states to tighten state franchise laws, making it virtually impossible for manufacturers to sell cars except through franchised dealers. Governor George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, signed the toughest such law in the nation last year, and the Texas Department of Transportation has become the nation's leader in becoming stricter on Internet commerce involving cars. Legislatures in many more states are expected to consider legislation pushed by dealer groups this year, with one bill introduced last week in the Nebraska Legislature, which is nonpartisan and has only one house.
State motor vehicle regulators, acting partly at the prompting of dealers but also because of concern that businesses could use the Internet to commit fraud, have become alarmed that Internet companies may be violating longstanding laws in most states that require anyone selling a new car or truck to be licensed and have a franchise relationship with a manufacturer.
The regulators said that they believed the newest services, those which actually deliver cars to customers' homes, might violate laws intended to protect dealers and consumers.
Top regulators from Wisconsin and Texas said they had ordered CarsDirect.com, an Internet seller, to halt operations in their state. Regulators from Virginia, Kentucky, Nebraska and Louisiana said they doubted CarsDirect.com and similar companies complied with their states' laws; Louisiana regulators said they were "on the verge" of taking action on the issue, although they refused to elaborate.
Wendy Barbour, a spokeswoman for CarsDirect.com, said the company was still doing business in every state except Texas and Arkansas, where the company acknowledges regulatory restrictions. She declined to comment on any litigation and regulatory complaints pending against the company.
Regulators in Texas also used that state's tough new law in November to order the Ford Motor Company to stop using its Internet site to sell used cars in Houston. Ford has complied, but is suing the state to reverse the order.
For the last three years, dozens of Internet companies have generated sales leads for car dealers, providing abundant information to consumers about what is available and then sending the customer to a dealer to close the sale. But a few companies, led by CarsDirect.com, have recently become car-buying services, taking prepaid orders from customers, buying cars from nearby dealers and delivering them to customers' homes on flatbed trucks.
The regulators reached a consensus here that a model law should be drafted for each state to regulate car sales over the Internet, although the details of the legislation have not been agreed upon. Lobbyists from most state dealer associations attended Friday's meeting and supported the drafting of such a law.
A dozen regulators said in separate interviews that while complaints about the new services had been coming from dealers, not consumers, they believed that consumers could someday be hurt by insufficient regulation of the new companies. State regulators have the authority to enforce lemon laws, requiring makers to take back seriously defective cars, and to fine or even revoke the licenses of dealers in their states who commit certain frauds, such as charging a buyer for options that are not actually on a car.
Even a few of the older Internet companies that sell referrals to dealers are running into regulatory problems. Samuel M. Hedgpeth, president and chief operating officer of Autoweb.com, said that current state laws and regulations favored dealers. Autoweb unsuccessfully challenged a rule in Texas, for example, that requires companies to charge a fixed monthly fee to dealers for supplying them with sales leads, instead of selling each referral separately.
The law, Mr. Hedgpeth complained, was the equivalent of telling an ice cream vendor that "you have to charge the same whether it's one scoop, two scoops or three scoops."
The enforcement efforts and tougher franchise laws have been found mainly in the South and Midwest, where dealers' political influence is particularly strong. Regulators and legislatures in the Northeast and West have done little so far to address the Internet car-buying services, with the exception of Connecticut, where the Legislature tightened rules last year against manufacturers' ownership of dealerships.
For consumers, the bottom line in the current squabble is that cars are unlikely to get much cheaper anytime soon. Fearful of angering their dealers and increasingly constrained by state regulations, domestic and foreign automakers alike have said in recent weeks that they have no plans to sell cars directly to the public through the Internet, nor do they even plan to sell directly to the Internet companies. Many dealers now sell several brands of cars, and sometimes retaliate against automakers that offend them by shifting their energy and advertising spending to a different brand.
General Motors ran into this problem last year, when it announced a plan to buy and operate up to 10 percent of its dealerships, using them partly for Internet sales. G.M. quickly retreated from the plan in the face of dealers' opposition.
Roy S. Roberts, G.M.'s group vice president for North American sales and marketing, said here on Sunday that the company now planned to work closely with dealers so that consumers would not feel a need for independent Internet services. What the services "are trying to do is take our customers, and they can only do that if we don't come together," Mr. Roberts said, adding, "We can cut them out."
G.M. and other automakers are planning to greatly increase the number of cars they build to order. This would diminish the need for dealers to hold huge inventories of cars, one of their main functions in the current market. Once most cars are custom-built, customers would be able to order them directly over the Internet. Dealers are fighting now to make sure that they will handle those orders -- and that their role is not supplanted by independent Internet companies, or by the automakers themselves.
According to J. D. Power & Associates, an auto consulting firm, nearly half of all new car buyers now use the Internet for research, and they tend to be relatively affluent. But only 2.7 percent use an Internet buying service, mostly services that send sales leads to dealerships. The firm estimates that 10,000 or so cars, worth about $250 million, were sold online last year, almost all in the last few months, with the numbers rising rapidly with each passing month.
Consumer advocates once supported auto franchise laws. The laws prevented manufacturers from retaliating against dealers who sell cars for less than the suggested retail price. The laws also discourage unscrupulous, unlicensed businesses from pocketing people's money and not delivering a car, which was a problem before the 1950's, when many franchise laws were enacted.
But now consumer groups worry that the laws are being amended in ways that hurt customers. "We do have some serious concerns right now that dealers are using old franchise laws to inhibit new and creative ways to sell cars, and most of these new and creative ways are in consumers' interest," said Jack Gillis, an auto retailing expert at the Consumer Federation of America.
The stakes in this legal battle are enormous. Much of the retail business now being transacted on the Internet involves fairly inexpensive goods, like $40 shirts or $20 books; direct sales to consumers over the Internet are estimated at $10 billion to $15 billion last year. Moving even a small part of the nation's $700 billion a year in new and used automobile sales onto the Internet would greatly expand the scale and economic importance of electronic commerce.
But automakers and entrepreneurs alike have found that moving car sales online is not easily done because of the regulatory issues and the political power of the dealers. "Everybody with a PC and a background in Palo Alto thinks they're going to revolutionize the auto industry and retire at 27 with a 180-foot yacht," said James Holden, the president of the Chrysler Group of DaimlerChrysler A.G. "They don't have a clue."
One company, CarOrder.com, is trying to get around the regulations by buying dozens of tiny rural dealerships in large states. The company hopes to use the dealerships to order huge numbers of cars directly from manufacturers for sale over the Internet. But CarOrder has not yet reached any agreements with manufacturers, which usually limit shipments to dealerships based on the size of the communities they serve.
Murray Chodos, a financial consultant in Greenwich, Conn., who bought a Toyota 4Runner sport utility vehicle that was delivered to his home on Sunday by CarOrder.com, said that buying over the Internet was much easier than going to a dealership. He has had a couple of problems, though. The Toyota arrived with an empty gas tank, while his order last November for a Lexus LS 400 sedan still has not been filled.
Mr. Chodos nonetheless said he thought Internet companies should be able to buy cars straight from manufacturers and charge even lower prices, adding, "I'd love to see the day when these Internet companies can go direct, and the dealerships stick to service."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
New Economics Of Recruiting Top Executives

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
SHARES of Internet-based companies remain the currency of the realm in Silicon Valley.
Neoforma.com kicked off the 2000 season for dot.com stock offerings yesterday and the deal looked like another bonanza for a variety of investors and suppliers who got in ahead of the general public, including the firm that found the company's chief executive, Heidrick & Struggles International. Shares of Neoforma, a start-up that operates electronic marketplaces for new and used medical equipment, tripled to $52.375 in their first day of trading on the Nasdaq stock market. 
 That gain showed that investors have not lost their voracious appetite for new Internet stocks and it could translate into a huge payday for Heidrick & Struggles. When the time came last fall for Neoforma to pay Heidrick & Struggles, a Chicago-based executive search firm, for recruiting Robert Zollars, a seasoned health care industry executive, the search firm accepted a cash fee plus a bundle of equity in the young company.
Fees for top executive search firms traditionally run to about one-third of an executive's first-year cash compensation. In Mr. Zollars's case, that would have amounted to about $250,000.
But, as on Wall Street, in Silicon Valley cash salary and bonuses often amount to less than half of a chief executive's total compensation. So, on top of its traditional fee, Heidrick & Struggles has often demanded equity equal to one-third of the executive's stock and options that vest in the first year.
For placing Mr. Zollars, Heidrick & Struggles received a warrant convertible into 436,623 shares of Neoforma stock at 10 cents a share. As of yesterday's close, that warrant was worth about $22.8 million.
"You'd probably choose column B here," said John Thompson, a vice chairman of Heidrick & Struggles in Menlo Park, Calif., who recruited Mr. Zollars away from a senior management position at Cardinal Health.
Mr. Thompson said he had accepted a mix of cash and equity for all of the searches he has conducted for more than two years. All told, Heidrick & Struggles has taken equity stakes in more than 70 companies and has commitments for equity in another 200 searches it is conducting. The firm has sold shares in fewer than 10 of those companies.
The Neoforma stake "is one of the larger ones and, hopefully, it's going to be worth a lot more," Mr. Thompson said. He said that Heidrick & Struggles cannot sell its Neoforma shares for several months because they are subject to the same restrictions as shares held by the company's managers.
"We want an opportunity to participate in the long-term performance of the C.E.O.'s we place," Mr. Thompson said.
Clearly, the firm, which itself went public last year, is taking a gamble every time it accepts stock in an untested company instead of cash.
Heidrick & Struggles sometimes hedges its bets, however, according to a prospectus for a three million share secondary stock offering it is currently marketing. In the case of one company that paid Heidrick & Struggles with a warrant, Covad Communications, the firm used stock options to limit the potential decline in the value of its stake. Still, Heidrick & Struggles took in more than $10 million for recruiting that company's chief executive in July 1998.
"This is a good strategy on their part," said Tom O'Halloran, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read. "It's part of a trend among professional-service firms to either invest cash in companies or take warrants from them in addition to the standard fee, or, in lieu of fees."
So far for Heidrick & Struggles, Mr. O'Halloran said, "this has not shown up as a big number on their financials but it could very well be a big number at some point in the future." If the firm proves it can repeatedly reap big gains from these stakes, investors will place a higher value on the firm's shares, he said.
Some executives of Heidrick & Struggles, including its chief executive, Patrick S. Pittard, plan to sell shares in the firm's secondary offering. But Mr. Thompson, who owns more than 1 percent of the firm, is hanging on. "I'm predicting it's going to be a major part of our company's financial future," Mr. Thompson said of the practice of accepting equity for fees.
Indeed, Mr. Thompson and his colleagues believe so strongly in their ability to pick winners, among managers and companies, that Heidrick & Struggles is branching out into the venture capital business. Borrowing a stratagem used by investment banks, the firm plans to use $25 million of its own money and its employees' money to start a fund that will invest in private companies, primarily those that hire Heidrick & Struggles to find executives for them.
Mr. O'Halloran said investing in companies "presents a conflict of interest, but it could be a tool to strengthen client relationships and could be an effective tool to recruit" its own employees.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid Is Diverted to Germ Warfare, Russian Scientists Say

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

 BODY:
Some of the American money awarded to support Russia's civilian biological research was secretly shifted to Biopreparat, a shadowy organization that once directed the Soviet Union's germ warfare program, several Russian scientists say.
American officials, who for five years have walked a delicate line in providing aid to Russia, remain suspicious about the activities of Biopreparat, which has been reborn as a state-owned drug company. 
 The Americans are concerned because of its continuing secrecy and because it is led by the same military and intelligence officers who spearheaded and concealed the Soviet Union's biological weapons programs during the cold war.
Separately, Clinton administration officials acknowledged that the United States had been less than meticulous in the mid-1990's in enforcing its ban on aid to Biopreparat.
Records show that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the United States Agency for International Development made grants in that period that benefited Biopreparat. Administration officials said today that they had tightened their procedures. "There's been a learning curve," one administration official said.
A spokesman for the space agency said it would investigate whether any American aid money had been diverted to the organization and would withhold $1.6 million in assistance until Moscow accounted for its spending of previous grants.
Officials at A.I.D. said they had not been aware of Biopreparat's history and should have checked with national security officials before approving aid to a joint venture that involved the organization.
Russian biologists familiar with Biopreparat said its director, Gen. Yuri T. Kalinin, had shifted at least 10 percent of several NASA grants intended for biological research in space to his organization.
General Kalinin has headed Biopreparat since its inception in 1973, and Western officials say he is the focal point of concern among American and British intelligence analysts about whether Moscow has fully given up research into germ warfare and what Acting President Vladimir V. Putin will decide.
"The Russian government is facing a key test," said Amy E. Smithson, a defense expert at the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington, who said Russian scientists had told her in confidence about diversions of money. "Either Putin will support the old guard of biological cold warriors, exemplified by Kalinin and his cronies, or scientists who want to put their biological warfare knowledge to peaceful use."
Asked today about the scientist's accusations, a spokesman for Biopreparat declined to comment. Neither General Kalinin, a former intelligence officer, nor any senior Biopreparat official who was active in the Soviet germ warfare program would agree to talk about Biopreparat's current or past activities.
The United States and the Soviet Union developed biological weapons after World War II. They agreed by treaty in 1972 to give them up, but a year later, Moscow secretly mounted a crash program to produce and stockpile even more lethal germs.
Ken Alibek, General Kalinin's former deputy in Biopreparat and the most senior Soviet germ official to defect to the West, and Igor V. Domaradsky, an early leader of the program, have identified General Kalinin and Biopreparat as the hub of the former Soviet germ warfare program, which at its peak involved some 40 institutes across the Soviet Union and more than 60,000 people.
General Kalinin and other senior officials from Biopreparat were also instrumental in covering up the program's existence after the first key scientists defected to the West in 1989, said Mr. Alibek, who left in 1992.
Russian scientists said General Kalinin had supervised Biopreparat's transition to civilian work after the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. Western officials say they know little about Biopreparat's operations.
But a Biopreparat brochure signed by Yuri T. Kalinin, identified not by military rank but as a "professor, doctor of science," states that the Russian government owns 51 percent of the joint-stock company and that Biopreparat now includes some 20 research institutes and other enterprises that make about 1,000 vaccines, medicines and biotechnology products.
In response to American protests in 1992 over Russia's germ warfare activities, Boris N. Yeltsin, then the Russian president, assured Washington that he had ended his country's germ warfare program. He also promised to dismiss General Kalinin as Biopreparat's director. But for unknown reasons he was unwilling or unable to fulfill that pledge.
In recent months tensions have arisen between Biopreparat and several of the civilian institutes that remain under its control. American officials say their aid efforts are intended in part to funnel money to those institutes while starving Biopreparat of funds.
But Russian scientists and American officials say General Kalinin has undermined that policy, using his bureaucratic powers over the institutes and their employees. The general, who authorizes foreign travel by employees, has also tried to prevent institutes from developing independent ties to Western institutes and companies.
General Kalinin appears to have gained access to American money nonetheless. In 1995, NASA awarded $1.6 million to more than a dozen civilian institutes to conduct biological research in space. The executive committee set up by Russia and the United States to distribute the money included a scientist identified in documents only as Y. Kalinin.
Dr. Arnauld E. Nicogossian, head of a NASA's $20 million joint research program with Russia, said a man he knew as Dr. Kalinin had helped identify which institutes were to receive American aid. Dr. Nicogossian said he had not heard of Biopreparat until last year.
Biopreparat also stands to benefit from a grant made by the Agency for International Development in 1997. In a project approved by a Russian-American commission headed by Vice President Al Gore, the aid agency awarded a $6 million grant to a collaboration between the Searle pharmaceutical unit of Monsanto and a Russian institute partly owned by Biopreparat.
Officials and scientists say none of the A.I.D. money went directly to Biopreparat. But, they acknowledge, Biopreparat stands to earn a share of the profits if the company's sale of high-quality medicines succeeds.
In interviews, administration officials defended the grants. The American money, they say, has helped deter a scientific brain drain to rogue states and terrorists and there is no indication that it was used to support covert germ research.
But many national security officials were furious when they first learned of Biopreparat's involvement in the grants last year. "What happened in these cases was outrageous," said a senior national security official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "A.I.D. and NASA were essentially running their own foreign policy."
Several officials attributed the early problems to the reluctance of intelligence officials to share information. As a result, few American officials reviewing the NASA grants in 1995 were aware of Biopreparat's key role in the Soviet germ warfare program.
Administration officials said the system for reviewing sensitive projects was now far tougher. For example, in June 1998, the Energy Department rejected a request that all American research grants to institutes linked to Biopreparat be channeled through Biopreparat officials. "By that time," the official said, "we knew we wanted nothing to do with them."

BRITAIN: PINOCHET APPEAL
In a joint action, six rights groups are asking the High Court today to block the release of Gen. Augusto Pinochet from house arrest. They are seeking a public hearing into Home Secretary Jack Straw's Jan. 11 determination that the former Chilean dictator is medically unfit to stand trial in Spain on torture charges. Mr. Straw said he would await the outcome of any judicial review before announcing his decision on whether General Pinochet, 84, can return to Chile. Warren Hoge (NYT)

HEADLINE: Outer Space vs. Parking Space;
Planetarium and Wary Neighbors Prepare for Opening

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Stepping over the battered orange extension cord snaking from a 16-gallon Shop Vac, Ellen V. Futter, president of the American Museum of Natural History, pointed to the floor of the sleek new $210 million planetarium about her. "Right now, it's all about wires," she said, her voice competing with a symphony of power tools.
To her left, three electricians were unwinding 21 spools of red, white, blue and green wire, activating a wall of video monitors on a recent afternoon. Upstairs, technicians were tuning the new $3.5 million Zeiss projector. And next door, interviewers were filling the last of 289 new planetarium jobs, including 37 security guards and 6 switchboard operators. 
 Thus, these days, the museum braces for the onslaught. On Feb. 19, the first of as many as a million extra visitors over the next year will descend on 81st Street and Central Park West to see the new Rose Center for Earth and Space.
Even if the planetarium had not been a New York City icon for 65 years, this debut would be no ordinary opening. Expressing everything from jubilation to intense concern, city officials, tourism czars, culture sachems and neighborhood naysayers have at last found themselves in agreement about something: that the impact of the new building will be off the charts.
The advent of the Rose Center "is perhaps the single most important attraction in the city this year," said Cristyne F. Lategano, president of NYC and Company, formerly known as the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau.
"It will have a tremendous impact on the city's economy," she said, "and there will be spinoff benefits to restaurants, retail shops, hotels and theaters as well."
Specifically, the new planetarium is expected to generate $76 million in retail sales and an additional $5.8 million in tax revenue for New York City, according to an economic impact statement prepared for the museum by a consultant, Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler.
To Schuyler G. Chapin, the city's cultural affairs commissioner, the very-2000 planetarium -- an 87-foot-wide aluminum-clad sphere in a titanic glass cube -- will be nothing less than "a new symbol for New York City," he said.
"Think of the postcards," he said.
But it has to open first. "There have been moments when we thought we'd never get it done on time," Ms. Futter, 50, said of the six-year construction project.
Work proceeds, feverishly, including: moving the speakers inside the 432-seat Space Theater to eliminate dead spots. Printing enough giveaway floor plans to guide visitors. Cleaning the construction dust off the touchable bronze model of the moon. Laying the red-shifted rainbow carpeting on the Cosmic Pathway, where at 50 million years a step, visitors can stroll down a 350-foot ramp recapitulating the 13.2-billion-year evolution of the universe. (Signage designates one spot where the entire span of human history is represented by a single hair.)
Beyond this, the museum is anticipating planetarium lines so long that astronomical lecturers are being hired to entertain standees with impromptu talks on science and space. The spielers will be kept busy, according to preliminary estimates, by 4.5 million museum visitors next year.
Such a total, exceeding the population of Los Angeles, will come close to the five million yearly visitors to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, across Central Park. "Undoubtedly there has been a sibling rivalry," said Mr. Chapin, referring to the close 19th-century origins of both institutions (the American Museum was founded in 1869, the Met in 1870), "but they are a perfect pair, the cultural anchors of the city."
In an era when the Met has reigned supreme, will the new hoopla accorded the long-stodgy American Museum revive this 130-year rivalry?
"We're very happy to be bookends on a beautiful park," Ms. Futter said diplomatically, adding that the increasing number of tourists coming to the planetarium could benefit the Met's admissions as well.
The Met "doesn't consider other museums competition," Harold Holzer, the museum's vice president for communications, said, "and we think the Rose Center is a perfect addition to the neighborhood."
That opinion is hardly shared by some in the neighborhood. Three years after courts rebuffed community law suits trying to block the new building's construction, the museum still faces opposition from a dwindling but vocal band of neighbors, some of whom are opposed to the aesthetic of the new planetarium.
"They could have put the new Zeiss projector in the original landmarked Hayden Planetarium and preserved it," said Samuel H. Leff, president of the Community Alliance for Responsible Museum Development, one of two groups that unsuccessfully sued the museum. "The city could have saved tens of millions of dollars, but now we have a glass box with a ball in it that looks like a high-tech tumor."
"They wanted to put something in there that was very flashy, so they'd have something like the Pyramide at the Louvre and get a lot of attention," he said, referring to I. M. Pei's acclaimed addition to the Louvre.
His organization has substantially declined from 350 members during the salad days of planetarium insurgency, but Mr. Leff claimed that many in the neighborhood opposed what he called "the traffic disaster" caused by automobile and bus visitors "and the additional congestion and pollution in an already densely populated neighborhood."
Although dozens of school buses could park in the old street-surface lot on the planetarium grounds, there is room for but 10 of them in the Rose Center's new 370-space garage.
School buses, tour buses and the cars of visitors unable to fit in the garage "will cruise the neighborhood, parking up and down the local streets and avenues, causing gridlock," Mr. Leff said.
Furthermore, "The buses will leave their motors running, causing pollution," he said.
"At the museum," he added, "they make much of all their exhibits about ecology and biodiversity, but they're polluting the community right outside their buildings."
But another local group, Friends of Museum Park, says that since the population of the West Side has declined 25 percent since the 1950's, and since museum attendance was considerably higher 25 years ago than it was last year, the fears of overcrowding are unfounded.
"The neighborhood can support more museum visitors," said Peter M. Wright, the organization's president and co-founder. But like Mr. Leff, Mr. Wright is worried about bus parking and pollution.
Concerns about traffic have also been raised by residents of the Beresford building on West 81st Street and Central Park West, who have another complaint about the museum's future as a much-sought-after party venue.
At the planetarium's sneak-preview opening party for 1,700 on New Year's Eve, "they had outdoor music, which I could hear in my apartment, and the cheap and ugly psychedelic lights made the planetarium look like a theme park," said Richard Lieb, a lawyer and Beresford board member who unsuccessfully sued to stop construction.
Lisa J. Gugenheim, the museum's vice president for government relations and community affairs, said that since 1995 she and others at the museum have "met more than 250 times with members of the community."
"We have, together, modified the museum's plans where appropriate and possible," she said.
Ms. Gugenheim said the museum regretted any inconvenience caused by the New Year's Eve celebration. She said the museum would "limit the use of outdoor amplified music" in the future.
Ms. Gugenheim says that the museum has adequate plans to unload and store the average of 41 school buses each weekday that visit the museum between 9:30 a.m and 1:30 p.m. She said there is room both in the Rose Center garage, in legal street-parking spaces and in a 25-vehicle overflow parking center at 60th Street and West End Avenue.
For the first time, the commander for the 20th Precinct has assigned an officer to ticket buses that are illegally parked or are idling their motors.
The museum is also mounting a $1 million advertising campaign with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to encourage visitors to take public transportation, while sharing half the $20 million cost of renovating the 81st Street subway station and the museum's ground floor to allow more visitors and school groups.
Ms. Futter said the museum was equally focused on people-moving inside the Rose Center, because the planetarium "will change the nature of how people visit the museum, how long they spend here, and how often they come back."
As people swarm into the planetarium from eight entrances, managers are projecting what they call "throughput" that averages two hours per customer. The museum designers are preparing for three kinds of visitors: "streakers, strollers and studiers," Ms. Futter said.
Streakers, of course, race through; strollers amble about at a steady pace, and studiers insist on reading every word of every label.
One nightmare is that "there will be no throughput," said Barbara D. Gunn, senior vice president for government relations and community affairs. "If they find everything fascinating in the planetarium, they won't want to leave," she said, half seriously.
But some just might go on to study the universe. "The Rose Center will be an inspirational venue for communicating science to young people," said Dan Goldin, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in Washington. "I'll never forget my first time at the Hayden Planetarium when I was 7," said Mr. Goldin, who was raised in the South Bronx. "For me it was, well, eureka! It launched my interest in space and astronomy."

HEADLINE: Budget Rise Is Proposed By Whitman

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Saying New Jersey's sustained economic boom and the state's mounting surpluses had created an "unprecedented opportunity," Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed today her most generous budget yet, a $21.2 billion plan that increases spending by $1.3 billion for a host of new programs, tax cuts and ambitious school and highway construction projects.
Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, asserted that her spending plan, which she titled a Prosperity Dividend, would actually strengthen her record as a fiscal conservative. She boasted that she had completely eliminated so-called one-shot revenues and that her budget would leave yet another record surplus while keeping the average yearly growth in spending during her two terms to the lowest level of any governor in 30 years. 
 The governor, who likes to remind voters how often she has lowered or eliminated taxes, proposed three new tax cuts today, including an earned income tax credit for which nearly 280,000 residents would be eligible. Under the program, families earning $15,000 would receive a $338 check.
"Oh, and in case anyone's counting, it will make for tax cut No. 40," Mrs. Whitman said.
The governor also proposed a two-year suspension of employees' contribution to unemployment insurance, which is now capped at $42.40 a year per worker, as well as the employers' share, which ranges from $440 for a small business to $44,000 for a large company. The state's unemployment insurance fund has ballooned to the nation's third largest, at $2.9 billion, enough to pay for two and a half years of anticipated benefits without any additional collections.
Acting to shore up the area in which she has been most vulnerable to criticism -- her propensity to borrow -- Mrs. Whitman called for a new fund to begin to retire the state's debt. But she set aside no money in her budget for that purpose, and Democrats roundly criticized her proposal as disingenuous.
"This budget is the latest exercise in spending for an administration that has never seen a line of credit it didn't like," said the Assembly minority leader, Joseph Doria, a Democrat from Bayonne.
There was real money in the budget, however, for a broad array of constituencies: $70 million for health insurance for the working poor and $55 million for the disabled, $100 million for hospitals and more than $45 million for colleges, $25 million for high-tech entrepreneurs and $10 million for cancer researchers, to name a few.
Immediate complaints came only from those who got something but wanted still more. A coalition of antismoking groups known as New Jersey Breathes lamented that Mrs. Whitman had only allocated $30 million for tobacco prevention efforts. "We're shocked," the group's chairman, Paul Wallner, said, adding that an additional $15 million could make New Jersey's program as effective as any in the country.
The budget includes two long-awaited capital programs, and each entails an important concession to a Republican contender to succeed Mrs. Whitman as governor. She proposed to spend $9.4 billion to rebuild the state's crumbling schools, including $5 billion for inner-city districts to comply with a court order. But she agreed to a demand by the Assembly speaker, Jack Collins, a likely candidate for governor, that she set aside $100 million to finance such construction from the $300 million a year in anticipated receipts from the nationwide tobacco settlement. The governor had sought to reserve the tobacco money for health care programs.
In her speech today, Mrs. Whitman sounded a note of caution about the tobacco money, which is certain to come under pressure from lawmakers during the budget negotiation process, which by law and tradition must end with passage of an appropriations law before the end of June.
"With $7.4 billion over the next 25 years, we have to set a good example -- avoid the raid-the-cookie-jar mentality -- and spend this money responsibly," she said.
Education lobbyists praised the governor's concession, saying a stable source of revenue was needed to pay for such an ambitious statewide construction effort. But Mrs. Whitman's budget acknowledges that after five years, additional revenue sources will be needed to generate annual increases of $50 million in debt service costs.
The governor also proposed a refinancing of the state's depleted transportation trust fund to pay for $1 billion in new projects each year.
She had raised the possibility of an increase in the state's 11.5-cent gasoline tax for that purpose. But she acceded to wishes of the State Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, another potential candidate for governor, who opposed a higher gas tax.
Instead, the state would pay about $220 million more into the fund from general revenues, and would float $580 million more in bonds.
Mrs. Whitman's budget address was most intriguing when she turned to the state's debt level, which has more than doubled, to $14.6 billion, since she took office. She first contended that the state's real debt had grown much less -- about 6 percent a year -- explaining that her financial officers had begun recognizing many existing obligations as debt, in the interest of "honest accounting." She did not mention her issuing of $2.8 billion in bonds in 1997 to bring the state's payments into its employee pension system up to date.
"Now, it's time to take the next step," the governor added, proposing a debt retirement fund. Half of any future surpluses greater than $720 million -- the current size of the state's fund for emergencies -- would be put aside to pay down the state's debt.
"Putting money toward debt reduction is like paying more than the minimum due on your credit card," Mrs. Whitman said. "The sooner you pay down the balance, the less you have to pay in the long run."
Critics immediately derided the governor's suggestion. "This sounds like, 'Now that I've got religion, let me go have another drink,' " said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspectives, a liberal group. "At the same time they're saying this, they're borrowing even more for the transportation trust fund, without creating a new revenue source."
And Senator Wayne R. Bryant said the governor's talk of reducing the debt was welcome, "but actions speak louder than words." Mr. Bryant, a Camden Democrat, added, "Using this budget to make a down payment on the $2.8 billion pension bond would help convince skeptics that the administration's debt retirement intentions are genuine."
But Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon County who is chairman of the Assembly Appropriations Committee, said he was pleased that at least some of the new money for the transportation fund was so-called pay-as-you-go capital instead of bonds. "The governor's moving in the right direction," he said.

HEADLINE: At Hearing, Longshoremen and Environmentalists Clash Over Dumping

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Jan. 24

 BODY:
A small group of environmentalists that is seeking to stop the dumping of dredged material into the ocean off Sandy Hook squared off raucously today with more than 2,000 angry longshoremen, who turned out in support of a four-year-old agreement crucial to port jobs.
The setting was a hearing in an Army base auditorium by the United States Army Corps of Engineers, where the longshoremen, many of whom spilled into the parking lot, shouted down and booed opponents of ocean dumping. An official with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said the turnout by the longshoremen -- who said they took the day off without pay -- had effectively closed the region's ports to loading and unloading as of noon. 
 But about 200 opponents, including officials of shore communities, a Congressman, sport fishermen and a Boy Scout troop from Oceanport, seemed unintimidated, often giving as good as they got when officials from the International Longshoremen's Association stood to speak.
The opponents' numbers increased during an evening session of the hearing, as shore residents came home from work. But the session grew so noisy that the meeting was ended prematurely, about 8:15 p.m., said Pete H. Shugert, the public affairs officer of the Army Corps of Engineers. He said the meeting was ended "for safety reasons, and because there was not an opportunity for a free exchange of information."
At issue was the agreement among unions, port businesses, government agencies and environmentalists that was reached in negotiations presided over by Vice President Al Gore in 1996. The deal ended a spate of lawsuits over the dumping about six miles off Sandy Hook, which had blocked the dredging of 240 miles of channels in the New York and New Jersey port region for years.
The environmental group involved in the negotiations, Clean Ocean Action, is charging that the federal government and port interests have reneged on the agreement's goal of a cleaner ocean by failing to tighten restrictions on what can safely be dumped into the ocean and by failing to speed development of alternatives to dumping. The group says materials are being dumped with levels of some contaminants that are higher than those already at the dump site, which they say is a violation of the agreement brokered by Vice President Gore. "How can you clean up a toxic stain with materials that are dirtier than what is there?" asked the group's executive director, Cynthia Zipf, shouting over the boos and catcalls of the longshoremen. "We will not sit by and allow you to bring back the barbaric days of ocean dumping."
Clean Ocean Action and its allies, including United States Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Democrat of Long Branch, said that they wanted the Army Corps of Engineers to rescind two recently granted permits to dump material dredged from two New York City port locations, the Castle Astoria fuel depot in Queens and the Brooklyn Army Terminal near Red Hook. Ms. Zipf said that if the federal agency did not stop the two projects, the group's lawyers would sue.
The union says the environmental groups are reneging on the four-year-old pact. "A deal is a deal," shouted John Bowers, president of the 80,000-member International Longshoremen's Association. "We want to make certain that the billions of dollars in cargo that fuels the economy of the harbor and the region can continue to move, and the stakes are too great to let the wrong signals be sent to port employers."
Under the agreement, dumping of dredged material at the site off the coast of New Jersey was restricted to material that met federal Environmental Protection Agency standards as nontoxic and not likely to cause chemicals such as mercury, cadmium, lead and dioxins to find their way into fish and eventually the food chain. The agreement does not appear to call for any specific tightening of those restrictions, as the environmentalists contend.
Mary Mears, a spokesman for the regional office of the federal environmental agency, as well as officials of the Port Authority, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the Army Corps of Engineers, have said that the material being opposed by Ms. Zipf and other opponents meets E.P.A. standards.
That is because although the dredged material being dumped at the site may contain higher levels of some contaminants than are already present, most of the contaminants are at lower levels, officials said. That is consistent with the deal brokered by Mr. Gore, they said.
Outside the auditorium, Michael Svorini, a longshoreman since 1972 at the Global Marine Terminal in Jersey City, said: "If they stop the dredging, it won't just affect us. It will affect truck drivers and warehouse workers. Ships won't come here if we can't dredge because they can only make money if they keep moving."
Inside the auditorium, Lois Gallini, a Wall Township resident, waved a sign proclaiming herself an "Environmentalist for a Working Port." She said the waters were "where our children swim, and I remember when my son years ago would come home with all kinds of rashes from the bacteria."
Both sides in the dispute were critical of New York State's efforts. Opponents of dredging noted that New Jersey had developed land-based alternatives for some of the more toxic and contaminated material, while New York had yet to do that.
Jennifer Post, a spokeswoman for the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, dismissed such concerns. While New York had yet to come up with a specific disposal site on land, she said that the state was looking for one while spending millions of dollars to reduce pollution of the port waters.

HEADLINE: Justices Uphold Ceiling of $1,000 On Political Gifts

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Ruling in a Missouri campaign finance case with important national implications, the Supreme Court today decisively upheld limits on political contributions and rejected the argument that the $1,000 limit it upheld 24 years ago no longer buys enough political speech to be constitutional.
The 6-to-3 decision left states with considerable latitude to adopt the $1,000 limit upheld in the court's much-disputed 1976 Buckley v. Valeo decision, or to experiment with lower caps, as many states recently have. 
 The test, the court said in a majority opinion by Justice David H. Souter, is not any fixed or indexed dollar amount, but whether a contribution limit was so low "as to render political association ineffective, drive the sound of a candidate's voice below the level of notice, and render contributions pointless." Missouri's $1,000 cap met this test without running afoul of the First Amendment, the court said. Excerpts, page A16.
The decision overturned a 1998 ruling by the federal appeals court in St. Louis, which declared the Missouri limit unconstitutional on the ground that it was too low -- $1,000 in 1976 being the equivalent of less than $400 today -- and that the state had failed to provide proof of problems resulting from large contributions. Had the justices agreed with the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, the federal campaign finance system, which also has a $1,000 limit, and those of many states would have been thrown into turmoil.
The closely watched case did not call on the justices to reconsider the Buckley v. Valeo decision as a whole or even to address its most widely criticized element, its holding that campaign expenditures, as opposed to contributions, represent the highest form of political speech and may not be limited. Many people have blamed the decision for the tide of independent expenditures as well as unregulated "soft money" contributions that appear increasingly likely to swamp the political system. Advocates of new federal limits on campaign contributions said the ruling strengthened their hand. Page A16.
The limit applies to donations from individuals to any single candidate for federal office per election.
 In a dissenting opinion today, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy declared that "Buckley has not worked," having "created a misshapen system" that has "forced a substantial amount of political speech underground." Justice Clarence Thomas dissented as well, declaring in an opinion that Justice Antonin Scalia also signed that Missouri's contribution limits were "patently unconstitutional" and that Buckley v. Valeo should be overruled.
But while the question before the court was limited to the contribution question, the various opinions today contained some intriguing tea leaves for the future.
A concurring opinion by Justice Stephen G. Breyer, joined by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, suggested that the court should give the political branches considerable leeway in sorting out a difficult question on which "a legislature has significantly greater institutional expertise" than a court.
Within the existing Buckley framework, laws regulating soft money might well be upheld, Justice Breyer said. Alternatively, he said, the decision could be reinterpreted "in light of the post-Buckley experience" to make "less absolute the contribution/expenditure line, particularly in respect to independently wealthy candidates, whose expenditures might be considered contributions to their own campaigns."
But if the precedent did not prove sufficiently flexible, Justice Breyer concluded, "I believe the Constitution would require us to reconsider Buckley."
Among the other members of the court, Justice John Paul Stevens indicated in a concurring opinion that he, too, would be ready to uphold limits on money in politics well beyond those upheld in the Buckley decision. "Money is property; it is not speech," Justice Stevens said, in a comment that rejected the essential equation of money and speech that was the analytical foundation of Buckley v. Valeo.
And Justice Kennedy, in his dissenting opinion, distanced himself from his two fellow dissenters with a paragraph that startled those who thought they understood the dimensions of his near-absolutist view of political speech. "I would leave open the possibility that Congress, or a state legislature, might devise a system in which there are some limits on both expenditures and contributions, thus permitting officeholders to concentrate their time and efforts on official duties rather than on fund-raising," Justice Kennedy said.
In recent campaign finance decisions, only Justices Stevens and Ginsburg had shown a willingness to revisit the Buckley v. Valeo dichotomy between contributions and expenditures, so supporters of limits on expenditures and soft money, while acknowledging that they still could not count on a court majority, detected significant forward movement.
"Reality infuses these opinions," one such advocate, E. Joshua Rosenkranz, executive director of the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University Law School, said in an interview. "The court is taking account of what's going on out there. We're in far better shape than we were before this decision."
Nicole A. Gordon, executive director of the New York City Campaign Finance Board, a city agency that administers the public financing of local political races, said the decision had produced "a collective sigh of relief from the reform community" that not only did the court not reject contribution limits, as some had forecast, but now appeared open to arguments on behalf of new limits.
While there is no immediate next test looming for the court, cases in the pipeline could provide one. Expenditure limits adopted in 1995 by the state legislature in Vermont are being challenged in Federal District Court in Burlington. Under the state's limits for gubernatorial races, for example, the challenger may spend no more than $300,000 while an incumbent seeking re-election is limited to 85 percent of what the challenger spends.
Unlike the other members of the majority, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor joined Justice Souter's opinion, Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, No. 98-963, without further elaboration. The majority opinion studiously avoided speculation about the future. Justice Souter, acknowledging the calls of his colleagues for overruling Buckley v. Valeo, said: "The answer is that we are supposed to decide this case." He noted that the broader question was not before the court.
The challenge to the Missouri contribution limit, adopted by the state Legislature in 1994, was brought by a former candidate for state auditor and a political action committee that supported him. The candidate, Zev David Fredman , argued that the limit was so low that, as an insurgent, he could not exercise his First Amendment right to mount an effective campaign.
Mr. Fredman's victory in the appeals court threatened to unsettle many states' contribution limits on two levels: first, under the notion that inflation should be taken into account in assessing a limit's adequacy, and second, by demanding a level of evidence of corruption beyond what the Supreme Court had required when it upheld the federal limits in Buckley v. Valeo.
In his opinion today, Justice Souter said the Eighth Circuit's view that inflation must be taken into account reflected a "fundamental misunderstanding" of Buckley v. Valeo as having adopted any particular level as a minimum. And on the question of evidence, he said, "this case does not present a close call." Justice Souter said "there is little reason to doubt" that large contributions can be corrupting, or can be seen as such by voters.
As a matter of constitutional doctrine, there was considerable wrestling over how to define the First Amendment standard of review for the limits in question, an issue on which the Buckley precedent was imprecise. The majority held today that the strictest judicial scrutiny need not apply to contribution limits.

HEADLINE: Ecuador's Endangered Democracy

 BODY:
Military meddling in politics has become rare in Latin America during the past two decades. But Ecuador is a conspicuous and worrisome exception. Last weekend's forcible removal of President Jamil Mahuad is disturbing, especially since it is the second time in less than three years that an elected Ecuadorean leader has been prematurely ousted from office. Ominously, on both occasions the army played a decisive role in shaping the presidential succession.
At the end of a confused weekend of maneuvering capped by strong warnings from Washington against the establishment of a military regime, Vice President Gustavo Noboa Bejarano has been sworn in as president. Ecuador's government thus remains in civilian, constitutional hands. But democracy's future there looks tenuous. Washington must be ready for further turmoil as Ecuador steers its way through a difficult economic and political crisis. 
 Mr. Mahuad, who won a majority in presidential runoff elections barely 18 months ago, saw his popularity plunge to 9 percent as Ecuador's chronically ailing economy slipped beyond his control. Blocked by an impasse with a politically fractured Congress from enacting needed tax increases on the wealthy and reforms of an inefficient public sector, Mr. Mahuad stood by helplessly as inflation raged, unemployment soared, banks tottered and half of Ecuador's foreign debt passed into default.
In desperation, Mr. Mahuad announced earlier this month that he would replace Ecuador's battered currency with the dollar. Many Ecuadoreans, especially the large and impoverished Indian minority, feared that converting to dollars would lead to painful reductions in their already low living standards.
Last Friday thousands of Indians marched on Congress. Army guards stepped aside, leaving Mr. Mahuad besieged in the presidential palace. Two military-civilian juntas were named in rapid succession. Then, after the Clinton administration strongly condemned the unfolding coup and threatened the new regime with economic isolation, the military handed power back to Mr. Noboa, the elected vice president.
Washington's timely diplomatic intervention was constructive. But real stability will not return until Ecuador's leaders, starting with Mr. Noboa, address the country's fundamental economic problems. Tax revenues must be fairly increased, corruption prosecuted and public-sector subsidies sharply reduced.
Austerity measures such as these will be hard to apply until the government broadens its popular legitimacy and wins the confidence of the Indian population. Meanwhile, Ecuador's political parties have to recognize that their incessant infighting is discrediting civilian rule and dangerously increasing the political power of military commanders. They must show themselves capable of serious reforms before outside creditors can be approached for further debt relief.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Looking to New Hampshire, Gore Outlines New Strategy

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: DES MOINES, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Four months after he acknowledged that his campaign was in serious trouble, Vice President Al Gore stood on a stage here and with confetti plastered to the side of his face, claimed his first success of the 2000 presidential campaign, a resounding 2-to-1 victory over Bill Bradley.
"We've just begun to fight," Mr. Gore yelled to a crowd of more than 600 people at the Iowa State Fairgrounds as his wife, Tipper, pranced at his side. 
 In his victory speech, he quickly turned his attention to the race ahead in New Hampshire and signaled a "new phase" in his campaign strategy. He said he would be campaigning not only on the current economic prosperity but also on the idea that the country could do even better than its current record-breaking economic expansion.
After months of often-harsh attacks against Mr. Bradley, Mr. Gore referred to him only glancingly tonight and seemed more interested in talking about the Republicans. He said Mr. Bradley had asked Iowa audiences if they were better off today than they were seven years ago, then told the crowd here that clearly they were but that that was not the right question.
"The question is, Can we do even better?" Mr. Gore asked. "I believe the answer is yes."
He said the Republicans -- specifically Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and the publisher Steve Forbes -- would ruin the country with irresponsible tax cuts.
Now, as the race shifts to New Hampshire, Mr. Gore's aides said his message would shift from the heavy focus here on agriculture to the booming New England economy. Mr. Gore plans to tell New Hampshire voters that while the Clinton-Gore administration has done wonders for the economy, there is more to do.
New Hampshire should be especially receptive to this message since it was losing 10,000 jobs a year in 1992 when Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore first ran, and it is now gaining 16,000 jobs a year. Moreover, aides said, focusing on the economy will help Mr. Gore deliver a "positive" message.
Bob Shrum, a top Gore adviser, said: "What the Clinton-Gore administration has done over the last seven years economically helps Al Gore a lot, and I think President Clinton will be a very valuable asset during the campaign."
Still, campaign aides said it was Mr. Gore's support for farmers and his knowledge of agricultural issues that he leveraged into his lead here over Mr. Bradley.
Referring to the Jan. 8 debate in which Mr. Gore said Mr. Bradley did not support various issues important to Iowa and farmers, his spokesman, Chris Lehane, said: "That was a crystallizing moment. Al Gore showed that he was fighting for Iowa and Bill Bradley showed he wasn't."
Mr. Gore said the town meetings in Iowa and New Hampshire helped him sharpen his campaign.
"The total immersion in this process has been something that I think has been very good for me," Mr. Gore said tonight. "I have been able to communicate more effectively because of what I've learned from the people of Iowa and New Hampshire."
