HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
Bradley Says Campaign Is on the Right Path

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa, Jan. 24

 BODY:
Despite concerns among some aides about the state of his campaign, former Senator Bill Bradley said today that he was more convinced than ever that the course he chartered for his presidential campaign more than a year ago was fundamentally correct.
In recent weeks, Mr. Bradley's insurgent campaign has been battered by negative news coverage and falling poll numbers, and many political analysts have argued that he has not been sharp enough in drawing distinctions with Mr. Gore or aggressive enough in responding to the vice president's repeated attacks. Mr. Bradley ended up with 35 percent of the vote, compared with Mr. Gore's 63 percent. 
 Even some of his aides have recently raised questions about the campaign's tactics in Iowa, complaining that it had been late getting organized, slow to respond to Mr. Gore's criticisms and inadequate in preparing for debates. One adviser described Iowa as a "shakedown tour" for the Bradley organization.
But in an interview today just before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Bradley suggested that if anything he had been too negative in his battle with Mr. Gore, arguing that the "rat-a-tat-tat" of the race might have turned off voters and drawn attention from his own idealistic call to reform politics and end poverty.
"If you were trying to do a cookie-cutter campaign where you go negative on somebody, there's a little textbook that you take that says, chapter four, going negative, here are the five things you do," Mr. Bradley said.
"What adds to cynicism in politics is negative campaigning and attack ads," he added.
But even as Mr. Bradley contends that he will try to stay above the messy fray, his aides said they recognized that they, and Mr. Bradley's prominent supporters, will need to strike back faster and perhaps more fiercely against Mr. Gore when he goes on the offensive.
Indeed, the Bradley campaign began running a television advertisement in New Hampshire today in which Niki Tsongas, widow of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, accused the Gore campaign of distorting Mr. Bradley's record. During the 1992 presidential campaign, Mr. Tsongas made similar accusations against Bill Clinton.
Mr. Bradley said he realized his campaign had drifted from its moorings last week when he heard the story of a New Hampshire woman whose teenage son apologized for getting sick because the family had no health insurance. Her story, which brought tears to his eyes, "recentered" him on the reasons he had entered the race, particularly to create a system of near universal health insurance, he said.
"Sometimes in the rat-a-tat-tat of politics, in the rush of the media and the emphasis on tactics, you lose sight of why you're in this," he said. But there may also be political reasons for Mr. Bradley's wanting to step back from attacking Mr. Gore. Two weeks ago, Mr. Bradley had been sharpening his criticism of the vice president, even attacking a 15-year-old Senate vote by Mr. Gore that helped the tobacco industry. But many analysts said Mr. Bradley's attacks gave a sense of desperation in his camp.
Mr. Gore has also toned down his criticism of Mr. Bradley in recent days. Asked whether he would return fire if Mr. Gore started attacking him again in New Hampshire, site of the nation's first primary next Tuesday, Mr. Bradley replied, "You always have the option, of course, to adopt the atomic bomb. But the point is, I'm going to try to keep this thing positive."
To both his critics and supporters, Mr. Bradley's refusal to aggressively attack Mr. Gore recalls his 1990 re-election campaign, where he was slow to respond to criticism by his opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, and almost lost the New Jersey Senate race. Some political analysts argued that the race showed that Mr. Bradley was too headstrong to adjust his strategies to deal with unforeseen or shifting circumstances.
But Mr. Bradley denied that he was inflexible, saying: "I think there should be a distinction drawn between being inflexible and being rooted. I'm rooted in what I know what I believe and what I know I want to do. I'm flexible in how I want to achieve it."
He said he had no plans to change significantly his basic stump speech in the coming weeks. But Mr. Bradley offered a glimpse today of the message he intended to emphasize in New Hampshire: that he would be better at maintaining the nation's prosperity because he has a track record of predicting changes in the economy. Mr. Bradley referred to his early support in the 1980's for cutting the deficit, reducing Third World debt and simplifying the tax code.
Mr. Bradley also said he would increasingly highlight the economic benefits of his health care proposal, which he said would provide the equivalent of a $25 billion-a-year tax cut for people earning less than $50,000 a year.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
SARGENT, DAVID RUTLEDGE

 BODY:
SARGENT-David Rutledge. Financial publisher and civic leader, died on January 22 of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 79 years old. Mr. Sargent, former president of United Business Service of Boston, was a resident of Wellesley, MA from 1947 until he retired to his family farm in Norwich, VT, in 1992. An active public servant in his town and the greater Boston area, he served Wellesley for more that twenty years as town meeting member, member and chairman of the Wellesley School Committee and the Select Board, as well as Town Moderator. He was Chairman of Wellesley Red Feather in 1955, the forerunner of the United Fund, and also served on its greater Boston Board. In 1966, he was a cofounder of Metco, the Metropolitan Council for Educational Opportunity, which organized volunteer busing of Boston children to suburban schools. He was a gubernatorial appointee to several state committees on economic policy. During the same period, he served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Peter Bent Brigham, now known as Brigham and Women's Hospital. From 1983-1993, he was a member of the Board of the Hitchcock Clinic and a trustee of Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital. Born December 21, 1920 in Orange, NJ, he entered Dartmouth College from Hastings on Hudson, NY's high school, graduating in 1942. He was an active alumnus and was class secretary from 1982-1988. After college, Mr. Sargent joined the military serving from 1942-45 as an R.A.F. pilot and U.S. Air Force flying instructor. He joined United Business Service in 1946, and became president in 1961. An author of two books on personal finances, he was also a nationally syndicated columnist in the 1980's. A man of tremendous wit and energy, his life was enriched by his wide variety of interests. Mr. Sargent was an accomplished tennis player and bicyclist. When he was 60 years old, he rode his bicycle across the state of Iowa in the annual Ragbrai bike ride, sponsored by the Des Moines Register. An avid birder and outdoorsman, he canoed many local rivers and could identify most birds by sight and sound. He had a restless intellect, which fueled his passion for books, learning, and verbal debate. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Jane Oman; two daughters, Karen Sirkin of Wayland, MA; Anne Walker of Wellesley, MA; and four sons, Dwight Sargent of Norwich, VT; Carl Sargent of Boston, MA; David Sargent Jr. of Norwich, VT; and Thomas Sargent of Wellesley, MA; and ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to: American Parkinson Disease Association, 1250 Hylan Blvd., Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305, The Visiting Nurse Alliance of VT and N.H., 46 South Main Street, White River Junction, VT 05001, Norwich Conservation Trust Fund, Norwich Conservation Commission, PO Box 376, Norwich, VT 05055. Information: Rand-Wilson Funeral Home of Hanover, NH. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Paradox in Game Theory: Losing Strategy That Wins

BYLINE: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE

 BODY:
A Spanish physicist has discovered what appears to be a new law of nature that may help explain, among other things, how life arose out of a primordial soup and why investing in losing stocks can sometimes lead to greater capital gains.
Called Parrando's paradox, the law states that two games guaranteed to make a player lose all his money can generate a winning streak if played alternately. 
 Named after its discoverer, Dr. Juan Parrando, who teaches physics at the Complutense University in Madrid, the newly discovered paradox is inspired by the mechanical properties of ratchets -- the familiar saw-tooth tools used in automobile jacks and in self-winding wristwatches.
By translating the properties of a ratchet into game theory, the scientific discipline that seeks to extract rules of nature from the gains and losses observed in games, Dr. Parrando discovered that two losing games could combine to produce winnings.
"The importance of the paradox in real life remains to be seen," said Dr. Charles Doering, a mathematician at the University of Michigan, who is familiar with the research.
"It gives us a new and unexpected view of a variety of phenomena," he said, "and who knows? Sometimes finding that one piece of the puzzle makes the whole picture suddenly clear," Dr. Doering said.
Dr. Derek Abbott, director of the Center for Biomedical Engineering at the University of Adelaide in Australia, said that many scientists were intrigued by the paradox and had begun applying it to engineering, population dynamics, financial risk and other disciplines.
Dr. Abbott and a colleague at his center, Dr. Gregory Harmer, recently carried out experiments to verify and explain how Parrando's paradox works.
Their research is described in a recent issue of the journal Nature.
The paradox is illustrated by two games played with coins weighted on one side so that they will not fall by chance to heads or tails.
In game A, a player tosses a single loaded coin and bets on each throw. The probability of winning is less than half.
In game B, there are two coins and the rules are more complicated. The player tosses either Coin 1, loaded to lose almost all the time or Coin 2 loaded to win more than half the time. He plays Coin 1 if his money is a multiple of a particular whole number, like three.
If his money cannot be divided evenly by that number, he plays Coin 2. In this setup, the second coin will be played more often than the first.
"Sure enough," Dr. Abbott said, when a person plays either game A or game B 100 times, all money taken to the gambling table is lost. But when the games are alternated -- playing A twice and B twice for 100 times -- money is not lost. It accumulates into big winnings. Even more surprising, he said, when game A and B are played randomly, with no order in the alternating sequence, winnings also go up and up.
Because these results seem so surprising, the outcome is paradoxical -- Parrando's paradox. Switching between the two games seemed to create a ratchet-like effect. With its saw-tooth shape, a ratchet allows movement in one direction and blocks it in the other.
"You see ratchets everywhere in life," Dr. Abbott said. "Any child knows that when you shake a bag of mixed nuts, the Brazil nuts rise to the top. This is because smaller nuts block downward movement of larger nuts." This trapping of heavier objects -- moving them upward when one would expect them to fall down -- is the essence of a ratchet.
The same is true for particles that tend to move randomly within cells but can be captured, or ratcheted, into performing useful work. This is how many proteins and enzymes are designed, Dr. Abbott said.
Sharing an interest in microscopic ratchets, Dr. Abbott and Dr. Parrando met in a coffee shop in Madrid in 1997 to discuss the phenomenon. They started to wonder what might happen with a so-called flashing ratchet.
First, they imagined two tilted slopes that could be laid on top of each other or held apart. One is smooth and straight, the other saw-toothed.
Particles placed at the top of either slope would fall down to the bottom under the pull of gravity. Particles placed at the bottom of either slope would go nowhere. But if the two slopes were superimposed and alternated or "flashed" back and forth, particles resting at the bottom could be made to move uphill.
Dr. Parrando then translated a flashing ratchet into the language of game theory. Then, he devised the two coin games. Dr. Abbott confirmed their outcomes in recent experiments. Game A is like the smooth slope. The single loaded coin produces steady losses, just like particles sliding straight downhill. Game B is like the saw-tooth slope that can catch objects. Each tooth on a ratchet has two sides, one that goes up and one that goes down. The two coins, one good and one bad, are like two sides of a single saw-tooth. In a computer, the games are played 100 times, mimicking a ratchet with many teeth.
When the games are run in a computer, Dr. Abbott said, capital starts accumulating. Switching the game traps any winnings before new rounds of the game can cause the money to be lost.
Unfortunately, Parrando's paradox will not work for the kinds of games played in casinos, Dr. Abbott said. Games A and B must be set up to copy a ratchet, which means they must have some direct interaction. In the experiments carried out by Dr. Abbott, game B depends on the amount of capital being played and game A affects those amounts. They are subtly connected, he said.
Parrando's paradox may help scientists find new ways to separate molecules, design tiny motors and understand games of survival being played at the level of individual genes. Life itself may have been bootstrapped by ratchets, Dr. Abbott said. When simple amino acids were formed by chance, environmental forces would tend to destroy incipient order. Factors that acted like ratchets could prevent that destruction, helping move life along its evolutionary pathways toward greater complexity.
Economists are studying Parrando's paradox to help find the best strategies for managing investments. Dr. Sergei Maslov, a physicist at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, N.Y., recently showed that if an investor simultaneously shared capital between two losing stock portfolios, capital would increase rather than decrease. "It's mind-boggling," Dr. Maslov said. "You can turn two minuses into a plus." But so far, he said, it is too early to apply his model to the real stock market because of its complexity.

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Jan. 25 about a paradox in game theory, a discipline that seeks to extract rules of nature from the gains and losses observed in games, misspelled the name of its discoverer. He is Dr. Juan Parrondo, not Parrando.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
A Political Showdown At Gamy Tammany Hall

BYLINE: By PHILLIP LOPATE; Phillip Lopate edited the recent anthology "Writing New York."

 BODY:

ONCE UPON A TIME IN NEW YORK
Jimmy Walker, Franklin Roosevelt
and the Last Great Battle
of the Jazz Age
By Herbert Mitgang
Illustrated. 259 pages. Free Press. $25.
Corruption and reform -- that cha-cha-cha of big city rule -- have come to seem as embedded in New York's deep structure as the grid plan of its streets. Underpaid civil servants will occasionally take bribes; political kingpins like Boss Tweed of Tammany Hall will build patronage empires, meanwhile feathering their nests until such time as ambitious do-gooders arouse the outrage of the sleeping populace.
Herbert Mitgang's lively "Once Upon a Time in New York" restages one of the classic confrontations in the city's history: on the one hand the dapper, immensely likable if venal mayor, Jimmy Walker, and his earthy cronies in the Tammany machine; on the other hand the virtuous if priggish Judge Samuel Seabury, investigating municipal corruption, and his ally, the patrician governor, Franklin Delano Roosevelt. In the wings stood Fiorello H. La Guardia, ready to take over the mayoralty if Walker should fall. The wild card was ex-Gov. Al Smith, a onetime liberal hero who had been defeated for president and, resenting Roosevelt's presidential ambitions, threw his support to Walker. 
 Mr. Mitgang, a former writer for The New York Times and author or editor of 15 books, knows this territory well, having already written a book on Judge Seabury. If the current volume feels like something of a rehash, revisiting favorite anecdotes and scandals, Mr. Mitgang is certainly a most reliable guide, a true Gotham maven. All the colorful Jazz Age characters you would hope to see make their appearance: the gambler Arnold Rothstein and the madam Polly Adler, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Jack Dempsey, Walter Winchell and the saloonkeeper Texas Guinan.
The rapid bark of Winchell and the streetwise ironies of Damon Runyon echo in Mr. Mitgang's journalistic prose: "Legs owned a piece of the Hotsy Totsy Club, a Prohibition joint on 54th Street and Broadway. There he could be seen with his girlfriend, Kiki Roberts, a Ziegfeld Follies looker whose actual name was Marion Strasmick."
In reaching too constantly for a bright cleverness, he can sound glib, calling Walker "a dude for all seasons," or piling up figures of speech, however clashing: "Eventually, the economic boom that began after the First World War began to run out of steam. Yet even when prosperity failed to appear just around the corner, Mayor Walker continued to trip the light fantastic."
This is popular history, longer on vignette than analysis. What makes it worthwhile are Mr. Mitgang's shrewd insights into local politics -- the implications of each player's chess move for future elections -- and the deft way he sets up the protagonists of his story and orchestrates them cunningly for the final showdown.
The nightclub-hopping Walker, openly escorting his mistress, a showgirl named Betty Compton, seems to have been one of those officials, like Adam Clayton Powell Jr. or Bill Clinton, who charms the electorate by their peccadilloes. A politician perfectly suited to the good times of the Jazz Age, Walker identified himself with the people, vacationing on the Riviera in their stead. His failing was that he could see no further than his own popularity, even when the Depression called for a different, more imaginative response.
Roosevelt, who had struck the pundit Walter Lippmann and others as a lightweight (they doubted that he would show the moral fiber to stand up to Tammany), surprised everyone. Using his prerogative as governor, he served as judge and jury in special hearings, where he interrogated Walker, with the aid of Judge Seabury's investigative findings, and essentially forced the mayor to resign.
In doing so, Mr. Mitgang writes, Roosevelt passed an important test of character that prepared him to win the presidency, an attempt to govern on this premise: "The hopes of the Republic cannot forever tolerate either undeserved poverty or self-serving wealth."
For all that is said in Walker's behalf, it is clear whom the author regards as the good guys: Roosevelt and Seabury. Stressing the ironies of class, he sees the blue bloods as defending the working poor and unemployed and the politicians who rose from the sidewalks of New York as their predators. Some revisionist historians have argued for Tammany Hall as protector of the poor and the immigrant, and the reformers as ruling-class pawns, but Mr. Mitgang is having none of it. He makes a convincing case, on the evidence, that Walker and his associates had their hands in the till and betrayed the voters' trust.
A child of the 30's, Mr. Mitgang is nostalgic not for the Jazz Age but for leaders like Roosevelt and La Guardia; he yearns for the return of their visionary idealism and innovative programs serving the less fortunate. In this sense his genial book is a jeremiad and a liberal's call to arms.

HEADLINE: IDEAS INTO ACTION;
Dell, It Turns Out, Has a Better Idea Than Ford

BYLINE: By FRED ANDREWS 

 BODY:
TIME was when Ford Motor's giant River Rouge plant in Dearborn, Mich., was the pinnacle of industrial achievement. Barges of iron ore docked at one end, new Fords rolled out the other.
But that was half a century ago, an eternity at Internet speed. Today's model is no longer Ford's assembly line but the quick assembly techniques made famous by Dell Computer. Dell's pioneering methods for making and selling personal computers have become required reading at business schools. Manufacturers in every industry have studied Dell's immense success. 
 Yes, that includes the auto industry, producer of the most complex mechanism that human intelligence has ever devised for mass consumption. Now operating in a faster-paced economy, the industry is urgently seeking ways to bring its products to market more quickly. The trade talk at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit earlier this month suggests that the auto giants are lumbering toward Dell's idea of manufacturing for today's world.
Dell made its name by selling directly to customers and allowing them to specify the features they wanted their personal computer to include. Dell quickly assembles customized machines to fill orders arriving by way of the Internet or by phone. Among manufacturers, the company is known for extreme reliance on suppliers for components.
Charles H. Fine, who teaches manufacturing at the Sloan School of Management at M.I.T., attributes the company's success to mastery of "supply chain management," that is, its complete flexibility about whether a particular function is performed by its own people or by outsiders.
The automakers seem to have absorbed that lesson. Last week, General Motors, the world's largest company and traditionally Detroit's most self-sufficient, declared that from now on it would seek growth through partnerships and alliances -- "clearly a different approach," John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman and chief executive, acknowledged in a speech at the Automotive News World Congress in Detroit.
Mr. Smith's speech was policy ratifying practice. General Motors has gradually evolved a web of alliances with Toyota, Isuzu, Suzuki and other foreign automakers. Last May, G.M. took the watershed step of spinning off its captive parts maker, Delphi Automotive Systems, a $30 billion business. The parting freed Delphi to seek new customers among rival manufacturers and signaled G.M.'s intent to open its supply base to more vendors. Ford is in the process of following suit with its parts maker, Visteon Automotive Systems.
That decision was right out of the computer industry's playbook. Selling direct, with no distributors or retailers, Dell is spared the expense of an inventory of finished goods. Its supplier system keeps investment in materials to a bare minimum. The Dell process depends on close tracking of customer demand and sharing that intelligence with its suppliers.
An order in hand before making a car amounts to an automaker's vision of heaven. Today, almost all vehicles are manufactured for dealers' stocks. That requires the automakers to anticipate demand and figure out an attractive product mix. That task has become exceedingly difficult as consumer tastes have splintered and as products proliferate. Car and Driver's current guide to new cars, vans, sport utilities and pickup trucks indexes 279 model lines, sold under 45 different brands. The choices in color and options make the potential combinations almost infinite. Wrong guesses result in "lot rot": hard-to-sell vehicles piling up expensively on dealers' lots.
If companies could make cars and add options to order, Professor Fine said, "not only could they charge full price, they could satisfy the customer -- people will pay more for what they really want."
The Internet offers buyers instant access to car data, putting pressure on car companies for immediate response. A customer can choose a vehicle and select options now, of course, but must then wait weeks or months for delivery. Nearly every carmaker has a high-priority plan for chopping down that delay.
At the Detroit auto show, Louis Schweitzer, chief executive at Renault S.A., said that by next year Renault would provide 15-day delivery of cars manufactured to customers' specifications. Fujio Cho, president of Toyota, said the time had come to apply the company's mastery of "just in time" manufacturing to distribution and marketing.
Roy Roberts, group vice president for North American sales at General Motors, said G.M.'s ambitious goal was to cut "order to delivery" from about 50 days to 10. Robert L. Rewey, a group vice president at Ford, said Ford was busily building an information system to dispatch a new order instantly back through the chain to parts suppliers, speeding the manufacturing process.
The Dell system's quick response time depends on "modularity," a basic building block in the computer industry. The term refers to "plug and play" components that click together, like a home-entertainment system. Modularity relies on industrywide agreement on performance standards and on ease of connection.
Professor Fine and others say that all the auto companies are working hard to exploit modularity, especially the companies that produce the cheaper cars. Primary suppliers like Delphi or Johnson Controls no longer provide mere parts. They offer complete "systems," from climate control or braking to entire interiors or fully equipped cockpits. By all accounts, the automakers are relegating more and more engineering of complex components to suppliers.
Not everyone thinks that modularity is the answer for Detroit. The United Auto Workers vigorously opposes it as mainly a pretext for removing work from its jurisdiction. Beyond that, fine cars like Mercedes or B.M.W. all tend to be highly integrated designs, Professor Fine said, with much less scope for "plug and play" systems. Nevertheless, most of the 17 million vehicles sold in the United States last year were not peak-performance cars, and the industry's swing toward modularity is unmistakable.
"Across the board, more systems, more subsystems and whole modules are being done by the supplier community," Harry Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman, said in an interview at the Detroit show. He predicted that a shakeout among suppliers would produce "half a dozen powerhouses." Those companies will then engage in "a natural tug of war" with automakers over controlling the critical engineering in a vehicle.

HEADLINE: Amyas Ames Is Dead at 93; A Champion of Lincoln Center

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
Amyas Ames, an investment banker who devoted half his life to the support of the arts, becoming board chairman of both the New York Philharmonic and Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, died on Monday at a retirement community in Lexington, Mass. He was 93.
During his long business career Mr. Ames was managing partner at Kidder, Peabody & Company and chairman of its executive committee. He also served as president of the Investment Bankers Association. 
 But as an amateur pianist and longtime lover of the arts, Mr. Ames realized early on that he did not want to follow the 'straight-business route,' as he explained in an article in The New York Times on the occasion of his appointment to the Lincoln Center post in 1970. "I wanted to phase out early," he said, and help "tie the performing arts into political developments, into the fight to improve the quality of life, the quality of the environment in our cities."
He was elected to the board of the New York Philharmonic in 1955, became its president in 1963 and served as chairman from 1970 until 1983. In 1970 he also accepted the appointment as chairman of Lincoln Center, following the retirement of John D. Rockefeller III, and held the position for 10 years.
At the time he accepted the Lincoln Center post, the organization was in its seventh year and facing financial crisis. Mr. Ames believed that the decrease in private and government funding for the arts was a reflection of more pressing societal concerns about urban, racial and educational problems. He was a self-described optimist about the ability of the arts to help these problems. "We're fighting the pollution of the inner city, and along with it we should be fighting the pollution of the inner mind," he said in the same interview.
During his tenure at Lincoln Center he headed two major endowment drives that raised over $28 million. He instigated the New York Philharmonic's free "Concerts in the Parks" series, which began in 1965 and still thrives, and oversaw the creation of the "Live From Lincoln Center" television broadcasts, the first of which in 1976 presented a New York Philharmonic concert with the pianist Van Cliburn.
Most notably, he spearheaded the renovation of the Philharmonic's concert hall at Lincoln Center, which had opened as Philharmonic Hall in 1962. To correct the hall's notoriously poor acoustics, some expensive adjustments were tried during the 1960's. But it was not until Mr. Ames solicited the support of Avery Fisher and the hall was totally renovated and reopened in 1976 as Avery Fisher Hall that critics pronounced themselves satisfied with the results.
Mr. Ames was born in Sharon, Mass., on June 15, 1906. His father was a biologist at Harvard University and his mother was an artist and musician. His grandfather, Oliver Ames, had been governor of Massachusetts. Mr. Ames's unusual first name, Amyas, was an old English spelling of the family name.
He attended Harvard, playing baseball and also performing on clarinet in the Harvard Band. After graduating in 1928, he entered Harvard Business School. The next year the stock market crashed. Undeterred, his master's degree in tow, Mr. Ames joined a Boston financial firm and three years later moved to New York to begin his career at Kidder, Peabody.
During World War II he served as administrative officer of the War Shipping Administration in Washington, a civilian government agency that coordinated the operation of the 4,000 allied ships that were transporting food and war materials.
For 60 years he was married to Evelyn I. Perkins, a published poet and author, who died in 1990. In 1995 Mr. Ames married Lucia Millham of Locust Valley, N.Y., who had worked in hospital administration, and who survives him.
Mr. Ames was an avid environmentalist and nature photographer. At his summer home in Martha's Vineyard he took photographs of flowers and wildlife, many of which were published with his accompanying essays in The Vineyard Journal. In 1980 a collection of his photographs and essays entitled "The Private Lives of Our Natural Neighbors" was published as a book by George Braziller of New York.
Besides his wife, Mr. Ames is survived by four children from his first marriage: two sons, Edward and and Oakes, both of New York City; two daughters, Olivia Hoblitzelle of Cambridge, Mass., and Joan Ames of Eugene, Ore., as well as 11 grandchildren and 6 great-grandchildren.
In his final years at the Brookhaven in Lexington retirement community, Mr. Ames designed and oversaw the creation of a nature trail through the wooded grounds there that was accessible to elderly people with limited mobility.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
From plumbing problems to medical evacuations, International SOS can be a big help on the road.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey; The Business Travel column appears each Wednesday. Joe Sharkey's e-mail is jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I was doing the old Dallas quick-step one day last week, huffing a half-mile between gates at the nation's most aerobically demanding airport to lunge for a connecting flight whose tail fin could be seen gliding away just as I reached the counter, where the ticket agent wore a look that said, ha-ha.
Normally, this would have generated a foul and self-pitying mood, except that I had been speaking just the day before with Arnaud Vaissie, the president of International SOS Ltd., a company based in Philadelphia that provides emergency services, medical and logistical, to corporate business travelers. And suddenly the prospect of an unanticipated layover of an extra couple of hours didn't seem so terrible, considering some of the things that can go really wrong on a business trip. 
 Take the hijacking last month of that Indian Airlines plane, whose passengers were held hostage in Afghanistan. Imagine being on that leg of a business trip. Three clients of Mr. Vaissie's company were.
International SOS dispatched a medical team to treat the clients when they were released. In a typical travel emergency, the company also takes care of details like retrieving luggage, rescheduling missed connections, and making sure that business meetings are canceled with appropriate explanations.
"The hijacking was such a megasituation that everything else disappeared except the medical need," said Mr. Vaissie, who himself spends about a third of his time traveling on business. "Missing a business meeting in Frankfurt was not a big factor here. It's rare that we're not involved when there is a major international incident -- bombings, terrorism, coups, civil disasters. But most of our business is less dramatic."
Several basic trends drive a company like International SOS, which began operations in 1974 and now has 2,500 employees and emergency offices that operate around the clock in more than 30 cities, from Houston to Hanoi. An illness, accident or other emergency is usually more complicated to deal with when someone is traveling or living temporarily abroad for business. And international business travel is increasing sharply. An American Express survey indicates a growth of about 30 percent this year, with a far wider range of destinations as economic interests connect around the world.
While it is more true in Europe than in the United States, "the need to actually be there is certainly the case in Asia, where you typically have just one big city for doing business in each country," Mr. Vaissie said. "People want to know you, look at your face and see if you are genuine before doing business."
His clients, mostly major multinational corporations, but also including airlines, hotels and cruise ships, pay a retainer based on their size to have access to emergency offices worldwide, where 500 doctors and nurses are on staff. There are extra charges for extraordinary services like evacuations.
People working abroad on emergencies necessarily develop good local networks. Arranging a sudden medical evacuation from China, for example, requires dealing successfully with potentially indignant local doctors, but also with political officials who can expedite exit clearances, and even with military types whose approval might be crucial for clearing air space for an emergency charter.
"When we deal with the medical interests of a traveler we also deal with the logistics of the situation," Mr. Vaissie said. "We have developed the capability of dealing with the nonmedical components which are key to making things happen. The medical outcome is completely linked to the quality of the logistics involved. Our people have their contacts. We can access things that basically are closed to everybody else."
Medical evacuations, coups and terrorist incidents aside, International SOS will even do such tasks as put up bail if a corporate vice president for sales gets jammed up with a little unpleasantness involving the gendarmes in, say, Tangier.
And you thought all the adventure had gone out of the world. Yet here we have an organization where a case of appendicitis is suddenly fraught with international intrigue and derring-do. John Le Carre may be old hat, but dangerous, exotic adventure lives on, as a component of the corporate bottom line.
It is at least something romantic to mull over the next time you're stranded in Atlanta blinking helplessly at the departures screen. A smart thriller writer with an eye on airport paperback sales could clean up in the suddenly exciting business-travel genre.
Though it had not occurred to him before, Mr. Vaissie suddenly grasped the movie possibilities. Think James Bond meets "The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit." "A modern sense of adventure," Mr. Vaissie said. "Business people are going all over, to the most impossible places on the earth, to more and more remote locations."
But as a corporate executive he had some thoughts on the narrative arc: "The point of the whole thing is making sure adventure is going to be mastered, if you will. To make adventure safe."
He noted that among the minor details a regional International SOS office can take care of are helping to get prescriptions refilled or even arranging for a plumber to come to your house if the pipes burst while you are out there tending to the business of the world.
This isn't exactly the stuff of thrillers, lamentably. "Our people have the right phone numbers and local contacts," Mr. Vaissie said. "They can find a plumber at night. It's very mundane." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Law on Campaign Money

 BODY:
The Supreme Court performed a valuable public service on Monday by demolishing one of the main arguments brandished by Congressional foes of campaign finance reform. In a decisive 6-to-3 ruling, the court reaffirmed the constitutionality of campaign contribution limits and exposed the emptiness of claims that the First Amendment presents an insurmountable bar to meaningful action by lawmakers to restrict the corrupting flow of money into campaigns.
The case involved a test of Missouri's $1,075 limit on an individual's donations to a statewide candidate. A lower appeals court had struck down the limit on free-speech grounds, in essence overruling the portion of the Supreme Court's 1976 decision in Buckley v. Valeo that upheld the $1,000 contribution limit for federal candidates as a permissible precaution against corruption. 
 In rejecting this invitation to reconsider its approval of the cap in light of 24 years of inflation, the court put due emphasis on the corruptive nature of large campaign gifts. It also turned aside arguments that such limits amount to suppression of speech, lacking any concrete proof that candidates are prevented from raising sufficient funds to get their voices heard. "Leave the perception of impropriety unanswered, and the cynical assumption that large donors call the tune could jeopardize the willingness of voters to take part in democratic government," wrote Justice David Souter in the majority opinion signed by five of his colleagues, including Chief Justice William Rehnquist.
Senator Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican who is the leading Congressional opponent of campaign finance reform, says the opinion is inconsequential to the ongoing battle over banning the unregulated contributions to political parties known as soft money. Yet one immediate effect of the decision is to render laughable Mr. McConnell's attempt to portray himself as a First Amendment champion for opposing a soft-money ban. The majority opinion did not address soft money directly. But its endorsement of contribution limits to protect the integrity of the political process strongly suggests that legislative steps to prevent candidates from evading those limits by raising and spending soft money would also pass muster.
Indeed, as the two concurring opinions by Justices John Paul Stevens and Stephen Breyer underscored, a number of justices are deeply concerned about the dominant role of big money in politics. They also seemed concerned about the court's own role in helping to accelerate the money chase by ruling, in another, highly lamentable part of the Buckley decision, that limits on campaign spending violate the First Amendment. In future rulings, the court needs to allow limits on both contributions and spending of personal funds by wealthy candidates.
In reaffirming contribution limits, the court decided that those limits do not harm anyone's rights to free speech. No one is prevented from speaking, just from buying undue influence.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence at a Record High

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence rose to a record level so far in January, suggesting that the economy's expansion will continue, the Conference Board said yesterday.
Abundant jobs, a rising stock market and an uneventful change to the year 2000 helped drive the consumer confidence index to 144.7, its highest level in 32 years. The Conference Board polls 5,000 households and now uses 1985 as the index's base line of 100. 
 "This is evidence that there's more fuel in this economic expansion," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist with the Argus Research Corporation. "Everyone is employed. When you have a job, you are confident. When you're confident, you spend."
The previous high for the index was 142.3 in October 1968. The economy is on the verge of a record expansion, led by consumer spending and increased worker productivity.
Also yesterday, in a report that was inadvertently released early, the National Association of Realtors said that home resales reached a high of 5.2 million last year, up 4.6 percent from 4.97 million in 1998. It was the first time more than 5 million homes were resold in a year and was the fourth consecutive yearly record.
Job security formed the backdrop for the confidence report, which surprised analysts expecting a bigger effect from higher interest rates and recent volatility in stocks. Economists had forecast a level of 142.1 this month.
The report suggests that the economic expansion, on track to set a record of 107 months in February, could continue at least into July. Productivity gains have enabled the economy to grow at more than 4 percent a year without accelerating inflation so far. Third-quarter productivity grew at a 4.9 percent annual rate, the biggest gain in almost seven years.
The reading added to speculation that Federal Reserve policy makers will raise short-term interest rates at their February meeting to try to curb inflation.

HEADLINE: White House Talks Set in Dispute on Base

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
The White House has agreed to a request by the governor of Puerto Rico to step in and accelerate negotiations with the Navy about resuming weapons training on its base on the island of Vieques.
After the governor rejected the Navy's latest proposal to hold a referendum on the issue, the White House agreed to the request last night and invited Puerto Rico's top negotiator to resume negotiations on Thursday in Washington. But White House officials voiced support for the Navy's proposal to leave a final decision on the base's future to the citizens of Vieques rather than to Gov. Pedro J. Rossello. 
 The Navy proposed last week that a referendum be held in 3 to 18 months offering the citizens of Vieques a choice of allowing the armed forces to resume training with live ammunition and receive $40 million in community aid in gratitude or closing the base within five years. There would be no testing on the island, where there is a moratorium on live-fire exercises through March 1, after the referendum, administration officials said.
"This proposal is worse than the last one," said Alfonso Aguilar, spokesman for the governor. "We've only got a few weeks left, and we know the Navy is pressuring the president for a decision before the moratorium ends in March."
The president suspended all military exercises on Vieques, a small island in the commonwealth of Puerto Rico, in April, when a civilian Puerto Rican guard was killed after Marine jets dropped bombs that unintentionally hit an observation tower. That death touched off protests that have led to the occupation of the base by more than 100 people.
In December the president halted live-fire military exercises there and ordered an end to all exercises in five years. Governor Rossello immediately rejected that as not a sufficient compromise, saying Puerto Rico wanted a ban on bombing exercises on Vieques that could be legally binding.
Last Friday the Navy made its counterproposal, a referendum, which has the backing of the president, a senior administration official said.
"We're suggesting the referendum is the way to go to give the Navy a chance to present its plan and see what the will of the people of Vieques really is," a senior White House official said. "The Puerto Ricans need to understand that the president as commander in chief must push forward the readiness of the armed forces while weighing the concerns of the people of Vieques."
Since World War II, the Navy and Marines have used the 900-acre range on Vieques for their only comprehensive live-fire exercises on the East Coast, involving amphibious landings, aerial bombardments and naval gunfire. While the Navy calls the range its "crown jewel" because these joint exercises are necessary to prepare the battle groups for deployment, the citizens of Vieques have called the base unacceptable.
Governor Rossello has said the bombardment of Vieques over more than 50 years has led to high unemployment, high rates of cancer and severe damage to the island's wildlife and its fragile coral reef.
The Navy has admitted that it mishandled relations with the people of Vieques and has asked for another chance. But the citizens of Puerto Rico have put Vieques on the political agenda in the presidential campaign and in New York State, which has a large Puerto Rican population.
Vice President Al Gore sides with Puerto Rico in the debate, as does Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is running for the Senate from New York.
Republicans in Congress have backed the Navy and have scheduled hearings in the House and Senate on legislation that would the Roosevelt Roads naval station in Puerto Rico, a $3 billion entity, if the commonwealth refuses to allow the resumption of live-fire training.
Puerto Rico officials derided that proposal as scare tactics and have asked that the Navy be excluded from the talks on Thursday.
"We don't want to talk to the Navy anymore," Mr. Aguilar said.
On Thursday, Angel Morey, Puerto Rico's secretary of state, will meet with John D. Podesta, the White House chief of staff, and a Defense Department representative.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Holy Family Is Miscast As Homeless

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THERE seems to be no hope of a serious debate about homelessness until we resolve the question troubling devout politicians and journalists: What would happen to the baby Jesus and his parents in today's New York City?
Hillary Rodham Clinton raised the issue last month by describing Jesus as "a homeless child" during a speech criticizing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's policies on the homeless. Then the Rev. Al Sharpton elaborated during a rally several days later. 
 "If Jason Turner had come into the barn that night," Mr. Sharpton said, referring to the commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, "he would have said to the baby Jesus: 'You have been born to two unwedded parents. They don't have an address. They don't have a job. We have to take you in custody and arrest your parents.' "
Next, Mike Barnicle, the Daily News columnist, imagined Joseph as an unemployed "illegal alien" taunted by cruel Manhattanites when he asked for help for his pregnant wife. In his column, Joseph and Mary managed to escape arrest, but Jimmy Breslin was not so optimistic in Newsday. His column on Sunday assailing city officials began: "Next, they'll arrest Christ and his family for being homeless."
Such piety is noteworthy in politicians and journalists, especially ones who don't like conservatives dragging the Bible into political debates. Maybe liberals will soon be sporting bracelets and bumper stickers labeled WWJD, for What Would Jesus Do?
But imbuing Jesus' family with modern social pathologies -- you might call it defining deviancy up -- is problematic. To call Mary an unwed mother is about as scripturally accurate as calling her a crack addict. She was already engaged when she became pregnant, and Joseph "took unto him his wife" (Matthew 1:25) before the birth.
Joseph, a carpenter who taught the trade to his son, is never described in the New Testament as unemployed. Nor are he and his family ever depicted as homeless. At worst, Joseph and Mary were travelers far from their home in Nazareth who were unable to find a room one night at the inn in Bethlehem. But they might not have encountered even that problem, because there is reason to think that Jesus was actually born at their home.
The Gospel of Mark, which was probably the first one written, does not mention the birth in Bethlehem and repeatedly identifies Jesus as the "Nazarene." Some scholars, believing the actual birthplace to be in Nazareth, suspect that later Gospels drew on legends placing it in Bethlehem, David's home town, because that corresponded with an Old Testament prophecy of the Messiah.
The Bethlehem stories are only in Matthew and Luke, and they're not consistent with each other. In Matthew's Gospel, Bethlehem is apparently the first home of Joseph and Mary, and Jesus is born in their "house" (Matthew 2:11). Only later does the family move to Nazareth.
IN Luke's Gospel, the source of the popular Nativity story, Mary and Joseph are already in Nazareth when she becomes pregnant, and they travel back to Joseph's ancestral town to register for a Roman census. But if their primary home had been in Nazareth, they wouldn't have been expected to go anywhere else for the census, as the British theologian John Bowker notes in "The Complete Bible Handbook."
"A journey from Nazareth to Bethlehem would make sense only if Joseph was in some significant sense already resident there," Dr. Bowker writes. "The Greek phrase translated in Luke as 'there was no room at the inn' (Luke 2:7) could also be interpreted as meaning there was not enough space for Mary and Joseph in their extended family's 'living room,' so Mary laid Jesus in a food trough for animals, which were sometimes kept near the entrances of first-century Christian Era cave dwellings found in Bethlehem."
If that's the case, maybe politicians and journalists can draw new lessons from Christ's birth. Conservatives might see it as a vindication of family values and the work ethic and the private sector: Joseph and Mary raised a healthy, wonderful child on their own. Liberals might point to the crowded, unsanitary conditions in the cave as evidence of the need for more public housing projects and prenatal care programs.
Or maybe both sides could agree that the problems of today's homeless did not afflict Joseph and Mary, and that New York's social programs are not relevant to life in ancient Judea. Maybe we could debate the best way to help the homeless without dragging Jesus' family into it. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: In Japan, What Price Coca-Cola?;
'Throwaway' Lawsuit Grows Into a Far-Reaching Case

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

DATELINE: WALNUT CREEK, Calif.

 BODY:
For years, Japanese consumers have had two Coca-Colas to choose from -- identical except for their packaging, but at strikingly different prices. There is the locally bottled brand, labeled simply Coca-Cola, and "American Coke," labeled Coca-Cola Classic -- bottled in America and shipped abroad.
The name "Coca-Cola Classic" is used only in the United States and Canada, denoting the return to the original formula in 1985 after the "New Coke" debacle. But it's all the same stuff. 
 Despite the thousands of miles American Coke has to travel, it is usually cheaper than Japanese-made Coke, which typically sells for 120 yen ($1.14) in a 12-ounce can from vending machines. American Coke costs as little as 70 yen (67 cents), or 40 percent less, said Kazumasa Nagasaki, president of a company that imports American Coke. That compares with about 80 cents in the United States. "I have never seen Japanese Coca-Cola for 70 yen," he added.
That price gap is at the heart of a complex civil case soon to be heard by a federal jury in San Francisco. For four years, Coca-Cola has been battling a pair of tiny California exporters. Coke brought the original lawsuit, but last year the companies, Omni Pacific and Dependable Vending, filed a countersuit accusing Coke of violating antitrust laws.
Simply put, these are the opposing positions: Coke says the sale of its products outside specified regions raises quality-control issues, infringes its trademark rights, and violates contracts with bottlers. The exporting companies say Coke is grasping at straws to drive them out of business.
The stakes are high. Coke makes more money per can in Japan than anywhere else. Only about 5 percent of its production is sold there, but it brings in at least 20 percent of profits -- about $1 billion before taxes, said Andrew J. Conway, an analyst for Morgan Stanley.
The growth of this market, Mr. Conway wrote in a report to investors, is "critically important to Coke's ability to grow corporate-wide operating income in the 12 percent to 14 percent range."
What began in 1996 as a throwaway lawsuit has blossomed into one that could have major implications for the way Coca-Cola does business with bottlers around the world. Within the 200,000 pages of documents in the case, the company is shown struggling to mollify its Asian bottlers, who complained to Coke in Atlanta about cheaper American drinks flooding their markets. But other documents show the biggest Coke bottler, Atlanta-based Coca-Cola Enterprises, or C.C.E., eagerly selling to companies like Dependable Vending.
"I'd get calls and they'd say, 'We haven't made our numbers this month. Can you take 30,000 cases?' " recalled Mark Oliver, Dependable's soft-spoken president. One manager told him he would not be eligible for a hefty bonus if he did not sell a particular amount by a certain deadline, and asked Mr. Oliver to help.
A spokeswoman for Coca-Cola Enterprises did not return phone calls yesterday.
Omni Pacific and Dependable, which together did about $20 million in business last year, a mere trickle next to Coke's $18.8 billion in annual sales, say they bought Coke products from bottlers and wholesalers in the United States who were well aware of their exporting plans and sold them to distributors like Mr. Nagasaki. With its lawsuit, Coca-Cola asserted that no one could sell Coca-Cola outside the territory where it was bottled. The countersuit contends that Coke provided some Japanese bottlers with discounted American-made Coca-Cola in an effort to undercut companies like Dependable and Omni Pacific.
Controlling which cans of Coke end up where in Asia is a problem back in Atlanta. "This is about our right to protect our trademark, our bottlers' contractual rights and the system that benefits customers and consumers in local communities around the world," said Ben Deutsch, a Coke spokesman. Among the hundreds of hours of depositions on videotape is one from Douglas N. Daft, Coke's president, who oversaw the company's business in Japan for 11 years and is expected to become chairman and chief executive in April.
The central issue is whether companies like Omni Pacific and Dependable have the right to buy cans of Coke from any source and resell them abroad. Mr. Deutsch said bottler contracts contain "territorial sales provisions" meant to prevent that. The chief lawyer for the companies, which make money on the price differences between American-made Coke and overseas versions, says Coca-Cola is unfairly trying to control prices worldwide. The methods involved -- threats of legal action, agreements with bottlers not to do business with suspected transshippers and "blacklists" that order distributors not to sell Coke to particular companies -- violate foreign fair-trade laws and American antitrust statutes, said the lawyer, William A. Wineberg.
In the United States, Coca-Cola and other soft drink companies grant exclusive franchise rights to bottlers in given locations. That exclusivity was reinforced by a 1980 law, the Interbrand Competition Act, which holds that as long as competition exists, exclusive territories are acceptable. Coke and Pepsi fine bottlers whose products are found outside their territories. But no such law exists abroad.
In Japan, where about 50 percent of Coke products are sold through vending machines, Coke's sales of carbonated soft drinks have been flat or falling lately. Coca-Cola makes $1.26 in profit a case in Japan, Mr. Conway estimated, compared with 28 cents at home and 94 cents in Germany. Bottlers' profits have declined in recent years, while Coke's have risen.
Mr. Deutsch said the bottlers set the wholesale and vending prices, but prices in stores and supermarkets are set there.
The lawsuit, scheduled for a jury trial in May, began as a relatively simple case brought by Coke lawyers against one of Omni Pacific's suppliers, a small family-run company in Canada, in 1996. Brett Roberts, the lanky and colorful president of Omni Pacific, said that after he provided a statement to Coke's lawyers, he was added as a defendant.
For Mr. Roberts, who founded Omni Pacific and runs it from a low-profile office building at the edge of a highway in Walnut Creek, the experience of going up against Coke has been traumatic. "I used to sit here at my desk and throw up into the trash can," he said. "I got real paranoid."
Customers fled, some after receiving subpoenas from Coke's lawyers. He himself was shocked by the initial lawsuit, he said, since he had been exporting Coke for years unhindered. He began by looking up law firms in the Yellow Pages. To cope with his increasingly ragged emotional state, he said, he bought a gun, took up meditation and started a Web site with details of the case. In his wallet, he keeps a copy of a letter he received from a Coke lawyer in 1997; he rereads it now and then for inspiration. "Litigation," the lawyer, Frederick L. Whitmer, wrote, "is not for the squeamish."
Looking for legal help, Mr. Roberts bounced around, racking up six-figure bills from firms like O'Melveny & Myers, before Mr. Wineberg took the case. Mr. Wineberg, a longtime antitrust lawyer whose trophies include a $320 million settlement with oil companies in a price-fixing case on behalf of Long Beach, Calif., brought the countersuit on a contingency basis and has asked for more than $10 million in damages.
Mr. Roberts and Mr. Wineberg form an unlikely pair, although they share a fondness for frequent cigarette breaks. Mr. Roberts is a fast-talking, at times emotional 40-year-old who left rural Iowa at 18 and, once he saw the ocean, decided never to leave California. Mr. Wineberg, a father of five, personifies the eminence grise, strolling pensively in a trenchcoat near his office in downtown San Francisco. Mr. Oliver falls somewhere between the two, closer to Mr. Roberts in age but understated like Mr. Wineberg.
Their joint odyssey has highlighted many internal business decisions made by Coca-Cola. It has also raised the question of whether the interests of shareholders in Coca-Cola Enterprises, in which Coca-Cola holds a 39 percent stake, as well as other publicly traded bottlers are being served by Coca-Cola's actions. Has Coke's worldwide empire grown too large to be managed efficiently and without conflict?
"We could live with C.C.E. making an independent decision not to sell to us, although we think it's in the economic interests of their shareholders to sell to us," Mr. Wineberg said. "We are saying that it was pressure from the foreign bottlers that made Coke start this vendetta."
Mr. Deutsch would not comment, citing the litigation.
Omni Pacific and Dependable have obtained a court order barring Coke from using names or documents in the case to block supplies to them. But it is happening anyway, Mr. Oliver said. "I was told by one of my sources that Coke lawyers called and told them to continue to sell to me," he said. "Then the lawyers called back after I placed my order, and said, Don't deliver to him."
Whether there has been a breach of antitrust law is unclear. "The real question is whether the law supports this case," said Maxwell Blecher, an antitrust expert in Los Angeles.
Mr. Wineberg said the damage to his clients' business was cause enough to show the antitrust laws had been broken. "There's no question that consumers in Japan have been injured, but that's not what this case is about," he said.
Mr. Roberts said Coke's dominance in Asia emboldened it to set high prices, creating a market for companies like his. "Other people can come in with other Coke products that they have shipped halfway around the world, and still undercut them," he said.
Keeping those prices in place in Japan is a big chore for Coke, Mr. Wineberg said. "Our claim is that Coke has set up an agreement among all of its bottlers that they won't compete with each other in the sale of Coca-Cola products, and that is inhibiting Coca-Cola Enterprises from competing with bottlers in places like Hong Kong and Japan," he said, calling the arrangement a "hub and spoke" conspiracy.
Mr. Roberts and Mr. Oliver say Coke was aware of their activities for years. Mr. Oliver placed orders for Coke by the containerload from bottling plants in Seattle, Denver and Jacksonville, Fla., and says it became a problem only when a foreign bottler complained.
His liaison in Jacksonville, he said, was a Coca-Cola executive, to whom he sent "supporting documents explaining who I was and what I do," Mr. Roberts said. He bought up to 100,000 cases of soft drinks a week until 1993, when he was cut off.
He contends that Coca-Cola encouraged the practice because it helped build sales overseas. "This is their way of profiting in those marketplaces," he said. "The Jacksonville plant manager told me that the only reason he was able to fill these orders was that they were coming from Coke."
Mr. Oliver continues to export Coke, but "not nearly as much as we want to," he said. Among his customers is Mr. Nagasaki, president of an Osaka company called Panavac, which imported about 400,000 cases of Coca-Cola Classic last year.
"I supply shops, vending machines and discount stores," Mr. Nagasaki said in a telephone interview, adding that no one from Coca-Cola in Japan had ever objected. He is hardly the only company importing American Coke, he added. Although consumers seem to be switching to less sugary beverages, "there is still good demand," he said.
The lawsuit, meanwhile, wends its way toward trial."It never goes away," said Mr. Roberts, who has stopped selling Coke abroad. "I go to bed thinking about it, and I wake up thinking about it."

Two kinds of Coca-Cola are sold in Japan. One is made entirely in the United States then shipped to Japan, the other is made in Japan from concentrate. Despite the cost of shipping to Japan, American-made Coca-Cola Classic is cheaper for Japanese consumers.

MADE IN JAPAN

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Up As Shares Recover From 5-Day Losing Streak

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rebounded yesterday from Monday's slump as investors bought companies with surprisingly strong earnings, like Walt Disney, and some of the fourth-quarter rally's leaders.
Major indexes swung between gains and losses most of the day while investors weighed enthusiasm for faster profit growth against concern about how much the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates next week. The Nasdaq composite index had the bumpiest ride, falling as much as 1.7 percent before closing at its high for the day, up 1.7 percent. 
 "Today's market has been a microcosm of the year," said Francis Gannon, a portfolio manager with the SunAmerica Asset Management Corporation, which oversees $23.5 billion. "Earnings reports continue to be solid, but people are still focused on Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan and what he might say."
The Nasdaq composite index rose 71.33 points, to 4,167.41. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 8.50 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,410.03, as Disney gained 12.6 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 21.72 points, or 0.2 percent, to 11,029.89. American Express led the rebound, which ended the average's five-day losing streak. Still, almost three stocks rose for every two that fell on the New York Stock Exchange.
Disney, with a stock that had shown only one-third of the 153 percent gain made by the S.& P. over the last four years, jumped 5, to 37 1/2, after the company reported a surprise increase in its fiscal first-quarter profit and said it promoted Robert Iger to president.
Analysts at Goldman, Sachs; Merrill Lynch; and Salomon Smith Barney, among others, raised their recommendations on Disney.
American Express soared 6 3/8, to 158 3/8, after the issuer of credit cards said profit in the latest quarter rose 14 percent on higher charge card revenue. The company also said it would split its stock 3-for-1, the first share split since May 1987.
Qualcomm, the biggest gainer in the S.& P. 500 in 1999, rose 8 15/16, to 149, rebounding from a 9.6 percent drop Monday. But in after-hours trading shares of Qualcomm fell as los as 133.
Some 1.1 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board, up from the three-month daily average of 938 million. The Nasdaq stock market had its fifth-busiest day, with 1.7 billion shares trading.
Tellabs Inc., the most-active U.S. stock, plunged 9 9/16, to 59 1/2, after the telecommunications equipment maker warned earnings were likely to be less than analysts forecast.
Procter & Gamble fell 5 3/8, to 97 1/2. Per-share earnings in the third quarter will rise about 7 percent to 9 percent, less than forecasts of about 12 percent, the company told analysts during a conference call. The company said it still expects to meet estimates for the year because of increased profit in its fourth quarter.
Texas Instruments Inc., which provides computer chips for two-thirds of the world's cellular phones, rose 3 9/16, to 113 5/8, after the company reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit and said first-quarter sales would rise.

Treasury Prices Up
 
By The Associated Press
Long-term Treasury bond prices rose slightly yesterday after President Clinton said he would propose paying off the government's debt earlier than projected.
The price of the 30-year note climbed 6/32, to 93 16/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.63 percent from 6.65 percent.
Trading was light in other issues, which closed with little change.
Investors are awaiting Congressional testimony by Mr. Greenspan. His appearance before the Senate Budget Committee was canceled yesterday because of a winter storm, but he has another date before legislators today.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE FRONT-RUNNERS;
Bush and Gore Faced With New Set of Challenges

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 25

 BODY:
Despite their justifiable jubilation after first-place finishes in Iowa, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush confront unexpectedly complicated terrain here in New Hampshire.
This state may ultimately provide more of a test of their appeal and their political adaptability than the low turn-out caucuses that began this year's presidential contests. 
 Mr. Bush arrived in New Hampshire facing not one opponent, as he had expected with Senator John McCain, but two, with Steve Forbes emboldened by his strong second-place finish in Iowa.
Although this could end up playing to Mr. Bush's advantage by dividing his opposition, it places him in the immediate position of having to confront an attack from two sides of the political spectrum.
For Mr. Gore, the dynamic is simpler, but not without hazards. While his campaign hopes he can build steam from his easy win in Iowa, he lacks the built-in benefits he enjoyed there, in particular, a foundation of support from organized labor.
In addition, polls show that Bill Bradley is far more competitive with Mr. Gore here and that many more voters are inclined to embrace his message as a fresh, reform-minded alternative.
Obviously trying to dampen expectations, the vice president acknowledged as much when he arrived here early this morning and instantly took to the streets.
"New Hampshire doesn't take its lead from anywhere else," he declared. "You make your own decisions, and I'm asking for your vote."
Mr. Bradley made a similar point, though obviously from a different perspective. "New Hampshire is a bastion of independent thinking," he said. "Nobody tells them what to do. They make up their own minds."
Yet for all their challenges, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush are, of course, in the most enviable positions, because success in this state is crucial for Mr. Bradley and Mr. McCain.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush both have the resources and the institutional support in their parties to survive a defeat here. That would be more difficult for Mr. McCain, who skipped Iowa altogether so he could concentrate on New Hampshire, or Mr. Bradley, who has always counted New Hampshire as a state he should win. They have had their best showings in polls in this state.
By finishing a distant second after Mr. Gore in Iowa, where he stumped vigorously, Mr. Bradley faces even more pressure in this state, as even Mr. Bradley's own supporters acknowledged this week. "Bill needs to have a credible showing in Iowa and to win in New Hampshire," Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota said.
Steve Murphy, a Democratic strategist in Washington, said Mr. Gore's victory in Iowa so changed perceptions that a win here by Mr. Bradley would boost his prospects far more than had he performed better in the caucuses.
"Gore is now set up to take a fall if he doesn't win in New Hampshire," Mr. Murphy said. "Since the consensus is that Gore will win, if Bradley can pull off a win his campaign will be quickly revived."
Even in their victory speeches in Iowa on Monday night, Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore, mindful that they face an entirely different electorate in New Hampshire, were sounding new themes.
Mr. Gore, instead of talking about farmers and flood relief, focused on the economy and asked voters if they were better off now than four years ago, a tribute to the economic concerns that have long framed politics in this state. It is a message designed to capitalize on the accomplishments of the Clinton administration on the eve of the president's State of the Union message, which has ended up being propitiously timed for Mr. Clinton's protege.
As he celebrated his victory in Iowa, Mr. Bush declared, "The message worked here, and the message is going to work in New Hampshire as well."
But in the next breath, the Texas governor shed the more direct appeals to conservatives he had made in recent days and, reaching out to the more secular, libertarian and independent voters in New Hampshire, presented himself as the most electable and mainstream candidate. Mr. Bush's task is arguably more complicated because he has the challenge of running against two opponents, both of them potent.
Mr. McCain has been assiduously preparing for this week in New Hampshire, presenting himself as both the political reformer, an appeal that could draw independent voters, and the more responsible steward of the nation's foreign policy. Meanwhile, Mr. Forbes, with his vast personal wealth and history here of running sharp-edged advertisements, has been attacking Mr. Bush as not sufficiently conservative.
It is not unlike the challenge faced here by Bob Dole in 1996 when he was buffeted on one side by Patrick J. Buchanan, who ended up winning the New Hampshire primary, and the other by Lamar Alexander, the former governor of Tennessee who came close to finishing ahead of Mr. Dole.
Mr. Bush's advisers said they considered Mr. McCain more of a threat, both because he is seen as a more credible candidate and because some voters continue to bear ill-will toward Mr. Forbes for the attacks he launched on Mr. Dole in 1996. Accordingly, Mr. Bush intends to be particularly aggressive in trying to discredit Mr. McCain.
The front-runners are not the only ones facing some difficult political calculations. Mr. Bradley is under increasing pressure to show some assertiveness and to stand up to Mr. Gore, who has criticized him with obvious effect. But Mr. Bradley has thus far resisted, for instance, today, speaking for nearly 40 minutes without once mentioning the name of his opponent. Even some supporters said they were concerned that in his concession speech on Monday, Mr. Bradley seemed defeated and unprepared for the kind of political scrapping that he may need to do to win here this week.
That may be good news for Mr. McCain. While he may not have gained or lost anything from the Republican outcome in Iowa, he may have been helped by Mr. Bradley's defeat, because some independents who were inclined to vote for Mr. Bradley may now support Mr. McCain.
As a result, Mr. Bush, despite his victory on Monday, finds himself in the unlikely position of not being viewed as the front-runner -- at least in this state.
"Governor Bush comes into New Hampshire as an underdog," said Q. Whitfield Ayres, a Republican pollster.

HEADLINE: Anti-Sweatshop Movement Is Achieving Gains Overseas

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Apparel and footwear factories overseas have slowly improved working conditions in response to a highly vocal anti-sweatshop movement, labor rights advocates say.
Pressure from college students and other opponents of sweatshops has led some factories that make goods for industry giants like Nike and the Gap to cut back on child labor, to use less dangerous chemicals and to require fewer employees to work 80-hour weeks, according to groups that monitor such factories. 
 These changes, labor advocates say, could signal the beginning of a broad improvement in conditions for low-paid apparel workers in Asian and Latin American factories after four decades in which the trend has been for American companies to transfer production overseas in search of ever-cheaper labor.
The advocates stress that the improvements have been spotty, and that serious problems remain at factories from Honduras to Hong Kong. Wages are often too low to feed a family, factory air is often filled with chemicals and many managers refuse to let sick employees leave work to get medical attention.
"There has been some improvement on the ground, but nowhere near significant enough," said Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee, a leading anti-sweatshop group.
At many factories, labor rights advocates say, managers have stopped hitting workers, have improved ventilation and have stopped requiring workers to obtain permission before going to the toilet.
Sweatshop opponents praise some companies, like Liz Claiborne, for improving conditions, while accusing others, like Wal-Mart, of being slow to ensure changes at the overseas factories that produce their apparel.
"Some steps have been taken, but I don't think one can say that conditions have improved in any wholesale way," said Pharis Harvey, executive director of the International Labor Rights Fund, a watchdog group in Washington."A number of companies that produce globally are watching much more carefully to deal with problems before they become embarrassing public problems."
The anti-sweatshop movement has put many apparel makers, like the Gap and Kathie Lee Gifford, on the defensive by picketing in front of stores, holding sit-ins at colleges and bombarding companies with letters.
The movement, one of the nation's largest to push for changes since the 1960's, includes church and consumer groups, labor unions, human rights organizations and college, high school and even middle-school students. The movement's leaders often note that sweatshops are not just found overseas; many remain in New York, Los Angeles and other American cities.
At last month's protests in Seattle, conditions in such factories were a major focus, with many demonstrators demanding that trade treaties punish countries that permit violations of minimum labor standards.
Apparel industry executives say that with shoppers hunting for bargains, they face intense pressure to produce goods as cheaply as possible, encouraging many to turn to substandard factories.
Many corporate executives acknowledge that the anti-sweatshop movement's efforts are paying off.
Phil Knight, chairman of Nike, the world's largest footwear maker, said the movement had gotten his company to accelerate efforts to improve conditions. "It probably speeded up some things that we might have done anyway," said Mr. Knight, whose company uses 565 footwear and apparel factories employing 500,000 workers in 46 countries. "Basically, the workers in footwear factories, not just our factories, are better off today than two years ago."
In one significant move, Nike and its rival Reebok are requiring the many Asian factories that produce for them to stop using petroleum-based adhesives that cause damage to the liver, kidney and central nervous system in favor of safer water-based adhesives.
Labor rights experts point to many improvements. Five years ago, monitoring groups say, apparel factories in Honduras often employed children under 14, but now it is rare to find workers under 16. In Indonesia, managers no longer systematically squash unionization efforts.
Liz Claiborne, the Gap and Reebok have all hired respected human rights groups to monitor a handful of their factories.
"The anti-sweatshop movement has improved working conditions," said Apo Leong, executive director of the Asia Monitor Research Center, a labor rights group based in Hong Kong. "We're seeing the multinationals putting pressure on their contractors, and subsequently conditions have improved."
Mr. Leong noted that factories in China were using less child labor and prison labor. But he said grave problems remained throughout Asia. He said that China often imprisoned union organizers, that many Nike and Reebok plants still lacked adequate ventilation and that many factories in Cambodia had deplorable health and safety conditions.
Sweatshop opponents point to other problems. Jeffrey Ballinger, executive director of Press for Change, a labor rights group, said wages paid by Nike's Indonesian factories had fallen in recent years, after accounting for inflation, an assertion the company denies. " Wages are behind where they were," Mr. Ballinger said. "They're below what is considered necessary to meet the minimum needs of a single adult."
Mr. Kernaghan of the National Labor Committee said, "There are two places where progress seems to grind to a halt: the effort to form unions and the effort to have wage increases."
One recent development is the formation of the Fair Labor Association, a White House-backed group of human rights organizations and companies, including L. L. Bean, Nike and Reebok. This group is setting up a monitoring system to inspect overseas factories to get them to meet minimum labor standards, like not requiring employees to work more than 60 hours a week.
Many campus groups call the association pro-corporate, and criticize it for not requiring factories to pay a living wage. But the association's members defend it as the first serious corporate-backed effort to inspect apparel factories and to put teeth behind basic labor standards.
