SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 755 words

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
Timid at the Top: A Question of Leadership

BYLINE: By William H. Honan 

 BODY:
ABOUT a year ago, I cornered a group of eminent college and university presidents. A major study of the impact of race-sensitive admission policies at selective colleges and universities had just been published. It asserted that affirmative action at those institutions had played an important role in bolstering the black middle class.
All of the assembled thought that was good news. 
 And so I asked, "Now that you have evidence that this policy has worked, don't you have a responsibility to defend it?"
All were silent. Sheepish glances were exchanged. Heads hung low. No one was willing to take a stand.
That timidity by some of the brightest and most articulate men and women in the nation exemplifies my conclusion that American colleges have superb faculties, wonderful students, beautiful and well-wired campuses but weak-kneed, pussy-footing presidents.
The losers, of course, are all of us who are deprived of the stimulation and thoughtful leadership of the people Thorsten Veblen, the 19th-century economist, once called the "captains of erudition."
When is the last time a college or university chief made headlines by speaking out on campaign finance reform, genetic alteration, the rash of vocationalism (giving rise to "McUniversities"), national health insurance, tolerance for homosexuals, the fight over an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, the White House sex scandal?
Academic executives sometimes argue that they must mind their tongues for fear of antagonizing potential contributors, but that is the sort of rationalization to be expected from profit seekers, not from broad social thinkers and intellectual leaders who stand at the helms of great institutions.
It was not always this way.
A generation or two ago, James B. Conant, the president of Harvard from 1933 to 1953, served as an adviser to the Atomic Energy Commission while president and never hesitated to lecture the country on the importance of civilian control of atomic energy, educational reform and other matters.
John Silber, who became president of Boston University in 1971, advised President Ronald Reagan on foreign policy and, in 1990, took a year off to run for governor of Massachusetts while excoriating not only the icons of the new left but also such fellow university presidents as Clark Kerr at the University of California and Grayson Kirk at Columbia, whom he considered soft on student radicals.
Robert Maynard Hutchins, the president and then chancellor of the University of Chicago from 1929 to 1951, was a fearless fountain of ideas, many of them deliberately provocative. While dean of the Yale Law School, Hutchins denounced the Massachusetts court that condemned Sacco and Vanzetti to death. Chief Justice William Howard Taft sputtered that Hutchins must be in league with "every Bolshevik communist movement in the country," but that did not faze the Chicago trustees who shortly thereafter named Hutchins president, thus unloosing a flood of his frequently unpalatable ideas and opinions.
It was not just the big fellows who refused to hush up. Stringfellow Barr, who became president of St. John's College in Annapolis, Md., in 1937 and introduced a radically new curriculum composed entirely of 100 "great books," fiercely fought off those who objected to studying Marx and Freud alongside St. Augustine and St Thomas.
In 1945, Barr urged the creation of a world government after World War II.
Hamilton Holt, who had been editor of The Independent, a liberal weekly, before 1925, when he became president of Rollins College in Winter Park, Fla., spoke out on virtually everything that crossed his mind.
His most daring pronouncement -- the legend on a 1938 war memorial guaranteed to provoke just about everyone -- was inscribed on a bronze plaque under a heavy-caliber naval artillery shell mounted prominently on a pedestal on campus.
It read:
This engine of destruction, torture and death symbolizes
The prostitution of the inventor
The avarice of the manufacturer
The blood-guilt of the statesman
The savagery of the soldier
The perverted patriotism of the citizen
The debasement of the human race
If any would-be contributor did not like it, Dr. Holt said, he or she could go jump in the lake (Winter Park has seven from which to choose).
One need not agree with all that these feisty chief executives said in order to recognize and value their contributions to the intellectual vitality of the country.
At the very least, they made life more interesting.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Justice Department Issues A Rebuttal to Microsoft
The Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft jointly issued a stinging and disdainful rebuttal to the company's legal arguments last week that it had not violated the nation's antitrust laws. 
 In a 30-page document filed with Federal District Court in Washington, the Justice Department and the states characterized Microsoft's arguments as a strained effort at knocking down legal "straw men." Concluding arguments in the antitrust case have been scheduled for Feb. 22. Page C8.
 
A federal judge has ruled that Microsoft must conform to standards set by Sun Microsystems when it sells products that use Sun's Java programming language. C2.
 
Thomson to Acquire a Unit of Sylvan
Thomson, the owner of the Globe and Mail newspaper in Canada, is expected to announce the $775 million acquisition today of Sylvan Prometric, a computer-based testing company that certifies professionals and graduate school applicants. C4.
 
Procter Meets Earnings Estimates
Procter & Gamble, a day after deciding against a bid for Warner-Lambert and American Home Products, reported second-quarter earnings that were little changed from a year earlier but still met analysts' expectations. Shares of Procter & Gamble, which is based in Cincinnati, fell $5.375, to $97.50. C6.
 
Merrill Lynch & Company said its earnings more than doubled last quarter as its customers poured money into the firm and its corporate clients continued to sell stocks and bonds and buy other companies. C6.
 
American Home Products and Johnson & Johnson reported fourth-quarter profits that matched Wall Street forecasts. C14.
 
Consumer Confidence Sets Record
Consumer confidence has risen to a record level so far in January. Abundant jobs, a rising stock market and an uneventful change to the year 2000 helped drive up the consumer confidence index to 144.7 in January, its highest level in 32 years. C16.
 
Group Weighs Bid for Calvin Klein
Maurizio Romiti, chief executive of Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali, one of Italy's major fashion holding companies, said the company was considering an acquisition of Calvin Klein Industries. In October, Calvin Klein, left, and his partner Barry Schwartz hired Lazard Freres to explore strategic moves, including an alliance or possible sale. C4.
 
Qualcomm Expects Shipments to Dip
Qualcomm, the wireless technology company, warned that shipments of cellular telephones and chips might dip in the second quarter, sending its shares plunging $16 in after-hours trading. The warning came as Qualcomm reported earnings that beat the expectations of analysts by a penny a share. C14.
 
Chase Settles Privacy Case
Chase Manhattan Bank and a Denver-based Internet company will no longer routinely share personal or financial information about their customers with other companies under a settlement announced by the state attorney general in New York. The companies, according to the attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, had violated their stated privacy policies by providing information to telemarketing companies and advertisers without the full knowledge and consent of customers. B1.
 
Merging Led Zeppelin and Sinatra
When the newly created AOL-Time Warner further consolidated its pop power by announcing plans this week to merge with EMI Group, it was a message about content. EMI's catalog includes the Beatles, the Beach Boys, the Rolling Stones, Frank Sinatra and Garth Brooks. If made available for direct digital download online alongside Warner Music's superstars (from Madonna to Led Zeppelin to the Eagles), this could hasten public acceptance of the music computer file as an alternative to the CD. E1.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Beware Guys Named Junior

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Al Gore wants to be the person who says how things go. But if you wanna be boss, you gotta be willing to whack some people. You gotta get Bill Bradley to donate his kneecaps. You gotta put your (expletive) rivals in a Luca Brasi situation. Bradley may have run Jersey once, but he was never a made guy in the administration. He never reached the heights.
So Al Gore is hardening his position. Bradley can show some (expletive) respect and drop out . . . or it's gonna be a rainy night in Lyndhurst. 
 Who knew, with all the candidates promising to run positive and upbeat campaigns, that Al Gore would turn into Tony Soprano -- a thoughtful and increasingly self-aware family man who always does what he has to do?
Who knew that those polite and upright Iowans would reject the polite and upright Bill Bradley?
This week the Iowa caucuses and the Golden Globes made it official: Thuggery is chic.
The homely caucuses and the glittery Hollywood awards have more in common than you might think. As my friend Eric Mink, the TV critic of The New York Daily News, puts it: "They're both phony events concocted almost entirely for media exposure. They're decided by a tiny number of wholly unrepresentative people with dubious to nonexistent credentials. The politicians and celebrities kiss up to the voters. The results are objectively worthless, but they are granted self-fulfilling significance by the media as supposed bellwethers of the more legitimate contests that follow."
Winners Al and Tony both have rivals nicknamed Junior. They both have the Teamsters on their side, and savor new technology -- Tony's soldiers hijacked a truckload of DVD players. They both have health care plans. Tony's involves setting up fake clinics and billing the insurance companies for phony M.R.I.'s.
They both care about values. "Nowadays there are no values," Tony frets to his shrink, about how mob captains will no longer go to prison rather than break the code of silence. "Guys today have no room for the penal experience."
And they appreciate therapy, even though they are in businesses that traditionally scorned sharing inner feelings. ("What they didn't know," Tony says, "is once they got Gary Cooper in touch with his feelings they wouldn't be able to shut him up.")
The veneer of suburban domesticity in Tony Soprano's life -- watching his daughter's volleyball games, barbecuing sausages for his pals -- is interrupted by random, self-interested acts of violence.
In Iowa, Mr. Gore added verbal roughhouse to his touchy-feely campaign, pounding Mr. Bradley as an insensitive man who would "tear down" Medicaid and who betrayed farmers by voting against a 1993 flood-relief amendment.
"The single most dramatic change has been Al Gore's transformation from wooden soldier to junkyard dog," Time marveled. The magazine observed that the Gore aide Carter Eskew, whose ad campaign derailed the administration's attempts for a tobacco deal, "has fostered Gore's instinct to go for the jugular." (Or, as the Soprano capos cajole a man with a broken leg, "Do you want to go for a walk on the rocks?")
Newsweek recounts how Mr. Gore surrounded himself with Washington's version of "cold-blooded" made men: "He knew what he wanted: a posse of the 'Unforgiven,' who care more about winning than being liked."
Playing rough, Al Gore brings to mind Tony Soprano. But the Bushes have been dubbed "the WASP Corleones." Those who do not abide by the Bush code -- either you're with us or you're not -- may find themselves summering with the fishes.
This race, despite its posturing about civility, is really about revenge. Bill Clinton wants to avenge himself on the Republicans. And W. wants to avenge his father's loss in 1992. Vendetta 2000.
Iowa had only just crowned Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore when the vice president clipped his Republican rival as a threat to the economy and abortion rights.
So now we go to the mattresses: a war of restitution by the sons of two established families, each surrounded by ruthless capos.
Maybe the ratings will increase.

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
Being Bob Forehead

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
In the opening scene of "Washingtoon," Mark Alan Stamaty's classic Reagan-era political comic strip, an insomniac plutocrat is impressed by a late-night infomercial host. "Anyone who can sell glow-in-the-dark coat hangers to me could probably sell supply-side economics to America," he declares. And thus, with guidance from the nation's leading charismatician, begins the career of Congressman Bob Forehead.
The strong performance by Steve Forbes in the Iowa caucuses shows that a good charismatician, with a hefty budget, can do well even with unpromising raw material. But why does the wealthy publisher feel the need to be his own Bob Forehead? Is he just a capitalist fool? 
 Many commentators have speculated about the candidate's personal motivations. And of course, rich men in general are made more likely to run for office by campaign finance laws that allow an individual of means to lavish hard money on his own campaign but not on someone else's. But the reason this restriction matters so much is that Mr. Forbes is all alone, forced to finance a supply-side campaign single-handed -- because the rest of his party isn't interested. After all, who needs another crusade when you've already won?
Consider, if you will, how America at the end of the Rubin-Summers administration compares with America at the end of the previous Democratic presidency. In 1980 the wealthiest taxpayers faced a marginal tax rate of 70 percent -- that is, they got to keep only 30 cents of each extra dollar they earned. Now they get to keep more than 60 cents. In 1980 conservative social critics warned that excessively generous welfare was sustaining a culture of poverty; in the 90's Bill Clinton ended welfare as we knew it. In the late 70's powerful unions extracted huge wage increases in industries like autos and steel; today only one private-sector worker in ten is unionized, and the unions that remain are shadows of their former selves.
And even more important than these changes in policy is the changing shape of the economy itself. In 1980 conservative critics used to complain that enterprise was not being rewarded, that stock prices had declined in real terms, that America was becoming a society in which it just wasn't worth trying to get rich. Twenty years later, after a decade that makes the 1920's seem merely meowing by comparison, it is hard to see what more the rich could ask for.
So why can't people like Steve Forbes simply declare victory and go home? The well-off would, of course, like to see even lower taxes -- which George W. Bush, his life made easy by the revenues a booming economy generates, promises to deliver. (Is he sincere, or is he just doing this because that is what Republicans are supposed to do? Who knows?) But there is one important thing that the supply-side movement has not gotten, and still desperately wants: intellectual vindication.
Put it this way: Mr. Bush's economic advisers, at least the ones whose names have appeared in the press, are -- it pains me to say this -- reasonable men. Translated, that means they have a view about the way the world works that differs in some important details but not in broad outlines from the view held by a mainstream economist like me -- or, for that matter, Larry Summers. And that reasonableness is what drives Mr. Forbes up the wall.
For Mr. Forbes is, intellectually at least, the true heir of the Reagan revolution -- a revolution that was supposed to sweep the ideas of all those establishment types from Wall Street and Harvard into the dustbin of history. The true believers didn't want a scaled-back welfare state, they wanted a repudiation of the whole idea of a social safety net. They didn't want economic policy that worried less about Keynesian demand management and more about incentives, they wanted an official declaration that Keynesian economics was a fraud. Call it idealism, call it vanity -- the supply-side cause has always contained more than its share of frustrated academics (Newt Gingrich, Dick Armey) -- but the movement Mr. Forbes represents wants nothing less than unconditional victory.
The Republican establishment, however, isn't interested. It has gotten what it wanted; now it's mainly a matter of protecting its gains. And it doesn't need Bob Forehead, because it's got George Bush.
Or maybe it's the same thing.

HEADLINE: Strongman From Congo Seeks Image Change at U.N. Meeting

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Elusive and unpredictable, President Laurent Kabila of Congo kept the United Nations guessing about whether he would attend a special Security Council session on the war in his country almost until his plane landed on Friday night, disgorging the largest of seven presidential parties for what has become an impromptu African summit.
Having decided to come, however, Mr. Kabila and his advisers are making the most of his first visit to the United States to try to give his government a new image. Mr. Kabila, a radical of the Che Guevara period and mold, finally fought his way to power in 1997 in what was then called Zaire, overthrowing the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko. He has since acquired a record of strong-arm politics, suppression of the press and human rights abuses that he will not let the United Nations investigate. 
 In New York, with the help of a Washington lobbyist, John Aycoth and his EAW group, Mr. Kabila has sought out reporters and television producers. He portrays Congo as a country that, after struggling for years to cope with the vast flow of refugees fleeing the Tutsi-Hutu violence in Rwanda, was then besieged by turncoat governments in Rwanda and Uganda, countries it once counted as allies and which now support rebels trying to oust Mr. Kabila.
He urges American officials to stop supporting his enemies in the interests of peace. He has convinced himself that the Clinton administration is listening.
Today Mr. Kabila met for three hours with six fellow African presidents and Secretary General Kofi Annan. He is ready to cooperate to end the war, he told reporters over breakfast, because another year of war would devastate his country.
Before they leave later this week, the African leaders assembled here are expected to endorse a call to revive a dormant peace agreement signed last July in Lusaka, Zambia. With that agreement back on track, diplomats say, there could be serious talk about creating a United Nations peacekeeping force for one of the world's most complex recent wars.
For Mr. Kabila, there is more riding on this trip than image, diplomats and other experts on Africa say. Increasingly isolated at home and abroad, his last, best chance, diplomats say, is international guarantees that all sides can be disarmed in the Congo war, which is draining the economies of other countries drawn into it -- and contributing to the spread of AIDS in Africa through troops from around the region.
A Western diplomat said today that Mr. Kabila faced a sharply narrowing support base. In military terms, this diplomat said, he has become dependent on the Zimbabweans under President Robert Mugabe, although he also gets some help from Angola and Namibia, and draws recruits from the former Hutu militias of Rwanda, which were driven out of the country into Congo in 1994.
"This war is costing all the countries of the region," the diplomat said. "Mugabe wants out but can only get out with a face-saving exit. There were economic interests, and a lot of business deals were cut in Congo. But the costs of engagement in the war are becoming greater than the economic gains."
Experts say Rwanda and Uganda are also feeling the pinch.
When Richard C. Holbrooke, the American representative at the United Nations and this month's Security Council president, toured Africa in December and asked all the nations involved in one side or another of the war in Congo to come to New York for a special session of the council, most accepted with alacrity. Getting Mr. Kabila to come was more difficult, Mr. Holbrooke said in an interview today.
"Without Kabila this meeting would have had a completely different context because it would not have had the president, whether you like him or not, of the country we were discussing, and that would have reduced the value of the meeting," Mr. Holbrooke said. "Our goal here to prevent this war in Congo from metastasizing into the neighborhood."
Mr. Holbrooke enlisted Mr. Mugabe; Mr. Annan; President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola; and the American ambassador in Congo, William Swing, to prevail on Mr. Kabila not to let this opportunity pass.
Maurice Tempelsman, chairman of the Corporate Council on Africa, a private business group that promotes investment and development, said Mr. Kabila may have calculated that he had more to lose by staying away.
"I think one has to step back and say, what are his options?" said Mr. Tempelsman, who has extensive mining interests in Africa. "He would have been facing the condemnation of the international community for not wanting to even appear. I think it's essential for his people and it's essential for him to come to some resolution of this conflict. His own power base at home is eroding. He came in with promise and great hope and unfortunately he has not been able to deliver."
Diplomats say it is too soon to know if there will be long-term gains from the meeting Mr. Holbrooke pulled together. "Some people say that the risks of getting involved in such a difficult effort -- and failing -- are so great that we can't risk national prestige," he said today. "I think that is a cold war view.
Mr. Tempelsman said the cold war was over in Africa too, and leaders realized that old backers were gone and that the decisions made by African leaders would have consequences that they would have to deal with themselves.
"The rest of the world is sympathetic and encouraging, but the leadership has to come from within," he said. "If success is achieved here that will be a very important, a very major breakthrough." Among other achievements, he said, it will make Africa more attractive to the investors its countries seek.
"Few private sector companies will deploy their people and take the risks inherent in that, or deploy their capital in a conflict situation," Mr. Tempelsman said. "On a whole series of scores, and certainly in terms of development, the first step is capacity for conflict resolution. It's not that conflicts won't happen. But it's how you resolve them, how you deal with them, which this in an ad hoc fashion may produce."
The involvement of the Security Council, he added, gives the Africans' own effort a kind of international recognition. "This is basically using a historical, cultural African way of resolving things - palaver - and putting it into the machinery the international community has for dealing with conflicts."

HEADLINE: FEDERAL SURPLUS SOARS IN FORECAST BY BUDGET OFFICE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Driven by the strong economy and the resulting flood of tax revenues, the federal budget surplus will surge over the next decade to levels that would have been inconceivable only a few years ago, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report made public today.
By one measure, the surplus outside of the Social Security system for the next 10 years would total more than $1.9 trillion, nearly twice as much as estimated by the budget office last year, the report said. 
 Using other assumptions that provide for higher spending levels, the 10-year surplus projections outside of Social Security would range from $838 billion to more than $1.8 trillion.
The surplus in the Social Security system, which is projected to turn into a deep deficit within 20 years as the baby boom generation retires, was estimated by the budget office at $2.3 trillion over 10 years.
Long-term budget projections have proven notoriously volatile and unreliable. A decade ago, when deficits appeared immutable, no one would have dared to predict that the government would be in surplus today. But just as the long economic expansion has now brightened the fiscal picture more than expected, so too could a downturn darken it.
No matter how the new surplus numbers are qualified, they are big and will effectively expand the parameters of an election-year debate over how best to use the bounty of the nation's prosperity.
Even before the new estimates emerged, all the leading presidential candidates had offered plans to divide the surplus among tax cuts, spending programs, reducing the national debt and putting Social Security and Medicare on sounder footing. The sharp divisions on the campaign trail mirror the political and ideological clash in Washington that has left Congress and the Clinton administration deadlocked over fiscal policy for the last several years.
The increase in the surplus estimates also allowed the Republican majority in Congress to claim that it had stuck to its pledge not to dip into Social Security money to pay for general government operations during the current fiscal year. The Social Security money is instead going toward debt reduction.
Under prior projections by the budget office, the spending bills passed by Congress last year required borrowing $17 billion from Social Security this year. But the new projections show that there will be an operating surplus for this year of $23 billion, a swing of $40 billion that insulates Republicans from charges of fiscal irresponsibility.
The Clinton administration will issue its own surplus projections in two weeks. President Clinton has laid out an ambitious series of tax and spending initiatives in the last few weeks in an indication that the budget proposal he sends to Congress next month will not be shy about putting the projected surplus to use.
But in an effort to bolster his case that spending increases in an era of surpluses can coexist with fiscal prudence, Mr. Clinton said today that he intended to push for accelerated repayment of the national debt.
Mr. Clinton said he would offer a plan to pay off by 2013 the entire $3.6 trillion owed by the federal government to the public in the form of Treasury bonds. He did not provide details. Last year Mr. Clinton proposed a similar plan to pay off the public debt by 2015, and House Republicans are also developing a plan that would eliminate the public debt by 2015.
The total national debt of $5.7 trillion includes both the public debt and more than $2 trillion owed by the government to the Social Security system.
The budget office figures go only to 2010, but they show that the debt would be reduced to $941 billion by that point if all of the Social Security surpluses are used for debt reduction, as both parties have more or less agreed to do.
The political ramifications of the new surplus estimates could be substantial. In Congress, Democrats said that with so much money on the table it would be increasingly difficult for them to beat back all Republican efforts to cut taxes. In particular, Democrats are considering supporting some version of proposals by Republicans to reduce the so-called marriage penalty paid by many two-income couples.
Republicans said the bigger pot of money will increase the pressure on them to agree to some version of Mr. Clinton's main priority, an expansion of Medicare to include prescription drug coverage.
In the Republican presidential race, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas will be able to claim that his big tax cut proposal is more prudent than it looked when the surplus estimate was smaller. On the Democratic side, former Senator Bill Bradley might be less vulnerable to assertions by Vice President Al Gore that his health-care and poverty-fighting programs are budget-busters.
The budget office offered three plans that provide a sense of what the government's books would look like under different assumptions about spending levels.
The main projection, yielding a non-Social Security surplus estimate of $1.92 trillion over 10 years, uses assumptions that have been standard for budget forecasting for a decade. It assumes that Congress and the administration will cut spending for each of the next two years to meet spending limits written into law in 1997, and then hold spending increases to the rate of inflation for the rest of the decade.
The two parties have shattered the spending caps each of the last two years in all but the most technical sense. With the surplus growing, there is almost no one on Capitol Hill who advocates trying to meet the limits next year. Doing so would require cutting outlays in annually appropriated programs -- the third of the total federal budget that includes most operations other than Social Security, Medicare and interest payments -- to $579 billion next year from $606 billion this year.
Many Republicans support use of another set of numbers that starts with current spending levels but then assumes that spending is frozen, without any adjustment for inflation, at that level for the rest of the decade. Under such a plan, the non-Social Security surplus would total $1.86 trillion over 10 years.
But many Democrats said that a freeze was totally unrealistic, especially since even the Republican-led Congress has regularly voted for spending increases. Democrats tend to prefer the third plan, under which spending is assumed to start at current levels and then to grow at the inflation rate for the rest of the decade. Under that plan, the non-Social Security surplus over 10 years would be $838 billion, far less than under either of the two other options.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who heads the Senate Budget Committee, said that Republicans had not decided which surplus projections to use and that he might develop a fourth option. But he said it was unlikely that there would be any effort to cut spending to adhere to the limits set in 1997, suggesting that the caps would be scrapped this year or reset at higher levels.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1858 words

HEADLINE: Master Plans or Pipe Dreams;
Giuliani Proposes Monuments; Skeptics See Fantasies

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
All New York City mayors dream about changing the face of their realm, of erecting a physical legacy. Fiorello La Guardia is remembered for his public housing, the airport that bears his name and the alliance he forged with Robert Moses, the most grandiose builder of all. John V. Lindsay fought for urban renewal. Edward I. Koch is credited with the rehabilitation of the South Bronx, and David N. Dinkins made the deal with Disney that led to the new Times Square.
And Rudolph W. Giuliani? Even some of his supporters say that the mayor's legacy will be in cleaning up the streets, not in changing the way they look with the creation of great monuments -- a point of view that, not incidentally, sent Mr. Giuliani into a seven-minute panegyric lauding his building accomplishments at a news briefing last week. 
 "Give me a break!" the mayor said. "Boy, that is the most warped analysis I've ever heard. We've done more building in New York City in any administration in about 50 years."
By Monday, Mr. Giuliani's aides had compiled a handy list of more than 100 completed or planned construction projects during the mayor's six years in office, including the restoration of City Hall Park and the revitalization of the Lower Manhattan's business district. But much of what Mr. Giuliani takes credit for, including the Conde Nast building and the ABC studio in Times Square, reflects his administration's ability to bask in the most robust New York City economy in history, and to grant billions of dollars in tax breaks to corporations and private developers.
Now, with perhaps only 11 months left in office, the mayor is promoting a fantastic array of great public works, many of them suitable for Giuliani legacy status or at least for his undeclared United States Senate campaign. Some ideas are new, many are recycled and one, a rail-freight tunnel under New York Harbor that could cost $4 billion, is older than the mayor himself.
All were offered in the mayor's Jan. 13 State of the City speech, which will be his last if he defeats Hillary Rodham Clinton in this year's Senate race.
Here, then, is a look at the politics, history and viability of four of the mayor's pet projects: the rail-freight tunnel, a stadium and Olympic complex called Midtown West on the Hudson River, the proposed sale of the Board of Education's decrepit headquarters at 110 Livingston Street and $5 million in improvements to East River Park -- one of the few projects, the mayor's critics say, that has the possibility of life.
The same critics predict that most of Mr. Giuliani's projects will founder in the inevitable political, environmental and economic battles, and that the mayor, who is often at war with the people he needs as collaborators, is in any case too late.
"I don't believe that anything he proposes in the sixth year of his administration that relates to large-scale construction projects can really get done," said Ester Fuchs, the director of the Center for Urban Research and Policy at Columbia University. "There's not enough time."
 Mr. Giuliani's supporters counter that the mayor's proposals are literally Olympian but realistic. "I think that only a big plan can be sold," said Alexander Garvin, the planning director for NYC 2012, the organization that is trying to lure the Olympics to New York City and that created Mr. Giuliani's $2 billion proposal for the West Side stadium.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, who supports the rail-freight tunnel but not the stadium, agreed in principle that prosperous times should produce larger-scale projects. "It's always good for the mayor to advocate," he said. "To think big is the right idea."
One thing is certain: mayors are often so overwhelmed by the demands of the city's infrastructure that it is impossible for them to think of erecting monuments the way Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller did -- the World Trade Center, for example, or Battery Park City. "That's like God came down and created them, and you associate yourself with God," Mr. Koch said. "But God doesn't do sewers. Mayors do sewers."
 The mayor's most behemoth proposal is the tunnel, which advocates acknowledge will never capture the imagination of most New Yorkers. "It is not politically sexy, and it does not have a natural constituency," said H. Claude Shostal, the president of the Regional Plan Association, a private planning group.
But that group clearly does not include the mayor, who first brought up the tunnel during his 1997 State of the City speech. He did not mention it in his 1998 and 1999 speeches, but revived it this year, conveniently timed to the completion of a two-year study, overseen by the city and paid for largely by the federal government, that is expected to recommend in May that the tunnel be built.
"It is not a pipe dream," said Representative Jerrold L. Nadler of Manhattan, a Democrat, who has been promoting the tunnel for more than two decades.
The tunnel would run from either New Jersey or Staten Island to a redeveloped Brooklyn waterfront, and would be a rail path into the city for such consumer products as furniture, appliances and construction materials. The study already estimates that it would divert 10 percent of the 35,000 large trucks that flow into the city each day, easing pollution and wear on the roads.
Advocates say that people who consider rail transport a thing of the past are themselves 10 years out of date. "Quite the contrary," said Seth Kaye, executive vice president for transportation at the Economic Development Corporation, the city agency overseeing the study. "Rail is a very efficient way to move goods. People can talk all they want about the information economy, but until you can figure out how to deliver your goods through a modem, we're going to be relying on trucks and rail."
Skeptics call the tunnel a mayoral fantasy, and point out that plans for it have festered since 1921, when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was created to build it.
"We've survived for almost a century without the tunnel, and we're going to survive for another century without the tunnel," said Mitchell Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University and co-author of a 1998 report contending that the tunnel would harm Brooklyn businesses and funnel thousands of additional trucks onto the Gowanus Expressway. "The purpose of this project is to give elected officials something to say. No one ever expects it to be built."
Even those who support the tunnel, like Mr. Shostal, say the immediate hurdles are questions about who will pay for it and whether the mayor can work well with others, particularly the Port Authority, which Mr. Giuliani has long complained favors New Jersey at the expense of New York City.
"The funding hasn't been spelled out, who would build it hasn't been spelled out, and the mayor is at such war with the Port Authority, which is the most likely candidate to provide some of the funding to build it," Mr. Shostal said.
Mr. Giuliani's most ardent proposal is an expansion of plans to build a home for both the New York Jets and the 2012 Olympics with a stadium that would have a retractable roof and stretch from 30th to 34th Street on the far West Side.
"He's got stadiums on the brain, and they're not going to be built," Mr. Koch said. "It's the environmental aspect, plus the money. It can't support the introduction of cars."
Mr. Garvin, whose NYC 2012 committee commissioned the plans for the stadium complex that the mayor excitedly held up during his State of the City speech, disagreed.
The project, he said, would not only be a stadium but also a goliath redevelopment of an underused area of Manhattan, and is to include nothing less than a 7.5-acre public square, two convention hotels, a new Madison Square Garden, an Olympic media center and an expansion of the Javits Convention Center -- all to be reachable through new rail stations that would extend service on Metro-North, the Long Island Rail Road and the No. 7 subway line.
Mr. Garvin, a professor of urban planning at Yale University and a member of the City Planning Commission, said that much of the project would be paid for by private developers and that the proposal was still "a work in progress." He acknowledged that it needed approval and cooperation from "everybody under the sun."
Everybody includes not only Madison Square Garden, the Javits Center and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, but also Gov. George E. Pataki, who has never endorsed the project and with whom the mayor has a contentious relationship.
The project is also dependent on the Jets, who have not made a deal with the city to move from New Jersey, and the United States Olympic Committee, which will decide in 2002 whether New York beats out seven other American cities, including San Francisco, Dallas, Cincinnati and Baltimore-Washington, for the right to be the sole United States competitor among cities at the international level.
The International Olympics Committee will make its final decision on a 2012 site in 2005.
 Mr. Giuliani's most politically pointed project is his proposal to sell 110 Livingston Street, the Board of Education's historic, leaking headquarters in downtown Brooklyn and the object of much mayoral scorn.
Although listeners at first thought Mr. Giuliani was joking -- particularly when he caustically said that a modern, "smart building" a fourth the size of Livingston Street would be good for the board he ultimately wants to abolish -- he was serious.
So, apparently, is the Board of Education, which must approve the sale. "There's no attachment to this building," said William C. Thompson Jr., the board president. "I'd like to see the dollars in the budget and what it would bring."
Board officials are still trying to determine the worth of the 12-story Italian-Renaissance-style building, which the American Institute of Architects Guide to New York City describes as "pallid and boring."
Designed by the legendary firm of McKim, Mead & White, board officials said the headquarters was originally three buildings -- an Elks lodge, a courthouse and a third of unknown purpose -- that were built in the 1920's for $6 million. The stock market collapsed a year later, the Elks lodge went into foreclosure in 1933 and the city bought the buildings in 1936 for $950,000. The Board of Education moved in in 1940.
Mr. Giuliani's most practical proposal is the improvement of East River Park, built by Moses in the 1930's and stretching for 57 acres on the Lower East Side from 12th Street to Montgomery Street. The $5 million planned renovation includes landscaping, a bike path, a soccer field with artificial turf, a roller-hockey rink, basketball courts and repair of the park's sea wall.
Anthony P. Coles, the mayor's senior policy adviser, said the money is in Mr. Giuliani's spending plan for the 2001 fiscal year that is to be released on Thursday. "No one is going to argue with this," Mr. Coles said.
 Henry J. Stern, the parks commissioner, added that "at least park proposals in the State of the City speech have a way of happening."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 148 words

HEADLINE: When the Rich Get Even Richer

 BODY:

To the Editor:
W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm ask, "Why Decry the Wealth Gap?" (Op-Ed, Jan. 24). First, inequality is correlated with political instability, one of the strongest findings of cross-national research. Second, inequality is correlated with violent crime. Third, economic inequality is correlated with reduced life expectancy, shown by a large and growing body of public health research. 
 A fourth reason? Simple justice. There is no moral justification for chief executives' being paid hundreds of times more than ordinary employees. Social policies that reduce inequality, like progressive taxation and living wages, should be strengthened and expanded for the health and well-being of those not at the top of the pyramid.
 
RICHARD HUTCHINSON
Ogden, Utah, Jan. 24, 2000
 
The writer is an assistant professor of sociology, Weber State University.

HEADLINE: When the Rich Get Even Richer

 BODY:

To the Editor:
W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm (Op-Ed, Jan. 24) assert that artificial efforts to curb inequality do more harm than good and that Americans ought to care more about growth than inequality. But this overlooks the fact that people of wealth and privilege are in a position to pass great advantages on to their children, while the children of the poor, lacking in resources, fall further behind. 
 Would Mr. Cox and Mr. Alm consider Social Security an "artificial" attempt to curb inequality? It is one of America's most successful and popular programs. Do they think more good would be done by eliminating it?
One by-product of economic inequality is its debilitating effect on social cohesion. Studies show that states and nations with great inequality often have reduced levels of social involvement and trust. These, in turn, are correlated with higher rates of illness and death.
 
GERALD KLOBY
Upper Montclair, N.J., Jan. 24, 2000
 
The writer is coordinator of the Institute for Community Studies, Montclair State University.

LENGTH: 1737 words

HEADLINE: We're Not All Connected, Yet

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
IF, as most people in the computer industry seem to think, the Internet is on its way to becoming the dominant mode of information exchange, then it is no longer a luxury but, like the telephone, a necessity. Anyone without it is in danger of being shut out.
"We've been saying for a long time that this transition is like what happened with telephones, and it's becoming clear to me that a whole lot of people will be left out," said Garrett Gruener, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist who is one of the people working on a solution to the problem. 
 But telephones are a lot easier to provide than computers. And while the so-called digital divide is an easy problem to label, it is a lot stickier to solve.
One of the most visible attempts, and one that illustrates the complexity of providing universal Internet access, is likely to come tonight, when President Clinton, in his State of the Union address, is expected not only to make note of the divide but also to suggest federally sponsored remedies.
Mr. Clinton's budget for next year, according to White House aides, will include some $50 million in competitive grants to communities and organizations involved in efforts to help low-income families go online. Aides said Mr. Clinton will also mention initiatives for teacher training and incentives for businesses to help bridge the gap.
One solution to the technology gap that has already been presented to the administration is the brainchild of a group of Silicon Valley executives, including Mr. Gruener. It is an initiative called ClickStart, a nonprofit organization that would use federal subsidies to help connect millions of low-income Americans to the Internet.
Whether the funds for such a program will materialize is far from certain. Still, the announcement of ClickStart has helped stir awareness of what promises to be a dominant issue for the next decade.
A recent Commerce Department study found that urban households with incomes above $75,000 are more than 20 times as likely to have home Internet access than rural households at the lowest income levels and that the gap for home Internet access between those at the highest and lowest income levels widened sharply from 1997 to 1998.
While many other efforts focus on building technology centers in low-income neighborhoods, ClickStart is focused on providing computers for home use. For a copayment of about $5 per month, each recipient will get a $10 monthly federal subsidy in the form of a voucher. It can be used to buy hardware and Internet access from any vendor participating in the program.
The ClickStart program, if it is financed at all, is scheduled to expire after five years. The reason, say the executives who created the program, is that by then enough people will have received the technology boost they need, market forces will have taken over and prices for hardware and Internet access will have dropped significantly enough to be affordable even to the poor.
"This is just an accelerator," said Eric Schmidt, chief executive of Novell and one of the ClickStart organizers. "We're not trying to create welfare here."
The subsidy, paired with the copayment, adds up to $180 a year, which the ClickStart organizers say is enough to buy both a functional PC and Internet access. Increasingly, low-cost PC's are being paired with free Internet access, and vice versa. The trade-off, however, is that the user is often besieged by advertising. That makes seasoned technology-access advocates like Daniel Ben-Horin wary.
"Historically, the poor are the most susceptible to advertising generally, the least able to afford to navigate the perils of our consumerist culture and the most prone to being misled by dishonest advertising," said Mr. Ben-Horin, president of CompuMentor in San Francisco, one of the nation's largest providers of technology assistance services to nonprofit groups and schools. At the same time, Mr. Ben-Horin said he lauded the effort as the first one to approach the problem on a large scale.
If Congress fails to approve federal financing to bridge the technology gap, the ClickStart creators say they will not abandon their idea. "We'll continue on a path of trying to raise as much money from the private sector to replace what would otherwise be the $10 subsidy from the feds," said Wade Randlett, who is vice president of an Internet startup company, Red Gorilla, and another ClickStart organizer.
But perhaps even more important than the initial hookup, say many in the nonprofit sector, is a program that takes care not to "dump the hardware and run." A program like ClickStart, they say, must provide follow-through.
"The tough issues here are not the hardware or the software," said Preston Moore, coordinator of the Digital Divide Working Group at the First Unitarian Church of Oakland, Calif., a city that has become a favored test bed for programs seeking to bridge the technology gap. "The tough issues are the brick-by-brick building of connections between people at a very individual level, which is a painstakingly slow process of learning what differences a computer and Internet access can make in a person's life."
Mr. Moore has a grant proposal pending with the AOL Foundation, the online service's philanthropic arm, that would provide technology mentoring. "The idea is to have a person assigned to train, then continue to work with a family after the family has received a computer and Internet access," he said. "And that means getting beyond buying consumer goods on the Internet. It take a lot of patience and a lot of listening, and a lot of humility.
"There's a lot of yearning to solve this problem by throwing technology at it. Don't get me wrong. The technology is essential, but that's not the hard part. The hard part is the person-to-person connections that have to go with it."
The ClickStart creators say this is something they have thought about. Julie Henderson, executive director of the Marcus A. Foster Educational Institute in Oakland, which is helping administer a ClickStart trial there, said her organization will help with ongoing training and support, in Spanish, Chinese and Vietnamese as well as English. Participants in the trial will receive computers from PeoplePC, said Nick Grouf, the company's chief executive.
But some say that simple training and technical support still fall short of what is needed when bringing Internet access to poor areas.
Like Mr. Moore, Mr. Ben-Horin expressed concern that training and support issues might be underestimated.
"There's a tendency to say, 'Here's a machine, here's the software and, maybe, here's some classroom training, now stop whining and use this great stuff,' " Mr. Ben-Horin said. "But that's not enough. What needs in their lives can computers and the Internet help disadvantaged people address? What obstacles are preventing use and how can these obstacles be removed? These are the hard questions a support program for these families will have to address."
Wendy Lazarus, founder and director of the Children's Partnership, a nonprofit organization based in Santa Monica, Calif., said her group had been studying communities across the country, conducting research on needs that extend beyond what Ms. Lazarus called "the boxes and wires."
"What seems clear is that the real meat is in two areas," Ms. Lazarus said. "First, coaching and making sure people can get the technical help that all of us need. And secondly that the information that is on the Internet is of real value to people in underserved communities." The group plans to release a comprehensive set of findings in the next two months.
Amy Borgstrom, executive director of the Appalachian Center for Economic Networks in Athens, Ohio, has been working to bring technology to poor areas for far longer than the topic has been a political issue.
Ms. Borgstrom said the economy of Athens County was devastated when the coal mines left in the 1930's, and the area has yet to recover. "People still have issues of food, clothing and shelter that are more profound than Internet access," she said.
Ms. Borgstrom noted that in Athens County, where 34 percent of the population falls below the poverty line, many households are still without telephone service.
Still, Ms. Borgstrom said, "in the past five or six years it became really clear to us that the Internet was going to become a really important tool for them to be able to expand, create jobs, grow and thrive."
One focus of her work, Ms. Borgstrom said, is working with very small companies that sell locally produced foods. Giving those enterprises Internet access, she said, helps them in a number of ways. It gives them good trend information, as well as useful information about their competitors, and the ability to engage in e-commerce.
"The focus is not Internet access for the sake of Internet access," Ms. Borgstrom said. "But it's the Internet for the really targeted objective of building a sustainable and thriving economy here with lots of good jobs."
Still others take issue with the "digital divide" concept itself. The phrase, wrote Steve Cisler, a consultant in San Jose, Calif., who has written extensively on technology and privilege, is a demeaning and simplistic characterization of a complex problem.
"You are online or offline," Mr. Cisler wrote in a recent editorial in The San Jose Mercury News. "You have a computer or you are without one; you are trained for the digital future or you are in dead-end, low-paying work."
In reality, Mr. Cisler wrote, even those who are online fall somewhere on a spectrum of connectivity. "A few million American families have D.S.L. and cable modem access, and the majority are still using modems of varying speeds," he wrote. "Those in rural areas may have poor phone lines that are an expensive toll call to the closest I.S.P. because 20 percent of the counties do not have an Internet point of presence. Are all of them on one side of the digital divide and those without any access on the other?"
Still, the Silicon Valley executives behind Clickstart are confident that they understand the issue and are doing the right thing. "The problem is there's a set of people for whom $10 to $20 a month is a lot of money," Mr. Schmidt said. "The question is, 'Is society better off if they're online, too,' and the answer is, 'Absolutely.' "

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD;
A Senegalese Singer Mixes the Street and the Spiritual

BYLINE: By David Hecht 

DATELINE: DAKAR, Senegal

 BODY:
Cheikh Ndigel Lo says he would never be able to make his music if it was not for his religion. He is a Mouride. Followers of this distinctly Senegalese Sufi Islamic brotherhood go into trances from hours of chanting, some while beating themselves with wooden clubs.
That is not the kind of music Mr. Lo is known for. One of his new songs is a remake of the Beatles's "Let It Be," though Mr. Lo, who is 44 and speaks little English, has changed those words to "Mbeddemi," meaning "in the street" in the Wolof language. (The song has not been released internationally because of unresolved copyright issues.) 
 In the title track of his new album, "Bambay Gueej" (Jololi/World Circuit), to be distributed in the United States in March by Nonesuch, he sings of how, when the Mouride founder, Amadou Bamba, was exiled by the French colonizers at the beginning of 20th century, he magically turned into the ocean, providing "the salt of life" and connecting continents and cultures.
The songs in the album also change like the ocean, from Cuban salsa, to Congolese soukous, to Nigerian Afrobeat, to Bambara music from Mali, with elements of reggae, funk and jazz. All are peppered with a distinctively Senegalese percussion sound. The final song of the album, "Zikr," is a simple Mouride religious prayer. (Zikr is an Arabic word for the ritual recitation of the names of God.)
So many different styles could become a mishmash. This album is not. "Bambay Gueej" ("Bamba Is the Ocean") has been No. 4 on the European-based World Music Chart since last month after having been No. 1 in November. The Senegalese singer Youssou Ndour and Nick Gold, the owner of World Circuit, caringly produced the album, getting the voice of a Mali singer, Oumou Sangare, for backups on one song, and the Cuban flutist Richard Egues for another.
But Mr. Lo, speaking in French and Wolof, insisted that the real producer behind his music is his marabout or spiritual guide, Maame Massamba Ndiaye Borom Ndigel. Maame (grandfather) "knows the secret of breath," he said, wearing a 4-by-6-inch photograph of the marabout around his neck permanently. The marabout, he said, has "powers that most people cannot even imagine."
From the village of Ndigel the marabout leads a group of holy Mouride warriors known as the Baye Fall who crisscross the hot dusty interior of Senegal, singing, proselytizing and begging. Senegalese often complain that the Baye Fall are loud and bothersome, yet they are also well loved. They dress differently from most Mourides, wearing bright costumes made of patchwork clothes and dreadlocks like the Rastafarians. The Baye Fall say they wear dreadlocks to emulate the Senegalese warriors of old, but they bear no arms. Many, like Mr. Lo, believe in magic.
"I connect to Maame through the earth," he said in his oceanside living room in a Dakar suburb called Mamelles. As he said this, he slapped his hand on the ground. "You think he isn't aware of what's going on in this room right now as we speak? Ha!"
With bulging eyes and resembling Sammy Davis Jr. in dreadlocks, Mr. Lo is considered by the Senegalese to be the most unusual looking Baye Fall of all. He rarely answers questions directly; sometimes he's friendly, other times, suspicious and accusatory. Attempts to cut short his monologues about his marabout are futile: "Maame is with me even when I'm touring the United States," he said. "The connection is stronger than a telephone and more serious than a facsimile machine."
Few followers of the brotherhood claim to have telepathic powers, but there is perhaps a special connection between the thousands of Mourides who have gone out into the world in recent decades. Thousands are street peddlers in cities across the United States, Europe and the Middle East. Their overseas "headquarters" is Manhattan, where many hawk knockoffs of name-brand watches and sunglasses in tourist areas, particularly Times Square. Many live in Harlem; in recent years the corner of 116th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard has become known as Little Senegal.
"Mourides were mostly farmers, growing peanuts for export," said Prof. Leonardo Villalon, author of "Islamic Society and State Power in Senegal." (He is presently teaching in Senegal.) "But with desertification and changes in the economy they have diversified into international trade networks, which are organized around connections to their various marabouts."
Many of these marabouts live in Touba, a holy city founded by Amadou Bamba after he made a deal with the French that enabled him to return from exile on condition that his followers stopped causing unrest. Although Touba lies in the desolate interior, it has become Senegal's second main commercial center, with a market full of merchandise, mostly from New York.
It also has huge white palaces and mausoleums for marabouts, living and dead, and a large library for the many books about and written by Amadou Bamba.
Bamba's philosophy has been called Sufi capitalism, and he has sayings such as "jef jel," meaning in Wolof, "What you earn for yourself, take for yourself." With so many Mourides in Harlem, African-Americans are converting.
"It's not antimodern, it's not antiwomen, its not antilearning," said Wendy Wilson Fall, an African-American Mouride who lives in Dakar. "Mourides are generally considered cosmopolitan, open and tolerant, with a strong tradition of religious discussion, much like the shul tradition among the Jews."
The door to Mouridism is the Baye Fall movement, Ms. Wilson Fall said. "It provides a way of life for people who are not ready for the discipline required of a practiced disciple," she said. Baye Fall members do not fast during the month of Ramadan or observe other basic tenets of Islam. "The emphasis is on intention," she said.
Mr. Lo was born to Mouride parents but showed little interest in the brotherhood when he was younger, and he hated school. Mostly he played music, eventually landing a job at a big hotel in Dakar. "I learned to play whatever the tourists wanted: rock, polka, flamenco, waltzes," he said. He had a big Afro hair style in those days, he said, illustrating by holding his hands about a foot away from each side of his head.
Life, he said, changed after he met his marabout. "Maame connected together all the disparate worlds I inhabit," he said. "Through him I learned to believe and know exactly what it is I believe in. That's very important for a person."
The Sufi brotherhoods hold Senegalese society together. Sixty percent of the economy operates through the Mouride, Mr. Lo said, thumping the floor, and adding, "Make sure you write that down." "We Mourides don't create much though," he said. "We are traders. We exchange."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Ends Mixedas Investors Shift to Financial Companies

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended mixed yesterday as gains in financial service companies, partly because of lower bond yields, were offset by a drop in leading technology companies on concern that their sales growth might be slowing.
"Generally the money in technology names is very skittish, and any time there's bad news, they just look for something else to go to," said Peter Gottlieb, the vice president and portfolio manager at First Albany Asset Management in Chicago. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished little changed, gaining 3.10 points, or 0.03 percent, to 11,032.99. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed down 5.94 points, or 0.42 percent, to 1,404.09, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell 97.5 points, or 2.34 percent, to 4,069.91.
The major catalyst for a switch from technology into financials was a warning from the cellular phone technology company Qualcomm late on Tuesday that its second-quarter product shipments could fall. That sent the previously highflying stock down 24 3/8, to 124 5/8.
"Qualcomm kind of upset some people with their forward-looking statement but that was really an excuse to sell some of the technology shares down," said Guy Truicko, portfolio manager of Unity Management in Garden City, N.Y. "The earnings in general have been stellar so I don't see this as a major shift. Some of the money right now is going into financials."
Financial stocks helped the Dow to remain in positive territory as the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond strengthened, pushing the yield down to 6.57 percent from Tuesday's close of 6.63 percent. American Express rose 1 3/8, to 159 3/4, and J. P. Morgan rose 73/16 , to 123 3/8.
 There was little reaction to initial comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, when he said the central bank's challenge was to avoid potential inflationary imbalances.
Mr. Greenspan, appearing before the Senate Banking Committee, which is considering his reappointment as chairman, made no reference to the immediate outlook for interest rates.

HEADLINE: A Last Grasp at Posterity

BYLINE: By Edmund Morris; Edmund Morris, the author of "Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan," is writing the second volume of a trilogy on the life of Theodore Roosevelt.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In popular imagination, this has always been a white city: block after block of pale marble buildings that glow even whiter at night, when the floodlights come into play. Under snow, its classical shapes -- domes and pediments, octagons and pyramids -- are linked in a geometry that remains generally pure, thanks to the speed with which government shuts down at the first sight of falling flakes.
Now, as William Jefferson Clinton muses his final State of the Union address, the city is more snowbound than any January I can remember -- whiter, certainly, than it was seven years ago, when I suggested on this page that we give the incoming president a tabula rasa "for at least one day in the four years looming." 
 We not only did that (despite pretty good advance warning that he would besmirch it), but we gave him another tablet four years later -- and look what he scribbled all over it: confessions, apologies, weasel words and constant redrafts of policy, in a hand that expertly forged the orthography of several of his predecessors.
Well, this is his last chance, legislatively speaking, to address himself to posterity. What can he write -- what can he say -- that will impress that notoriously difficult audience? And having said it, will he be able to invest his last few effective months in office with some degree of grace?
On the day that George Bush was elected president in 1988, I sat with Ronald Reagan upstairs in the White House, gazing out across the exquisite geometry of the Mall. He did not seem disturbed by the ebb of power. "This can be a lonely place, you know," he said, sipping a cup of decaf. "You feel so insulated here."
The tranquility of his voice belied his words. Never was there a president more content to be alone (as long as he could sense the nearby hovering of his wife), more certain of the rightness of his executive record, more sure that history would judge him well.
Mr. Clinton, apparently, lacks this majestic self-certainty -- for good or ill, a prerequisite of all true leaders. Hence his reported late-night need to schmooze with friends and former aides by telephone, an instrument Mr. Reagan disliked. Hence his insatiable desire to "grip-and-grin": I'm surprised he never tried to beat Theodore Roosevelt's White House record of 8,150 handshakes in a single day.
T.R. was as gregarious and power-loving as Mr. Clinton, yet just as happy as Ronald Reagan to pack up after two terms and go home. (Having done so, he soon began to chafe, but that's another story.) "I have done my work . . . I have nothing to ask; and I am very grateful to the American people for what they have done for me." When he left town, in weather quite as white as we're having now, he was only 50, and more interested in life than posterity.
Apropos of which, his favorite dialect commentator, "Mr. Dooley," issued a reminder that all presidents should ponder: "Posterity don't vote until after th' polls close." Mr. Clinton may rise to the occasion tonight, as he has done so often before, and even dazzle Congress with his designs for a more perfect Union. But history teaches that such designs usually redound to the honor of the next man. Look how George Bush was celebrated for the fall of the Berlin Wall, and how Mr. Clinton himself has profited from 12 years of Republican economic reforms.
If I may borrow a line from my biography of Ronald Reagan, "In the end what chiefly survives, or should survive, of any Chief Executive is the quality of his personality." In that respect, Mr. Clinton's final legacy will be something less than snow-white.

HEADLINE: Now Playing Europe: Invasion of the Multiplex;
With Subplots on Pride and Environment

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: DUNKIRK, France

 BODY:
Bruno Frydman had few illusions when he set up shop in Paris in 1993 to build the kind of multiplex theaters that helped revolutionize moviegoing in the United States.
Though Mr. Frydman works for a subsidiary of an American company, he is French and well aware of how passionately attached the French can be to homegrown culture. So, when he was asked by his company to open multiplex movie theaters all around Europe, he based his operations in Paris, thinking that if he could make it there he could make it anywhere. 
 Still, it took him six years to get his latest and biggest project built -- a 20-screen, 4,010-seat complex in a harborside shopping center in this French port city of 71,000 on the Straits of Dover, known for its tragic role in World War II.
His experience shows that he was right not to underestimate French pride in film heritage or the resistance of big domestic multiplex developers like Gaumont, Pathe and UGC. And he knew just how strong opposition in Europe can be to the way suburban malls -- often anchored by multiplexes -- chew up the landscape. Which is why he focused on urban projects.
But although similar resistance to sprawl is growing in the United States, in Europe the struggle to preserve historic towns is even more crucial. Urban culture is what defines much of the continent, and the old buildings and churches of inner cities are as important to tourist appeal as are museums and natural beauty.
Despite this tricky atmosphere, Mr. Frydman (pronounced FREED-man), whose company had been recruited by local officials and business groups, managed to get the multiplex built. Success came in part because local politicians, fearful themselves for the future of the city center, blunted environmentalists' concerns by putting the mall next to old downtown shopping streets. But it was also a result of some tough and creative negotiations.
Mr. Frydman's company, AMC Europe S.A. -- a unit of AMC Entertainment, the group that pioneered multiple-screen movie theaters in the United States -- opened the $20 million theater complex here in late November as part of a $110 million shopping mall. Featuring American hits as well as French films, the multiplex has been drawing 15,000 moviegoers a week, not far from the 20,000 that AMC expects when it is at full speed.
Dunkirk and its harborside multiplex illustrate a difficult choice facing Europeans. While some fear for the future of local film industries, developers and theater operators are convincing local planners that downtown shopping centers anchored by large multiplex movie theaters can help offset a decline in the vitality of inner cities. (AMC has been using similar arguments in the United States.)
Indeed, as multiplexes have spread across Europe in the last decade, the number of moviegoers has soared, to 895 million in 1999 from 757 million just five years earlier. Thanks mainly to the explosion of multiplexes, the number of screens rose to 27,466 from 23,108 five years earlier. In Dunkirk, where the decline of heavy industries like steel and chemicals and a drop in port activity have fostered decay in the inner city -- driving unemployment to 15 percent, well above the national average of 10.8 percent -- the complex that houses Mr. Frydman's multiplex created 600 jobs. About 2,000 people applied for the 109 jobs created by the multiplex alone, said Arnaud Charron, its managing director.
But the spread of multiplexes has done little to solidify the position of local filmmaking in Europe, where American-made movies reign supreme at the box office and the commercial success of local films is erratic. In 1998, for instance, the last full year for which statistics are available, the share of American movies in two of the biggest markets, Britain and Germany, climbed to more than 80 percent, from less than 70 percent in 1997, when strong European entries like the British hit "The Full Monty" briefly bolstered the European share. In France, the American share reached almost 70 percent, from slightly above 50 percent.
Karsten Grummitt, managing director of Dodona Research, which follows the film industry, said that "in France and Italy, particularly, where governments protect the film industry, multiplexes are viewed as an intrinsically American plan that lead to American domination of the industry."
In another sting to European pride, the spread of multiplexes has hastened the demise of the grand old movie palaces of the 1920's and 1930's. In Britain, the preservation group English Heritage is pressing the government to add 30 theaters from the glory days of moviegoing before World War II to a list of 120 that enjoy protected status, though some now serve as bingo halls or churches. The mayor of Paris, Jean Tiberi, has asked the French government for help in preserving La Pagode, a faux-Japanese movie theater that is a Parisian landmark, and the Champollion, a movie buffs' sanctuary that was once the haunt of the director Francois Truffaut.
Such conservation efforts have not slowed the spread of the multiplex. In Barcelona, Spain, AMC is putting the finishing touches on a 20-screen outlet in a megamall of 220 stores and restaurants on the site of a former locomotive works. In Manchester, England, developers are transforming a disused cotton mill into a shopping mall anchored by a multiplex.
Investors are not lacking. The Barcelona project is a joint venture of Hines Interests, a Houston developer, and a French partner, Jean Louis Solal. And the biggest financial backer of the Dunkirk project was a Dutch pension fund, Wereldhave.
Little more than a decade since the European debut of the multiplex, some countries already face overbuilding.
In Belgium, for example, a battle erupted earlier this year when UGC of France announced that it would challenge a domestic company, the Kinepolis Group, on its home turf. Kinepolis pioneered the multiplex concept in 1988 with a 25-screen, 7,600-seat monster in Brussels that remains Europe's largest. UGC hopes to capture at least 20 percent of the Belgian market; Kinepolis has had well over half.
So many multiplexes have opened in Rome, where the number of screens rose in the last year to 174 from 138, that Leandro Pesci, managing director of the Safin theater chain of the Cecchi Gori Group, recently complained, "We're cannibalizing each other."
Still, none of this derailed the Dunkirk project. Among its supporters is Bernard Montet, director of retail services of the Dunkirk Chamber of Commerce, which backed the city's 1992 plan to put a stop to suburban mall development (it "sucked people out of the center," he said) and promote a big shopping center near the disused port site that would be anchored by a multiplex theater.
The idea was to create fresh retail space plus parking, so as to draw people back into the city. Four local retailers and a Virgin Superstore would move in along with five restaurants, including McDonald's and the popular French seafood chain Leon de Bruxelles.
To design the multiplex, the city sought out AMC. The French theater operator Gaumont has a multiplex in nearby Calais and did not want to create competition for its own screens. The other two big domestic multiplex developers, UGC and Pathe, a unit of Vivendi, took themselves out of the running for developer of the project because they objected to details of the financing package, which AMC was willing to accept.
Though some local retailers feared the fresh competition that the shopping center would bring, others welcomed it as a source of fresh business, Mr. Montet said.
The greatest disruption from the multiplex, of course, would be faced by the two downtown movie houses -- an eight-screen outlet along Rue Nationale and a 90-seat art house called Studio 43. So, deals needed to be struck.
Philippe Nouveau, the city's chief finance official and a supporter of the project, said the city negotiated an agreement with its owners to close the Rue Nationale outlet, called Les Arcades, and build apartments on the site.
For Studio 43, the situation was trickier. The 90-seat theater receives considerable financial support from the city and was founded in the 1960's as part of the French government's effort to sustain interest in high quality film and the national film heritage. It shows French and foreign films, organizes film seminars and visits by school classes and holds an annual film festival.
According to French law, the mall project required approval by a seven-member commission that included representatives of the national film industry.
Mr. Nouveau and other city officials sought to convince Studio 43's operators that the new multiplex would enhance film, rather than hurt it. "We argued that AMC would raise interest in films by increasing people's taste for them," Mr. Nouveau said. "Our goal, of course, was to increase business in the downtown area."
Mr. Frydman aimed to convince Studio 43 that AMC was not likely to be a fifth column for American movies: though many other multiplex operators are part of big production and distribution companies, Mr. Frydman said, AMC is solely in the business of running theaters.
Fabrice Bassemon, a program director for Studio 43, said he found himself in a quandary. The theater relies on city aid, yet the city was now also the principal promoter of the new multiplex. Indeed, the city's only other movie theater, Les Arcades, was to be sacrificed to the development plan.
In the end, Studio 43 accepted a deal: the multiplex would be built, and AMC would make several concessions to the theater. Among them was an agreement that only Studio 43 would show non-French movies, including popular American films, with the original English-language soundtrack but with French subtitles; the multiplex would show only dubbed versions. Moreover, leaflets with the Studio 43 program would be distributed at no charge at the multiplex.
Mr. Bassemon is skeptical of the long-term effects of AMC's arrival, though the development was impossible to stop because of its larger potential economic benefits.
But the accord has brought short-term benefits, he acknowledged. After all, Les Arcades, which was closed under the deal, had competed with Studio 43 because it regularly featured on two of its eight screens foreign films in the original soundtrack, with subtitles.
So, in December, while AMC showed dubbed French versions of "Sleepy Hollow" by Tim Burton and "Sweet and Lowdown," the latest from Woody Allen, Studio 43 featured them in the original soundtracks with subtitles.
"It's a little bizarre," Mr. Bassemon said, "but that's the accord."
Mr. Frydman says patience and the will to negotiate smoothed local acceptance of change. "It's a political and cultural process," he said. He paused, reflected, then added, "Can we always stop the Concorde from flying?"
