HEADLINE: Ford Posts Higher Earnings, But Shares Still Take a Hit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 26

 BODY:
A broad improvement in auto and financial operations allowed the Ford Motor Company to post slightly better earnings for the fourth quarter than financial analysts had expected, but the automaker's shares fell on fears that further profit gains might prove elusive.
Ford's profits surged in North America, despite a one-time, $103 million charge related to last autumn's labor contract with the United Automobile Workers, while the company's losses narrowed in Europe and South America. Ford Credit, the division for car loans and leases, posted a 32 percent gain in profits after several years of flat earnings. Among Ford's biggest units, only its auto parts division, Visteon, posted slightly worse results than a year earlier. 
 Altogether, Ford earned $1.81 billion, or $1.47 a share, up 73.2 percent from profits of $1.04 billion, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. The earnings per share were 2 cents better than the consensus of analysts' forecasts issued by First Call/Thomson Financial.
Even excluding one-time charges in the last quarter and a year earlier, Ford's earnings were up 14 percent. Sales rose to $44.42 billion from $37.90 billion.
But with gasoline prices climbing and with the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates further, investors began selling Ford stock this morning even as other industrial stocks were rising. Ford shares fell $2.0625, to $48, while shares of the General Motors Corporation were up 62.5 cents, at $78.5625.
A few financial analysts said they were nervous that Ford's new chief financial officer, Henry D. G. Wallace, had seemed uncomfortable with their forecasts for first-quarter earnings this year during a conference call this morning. Mr. Wallace said in an interview that he had simply pointed out that it would be harder for Ford to meet analysts' forecasts for the first quarter than for all of 2000.
"The point I was making to them was their expectations grow week by week, and were getting pretty stretchy in the first quarter," he said, adding that by "stretchy" he meant challenging. It is unclear how much effect, if any, his comments to the analysts had on the stock, which dropped more than $1 at the opening of trading and slipped further through the day.
At a news conference here this morning, Mr. Wallace said that while Ford anticipates that auto sales will be a little slower than last year's record-setting pace, the automaker also hopes to increase its share of the North American market, using recently introduced or redesigned cars like the Ford Taurus, Lincoln LS and Jaguar S-Type. The automaker has based its planning on the assumption that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates this year, he said.
Ford is carefully examining the balance sheet of Daewoo, the virtually bankrupt Korean automaker, but has not yet made a decision on whether to invest in it, Mr. Wallace said. The growing Korean auto market remains virtually closed to imports while Korean manufacturers step up their exports, to the growing irritation of Western automakers. So companies like Ford, G.M. and Renault S.A. have been trying to buy Korean automakers.
Ford earned $7.24 billion for all of last year, or $5.86 a share, on sales of $162.56 billion. In 1998, Ford reported earnings of $22.07 billion, or $17.76 a share, but this included a noncash gain of $15.96 billion from Ford's spinoff of a consumer lending unit, Associates First Capital. Auto analysts have excluded that gain in their calculations of earnings.
There had been considerable speculation that Ford might announce today the closing of one or more factories in Europe and big layoffs there. While Ford did neither, Mr. Wallace acknowledged excess capacity in Europe and the possibility of cutbacks. While Ford earned $1.58 billion in the last quarter in North America, up from $1.05 billion, it lost $55 million in Europe, still better than a $74 million loss a year earlier.
Ford fared worst in South America, although losses narrowed in the fourth quarter to $95 million from $151 million a year earlier. Ford's sales in the region dropped 24.6 percent, as its market share dwindled in a weak overall market.
Visteon earned $95 million in the fourth quarter, down from $129 million a year earlier. Mr. Wallace said the new labor agreement and lower prices hurt the parts division, but repeated that Ford plans to make it an independent company.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
Time Again for Clinton's Reinvention

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
President Clinton has used his seven State of the Union addresses to define and redefine himself in response to the shifting tenor of the times. In successive years he has been budget balancer and health care fixer, political penitent and moral preacher, master of the classroom and savior of Social Security.
As he rises from the well of the House to the rostrum on Thursday night, he will adopt yet another identity. What guise will he assume in this, his last, legacy-defining State of the Union address? 
 Mr. Clinton has used these set-piece speeches as mileposts of his political pilgrimage. It has been a patchwork progression, marked by a number of consistent themes and a few unexpected detours. The speeches have sought to reposition the president when external events like the Republican takeover of Congress in 1994 and the 1998 year of scandal have forced him to adapt to changing political realities.
In them, he has seized the high ground of principle while deftly delivering a partisan stiletto. He has made scores of promises only to come back a year later to blame his opponents for failing to deliver them. He has taken credit for Republican plans he bitterly fought. He has been bombastic and demagogic, exhausting and occasionally apologetic, and almost always highly effective.
In his first speech to a joint session of Congress, in 1993, he declared that government must do more and proposed $30 billion in new spending; three years later he proclaimed the end of the era of big government and demanded that Congress pass a balanced budget. In 1995, he said he had been humbled by the collapse of his health care plan and the public repudiation he received in the mid-term elections of 1994; a year later he gloried in his victory over Republicans in the budget battle that led to the closing of the federal government, even as he stole many of their small-government themes.
Woven through this seeming crazy quilt are the president's bedrock themes of opportunity, responsibility and community. The themes appeared in his presidential announcement speech in October 1991 and are certain to be a part of his remarks this week and in any farewell address he might give next January, aides said.
Advisers say the State of the Union is the president's most cherished public ritual. For an hour or more, Mr. Clinton commands a national television audience and dominates the House chamber, literally and figuratively, looking down upon the assemblage of lawmakers, judges, generals and diplomats.
"This is his favorite time of year," said Michael Waldman, the president's former chief speechwriter who is writing a book about his White House experiences. "He loves the policy, he loves the rewriting and rewriting, the politics and the polling and the showmanship."
It is something of an oddity that Mr. Clinton each year has delivered this address in the midst of some event that has transfixed the nation or transformed his presidency.
In 1994, the speech came the same month he was forced to approve the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate the matters known together as Whitewater. In 1995, Mr. Clinton was driven to defend his relevance as he faced a hostile new Republican Congress. Two years later, he returned in triumph after winning an overwhelming re-election victory over Bob Dole -- but had to compete for the attention of viewers with the verdict in the O. J. Simpson civil trial. In 1998, he delivered the State of the Union barely 24 hours after pronouncing one of the most memorable sentences in American politics: "I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Ms. Lewinsky." Last year, he spoke in the middle of his Senate impeachment trial.
In each instance, he has been able to capture the public's attention and, when necessary, remake himself to meet expectations. After his legislative and electoral losses of 1994, he refashioned himself from prime minister responsible for passing laws to the head of state straddling the two parties and standing above them at the apex of a political triangle. In 1998, in a very real sense, he saved his presidency by persuading the public that the Lewinsky matter was a temporary distraction from the economic and social progress the nation was making under his stewardship.
"I think what we've seen is an incredibly adaptable politician conforming to the political necessities of the time," said Ross K. Baker, professor of political science at Rutgers University.
Mr. Clinton has understood the value of the formal address to Congress from the beginning. Although he did not give a formal State of the Union speech in his first year, he did address a joint session of Congress in February 1993.
The speech was a result of a chaotic drafting process and was still being rewritten as the president went to the Capitol to deliver it. Mr. Clinton proposed nearly $500 billion in taxes and spending cuts to reverse growing federal deficits, but insisted on including new spending on children, worker training, technology and infrastructure to prepare the country for the digital economy.
The 1994 speech was memorable for Mr. Clinton's pen-waving vow to veto any health care plan that did not provide coverage for all Americans.
A year later, a sheepish Mr. Clinton acknowledged that he and Hillary Rodham Clinton "bit off more than we could chew" and proposed modest steps to remake the health care system.
The 1996 speech was a model of the "third way" approach to governing that Mr. Clinton has advocated since the Republican victories in 1994. He declared "the era of big government is over" and adopted Republican language on making government smaller and more efficient.
There were few expensive new policy proposals and a heavy emphasis on promoting family values and cleansing popular entertainment of sex and violence.
"That speech put him in a commanding position to win the 1996 election," Mr. Waldman said. "It set a pattern he's followed ever since."
Mr. Clinton used the 1997 speech to review the highlights of his first term and to declare education to be the overriding priority of his second. While Mr. Clinton has pursued several education initiatives -- smaller class sizes, construction programs, national standards -- Congress has been stingy in paying for them and his attention has wandered.
The 1998 and 1999 speeches were memorable more for their context than their content. On a blustery day in January 1998, the nation held its breath, wondering whether Mr. Clinton would survive the revelations of an affair with a White House aide.
Mr. Clinton strode to the front of the House chamber and declared that the state of the union -- and, by implication, his own -- was strong. He never once mentioned the scandal and left his audience marveling at his resilience.
"Clinton uses the State of the Union better than many of his predecessors," said Douglas Brinkley, a presidential scholar at the University of New Orleans. "I have no doubt this speech will be a great success, like most of the others. He's such a great orator. Every time you see one of these speeches, you shake your head and say, 'He could have been a great president.' "

Some goals that President Clinton has set out in past State of the Union addresses:
 
1993*: "Tonight I want to talk with you about what government can do, because I believe government must do more."
 
1994: "If you send me legislation that does not guarantee every American private health insurance that can never be taken away, you will force me to take this pen, veto the legislation, and we'll come right back here and start all over again."
 
1995: "So let this be the year we end welfare as we know it. But also let this be the year that we are all able to stop using this issue to divide America."
 
1996: "I say again: The era of big government is over. But we can't go back to the era of fending for yourself."
 
1997: "Now, looking ahead, the greatest step of all, the high threshold to the future we must now cross, and my No. 1 priority for the next four years, is to ensure that all Americans have the best education in the world."
 
1998: "Now, if we balance the budget for next year, it is projected that we'll then have a sizable surplus in the years that immediately follow. What should we do with this projected surplus? I have a simple four-word answer: Save Social Security first."
 
1999: "Our fiscal discipline gives us an unsurpassed opportunity to address a remarkable new challenge: the aging of America."
 
*Address to a joint session of Congress, Feb. 17, 1993

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Conflicting Forces Roil Treasury Market

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Yields on short-term Treasury notes rose in the bond market yesterday, while the yields on the 10-year note and the 30-year bond fell, leaving some short-term yields higher than long-term yields.
The rise in short-term yields, which came as Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve testified at his Senate hearing for re-confirmation as Fed chairman, reflects the belief that the Fed will raise short-term interest rates to slow growth and restrain inflation. The first increase is expected when Fed policy makers meet on Tuesday. 
 At the same time, the fall in longer-term yields seems to reflect confidence about the outlook for inflation in the years ahead because investors expect the central bank to act to rein price increases.
These conflicting forces are creating oddities in the Treasury market. For example, the yield on the five-year note, which rose to 6.59 percent yesterday, was above the 6.57 percent yield on the 30-year bond, which fell from 6.63 on Tuesday. The price of the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 22/32 to 946/32 . The yield on the two-year note auctioned yesterday was 6.43 percent, not far below the yield on the 30-year bond.
Longer-term rates are normally higher than shorter term rates because of the risk of rising inflation in the future. But this type of interest rate inversion is common when the Fed is trying to slow the economy by raising its short-term interest rate target, the federal funds rate.
The decline in issuance of new Treasury notes and bonds by the Treasury and the plan to buy back existing Treasury debt -- all because of the growing federal budget surplus -- are also affecting Treasury yields. The yield on the 10-year note slipped yesterday to 6.66 percent from 6.68 percent Tuesday, but is still well above the 6.57 percent yield on the 30-year bond. This is because investors are paying a premium for 30-year bonds because there are fewer such long-term maturities available now.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Holds Forth Before a Friendly Panel

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 26

 BODY:
Holding forth on subjects including the stock market, immigration, the budget surplus and his own pay, Alan Greenspan went before the Senate Banking Committee today seeking the panel's recommendation for a fourth term as chairman of the Federal Reserve.
Members of both parties heaped praise on Mr. Greenspan, 73, and predicted that his nomination would sail through the committee and be promptly confirmed by the full Senate, perhaps as soon as next week. 
 "If you were forced to narrow down the credit for the golden age that we find ourselves living in," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas and the committee's chairman, "I think there are many people who would be due credit, and there are more who would claim credit. But of those who are in a position of authority, I think your name would have to be at the top of the list."
Mr. Greenspan, in his prepared testimony, provided no insights into his thinking about the strength of the economy as the Fed prepares for a monetary policy meeting next week at which it is expected to raise interest rates.
But in response to a question from Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, Mr. Greenspan suggested that he remained concerned about the possibility of a speculative bubble in the stock market. Asked if he was troubled by a surge in investors' purchases of stock on margin -- with money borrowed from brokers -- the Fed chief said that he was, and that the Fed was studying how best to respond, especially after a sharp upturn in margin buying late last year.
"It is certainly the case that the numbers that you cite, especially for November and December, have caught our attention," Mr. Greenspan said. "They have moved up at a pace which has created a good deal of evaluation on our part and, obviously, the supervisory regulators."
But he said the central bank had no plans to raise margin requirements, a step that he said would have little effect. Instead, he said, the Fed is studying other ways of responding to the increasingly leveraged positions of some investors, although he did not specify what they might be.
"We, obviously, have also been discussing what alternatives there are," Mr. Greenspan said. "And you have to be careful. It's very easy to invent all sorts of new schemes that allegedly are going to do something and, when put into practice, turn out to be less than perfect.
"I don't want to suggest that we're about to do anything at this stage," Mr. Greenspan added, "but I would confirm that we obviously are doing a good deal of thinking about the whole process."
Asked whether increased immigration would help the labor shortage affecting some industries, Mr. Greenspan said that it could. The current unemployment rate is 4.1 percent, the lowest in 30 years, and tight labor markets are one of the Fed's main concerns as it assesses the possibility of increased inflation.
"Demand is putting very significant pressures on an ever-decreasing available supply of unemployed labor," Mr. Greenspan said. "The one obvious means that one can use to offset that is expanding the number of people we allow in, either generally or in specifically focused areas. And I do think that an appraisal of our immigration policies in this regard is really clearly on the table."
He repeated his frequent calls for Congress to avoid spending binges, especially in light of new surplus estimates from the Congressional Budget Office suggesting that legislators from the two parties could have as much as $1.9 trillion in excess revenue over the next decade.
Closer to home, Mr. Greenspan said when asked that he did not need a raise in his $140,000-a-year salary because he had already become wealthy before he took up his post in 1987. But he said that some Fed governors over the years had left the central bank because they needed to make more money, and that it would be a shame if the bank could not attract and retain the brightest people because of salary levels.

HEADLINE: John Hancock Sells Stock In a $1.7 Billion Conversion

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
John Hancock Financial Services, the 15th-largest life insurer in the United States, raised $1.734 billion in an initial sale of stock that was priced yesterday.
The sale of 102 million shares at $17 each ended 137 years of ownership of the John Hancock Mutual Insurance Company by its policyholders. Several other mutual companies, including Metropolitan Life, are expected to convert to shareholder-owned companies and sell stock in the coming months. 
 The John Hancock stock offering was by far the biggest initial public offering so far this year, but fell well short of the record $5.47 billion raised by United Parcel Service in its first sale of stock in November, according to Randall Roth of Renaissance Capital in Greenwich, Conn.
John Hancock also distributed 229.7 million shares of stock to policyholders in exchange for their ownership of the company.
A dispute concerning as much as 4 percent of the policyholders' shares threatened to interfere with the offering. But John Hancock and New York state regulators finally agreed that the shares would be held in trust until resolution of a suit brought by the Mutual of America Life Insurance Company, a New York annuities and pension-plan company that owns Hancock policies.
John Hancock indicated in securities documents that it initially hoped to sell its stock for as much as $25 a share, but earlier this month set a price range of $16 to $18.
Analysts said the price of the Hancock stock was kept down by a generally depressed market for insurance and bank stocks, partly because of rising interest rates, which tend to reduce the profits of financial services companies. While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen nearly 15 percent since the start of 1999, insurance stocks have lost 28 percent of their market value.
Some potential investors saw the low price as an incentive to buy, but others said they were more likely to see greater growth in other areas of the market. Still others said they feared that at least for the next year or so, the prices of insurance stocks might be driven down further as the other mutual companies flood the market with new shares.
"Our concern is that there is going to be a period of indigestion," said Lannie Thorndike, a manager of the Century Shares Trust, a mutual fund in Boston that invests in life insurance and banking shares.
John Hancock has been trimming its operations for greater efficiency and Larry Altman, an insurance specialist at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the consulting firm, said the company "is better equipped" than other converting mutual insurers for the intensifying competition.
Still, said Larry Mayewski, a senior analyst at A. M. Best, John Hancock may face a tough sell. "As an investor looking at insurance stocks in general," he said, "you have to ask yourself, 'Is there something about this company that makes it a better bet?' This is a tough market to enter."

HEADLINE: Word of All the Layoffs Comes as Shock toAtlanta

BYLINE: By ANNE BERRYMAN 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 26

 BODY:
The mood at Coca-Cola headquarters was somber today, according to several employees leaving the company's gated compound here, and the reverberations of the job cuts were being discussed throughout the city.
Many employees would not speak on the record to a dozen reporters waiting outside the gates this afternoon. "I still have a job and I want to keep it," one man said as he rushed past the group. 
 Another took a more upbeat view. "It's an exciting day," said Tim Jacobi, a 32-year-old marketing manager. "We're slimming down."
Mr. Jacobi, who said he had not yet heard whether his job would survive, said: "I'm young. If they lay me off, I'll move on." But he added: "For a lot of people who are being laid off, it's a terrible day. You never know."
One woman, who also insisted on anonymity, wiped a tear from her face as she left the office. "These are people's lives," she said.
"This is a shock," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta. But he added, "It's more the psychological rather than the economic impact, which shouldn't be that large."
"We're talking about 2,500 jobs. The state made 155,000 new jobs this year. Even though they're higher-paid jobs, it won't be difficult for the state to absorb the loss," he said.
The most difficulty, he said, may come for the middle management workers.
"We don't have a lot of management structures like Coke," he said. "There aren't a lot of obvious openings in other parts of the Atlanta area for them."
Coke has recently faced a racial discrimination lawsuit by a group of black employees, and, no doubt concerned about its image on racial matters, recently managed to retain its top-ranking black executive, Carl H. Ware, after offering him a newly created position. As for the layoffs, "We are going to monitor this carefully," said Cyrus Mehri, a lawyer for eight employees involved in the lawsuit.
The cuts, which Coke called a "realignment," will slash jobs through early retirement, outsourcing and layoffs. Jobs to be outsourced include those in information system support, payroll, and compensation and benefits delivery, said Ben Deutsch, a company spokesman.
Some employees were first told this morning in individual meetings whether their jobs would be cut, and others will hear later of their fates in the meetings that are expected to continue through mid-February.
"Most people will know where they stand by the middle of February," Mr. Deutsch said.
The concern about lost jobs went beyond individuals to the community of Atlanta, especially the city's arts and educational institutions, which have benefited from the charity of the company and its workers.
When asked if he thought the layoffs could hurt those institutions, Shelton Stanfill, president of the city's Woodruff Arts Center, home to the Atlanta Symphony, the High Museum of Art, the Alliance Theater Company and the Atlanta College of Art, said: "At this time I don't expect that it will. But that certainly is not beyond the realm of possibility. My guess is that it will not."
Coca-Cola, which is also the main sponsor of the Super Bowl festivities in Atlanta this week, is the city's second-largest corporate donor, giving $481,903 in 1999, behind BellSouth, at $742,431, Mr. Stanfill said.
The company's leadership in donating through the years "has just been enormous," he said. Not only the arts community, but Emory University and Agnes Scott College have benefited from the company's largesse, he noted.
When asked if the company's charities would be affected, Mr. Deutsch said, "I don't think what has happened today will have anything to do with how we view our commitment to our community here in Atlanta and communities all over the world where we operate."

HEADLINE: Freed Puerto Rican Militants Revel in Life on the Outside

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R.

 BODY:
Luis Rosa had never seen El Yunque, Puerto Rico's renowned rain forest. He had never tasted a seafood stew like the one he ate the other day or tried many of the tropical fruits people here pick from their backyard trees.
Mr. Rosa, who was born and reared in Chicago, is only now getting to know the country in whose name he took up a life of political violence as a teenager and for which he spent more than 19 years in a federal prison. 
 One of the Puerto Rican radical nationalists granted clemency by President Clinton last September in a firestorm of controversy, Mr. Rosa, 39, said he had spent much of his four months of freedom bursting into tears -- at the sight of El Yunque, hearing Puerto Rican string music, gazing at a landscape.
"It's been a real emotional experience," Mr. Rosa said. "Everything that you fought for and dedicated yourself to, you see. It's alive. It's tangible."
The 11 Puerto Rican prisoners released last year -- 5 women and 6 men -- have spent most of their time catching up with life. Some have gone to cemeteries to visit for the first time the graves of parents. Others are getting reacquainted with their children and meeting new nephews and grandchildren.
But the nine of them who decided to live in Puerto Rico -- two chose to live in Chicago -- have also experienced a "homecoming" in a country that for most of them -- whose roots were in New York and Illinois -- was until now more a cause than home. The 11 were linked to a militant group that sought independence for Puerto Rico, an American commonwealth with limited self-governing powers.
And while what they still call their armed struggle against the United States is widely condemned on this island of 3.8 million residents, many Puerto Ricans have welcomed them, some as patriots, but most as people who have been punished and deserve a second chance.
"They should not be stigmatized," said Dorlizca Irizarry, 60, who unexpectedly found eight of the former prisoners at Mass recently as guests of the Archbishop of San Juan, Roberto Gonzalez. "They should be supported so they don't fall again."
The 11 received sentences of 35 to 90 years after convictions in the early 1980's for seditious conspiracy and other charges in the plotting of bomb attacks and armed robberies to finance violent activities against the United States government.
While none were convicted of any crimes that resulted in death or injury, the 11 were accused of belonging to the Armed Forces for National Liberation, known by the Spanish initials F.A.L.N., a group that waged an armed campaign in the 1970's and 1980's to end what it saw as Puerto Rico's colonial status. Federal law-enforcement officials tied the group to more than 100 bombings in the United States and at least six deaths.
For those like Mr. Rosa, the passion for Puerto Rico developed in the neighborhoods and households of Chicago and New York City where Spanish was spoken and Puerto Rican culture nurtured. In separate interviews, Mr. Rosa and five of the other former prisoners said their political commitment had been infused by personal experiences with segregation and discrimination in the United States, and the conclusion that Puerto Rico's economic problems and the need of Puerto Ricans to migrate north stemmed from the island's status as an American possession.
"We identified the situation in Puerto Rico as the root of the problems of Puerto Ricans in the states," said Carmen Valentin, 53, a former assistant school principal in Chicago who was arrested with several of the others in a stolen van in Evanston, Ill., in 1980.
The nationalists said an armed movement seemed a logical way to advance the cause of independence in the wake of the civil rights movement and with revolutions brewing in Latin America. The view that violence was a legitimate weapon, the nationalists and other independence supporters noted, also sprang up in response to the Puerto Rican government's repression of independence efforts on the island.
This pattern of harassment was acknowledged recently when Gov. Pedro J. Rossello, of the pro-statehood New Progressive Party, publicly apologized and offered restitution of up to $6,000 each to thousands of Puerto Rican "independentistas" and others who were spied on as "subversives" by a police intelligence unit starting in the late 1940's.
Mr. Rosa, who at the time of his arrest in 1980 was a college student, said he saw violent action as a necessary propaganda tool to draw world attention to Puerto Rico. "It was louder than a march," he said.
But in the eyes of federal law-enforcement officials, victims of F.A.L.N. bombings and critics in the United States and Puerto Rico, the nationalists were nothing more than terrorists.
In granting clemency, President Clinton said he considered humanitarian factors like the severity of the sentences. (Insisting they were prisoners of war, most of the nationalists did not present a defense at their trials.) But the offer set off fierce criticism that Mr. Clinton risked reinvigorating the Puerto Rican clandestine independence movement, and speculation that the president was trying to help Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign in New York, which has a large Puerto Rican population.
Critics were also found in Puerto Rico, where independence remains the choice of less than 5 percent of the voters in referendums. Most residents are divided between maintaining the commonwealth and seeking statehood.
"The basic crime they committed was to try to impose their aspirations for Puerto Rico on the people of Puerto Rico against their will," said former Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo, the island's resident commissioner in Washington and a statehood proponent who opposed their release.
But many more Puerto Ricans seem to have found extenuating circumstances. Rigoberto Diaz Jr., 41, a banker here who also supports statehood, said he found the sentences too harsh compared with those for crimes like murder, and attributed the punishment to prejudice against Puerto Ricans in the states.
El Nuevo Dia, Puerto Rico's largest daily newspaper, refers to the group as "ex-political prisoners."
"The crime of sedition they were imprisoned for is superarchaic," Mr. Diaz said. "How can a few people overthrow the government of the United States? They conspired, but the K.K.K. and the white supremacists have done worse."
While Puerto Rico remains a commonwealth, the 11 nationalists remain fervently committed to independence.
"What justifies the struggle for independence is not its popularity but whether you're right or not," said Elizam Escobar, 51, who was born in Puerto Rico and left at 23 for New York City, where he lived when arrested. "For self-respect, we should take our destiny in our own hands."
But bombings are not an option. The 11 were required to renounce violence to be released.
The nationalists noted that there had been a surge of nationalism in Puerto Rico, more tolerance of independence sympathizers and new-found unity among the three major political parties for asserting Puerto Rican rights in the case of the United States Navy's presence in Vieques, a nearby island the Navy uses for target practice.
All that can be channeled peacefully toward a final determination on the island's political status, some of the nationalists said.
"I don't think there's support for the commonwealth as it is and there's no support in the United States Congress for statehood either," said Edwin Cortes, 44, a former claim adjuster who was arrested in 1983. "Puerto Ricans are waking up to that reality."
Under the conditions of their release, the former prisoners may not associate with one another. Only the two sisters in the group, Alicia, 46, and Ida Luz Rodriguez, 49, have been allowed to live together. They declined a request for an interview.
Some of the nationalists, most of whom are still living with relatives or friends, have adjusted better than others. Some, like Ms. Valentin, are still looking for jobs. Others, like Mr. Rosa, who earned his bachelor's degree in prison, and Ricardo Jimenez, 43, have enrolled in the University of Puerto Rico.
Mr. Escobar, a painter, and Adolfo Matos, 49, an artisan, are teaching. Mr. Cortes is a clerk in a doctor's office, and Dylcia Pagan, 53, a television producer and one of two New Yorkers in the group, is planning a documentary about her first year back in Puerto Rico and learning how to drive.
All insisted there were no regrets.
"To me it was well worth it," said Ms. Pagan, whose only son, now 21, was reared by a family in Mexico. "We've been examples of people committed to struggle. If you believe in something that much, you're prepared to suffer the consequences."

HEADLINE: Giuliani to Seek Reduction In City Income Tax Rate

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will propose a 16 percent reduction in the municipal income tax rate when he releases his new budget plan today, two of his senior advisers said late yesterday. The reduction would mean a saving of about $132 for an individual earning $40,000 a year.
The cut in the personal income tax rate is the single largest component of what Mr. Giuliani is calling a $2 billion tax reduction plan, but it would not take effect until January 2002, after the mayor leaves office. 
 Mr. Giuliani's advisers would not say yesterday how the mayor intended to cut $2 billion in taxes without sending the city into debt. His own budget staff estimated late last year that the city was at risk of a $1.95 billion budget deficit in the 2002 fiscal year, even before the mayor offered additional tax cut plans.
City Council officials suggested late yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's enthusiasm for tax cuts was inspired by his undeclared bid for the United States Senate. They also questioned whether it was responsible for the mayor to advocate tax cuts that would not take effect until after his term ended.
"It is a big win for a candidate for the U.S. Senate to offer this kind of tax cut in an election year,"said Carolyn Daly, a spokeswoman for the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone. "But you have to look at what the deficit is going to be and if we can afford it."
The mayor's staff rejected charges that Mr. Giuliani was playing politics, noting that since he came into office in 1994 he had consistently proposed budgets that included cuts in taxes, increases in spending for worthwhile programs, and strategies to eliminate any possible deficits.
"The budget is prudent in all respects, even with these $2 billion worth of tax cuts," one of the mayor's advisers said, adding that Mr. Giuliani would offer a budget plan that covered the next four fiscal years.
The robust city economy -- which helped generate a $2.6 billion surplus in the 1999 fiscal year -- has given Mr. Giuliani increased flexibility in his recent budgets. But there are several open questions facing the city that could make balancing the budget this year more challenging. Contracts with unions representing more than 150,000 city workers are expiring, and even if wage increases do not exceed the rate of inflation, it will cost the city $360 million in 2001 and $1.2 billion in 2003. The mayor will also be under pressure to increase spending on the Board of Education, which has been reducing grade-school class sizes and moving to expand kindergarten programs.
But ultimately, the budget debate this year, which formally starts with the release of the mayor's spending plan, may turn into a contest over dueling tax cut plans. Mr. Vallone, who is considering a bid for mayor, has already proposed his own tax cut agenda.
Mr. Vallone's proposal differs from what the mayor has disclosed to date, in that the Council speaker is putting the emphasis on immediate tax cuts, including extension of the city's earned-income tax credit for 600,000 households whose income is less than $30,000 a year, elimination of a mortgage recording tax for first-time homebuyers, and provision of a tax cut for senior citizens who rent out apartments.
Bruce R. Bender, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff, said that if Mr. Giuliani was so intent on reducing the municipal income tax, he should do it immediately instead of waiting until 2002.
Mr. Giuliani is advocating waiting because the cut in the personal income tax rate would automatically be accomplished in December 2001 when a tax increase imposed in 1991 expires.
The mayor's municipal income tax rate cut, costing the city government $784 million in 2002, would come on top of a reduction that took effect last year, at the initiative of the City Council. Collectively, the two cuts -- and a third approved by the state -- would mean that an individual earning $40,000 a year would see a $393 tax cut. For joint filers with two dependents earning $100,000 a year, the cumulative municipal income tax cuts would result in a saving of $1,089.
The actual personal income tax rate would go down to 3.2 percent under Mr. Giuliani's plan, compared with the current 3.8 percent rate, and the 4.46 percent rate before the previously approved cuts.

HEADLINE: Austin Journal;
Seeking High-Tech Input to Stop a Silicon Valley 2

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Like so many of his fellow dot.com millionaires in this Texas city often ranked as one of the country's best places to live, Peter Zandan regards Silicon Valley in Northern California as a nightmare of overpriced houses, horrific traffic and bad planning.
Yet as those same problems press upon Austin, a city known for its live music, Mr. Zandan and other executives in the high-tech industry are pondering a pointed question: How do we save Austin from ourselves? 
 "I would hate to see Austin become another Silicon Valley," Mr. Zandan said.
So today, Mr. Zandan, chairman of the Internet company, Zilliant and founder of IntelliQuest, and another local entrepreneur, Steve Papermaster of Agillion, sponsored a gathering of 300 local "new economy" executives not only to discuss the future of the high-tech industry in Austin but to begin addressing problems plaguing the city: traffic and sprawl, inflated housing costs, environmental strains and a growing divide between the rich and the poor.
They had these facts: Austin saw the creation of 32,000 jobs last year for a growth rate of 5.3 percent, the highest of any metropolitan area in Texas. The cost of housing has risen 71 percent since 1990. Motorists now spend an estimated 53 hours a year stuck in traffic. The infrastructure has become so taxed that the largest employer, Dell Computers, which has 27,500 workers in Central Texas, recently had to expand in Nashville rather than here.
In a way, the gathering and a televised "town meeting" on Tuesday night was part of a courting ritual between the technology industry and a larger Austin. During a question-and-answer session today, one executive told the mayor of Austin, Kirk Watson, that, in essence, it was industry's job to create wealth and government's job to deal with the incumbent problems.
"If you say to me that it is in the government's court," Mr. Watson said, "Folks, government can't take care of all the problems."
Last year, Mr. Zandan and Mr. Papermaster had organized the inaugural conference, 360.Alpha Summit, after realizing that local high-tech leaders were disconnected from one another as well as the community.
The purpose, Mr. Zandan said, was "to stir things up," and it apparently worked. When Larry R. Faulkner, president of University of Texas, responded to criticism by commenting that the university would be around a lot longer than the denizens of the technology age, he was pelted by plastic golf balls, which had been handed out to participants.
This year, the golf balls were back, but the tone for the meeting, 360.00 Summit, seemed less confrontational, perhaps in response to the growing public frustration with quality of life issues. Executives watched a video in which a teacher described her difficulty in finding an affordable place to live. They listened to motorists complain about numbing traffic delays. At the town meeting, civic leaders made it clear that the companies, as much as government, must do something to improve the quality of life. One man asked if companies would agree to a minimum $9 an hour wage, noting that many residents lived on $350 a week. A minister asked what companies would do to narrow the "digital divide" and wire the Internet into classrooms for minority students.
"If we had a silver bullet," said Tom Meredith, chief financial officer of the area's largest employer, Dell Computer, and one of the more active high-tech executives in civic affairs "we'd have already found it."
Instead, Mr. Zandan announced a new Austin Network, connecting regional technology leaders with civic and governmental officials. What he hopes, as do others, is that the same decision making and creativity that have fueled the technology boom can be applied to solving the larger community problems.
Ultimately, the high-minded intentions of the conference will seem like little more than a hollow public relations exercise if nothing happens. Mr. Meredith, for one, talked about the need for improving public schools and building light rail, the latter of which is expected to come before voters later this year.
And in the spirit of the technology age, he boiled down what needs to be done to one word: Action.

HEADLINE: Bitter Indians Let Ecuador Know Fight Isn't Over

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: LATACUNGA, Ecuador, Jan. 25

 BODY:
Last week, the Indians marched by the thousands from this Andean market town to overthrow the government in Quito. This week, with a new president in place but all their other demands unmet, those same protesters have been drifting back to the farms here, feeling defeated, angry and bitter and warning of the fire next time.
"We were betrayed by a treacherous clique of generals and admirals," Antonio Vargas, president of the Confederation of Indigenous Nationalities of Ecuador, the country's principal Indian group, said after the rapid collapse during the weekend of the three-man military-led junta of which he was also a member. "But our struggle is not over, and we may have to be even tougher when we mobilize again." 
 To this country's largely white and Spanish-speaking elite, those are powerful and disturbing words. Though the Indians here constitute about one-third of the country's 12.5 million people, they have been treated as second-class citizens, deprived of economic and educational opportunities, with their languages and culture ridiculed, for even longer than Ecuador has been a nation.
Raul Lopez, the Roman Catholic bishop in this commercial center at the foot of the towering Cotopaxi volcano, points out that not too long ago newspaper advertisements "offered haciendas for sale with Indians included, as if they were cattle or horses." But in recent years, with financial support and advice from groups in Western Europe and North America, indigneous peoples have coalesced around demands for what they call "a plurinational and multi-ethnic state" here.
Though last week's uprising was the largest and most dramatic and ambitious that Ecuadorean Indians have ever staged, it was by no means their first. Such protests have been an effective and favorite tactic of the increasingly better organized indigenous movement since 1990, when what began as a civil rights protest soon took on broader political dimensions.
"We were tired of bus drivers insulting indigenous passengers, refusing to allow them to board or telling them to take off their hats," said Cesar Umajinga, president of the Cotopaxi Indigenous and Peasant Movement, the leading Indian group here. "After several of our people died from being thrown off buses, we decided it was time to demand respect and an end to such abuses."
At a news conference with foreign reporters on Monday, Gustavo Noboa, the new president, who took power on Saturday after the collapse of the Indian-military junta, acknowledged past injustices to indigenous peoples. He promised a "dialogue" with Indian groups and expressed sympathy for many of their goals.
"The indigenous theme is longstanding and hereditary, the result of a lack of confidence," he said. "The fact is that they have been deceived for centuries and their demands are right in part."
Indians rose up last week, he said, because governments "have not kept their word" after making promises to and signing agreements with indigenous leaders like Mr. Vargas.
Other nations throughout the Andes, as well as Central America and Mexico, must also contend with restive Indian populations demanding social equality and economic opportunity. But experts on the region say that the situation here is probably worse than elsewhere precisely because of government neglect.
"Ecuador is a country that has basically forgotten about its agricultural and rural base, so conditions in the countryside have deteriorated in the last decade," said Eduardo Gamarra, director of the Latin American and Caribbean Center at Florida International University in Miami. The resulting "process of pauperization in the countryside," he added, "marginalizes indigenous people almost by definition" because of their strong links to the land.
That trend has only been accentuated by an economic crisis worse than any other this country has faced in 70 years. Inflation, at 60 percent for each of the past two years, is the highest in Latin America, the government defaulted on half its $13 billion in foreign debt four months ago, and the country's currency, the sucre, lost 67 percent of its value against the dollar in 1999 and 20 percent this month.
"The price of seed, fertilizer and insecticide is tied to the exchange rate of the dollar and has risen so high that some of us can no longer afford to plant our crops," complained Gregorio Chiguano, a 54-year-old farmer here who took part in the march on the capital last week. "But we get paid in sucres for the potatoes and other products that we grow, and so we are suffering terrible deprivation."
In an effort to address inequities, Ecuadorean governments have carried out agrarian reform programs since the 1960's. But Indians have not only ended up with most of the least fertile plots of land, many of which have now been divided up as a result of population growth to the point they are barely productive, but have also received little in the way of credit and technical help from the government.
In addition, Indian leaders from the countryside who were here today to sell their wares at a weekly market all complained that their villages were the last to receive electricity, water, telephones and sewers. Struggling to fulfill the austerity measures they have had to agree to in order to secure loans abroad, successive administrations have also reduced support for bilingual education programs for speakers of Quechua and other Indian languages.
"The situation is truly tragic," Bishop Lopez said. "The government has cut the budget for everything in the social sector in order to satisfy the demands of the International Monetary Fund and to make payments on our foreign debt."
The government's decision this month to make the American dollar the country's new currency has further fed the discontent. Indian farmers here are vehemently opposed, seeing the measure as just another scheme by bankers and businessmen to further impoverish them.
"The dollar may be fine for mestizos and the big folks, but we are peasants and do not know how to manage dollars," said Apolinario Quishpe, 51, a farmer who was another of those who made the 55-mile march on Quito. "Many of us do not know how to read and write and do not understand what this is about. We feel cheated."
Indian leaders and their supporters emphasize that their uprisings and campaigns of civil disobedience also reflect frustration with the nature of the political process here. Though candidates on the right as well as the left say they are concerned about advancing Indian interests and rights, no Indian has ever held a cabinet post, they complained, and until very recently few had been elected to Congress.
"One thing about Ecuador that has always struck me is that the Indians are not treated very well by white society," Dr. Gamarra said. "Political parties spend very little effort to work with them, and whatever representation occurs is usually done in a very patrimonial way. They don't really have a voice or a party of their own."
Indian leaders here say that their unexpected alliance with the military, though temporarily unsuccessful, has gained them new respect as a political force. But Bishop Lopez argues that last week's coup and its chaotic aftermath are better seen as a setback for the indigenous cause.
"By trying to achieve an unreachable utopia, they have deeply angered and frightened the Ecuadorean population, which had been sympathetic to many of their demands," he said. "They broke with the rules of the Constitution, and that has cost them a lot of support."
The Indigenous Parliament that represents the country's Indian peoples is to meet here this week to try to draw lessons from the failed uprising, devise a new strategy and prepare an agenda for the next round of negotiations with the government, scheduled to begin next week. But Mr. Umajinga warned that "we are tired of being marginalized and treated as orphans by the government" and said the day might soon come when the talking would have to end.
"This was not an armed uprising, and that may have been a mistake that will have to rectified in the future," he said. "We do not even have weapons, and this is not the time to take up arms. But I want to tell you clearly and emphatically that if this system is not changed in the next five years, then you are going to see our people take up arms."

HEADLINE: Coca-Cola to Cut 20% of Its Staff AfterWoes at Home and Abroad

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Humbled by a year of problems at home and abroad, Coca-Cola said yesterday that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or a fifth of its global work force of 30,000, in the biggest reductions ever by the company.
Word of the job losses reverberated around the company's headquarters in Atlanta, where Coke images dot the skyline from billboards to the baseball stadium, and where the company is long identified with success both personal and collective. About 2,500 employees, or nearly half the people at Coke's gleaming downtown complex, will be let go. 
 "There was a lot of crying today," said one employee as she left through the iron gates of the company compound. "A lot of people are packing up." The company, which has been known for generous benefits, job security and unflagging optimism about its future, said some employees were notified yesterday, and others would be by the end of next month.
The last time Coca-Cola laid off workers was in 1988, when 200 people lost their jobs.
The impact on the Atlanta economy is not expected to be severe. "It's more the psychological rather than the economic impact, which shouldn't be that large," said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University in Atlanta.
To cover severance packages and other costs related to the cuts, the company will take an $800 million charge against its earnings this year. In addition, Coke announced an $813 million charge for the fourth quarter of last year to cover costs of its poorly performing plants in Russia and Eastern Europe. Indicating all its problems are not past, the company said bottlers in several key markets would buy less concentrate this year to reduce bloated inventories.
"The world in which we operate has changed dramatically, and we must change to succeed," Douglas N. Daft, Coke's newly designated chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. Since being named to the top job last month, he has moved quickly to decentralize operations and make Coke more responsive to its various markets around the world. He is replacing M. Douglas Ivester, who lasted barely two years and whose tenure was marked by falling profits and image problems around the world.
Through most of the 1990's, Coke was a paragon of success among globe-trotting American consumer-products companies, and it stuck resolutely to its strategy even as its profits eroded over the last two years. Many of its difficulties can be traced to regional economic woes.
But the reorganization announced yesterday was interpreted by some stock analysts and investors as Coca-Cola's tacit admission that it had blundered badly, overinvesting in some markets and failing to streamline its operations for too long.
"It's not just a small, insignificant number -- it's $1.6 billion," said Marc Cohen, a beverage stocks analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company, of the two charges for job and inventory reductions.
Sweeping moves to clear away problems are typical when a new executive takes over. The practice helps make future quarters look better in comparison, and it often gives a company's stock price a lift. Coke said yesterday that it expected savings of $300 million a year from the job cuts and related moves. Though the stock rose early on the company's scheduled earnings report, it fell $2.8125 a share on the day, to close at $63.0625.
While job reductions had been predicted, the cuts were much greater than expected. Indicating their seriousness, Mr. Daft and other senior managers discussed the moves in a morning conference call with Wall Street analysts and investors -- the first call of its kind for Coca-Cola, analysts said. Coke said that after a six-month review of the entire company, it had decided to eliminate departments that were not central to the company's objectives.
"What we are going to be doing is centering our activity on marketing and on meeting the needs of customers and consumers," Jack L. Stahl, who was named company president last week, said in an interview later in the day. "We said, gee, what kind of company do we want to be? We started that way, as opposed to setting a target on cuts."
Although the changes are radical -- the company also plans to transfer many responsibilities formerly handled by executives in Atlanta to local managers -- they left some investors wondering what else was to come.
One money manager said he sold his entire stake in Coca-Cola after reading the company's statement before the opening bell on Wall Street. "For the last 10 years, everything seemed to go right for Coca-Cola," said Fredric E. Russell, whose fund in Tulsa, Okla., had 70,000 Coca-Cola shares until yesterday. "Now there is a recognition that those years may have been unusual, and we can't count on the same volume growth and the same returns on equity."
Some of the volume growth reported in past years is now suspect because of the company's announcement that bottlers in Japan, Germany and Eastern Europe would reduce their inventories, said Andrew J. Conway, a beverage analyst for Morgan Stanley. While Canada and the United States account for about 27 percent of profits, Japan generates 20 percent. Germany is Coke's fourth-largest market.
"The biggest surprise is that they are taking down their inventory levels, which implies that they overstated their earnings growth between 1997 and last year," Mr. Conway said. "What's to stop them from doing it again? This is a very negative development because it pushes the improvement of Coke's returns further out into the future." The reduced purchasing by bottlers is expected to trim earnings by 11 cents to 13 cents a share in the first half of this year, the company said.
"This move is intended to take bottler inventories to their optimal level, which will help bottlers free up working capital and assist in increasing their returns on invested capital," said a Coke spokesman, Ben Deutsch.
After the company's announcement, it was clear that this would be the third consecutive year of disappointing results, instead of the "year of recovery" that Mr. Daft had promised when he was named to Coke's top job last month.
The charge against earnings in the last quarter are for losses on investments in Russia and the Baltic countries, but many expect additional charges related to India. Coke management is still assessing conditions there, and in other parts of the world.
What also troubled some listeners was that Mr. Daft indicated during the conference call that Coke's growth targets for both its sales and earnings would have to be revised, Mr. Cohen said. "He indicated that the long-term growth goals have been too ambitious," he said.
And for this year, Mr. Daft suggested the company would earn slightly more than $1.50 a share, Mr. Cohen added. That is at the low end of the $1.50 to $1.60 range the company had estimated. "This is the 11th quarter in a row that I have cut estimates for the Coca-Cola Company," Mr. Cohen said.
Other industry experts said the reorganization was Mr. Daft's effort to put Coca-Cola back on course, after a particularly troubling year. The company had the biggest product recall in its history in June, after children in Belgium who drank Coke products said they felt ill and the contamination scare spread to France and other parts of Europe. Coke was also fined $16 million by Italian regulators over its anti-competitive marketing practices and stumbled in its efforts to acquire the Orangina and Cadbury Schweppes brands in Europe. In Atlanta, the company is facing a discrimination lawsuit, filed by eight black employees who say they were denied promotions, raises and other benefits.
"The last two years have been a pseudo-trauma for Coke on so many fronts," said Emanuel Goldman, a global consumer-products analyst for Merrill Lynch. "When it rains, it pours. But they were in a monsoon."
Moving more executives into the field, away from Atlanta, is meant to improve the company's understanding of consumers in the 200 countries where it sells its drinks. The company will also embrace local brands more than it has in the past, although it will still emphasize Coca-Cola.
"The nature and scope of these changes reflect basically what Daft wanted and what Daft believes to be good for the company," said John D. Sicher, editor of Beverage Digest, a trade publication. "It certainly makes sense for some companies to be centralized. But it really makes sense for Coke to be decentralized."
Many of the 2,500 job cuts at Coke's headquarters in Atlanta will come from departments that are being eliminated or replaced by outside companies. Others will take early retirement, the company said. Some functions, like payroll management and groundskeeping, will be awarded to other companies.
About 800 people elsewhere in the United States will be displaced, as will 2,700 people in company offices abroad, or almost 14 percent of the overseas work force of 20,000.
Because of the pending racial discrimination lawsuit, the composition of the work force before and after the cuts will certainly be closely examined by lawyers and others. Mr. Daft recently wooed back the company's highest ranking executive, Carl Ware, who had been nudged out under Mr. Ivester.
For the fourth quarter, Coke said its volume growth was slightly better than expected. The company reported that case volume increased 6 percent, although volume for the entire year grew by less than 2 percent.
For the year, per-share earnings fell 31 percent, with the $800 million charge included, to 98 cents, compared with $1.42 a year earlier. The fourth quarter produced a rare loss of 2 cents a share. Without the charge, the company would have earned 31 cents a share. In the period a year earlier, the company made 24 cents a share.
One money manager who sold all of his Coca-Cola shares at the end of last year said that the moves might bring some investors back. "It's clear that they are moving the company back in line with economic reality," said David Garza, an analyst at Roxbury Capital Management in Los Angeles. "It's back to the future. It's the new Coke, and I am starting to like it again."

HEADLINE: Mayor Claims Credit for Times Sq. Revival

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he, not his predecessor at City Hall, deserved credit for cutting the deal with the Walt Disney Company that led to the resurrection of 42nd Street and Times Square.
Mr. Giuliani's remarks in a speech to the New York Building Congress were in response to an article in The New York Times yesterday about the mayor's legacy of building and development in the city. The article said former Mayor David N. Dinkins "made the deal with Disney that led to the new Times Square." 
 Mayor Giuliani said, "The deal that was made to bring Disney to Times Square was made in my office, and announced by me." He added that the statement in The Times was the product of "either incompetence or political ideology."
On the last day of the Dinkins administration in December 1993, Deputy Mayor Barry Sullivan signed a nonbinding agreement with Disney to rebuild the New Amsterdam Theater on 42nd Street. In February 1994, the new mayor, Mr. Giuliani, stood with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo at a City Hall news conference to announce a tentative agreement with the company, and a final deal was hammered out over the next 18 months.
Over the past 18 years, two governors and three mayors -- beginning with Edward I. Koch -- have jockeyed for credit for rebuilding Times Square into a neon-infused mixture of media corporations, theaters, financial companies, restaurants and television studios.
The redevelopment project, which was led by the 42nd Street Development Corporation, a state agency, was hobbled for more than a decade by lawsuits, internal bickering and a recession. But all that changed after Disney agreed to take over the New Amsterdam, a development that subsequently attracted a host of other companies to invest in what had been a seedy district.
"It was a combined effort," said David L. Malmuth, who was general manager of Disney's development company at the time. "Dinkins was critical from the outset because we started the project working with his administration. He was personally supportive, so much so that he pushed to get the framework for a deal done by the end of 1993. Immediately afterward, Giuliani indicated that he was supportive, so there was no loss of momentum."
The Giuliani administration and Gov. George E. Pataki worked out a final deal with Disney, which was signed in July 1995. The company had insisted that the state sign deals with at least two other entertainment companies and that the city rid 42nd Street of the pornographic shops. The Giuliani administration worked with Disney to write legislation that led to the migration of the shops.
"It was Giuliani and Pataki who were there when it opened," Mr. Malmuth said, "but without the support of Dinkins and Cuomo it wouldn't have happened."
The Cuomo administration, he added, "had decided that if they could get the Disney deal, they could trigger all the other things that have since happened on 42nd Street."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Legacy: His Own Making

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Jan. 24 editorial reviewing the Clinton years bemoans President Clinton's lack of accomplishment in the area of social legislation and wonders why he could not do more despite seven years of economic prosperity and peace. But for most of his time in office, Mr. Clinton has had a mean-spirited Republican Congress whose priority was to minimize his social-welfare accomplishments, even at the expense of the American people. 
 The growing tendency of the electorate to divide the presidency and Congress among the two parties, as an illusion of checks and balances, and the inability of the two branches to compromise to meet the needs of the people, bode poorly for our future.
 
LAWRENCE J. DEUTSCH
Longboat Key, Fla., Jan. 24, 2000

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN;
Excerpts From Five Republicans' Debate in New Hampshire

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a debate involving Gary L. Bauer, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Steve Forbes, Alan Keyes and Senator John McCain of Arizona, candidates for the Republican presidential nomination, last night at the WMUR television studio in Manchester, N.H., as recorded by The New York Times. The candidates answered questions from Bernard Shaw of CNN, Karen Brown of WMUR and one another. 

MR. SHAW -- Governor Bush, if you could write a two-sentence amendment to the United States Constitution on abortion, what would it be?
MR. BUSH -- It would be that every child, born and unborn, should be protected in law and every child should be welcomed in life. I believe it's important for our party to maintain our pro-life position.
I believe it's important for the next president to recognize good people can disagree on this issue, and so the next president must elevate the issue of life to convince people of the preciousness of life, not only for the young, but for the elderly as well.
The next president must lead our country toward policies that will reduce abortions. I will sign a partial-birth abortion ban. I will promote adoption. I will promote abstinence programs in our school systems.
The life issue is a important issue for our party, and our party must not abandon our pro-life position, but we must welcome people from different persuasions into our party, or different points of view into our party. . . .
MR. FORBES -- When you ran for governor in 1994, you criticized Ann Richards for the fact that Texas had 13,000 more state employees than did New York State. Since then, the gap is now 36,000. Texas has 36,000 more employees than the state of New York does, state level. Under your leadership spending has gone up 36 percent, almost twice the rate of the Clinton-Gore administration. On your so-called tax cut, your own budget director said that 6 out of 10 Texans did not get a tax cut in this last round. . . . What can you tell the people of New Hampshire and of America that you won't do in Washington what you've done in Texas?
MR. BUSH -- So many half stories, so little time.
Let's start with education. People who've looked at the state of Texas have consistently said that because we have set high standards, abolished social promotion, got a vibrant charter school movement, have got a public school choice movement, that we're making the best progress in the nation for improvement among minority students. . . .
In terms of the budget, I've slowed the rate of growth down. And when you take out population growth and inflation, it's by far the slowest rate of growth ever in my state's history. In terms of tax cuts, I not only led our state to a billion-dollar tax cut in '97, I led our state to a $2 billion tax cut in 1999, real meaningful tax cuts.
But I guess the way to answer your question is, you know, the people of Texas took a look at my record. The second biggest state in the union, a mighty important electoral state for any Republican running for president and they said, Mr. Governor, we accept your record, and they overwhelmingly voted me back into office. I nearly got 70 percent of the vote. . . .
MR. BAUER -- Steve, . . . will you repeal most-favored-nation status for China? I will in my first week in office.
MR. FORBES -- . . . I believe that we must let the Chinese know what the rules of engagement are. If they want a prosperous relationship, they can have it. But you have to lay down the rules because then, if they break those rules, then you can take a course of action and unite this country and unite our allies. The rules of engagement would include the understanding: We'd make it clear that they cannot run us out of Asia as they're trying to do now. And they cannot use force against Taiwan. Where they've made an agreement not to use force against Taiwan, we're going to hold them to it. And that means we must rebuild our military instead of run it down and we must move ahead with the missile defense system.
On human rights abuses, we will criticize them in every international forum possible. Dissidents in China have told me and others how important that is to put the spotlight on.
In terms of trade, of course, we want trade with China, but it has to be two way. They have to genuinely reduce barriers, not the fake promises they've made to the gullible Clinton-Gore administration.
And if China wishes to pass technology on to rogue states like North Korea or to Pakistan, we should put sanctions on specific Chinese companies, particularly those controlled by the People's Liberation Army.
So you let them know what the rules are. If they don't adhere to those rules, then you take the appropriate steps, including taking trade sanctions.
MR. BAUER -- Steve, you know, you, you've done it again. You've had over a minute and 15 seconds, and you can't answer a simple question. . . . All of the things that you just said hypothetically has already been done by China. You refuse to answer a simple question. Will you repeal most-favored-nation status for China or not?
MR. FORBES -- I'm trying to make it clear, Gary, in very simple terms. If China violates those rules of engagement, when they -- now -- now that they know what they are, then trade is going to be on the table including most favored nation. And most favored nation will be withdrawn if they want that confrontation.
 A full transcript of the debate is available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/politics

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Two Democrats Fire Broadsides In Testy Debate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 26

 BODY:
Facing questions about the vigor of his campaign and under frequent attack from Vice President Al Gore, former Senator Bill Bradley attacked Mr. Gore tonight over abortion, welfare reform, health care plans that "nibble around the edges" and for working "hand in glove with special interests."
In their seventh and most combative debate, held just six days before the New Hampshire primary, Mr. Gore hammered Mr. Bradley on familiar subjects, accusing him of voting with President Ronald Reagan against children and of offering a health plan that did not do what it promised. 
 The testy, one-hour debate was punctuated with contradictions and quarrels. Each Democratic presidential candidate accused the other of conducting a negative campaign, and Mr. Bradley even raised the specter of President Richard M. Nixon. With Mr. Bradley hoping to regain his political footing and avoid a second consecutive defeat after Monday's drubbing in Iowa, his aggressiveness was particularly notable while Mr. Gore's was more familiar.
"Why should we believe that you will tell the truth as president if you won't tell the truth as a candidate?" Mr. Bradley asked. "Any politician can pick a fight, but only a leader can move a country forward."
Mr. Gore defended his record against the special interest charge when he said, "I have fought for working people against every lobby that exists in Washington." And he spoke up for President Clinton, too, saying, "People are tired of the whole discussion about the president's personal mistake. They think that by and large he has been a great president, in turning this economy around."
Abortion was the first issue joined. Even as the Republican presidential candidates are competing to assert their credentials as opponents of abortion, Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley are arguing their records as defenders of abortion rights.
The Democratic candidates' positions are now identical, favoring no change in the Roe v. Wade decision and supporting a change in the law, to require Medicaid to pay for abortions for poor women. But Mr. Bradley pointed out that National Right to Life, an advocacy group, had given Mr. Gore an 84 percent positive rating in his early years in Congress, when he opposed Medicaid abortions.
"Your campaign shouldn't go around saying that you've always been for a woman's right to choose, because the record shows you did not," Mr. Bradley said.
Mr. Gore defended himself, saying "It's true that early in my career I wrestled with the question of what kinds of exceptions should be allowed to the general rule that Medicaid should also pay for this procedure. I have come to the strong view that all women, regardless of their income, must have the right to choose, and that's my position." He added, "If you want to manufacture a distinction, O.K."
The vice president's first salvo came on an issue Mr. Bradley has tried to make his signature, a pledge to "end child poverty in America."
Mr. Gore said, "The '81 budget cuts that Ronald Reagan proposed resulted in an increase of one million children losing health care under Medicaid and one and a half million children living in poverty. Why did you support those changes?"
Mr. Bradley replied, "My job was to try to diminish the effect of those budget cuts. We succeeded in doing that. Ultimately I voted for the Reagan budget," he said. "But it was an act of leadership."
Mr. Gore then asked his rival why he had voted against the welfare overhaul, which Mr. Gore said had "moved seven million people from welfare to work."
Mr. Bradley fired back by asking "why you think it's working so well when because of welfare reform there are one million children in this country who don't have health insurance." He called the October 1996 vote to pass the bill "a gamble with kids for re-election."
"I was not willing to take that gamble," Mr. Bradley said.
As they have throughout the campaign, they quarreled about each other's health care proposals. Mr. Gore said his plan would "get to universal health care for all Americans in a step-by-step way."
Mr. Bradley replied, "You've said again tonight you're for universal health care. The problem is you don't get anywhere close to getting there. You nibble around the edges and indeed you have nothing in your budget for the next ten years to get the universal health insurance."
Mr. Gore attacked the Bradley plan, as he often has before, contending that it provided too little money to buy the insurance plans it was supposed to furnish. "People here in New Hampshire would really be left out in the cold," he said.
But the policy arguments were sedate in comparison with the personal exchanges, with Mr. Bradley comparing the vice president to Richard Nixon.
Mr. Gore accused him of negative campaigning and said, "If you're going to talk about a higher standard, live by it."
Mr. Bradley said, "When Al accuses me of negative campaigning, that reminds me of the story about Richard Nixon. They said Richard Nixon is the kind of politician who would chop down a tree, then stand on the stump and give a speech about conservation. It just won't wash."
Mr. Bradley then quoted a Boston Globe article saying Mr. Gore was the favorite of lobbyists. He asked, "How can you be fighting for the people when you're working hand in glove with the special interests who are fighting against the people?"
The vice president replied, "If that's not negative, I don't know what it is. You know, I have never been afraid to stand up to the special interests."
"I have fought for working people against every lobby that exists in Washington for 23 years now," Mr. Gore added. "I have fought for the people."
Mr. Bradley answered that all Mr. Gore offered was "politics as usual." He said, "And that's a thousand promises and a thousand attacks. Promised to every little special interest group, attack, attack, attack every day. That's been the nature of it. And quite frankly, I think the people are fed up with it, but from your standpoint, nothing is changed, the lobbyists are still in charge in Washington."
