HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Not X'es, Not O's, It's the Dot-Coms That Matter

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Whether or not Super Bowl XXXIV is remembered for the game that the St. Louis Rams and the Tennessee Titans play on Sunday, it will certainly enter the annals of advertising as Dot-Com Bowl I.
But will consumers recall the commercial assault as a dot-comedy of errors or as a turning point for dot-coms on the road to respectability? That's the $135 million question -- the approximate cost of all the commercials to run during the game. 
 Seventeen of the 30-plus companies spending record sums to buy commercial time during the game to generate attention and awareness will be Web sites and electronic commerce entrepreneurs with unfamiliar names like Computer.com, Epidemic.com, Healtheon/ WebMD, Lifeminders.com, Netpliance.com, OurBeginning.com, Oxygen Media and Pets.com. Many have never advertised anywhere before, much less on a Super Bowl, the premier event on the Madison Avenue calendar.
By comparison, only three dot-coms advertised on the Super Bowl last year. The goal of the newcomers is to duplicate the success enjoyed by the dot-coms in 1999; two, Hotjobs.com and the Monster.com unit of TMP Worldwide, are returning to see if lightning can strike twice.
The stakes have never been higher for companies gambling that the value of the impressions they make by exposing themselves to the 130 million or so Americans watching the game -- typically the largest audience of the year for any television program -- will justify the high cost of commercial time. The biggest threat is that consumers will be unable to distinguish one dot-com from another, turning what was intended as a shrewd strategy to be noticed into a marketing blunder.
"The dot-coms could negate each other and have a hard time cutting through," said Robert Lachky, vice president for brand management at Anheuser-Busch in St. Louis, the only beer advertiser during the game.
"For us, the leader in our industry, coming off a record year, the Super Bowl is money well spent," he added. "For the dot-coms, the issue is who will have a distinctly branded message." Anheuser-Busch is paying an estimated $17 million to run commercials in every quarter for Budweiser and Bud Light beers -- almost $30 million if production, agency and other costs are included.
"The Super Bowl is a tough place to stand out, period," said Ted Sann, co-chief executive and chief creative officer at the BBDO New York unit of BBDO Worldwide, the Omnicom Group agency that is creating Super Sunday spots for Federal Express; Mountain Dew, the soft drink sold by the Pepsi-Cola division of PepsiCo, and Visa.
Mr. Sann continued: "I was in San Francisco a month ago, driving up 101, and there was a billboard every two feet for a dot-com. It was a blur. If it's a blur on the Super Bowl, you're going to be throwing your money away."
Advertisers, dot-coms or not-coms, are spending an average of about $2.2 million for each 30-second spot -- a heart-stopping $73,333 a second. That's 37.5 percent more than a 30-second commercial cost during Super Bowl XXXIII in 1999 and is believed to be the largest year-to-year increase ever.
The demand from dot-coms, amplified by the booming economy, led ABC to charge the record rates; some spots sold for as much as $3 million apiece.
Some see the dot-com stampede as the logical extension of the race into traditional media by Internet marketers, a phenomenon that anyone who watched television, listened to the radio or read a newspaper between Halloween and Christmas could not help but notice.
The frenetic demand for commercial time in the fourth quarter of the Super Bowl game was initially perceived as "a one-trick pony," said Marv Goldsmith, president for sales and marketing at the ABC Television Network in New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company. "But now we're going to have the highest gross in the history of our company for a first quarter," fueled by the superior Super Bowl ad sales.
"The dot-coms are coming in as strong as they are for the same reason as our basic, bedrock advertisers," Mr. Goldsmith said, "to build brand awareness, to introduce new campaigns."
"I'd like to have a Super Bowl once a month," he added.
But others worry that the dot-com mania is a sign of outlandish excess in the way that wild gyrations in the prices of mediocre stocks are a sign of a market top. They wonder whether this might signal the beginning of the end of the widespread presence of Internet marketers in mass-media advertising.
"A lot of these companies we haven't heard a lot about," said Norm Rickeman, partner in the media and entertainment group at Andersen Consulting in Minneapolis. "They want to get their names out there, make a big splash."
He questioned the wisdom of this strategy for some dot-coms.
"What if the commercial drives someone to a site and the experience is not what it should be?" Mr. Rickeman asked. "If you don't deliver, maybe you would have been better off spending the $3 million" on improving the computer user's experience at the site.
Other signs indicate that some players in Dot-Com Bowl I might not be ready for prime time.
For instance, executives at Lifeminders.com, which offers a personalized e-mail service, decided to buy Super Bowl time in late November. But their agency refused to create a spot, complaining that there wasn't enough time to produce anything worth running on such a big event.
"It's not to say you can't do things fast, but we didn't feel comfortable that we could deliver our best product," said David Lubars, co-president and creative director at Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, the Lifeminders.com agency. "It was not in our best interest, or the client's."
So the Lifeminders.com executives made a low-budget spot on their own. Crude type on screen proclaims, "This is the worst commercial on the Super Bowl."
Many dot-coms may be vying for that dubious distinction, and not on purpose.
"If you're putting a disproportionate amount of your ad spending behind a Super Bowl commercial, and you're just putting your name out there without saying what kind of company you are, it's not enough," said G. Michael Sievert, vice president for marketing at the E*Trade Group, the online brokerage firm, which will run three commercials during the game and be the first dot-com to sponsor a Super Bowl halftime show.
"As people focus on dot-coms, it plays to our advantage," Mr. Sievert asserted, "because we've been pounding away at our message, the value of taking charge of your own financial future, for a long time" -- well, a long time in Internet time, since September 1998.
"For a lot of these companies, the Super Bowl might work," he added, "and it might not." The E*Trade spots, part of an offbeat campaign by Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, an Omnicom agency, include one mocking the expectations for Super Bowl commercials. The deliberately amateurish spot, featuring a monkey, ends with this cheeky rejoinder: "Well, we just wasted two million bucks. What are you doing with your money?"
One dot-com, Computer.com, is spending more than half the $5.8 million that it raised during its initial round of venture capital financing to run three commercials before and during the game to promote the start-up of its Web site, which is aimed at novice computer users. The spots were created by Merkley Newman Harty in New York, part of Omnicom.
"I had to write the check, so I took a big, deep breath," said Mike Ford, president at Computer.com in Maynard, Mass., "but it's the only day of the year when everybody watches the commercials."
Mike Zapolin, chief executive at Computer.com, chimed in: "Since our idea is to make computing easy for the 80 percent of the people who say they don't feel comfortable with technology, we're talking to a huge number of people. And the Super Bowl gives you 100 million-plus people watching your commercial in a positive environment."
That appealed even to dot-coms that, unlike Computer.com, are seeking more sophisticated consumers.
"It's certainly the largest audience we've ever reached," said Randy Kilgore, executive director for marketing and sales at The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition in New York, a unit of Dow Jones & Company, that will run a commercial for WSJ.com by Arnold Communications in Boston, part of Snyder Communications.
Being one of many dot-com advertisers, said Neil Budde, editor and publisher at WSJ.com, "actually helps show the brand is part of the dot-com world, a big player in the dot-com space."
Conventional advertisers appear to be comfortable with so much dot-company. "We've got to stand out regardless of who else is advertising," said Dawn Hudson, senior vice president for strategy and marketing at the Pepsi-Cola Company in Purchase, N.Y. The company will run two spots for Mountain Dew by BBDO New York during the game.
"The dot-coms, like any packaged goods marketer, have to be remembered and give the broad audience an idea of what their brands are about," she said. "The only difference is the consumer isn't bumping into them in the supermarket, so the better dot-com commercials will give viewers a feeling of what the site experience is."

HEADLINE: Orders for Durable Goods Post Sharp Gain

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
A leap in demand for airplanes and electronic equipment pushed up orders for big-ticket goods by 4.1 percent in December, helping manufacturers to their best year since 1997.
For all of 1999, orders for durable goods -- items expected to last at least three years -- rose 7.1 percent. The performance matched the annual gain recorded two years ago and followed a 3.6 percent increase in 1998, the Commerce Department said today. 
 "The numbers clearly show that the manufacturing sector is very healthy right now," said David Huether, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
Economists said the strong showing for the year and for December largely reflected the vibrant economy that is behind the strong demand from American businesses and consumers for expensive manufactured goods, particularly high-technology and other types of equipment that allow companies to become more productive.
"Factory activity remains unquestionably robust," Stan Shipley, an economist for Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
In another report, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said the home ownership rate hit a record annual high of 66.8 percent in 1999. Plentiful jobs, rising incomes, stock market gains and low inflation have put Americans in the buying mood, economists said. In 1998, the rate was 66.3 percent.
The bigger-than-expected 4.1 percent increase in durable-goods orders in December was the best showing since July and increased orders to a seasonally adjusted $212.9 billion. Many analysts had forecast a 0.8 percent rise. In November, orders rose 1 percent.
A 16.2 percent jump in orders for transportation equipment, the largest since August 1998, contributed to the big increase in December's overall rise in durable goods orders. Transportation equipment, including cars, had gains across the board but the sector was led by strong demand for airplanes and aircraft parts.
Paul Taylor, economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association, said his industry sold an all-time high of nearly 17 million cars and light trucks in 1999. Sales in 2000 are expected to be slightly lower but still remain at brisk levels, he said.
Excluding the volatile transportation sector, overall durable goods orders grew 0.7 percent last month.
Orders for electronic and other electrical equipment, including semiconductors, circuit boards, telecommunications equipment and home appliances, rose by 4.6 percent, another factor behind last month's surge in overall orders. Orders for this sector have been up in six of the last seven months.
But orders for industrial machinery, including computers and machine tools, which have been down in six of the last eight months, fell 4.2 percent in December.
Separately, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose by 1,000 last week, to 266,000. Even with the small gain, the low level of claims indicates that employers are having trouble finding workers to fill job openings.

HEADLINE: Havana Journal;
On Show in Cuba: Marvels of American Medicine

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Toting bags bulging with everything from slick brochures for sophisticated surgical equipment to packets of Pepto-Bismol, crowds of Cuban doctors, nurses and technicians strolled along the red-carpeted aisles of the first American trade show here since the United States imposed an economic embargo four decades ago.
Sure, the whole affair could have been limited to the handful of Cuban officials actually responsible for purchasing medical products. But many of the 8,000 medical professionals expected to attend the United States Health Care Exhibition were eager to participate in a curious encounter that was part seminar on modern medical knowledge, part window-shopping for American medical devices and part political opening. 
 In some ways the scene at the Pabexpo Convention Center -- with Cuban doctors calmly talking shop with American sales representatives -- was oddly juxtaposed with the Cuban government's recent clamor for the return of the 6-year-old refugee Elian Gonzalez. The American executives, in turn, expected few quick deals, if any, because of the intricate regulations governing the embargo.
The exhibition is the latest small gesture, like last year's visit of the governor of Illinois to explore agricultural exports, where politicians and businesspeople seek to raise awareness of opportunities with the ultimate goal of lifting the embargo that has yet to topple President Fidel Castro.
"Why should we lose out?" said Tony DeLio, the president of ADM Nutraceutical, a division of Archer Daniels Midland, a sponsor of the exhibition. "The economic embargo has not worked. It has not accomplished its political objectives. Opening up trade and normalizing relations with Cuba would be in the best interests of America economically and politically. We trade openly with Vietnam, with whom we had a war."
Working for the Cuban health care system, which is an often-invoked accomplishment of the very revolution that eventually provoked the embargo, the Cubans crowded around demonstrations of optical equipment, tried on leg braces and chatted about the latest technologies and techniques that remain tantalizingly beyond their reach.
"Now we only need two things," concluded one Cuban as he left the exhibition hall. "More equipment. And the money to buy it."
Both things are in short supply here, ever since the collapse of the Soviet Union pushed Cuba into an economic slide from which it has yet to recover fully. Replacement parts for medical equipment can be scarce, as are some medicines at pharmacies. Cubans with relatives in the United States treasure their regular shipments of vitamins and aspirin, poring over bottle labels as if they were deciphering scriptures.
Medical goods and food are eligible for sale despite the embargo because they are considered humanitarian aid. American officials said that in the last 18 months they had licensed $45 million in medical sales to Cuba, although that only means companies were approved to begin negotiations. They said they did not know how many sales had taken place, but Cuban officials insisted none had because the deals fell through after delays or because financing or transport could not be obtained.
Cuban officials chafe at other American regulations, like the requirement to document that medicines and equipment supplies have not been used to treat foreigners and hence earn hard currency from hospital charges.
"How can I ensure that every patient is a Cuban?" said Rodrigo Alvarez Cambras, the director of the Frank Pais International Orthopedic Complex, where almost a third of
the patients are indeed foreigners. "They want a clinical history. That is crazy. If we pay for it, what does it matter if we give it to a Cuban or a foreigner? If you get hurt and come here, do I have to say to you I cannot help you and let you die?"
Most of the American products the executives brought here with them -- bandages, vitamins and, in one case, a $365,000 radiation therapy device -- will be donated as a gesture of good will, not to mention brand awareness and a first step toward the day when business and diplomatic relations between the two countries are normalized.
Befitting a medical show, several executives said that would come only through "the biological solution," a thinly veiled allusion to the aging Mr. Castro.
"This is a learning experience," said Jeff Dziura, the director of international sales for the Ferris Mfg. Corporation, a wound-care products company in suburban Chicago. "You have to test the water whether you make a deal or not. Things change politically. That's the beauty of international trade. A lot of people in the States are afraid of it. But if you have action in many countries, when one country is suffering problems you can enjoy prosperity in another part of the world. You spread your risks."
Although some people noted that the companies at the show did not send any high-powered delegations, it mattered little to the Cubans. A half-dozen people waited patiently to have their vision tested, while others gingerly tasted free samples of chile without carne, made from soybeans. And while the exhibition was devoted to health, cigarette smoke wafted through the air, a reminder that American medical attitudes against smoking have yet to filter down here.
"What I have yet to see are any little pills to help me stop smoking," said Xiomara Rodriguez, as she sheepishly crushed out her cigarette in a potted plant. She said that while Cuba had made its own medical advances, in the field of natural medicines in which she works, for instance, the displays of new equipment reminded her of the gap that remained in both technology and politics.
"We hope they remove the blockade so we can get ahead," she said. "Nobody has the right to take away our right to develop. We have been trying to advance, but they do not let us."
Intent on at least advancing her own knowledge, Dr. Vilma Lisnar spent hours instead of dollars learning about physical therapy equipment, disposable syringes and nutritional supplements. At a booth sponsored by Pfizer, she discussed with a sales representative the side effects of some new antibiotics.
"This is marvelous, because in the clinic where I work we need these a lot," said Dr. Lisnar, a family doctor. "Another company had a product to improve your memory. How wonderful that would be."
Of course, in some quarters, memories of the last four decades of revolution and embargo have persisted perfectly well without it.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
'Weekend Mom' Gets the Full-Time Job

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Three years ago, Nicole E. Arzu was expecting her second child, but she received some tough news instead. Her doctors told her that her kidneys were not functioning properly. If she continued her pregnancy, they warned, her kidneys might cease processing toxins, her lungs could fill with fluid, and she could ultimately die in a way that sounded much like drowning.
But Ms. Arzu felt fine, she said, and could not imagine giving up her pregnancy. 
 "I was in major denial," said Ms. Arzu, who turns 27 on Monday. "I went and got a couple of second opinions, and third opinions, because I didn't believe it. I was supposed to be feeling so awful but I felt like I could run around the block."
Eventually, when told that she might not survive labor, and that the baby was likely to be stillborn, she relented. "It was so traumatic," she said. "For a while I felt guilty, but so many people were coming at me from different directions. People were saying, 'Live for the one you have.' "
But her illness prevented her from focusing on the one she had, her son, Paul, who was then 2. Her kidneys had deteriorated so much that she needed to undergo dialysis, an enormously time-consuming process, three times a week. Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, Ms. Arzu had to sit in a hospital room for almost three hours while tubes attached to her pumped her blood through an artificial kidney that acted as a filter. The treatment, which continues today, exhausts her so much, she said, that it is difficult for her to do anything else on those days.
While undergoing treatment, Ms. Arzu was unable to look after her son in their home in Flatbush, Brooklyn. She was single and unemployed, receiving $535 in public disability assistance, $136 in welfare support for her son and $37 worth of food stamps each month. She could not afford child care for Paul, and so he lived with her sister in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Ms. Arzu visited him on weekends.
In effect, Ms. Arzu felt as if she had lost two children because of her illness. To help her take her son back home, the city's Administration for Children's Services recommended Ms. Arzu for the Homemaker Services Program, run by the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
A free temporary child care service intended to help families in crisis, the homemaker program sent Ms. Arzu a baby sitter for her son while she was undergoing dialysis. Ms. Arzu consulted a case supervisor, and a child care provider was assigned to her. Paul was able to return home.
"Thank God," Ms. Arzu said. "I was a weekend mom, and that really bothered me. That was really, really hard, especially when he'd call and would say, 'I want to come home, Mommy.' That made it even worse, to say, 'You can't come home. I can't take care of you.' "
Serving about 500 children each year, the homemaker program is intended as a bridge to help families stay together through the toughest struggles. But not all the families are like the Arzus.
In about 60 percent of the cases, caseworkers with the Homemaker Services Program intervene when the Administration for Children's Services is on the verge of removing a child from a home because of suspected abuse or neglect. In those cases, the support is more intensive, involving counseling for family members, additional child care for the children, and training in parenting skills for the parents. For the remaining 40 percent of the program's clients, one or both parents are ill, in many cases with AIDS.
But in all cases, the program is meant to be a temporary support. "The way the caseworker explained it to me, it's to try and teach you independence," Ms. Arzu said. "They help you through the crisis and help you get back on your feet."
Ms. Arzu needed the service only until her son, now 5, began kindergarten at Public School 91 in Flatbush last fall. Still, the homemaker program sends a caseworker to check on the family about once every two months.
Now, on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays, Ms. Arzu walks her son to school, gets her treatment and has several hours in the afternoon to, as she puts it, "do the mommy thing." Without the help of the homemaker program, said Ms. Arzu, the "mommy thing" would have been out of reach.
"Just knowing that my son was home was all I ever really wanted," she said. "I believe that a child belongs with his parents, and I was very happy to see that my child was here. It was great peace of mind."

HEADLINE: Group Sues to Halt Low-Level Training Flights

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
A coalition of environmentalists, outdoorsmen and rural landowners sued the Air Force today, seeking suspension of low-level training flights that they say have gravely disrupted wildlife, livestock and recreation, especially in the wild deserts, canyons and forests of the West.
The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court here, is the most serious legal challenge so far to the Air Force's training program, which has been beset by political and legal attacks around the country. 
 From cattle ranchers in Texas and American Indians in Idaho to hikers in New Hampshire's White Mountains, complaints about fighter jets and bombers roaring overhead have steadily increased in recent years, forcing the Air Force to scramble to keep its training spaces.
Virtually every Air Force proposal to find new places to train or to expand the use of existing spaces has faced increasingly vehement local opposition, but the coalition's challenge is the first to try to suspend all low-level training.
The coalition hopes to force the Air Force to complete a broad environmental study of the impact of its training flights on wildlife, as well as on tourism and other economic activities, in areas under or near its training areas. While the Air Force has conducted limited studies for individual areas, the lawsuit accuses it of violating the National Environmental Policy Act by not studying the cumulative effects of training flights.
"The evidence has been mounting for years that these flights are not compatible with a lot of land uses," said Peter J. Galvin, a biologist with the Center for Biological Diversity, a conservation group in Tucson that is one of the plaintiffs in the suit. "And the Air Force has never studied the cumulative impact."
The case underscores the difficulties the Air Force and the other services have had competing for the nation's increasingly crowded airspace -- as well as for public lands for bombing runs and firing other weapons -- as commercial airline traffic has increased and areas that were once remote have become more populated.
The challenges have intensified since the end of the cold war. Citing national security has proved less persuasive than it once was when it comes to sonic disruptions caused by jets and other military activity.
While the lawsuit's prospects are not clear, a suspension of all training is seemingly remote. But it could force the service to conduct the broad environmental impact study, which the coalition's leaders said was their main objective.
"At least then, we would have a public process we can interact in," Mr. Galvin said.
The Air Force did not respond directly to the lawsuit, saying it would not comment on pending litigation. But officials released a statement saying that the service regularly analyzed the impact of low-level flights and that a suspension is not warranted.
"Realistic training is essential for the United States Air Force," the statement said. "It provides the combat edge that enables victory in battle and reduces American casualties."
The Air Force is not alone among the services in facing these challenges, nor is the United States the only place where citizens have taken issue with the noise -- and potential danger -- of such training.
In Puerto Rico, the Navy has become mired in a political dispute over using the island of Vieques as a bombing range. In Germany, public outrage over NATO training flights forced German pilots to train at a range in New Mexico, prompting new legal challenges from residents there.
The Air Force began a broad study of the environmental impact of low-level flights in 1988, but abandoned it and never made the results public, Mr. Galvin said. An internal Air Force memo, obtained by the coalition under the Freedom of Information Act, concluded that the study's preliminary finding "does not put the Air Force in a favorable light."
Air Force pilots fly roughly two million hours a year around the world. In the United States, aviation regulations restrict military aircraft flying faster than 250 miles an hour to proscribed routes and operating areas, forcing them to stay away from cities, for example. Some of those areas are set aside exclusively for military use, but in most, military aircraft mix with commercial airliners, though at different altitudes.
The Air Force defines "low level" as below 500 feet, and officials said that only 5 percent of its training flights dip below that. But the coalition is seeking to suspend training flights below 2,000 feet, the voluntary standard for all flights that the Federal Aviation Administration recently established for national parks and other wilderness areas.
The lawsuit claims that low-level flights "are having cumulative and synergistic environmental impacts on many facets of the nation's environment." The shock of jets soaring overhead has disrupted protected species of birds and mammals, as well as livestock, causing herds to stampede and female cattle to abort calves, it says.
The lawsuit also cites reports by the National Park Service and the Fish and Wildlife Service that raise concerns about the disruption flights cause to hikers, hunters and others in parks and wilderness areas.
"The sudden, violent aural and visual intrusions of all these low-level training flights is eroding the ability of visitors to use these sensitive public lands for the purposes for which they were set aside," it says.
Air Force spokesmen disputed the impact on wildlife or livestock. They said scientific studies had shown that animals adjusted to the noise of jets, and they noted that many of the nation's bombing ranges had attracted abundant wildlife escaping human development.

HEADLINE: '99 Profit Sharing at Ford Averages $8,000

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that its hourly workers in the United States would receive an average of $8,000 in profit sharing for 1999, topping the record $6,100 average workers got for 1998.
Ford's figure compares with an average of $1,775 that the General Motors Corporation will pay its 154,000 United States hourly work force. DaimlerChrysler A.G. has not yet announced its profit-sharing levels, but local economists have estimated that it could be $8,500 each. 
 Detroit's Big Three automakers have been reporting healthy earnings gains for 1999, the best year for United States car and truck sales. On Wednesday, Ford reported 1999 earnings of $7.2 billion, a record for any automaker.
Ford said about 109,000 unionized workers would get the checks on March 3. For the first time, the 1999 checks are going to hourly workers only. Salaried employees will receive bonuses under a new plan.
The 1999 checks are the 14th payment under the company's profit-sharing plan since it was begun in 1982. The total of the 14 average checks comes to $40,575.

HEADLINE: Gillette's Struggles Become Clear in Ear nings Decline

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Gillette not so proudly affirmed its place within the ranks of struggling consumer products companies yesterday, reporting lower sales and earnings for the fourth quarter of 1999.
Boston-based Gillette, which is best known for its razors but makes everything from Duracell batteries to Right Guard deodorant, said earnings dropped 22 percent, to $339 million, in the final three months of 1999 from $435 million a year earlier. Quarterly sales slipped about 4 percent, to $3.03 billion in 1999. 
 The earnings were 32 cents a share, in line with the expectations of Wall Street analysts.
For the year, the picture was nearly as grim. Gillette's sales fell about 2 percent, to just under $10 billion, and profits dipped 12 percent, to $1.26 billion, or $1.15 a share.
Gillette has been buffeted by the aftereffects of the economic crisis in Asia and Latin America, which caused inventories of its products to swell worldwide. Reducing those inventories lowered sales and earnings throughout 1999.
In addition, profits for the company's Braun electric razors division fell sharply last year, and sales and profits from toiletries like Right Guard remained weak. Even the Mach 3 razor, rolled out with fanfare two years ago, has not been the panacea the company hoped.
In a conference call to discuss the earnings, a Gillette spokesman said that the company believed its worst problems were behind it and that it was comfortable with analysts' estimates that its profits and sales would rebound in 2000. Analysts estimate that Gillette will earn $1.28 a share in 2000, up 10 percent from 1999.
Still, the company will probably continue to face pressure from investors to sell its weakest divisions or even to consider a merger with Procter & Gamble. Gillette officials have declined to comment on a Wall Street Journal report of an overture made by P & G.
"They've had operating problems," said Timothy Ghriskey, a senior portfolio manager at Dreyfus, which owned almost four million Gillette shares as of September 1999. "It was a very-high-valuation blue chip that has certainly come down, and I'm not surprised that Procter took a look at them."
Gillette and P & G have "the same distribution channels, the same ability to innovate on a product," he continued. "I think they could probably help each other."
Gillette has said it may sell or reorganize Braun and its stationery products division. In the most recent quarter, Braun sales fell 4 percent, and profits dropped 55 percent, while stationery sales and profits fell 17 and 89 percent, respectively. In the conference call, the company said it would decide what to do about Braun and stationery products this year.
"Gillette's got a lot to prove," said Erik Gustafson, a senior portfolio manager of Stein Roe & Farnham, which owned 1.8 million Gillette shares in September, all of which it has sold. "Unless they can prove to their investors that they can show consistent quality earnings, this stock is going nowhere."
In trading yesterday before earnings results were released, Gillette closed at $40, up 68.75 cents.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Pakistan It May Be Branded a Sponsor of Terrorism

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
The Clinton administration issued a public warning to Pakistan today that it could be branded a state sponsor of terrorism -- ending any hope for a resumption of large-scale American aid -- if the Pakistani Army continued to support terrorists blamed for the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet last month.
The administration also denounced the decision by Pakistan's new leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to require all higher court judges to swear an oath that would bar them from challenging the army. The country's chief justice refused to take the pledge earlier this week and was immediately replaced. 
 The State Department's chief spokesman, James P. Rubin, said that a possible connection between Pakistan's military and the group tied to the hijacking, Harkat ul-Mujahedeen, "is a matter of extreme concern to us -- this is an organization that we have declared a terrorist organization."
Asked at a news conference to explain the implications of a link, Mr. Rubin said that "if the secretary of state determines that a government has repeatedly provided support of international terrorism directly, then she would be prepared to designate that country as a state sponsor of terrorism."
"Any country in the world should know that if we determine that they have provided support to international terrorism on a repeated basis, that they are subject to this designation," he continued.
The remarks make official what senior administration officials have been saying privately -- that Pakistan's ties to the terrorists threaten the already turbulent relationship with the United States, once a close ally, and could produce new American sanctions. General Musharraf took power in a coup last October.
In a meeting last week in Pakistan with a delegation of senior Clinton administration officials, General Musharraf refused their request that he ban Harkat ul-Mujahedeen, a radical group seeking independence for Muslims in the disputed territory of Kashmir, officials said.
A decision by the United States to add Pakistan to its official list of nations that support terrorism -- a list that includes Iran, Iraq and Syria -- would end any lingering hope in Pakistan for the resumption of what had once been a large package of American aid.
The package, which totalled hundreds of millions of dollars a year in the late 1980's, was cut off in 1990 as a result of fears over a Pakistan program to develop nuclear weapons. Washington now provides Pakistan with only about $6 million in aid each year -- half of it for counternarcotics assistance, half for health programs for women and children.
Administration officials have also said that the United States could use its leverage in the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to cut off loans to Pakistan, although they said the administration would be reluctant to take any move that might push already impoverished Pakistan into near collapse.
American officials said that without some quick move by Pakistan to clamp down on the terrorists or to push for reform, President Clinton will bypass Pakistan during a trip to the region at the end of March that is scheduled to include India and Bangladesh. It will be the first presidential trip to the Indian subcontinent in more than two decades.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Davos Forum Opens With Qualified Exuberance

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 27

 BODY:
A year ago, when the very rich and the very powerful gathered by the ski slopes of this Swiss resort for the annual hyper-schmooze called the World Economic Forum, their gathering fell under the shadow of the financial damage in Russia and Latin America and the lingering economic weakness in much of Asia. This year, at least in the opening hours, it was feel-good time.
A survey released by PricewaterhouseCoopers today showed that 1,020 chief executives who control companies with stock worth billions were overwhelmingly optimistic about Internet-driven growth. 
 Abby Joseph Cohen, the Goldman, Sachs market strategist, said soaring United States stock prices were not overvalued and the American economy would grow, too.
As if to punctuate the initial exuberance of the conference, the Boston Philharmonic's conductor, Benjamin Zander, led participants in a rousing rendition of Beethoven's "Ode to Joy."
But if there was a looming issue to tinge the crisp, blue skies of Davos a darker shade, it was how the haves, who benefit most from the fast-moving advance of technology, would continue to do so without courting the backlash of the have-nots -- evident at the World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle.
This is not the kind of gathering where people come expecting to frame stirring resolutions. Rather, said one participant, the investment banker Udayan Bose of Lazard India Ltd., it is a place where people meet the people who will be making the deals of tomorrow.
But with a heavy lineup of politicians -- including Bill Clinton, the first American President to attend, and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain -- plus a strong sprinkling of labor leaders and rights activists invited to leaven the capitalist mix, the debate surrounding globalization's future will impinge on many among the 300 politicians, 1,200 business leaders and 400 academics, writers and others here.
"We cannot forget that we are entering this new age with a lot of unfinished business from the 20th century," said Klaus Schwab, a Swiss academic who founded the economic forum as a foundation 30 years ago and has turned it into one of the world's glittery gatherings.
Indeed, such are the worries about Seattle-style protests that the Swiss Army has been deployed in the pine-clad valley surrounding Davos and American helicopters have been seen in the skies above. "U.S. pilots practice for C-Day," said the tabloid Blick, referring to President Clinton's six-hour visit on Saturday.
Possibly seeking to stir opposition to the president's visit, anonymous hoaxers sent a forged letter to homes and hotels saying a curfew would be imposed during that time, Swiss television reported tonight. A few days ago, a projectile, described variously as a firecracker or gasoline bomb, was thrown at the bunker-like center where the forum meets.
"Globalization can be a process which can be of benefit to everybody," Mr. Schwab said. "So what we have to see here is how we can create the policies and actions in order to make sure that there are no losers of this process."
Losers are not much in evidence here. Only the wealthiest and most successful corporations are invited; their executives pay more than $20,000 to attend; and the guest list this year includes such luminaries of the markets and the Internet era as Stephen M. Case of America Online, William H. Gates of Microsoft and the financier George Soros.
Such is the draw of this gathering that the American delegation includes not only the president but Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and the White House trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky. Their presence has reinforced a trend seen by other participants in the event, once dominated by Europeans, that it has become a forum reflecting the political, technological and economic weight of the United States.
Officially, the central theme this year is supposed to be the human impact of Internet technology and biotechnology. Today's survey from PricewaterhouseCoopers, for instance, said 64 percent of chief executives who responded were "somewhat optimistic" about their companies' prospects for the next three years and 27 percent were "extremely optimistic."
But here, too, social perspectives intruded: 50 percent said they expected Internet-based business to widen the gap between the world's rich and poor. while 38 percent said the gap would narrow. Mr. Schwab urged that the Internet and biotechnology revolutions become "beneficial and acceptable to all."
And, in a statement, labor leaders from Europe and the United States -- including Bill Jordan, head of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions, and John J. Sweeney of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- urged the elite here to "commit themselves to work toward universal social justice."

HEADLINE: Euro Settles Below Dollar For First Time

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The value of Europe's single currency, the euro, plunged 1.3 percent yesterday to finish trading for the first time below the psychologically important level of $1. Since its debut, one year and 27 days ago, it has fallen 15.3 percent against the dollar.
The difference between a euro at 98.86 cents, where it was in late trading in New York yesterday, and its $1.0013 value on Wednesday is small. But the decline is an emotional blow to a currency that was expected to rally after its birth and even challenge the supremacy of the dollar. 
 "It is turning into the little currency that couldn't," said Ann Mills, senior foreign economist at Brown Brothers Harriman.
Now that the $1 level has been pierced, foreign exchange analysts expect the 11-nation currency to fall further. Some are scaling back their expectations for a rally later this year as well. Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Securities, now expects the euro to fall as low as 95 cents and bounce back by the end of the year to $1.07, instead of $1.10, as she predicted late last year.
"There is a sense that there is a policy of benign neglect," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, a consulting firm in Essex, Conn. "The Group of Seven just met and didn't mention the euro in the communique," he said, referring to the meeting of finance officials of the seven leading industrial nations.
With the break below parity, which the euro had done in intraday trading on Tuesday and Wednesday and twice more in early December, the currencies represented by the euro are at their weakest point against the dollar since the mid-1980's and earlier. This is good for American tourists, as the cost of travel to Europe becomes cheaper. But it is tough on American exporters, whose products become more expensive in Europe.
What is mystifying about the euro's decline is that the economic fundamentals are positive. The 11-nation euro bloc, known as Euroland, is growing again, albeit slowly, and inflation is low. The pace of American growth, meanwhile, is expected to slow this year, as the Federal Reserve tries to cool the economy by continuing to raise short-term interest rates.
Currencies, though, can suffer even when economic fundamentals are positive. The dollar was quite weak in 1995 and 1996, as the current economic expansion was gaining a full head of steam and the American stock market was taking off.
The euro's weakness is aggravated by its recent record. Investors who bet on it early have lost a lot of money. Those losses serve as a reminder to investors to sell quickly when the euro fails to meet expectations. "When people start to see it go down, they don't have the heart to stay with it," Ms. Mills said. The beginning of the year was particularly disappointing. The euro rose 2.7 percent as the American stock market fell. But that rally sputtered after just seven trading days, and the euro has gone downhill since.
In some ways, a weak currency is not bad right now for Euroland (Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain). It helps exports, which are critical to Europe's economic recovery, by making them less expensive abroad. A weak currency can add to inflationary pressures by making imports more expensive.
But Europe is at the beginning of an economic rebound, while the United States economy is days away from setting a record for the longest expansion in its history. This means price pressures will build more slowly in Europe than they would in the United States. In addition, unemployment remains high in Euroland, and core inflation, excluding food and energy, remains low at about 1 percent.
The benefits of a weaker euro and the dearth of inflationary pressures put the European Central Bank in a tight spot. A rate increase could help strengthen the euro. But with no hint of out-of-control price pressures, there is no strong reason to raise interest rates aggressively to curb growth. Otmar Issing, chief economist of the European Central Bank, made it clear on Wednesday that the central bank would not worry about the level of the euro unless it was adding to inflationary pressures.
"I don't think they can afford to raise interest rates," said Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston. "The economy is still too weak."
Still, many analysts expect the European Central Bank to raise short-term rates modestly this year to assure that the economic rebound does not ignite inflation. A factor in the bank's decision will be the results of key wage talks, starting with IG Metall, Germany's largest union.
Policy makers of the European Central Bank are meeting on Feb. 3 to discuss whether to raise rates. Ms. Parker of Chase Securities said that the latest fall in the euro "may mean that they do half of a percentage point instead of a quarter of a percentage point, or do it earlier." She is still expecting policy makers to wait until March before acting.
Given that United States policy makers are expected to raise the key short-term interest rate target at least a quarter-point on Wednesday, the European Central Bank may have some added pressure to respond sooner, rather than later.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE FRONT-RUNNER;
Gore Hammers Bradley As Using Negative Attack

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore continued his drumbeat against former Senator Bill Bradley today, accusing him of using negative attacks.
The Gore campaign seemed stung at Wednesday night's debate when Mr. Bradley accused Mr. Gore of lying and of distorting Mr. Bradley's record. The Gore camp was fighting assertions not only by Mr. Bradley but also by the debate moderator that Mr. Gore has been distorting Mr. Bradley's record and his health-care proposal. During the debate, Mr. Bradley compared Mr. Gore to former President Richard M. Nixon, the emblem of dishonesty in high office. 
 Speaking to about 25 employees at Silknet, a software company, Mr. Gore sharply attacked Mr. Bradley. "Regrettably, I'm not sure that Senator Bradley wants a real debate on the substance of the issues," he said.
Mr. Gore accused Mr. Bradley of contradictory behavior, of attacking while complaining of attacks. Mr. Gore then got in his own digs at Mr. Bradley, but, in one example, interpreted a statement by Mr. Bradley with words he never used. Mr. Gore referred to Mr. Bradley's statement before the Iowa caucuses that Iowa "rewards entrenched power," a reference to Mr. Gore's lock on organized labor. Today Mr. Gore said Mr. Bradley "attacked the voters by saying that they were puppets of entrenched power."
Mr. Gore added: "Now in the closing days of this contest, he has raised another phony issue, condemning negative attacks while launching negative attacks himself. I don't quite understand how someone can condemn so-called negative attacks while in the next breath launching real negative attacks."
And he continued to hammer at Mr. Bradley's proposals for Medicaid. "I am going to fight to protect Medicaid," Mr. Gore said, adding: "Senator Bradley's plan would eliminate Medicaid and replace it with an inadequate substitute. That's a fact, not a negative attack." Mr. Bradley has proposed replacing Medicaid with a larger health insurance program that would cover more people.
Mr. Gore was put on the defensive himself today in an interview with New Hampshire Public Radio. The first caller, who identified herself as Sarah in Nashua, questioned his credibility: "I watched the debate last night and I heard you say you have always supported a woman's right to choose," the caller said. "I understand if you've changed your position during your career, but I'm just having a hard -- I don't know how I can support your candidacy if you're dishonest about such an important subject and especially on national television."
Mr. Gore, who declared in the debate that he had "always been for a woman's right to choose," said that he had always supported Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. But he acknowledged that he had wrestled with the question of whether public money should be used to pay for abortions for poor women.
"I have always supported keeping abortion legal, and it's true that earlier in my career I voted to restrict the use of federal funding in some circumstances, but over the years I have come to the very strong view that federal funding should also be available, and that has been my position for quite a long time," he said.
Also in the radio interview, Mr. Gore was asked about his apparent shift away from Mr. Clinton earlier and his shift toward him now.
"First of all, we're friends, and that friendship is genuine," Mr. Gore said. "Secondly, I have been critical of the personal mistake that the president made, which I've been asked about from time to time in this campaign. Third, I have fought alongside the president for this strong economy and for the other improvements that we've seen during the Clinton/ Gore administration. And fourth, I have to win this race on my own.
"Now," he continued, "depending upon the question that's asked or the perspective of the questioner, they may focus on one of those four aspects of the relationship and not really hear the complexity of it with all four, and if they hear only that I'm running on my own, they may say, 'Oh, he's distancing himself.' If they hear I fought with President Clinton for a strong economy, they may say, 'Oh, he's embracing President Clinton.' Well, all of those things are true, but it's not true that I'm either distancing myself from him or that I am trying to run as a derivative candidate. So it's a complex relationship, just as most human relationships are."

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
A Budget That Looks Beyond the 5 Boroughs

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he was not proposing anything in his new budget "for political purposes" and was "very offended" that people could think otherwise, the response from city Democrats was a collective roll of the eyes. The mayor's budget, Democrats said, was an even more political document than usual, with an income tax cut and an aggressive stance toward unions aimed at the upstate and suburban voters Mr. Giuliani needs in his undeclared United States Senate campaign.
"Politics? What politics?" said a facetious Peter F. Vallone, the speaker of the City Council, in his reaction to Mr. Giuliani's spending plan. 
 Although budgets are always political maps in which mayors lay out their priorities and vision, Mr. Giuliani's newest spending plan, full of the surpluses of prosperous times and seemingly with something for everyone, is different from his other budgets in that it reaches beyond the five boroughs to appeal to voters statewide. The mayor's call for a 16 percent reduction in the municipal income tax rate, although benefiting city workers only, would, for example, burnish his credentials across New York as a tax-cutting Republican who understands the middle class.
"I love cutting taxes," Mr. Giuliani said, then concluded with a defense of the kind of supply side economics not usually embraced in an overwhelmingly Democratic city: "So, tax cutting can produce more revenues. You need to think about it a little, but thinking about it is really what makes for intelligent human beings." If people cannot understand the relationship between reduced taxes and an improved economy, the mayor said, "then you should be studying the economy of Cuba."
Democratic strategists generally viewed Mr. Giuliani's budget as smart Senate politics intended to put the mayor just to the right of center. "Who is he talking to when he talks tax cuts?" said Hank Sheinkopf, a Democratic political consultant. "He's not talking to Manhattan liberals, who aren't going to vote for him. He's talking to outer-borough Catholics, outer-borough ethnics. He's talking to people in the suburbs, he's talking to people in Nassau County. He's telling them he's a good manager and he shares their values."
Mr. Vallone, who said he did not oppose the income tax cut, which could take effect as early as July, also said he understood its purpose. "If it wasn't an election year, would he have mentioned it?" Mr. Vallone said. "I don't think so."
Similarly, Mr. Giuliani's proposal to give city workers wage increases based solely on merit, not across the board, will probably be seen by upstate and suburban voters as a desirable crackdown on the city's powerful unions. Mr. Giuliani was in effect saying that he is an enemy not of all teachers, just bad teachers. "The city will not agree to a single-percentage pay increase," Mr. Giuliani said. "That era is over."
He added that the city would require, in labor negotiations, that city workers be offered up to five levels of merit pay increases, including no increase at all. He also said he wanted more flexibility to remove the worst employees. Across-the-board increases, he said, mean that "the very best teacher gets the same raise as the very worst teacher," and therefore, teacher "performance descends to the lowest common denominator."
Mr. Giuliani's budget presentation was also striking for its lengthy complaint, worthy of a senator, about how much more New York State sends to Washington in federal taxes than it gets back in revenue. Quoting a study by the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat, Mr. Giuliani said the state sent $15 billion more to Washington than it got in return. He added, to no one's surprise, that states like Arkansas -- the home of his likely opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, before she moved this month to Westchester County -- end up with a surplus. "So essentially what's happening is New Yorkers are subsidizing other places," Mr. Giuliani said.
Howard Wolfson, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, responded that she had been speaking out about New York's unfair tax burden since last summer, and added, "It sounds like they're stealing a page from our playbook."
In the Senate race, Mr. Giuliani has a narrow edge over Mrs. Clinton in statewide polls, but his vulnerable areas with voters remain his policies toward the homeless and the state of the city's schools. Yesterday, the mayor offered more details on a variety of education proposals he made in his State of the City speech earlier this month, including spending $45 million to privatize failing schools and $6 million for a school voucher program. He also suggested that the city could save money by selling the Brooklyn building that houses the Board of Education's headquarters, and by reducing the school bureaucracy by 75 percent. "We're going to sell that damn building," said Mr. Giuliani, promising that the city would introduce a resolution for the sale to the board in the next few weeks.
Mr. Giuliani also said he would expand his program for the homeless, although his budget calls for only a modest increase in funds for the Department of Homeless Services, from $176 million in fiscal year 2000 to $181 million in fiscal year 2001. But Mr. Giuliani, who spent the fall defending his policies toward the city's homeless, said he was spending "significantly more on less people," and those who say the city is not compassionate are engaging in "political spin."
Mr. Giuliani added, "There are people who make their money out of the welfare industry," but as the lives of the homeless improve, their advocates "have less money, less budget, less authority, and you put them on television less, which might actually be the thing that motivates them more than anything else."

HEADLINE: Unions Call Merit Pay Proposal Unacceptable

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani outlined a bold, even radical, departure for the city's labor relations yesterday, but the city's municipal union leaders immediately denounced it, saying they could never accept his plan to replace across-the-board wage increases with merit pay.
In his annual budget address, Mr. Giuliani hailed the concept of merit pay, saying that basing wage increases solely on how well individual workers performed would be a sure-fire way to raise productivity. 
 But the city's union leaders called his proposals a betrayal, especially when he is boasting about a budget surplus and a booming economy.
Labor leaders said that basing wage increases on merit alone would divide the city's work force and anger the many workers who believed that they deserved a sizable wage increase after accepting a two-year wage freeze in their current five-year contracts. Almost all of the city's unions are to negotiate contracts with City Hall later this year.
"His proposals are outrageous," said Charles Ensley, president of the Social Service Employees Union, which represents 15,000 social workers. "Anybody who works in city government deserves a wage increase because rents and everything else goes up. It is the sacrifices and hard work of the city's employees that have led to the renaissance of this city. It would be outrageous not to reward all municipal employees."
But Mr. Giuliani asserted that the best way to raise productivity was to reward high performers with large raises, perhaps 6 percent, while giving little, perhaps a 2 percent increase, or nothing at all, to poorer performers. He said using merit pay would work especially well in the city's schools by rewarding excellent teachers.
Labor experts said a substantial number, but far from a majority, of cities with unionized work forces had contracts with some merit pay formula, but almost always on top of an across-the-board wage increase. These experts said a program like the one outlined by the mayor, without a base pay increase, was almost unheard of.
Merit pay in public-sector union contracts has had mixed results, labor experts say. Merit pay provisions encourage many employees to work harder, but these provisions can create resentment when one group of employees receives more than another.
The presidents of the teachers' union, the main police union and District Council 37, the giant municipal employees' union, all said neither they nor their members could accept a contract without an across-the-board increase.
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said she would consider a merit pay provision but only in a contract that included a general wage increase at least equal to inflation.
"I was expecting proposals like those you see in the private sector," she said. "That would be a base pay increase and on top of that some merit pay. It's almost a foregone conclusion that base pay has to keep up with inflation."
Ms. Weingarten, who is chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, which coordinates bargaining strategy for more than 200,000 municipal workers, said she was very surprised by the mayor's proposal. "Anyone who knows anything about private-sector or public-sector salary structures knows it's not done that way," she said. "I can only conclude he's doing this because he's not serious about bargaining before next November."
She said a contract without a general wage increase would make it harder for the city to attract the estimated 54,000 new teachers it has to hire over the next five years.
Charles Brecher, research director for the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-backed research group, praised the merit pay proposal. "You can pay people by their output rather than pay them for just showing up," he said. "That way, you'll get more performance out of the people you have."
But union leader after union leader attacked Mr. Giuliani's plan. "It's an unfair proposal," said Pat Lynch, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. "All New York City police officers deserve a raise. No one police officer did the job on his own. It's a team effort, and all our police officers should be rewarded, especially when you take into account what police are earning in the suburbs."
Carroll Haynes, president of a Teamsters local that represents 22,000 Housing Authority employees and other workers, said: "We took a two-year wage freeze last time to help the mayor pull the budget together. The city had 25,000 layoffs, yet we still delivered the services the city needed. That's increased productivity right there."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
If Starbucks, the Gap and the Disney store open up in a neighborhood, can residential real-estate offices be far behind?
Executives of several of New York City's major real estate brokerage concerns are scouring the West 125th Street area for office space. One of them, Charles H. Greenthal, has already established a beachhead there. 
 "For the last year, our feeling has been that Harlem is the next hot area of the city," said Joyce West, director of sales for Greenthal. "With this economy, with prices of real estate being what they are and with the scarcity of product in Manhattan, things had to expand. With the gentrification of 125th Street, we were convinced we could be pioneers in Harlem."
Greenthal, which opened its office in the Bishop building on West 125th Street next door to the Apollo Theater in August, is concentrating on four residential areas made up almost entirely of town houses: Hamilton Heights, Striver's Row, the Mount Morris Park/Marcus Garvey Park section and the area from 125th to 133rd Streets between Madison and Lenox Avenues.
The Corcoran Group, Douglas Elliman and the Halstead Property Company are planning to follow suit and are looking for offices to increase their visibility in the neighborhood.
"Harlem is a speculative opportunity for investors and owner-occupants who were not interested in it until just recently," said Clark Halstead, managing partner of the agency bearing his name. "It could be called the last frontier of gentrification. As a preservationist, I would say Harlem has wonderful bones, fabulous buildings and nice scale. And the perception is that it may be safe to live there whereas it wasn't before."
In addition, he said, "With every other part of Manhattan already gentrified, Harlem may have the last bargains on the island."
Town house prices were also cited by the chairwoman of the Corcoran Group, Barbara Corcoran, who compared parts of Harlem with such recently gentrified areas as the blocks north of Little Italy. "We discovered Harlem through our Web site about three months ago," she said. "We do a monthly report asking for data about what draws the most inquiries. Almost 30 percent were about Harlem. Most of the Web site traffic is from out of town, where people say they want to spend $350,000 to $500,000 and expect to live in a house. But I am also hearing from people who are accustomed to looking downtown, and the uptown version of NoLIta is Harlem."
Though prices may look like bargains compared with what similar town houses would fetch elsewhere in Manhattan, they have risen rapidly.
"In the almost three years I have been here, I have seen prices double," said Yvonne T. Maddox, manager of Greenthal's Harlem office and a town house specialist who previously worked in the area for two other real estate concerns. "Three years ago, you could have bought a town house on Hamilton Terrace for the high $200,000's. Today it would be somewhere between $600,000 and $750,000."
Since its opening, Ms. West said, the Greenthal office has had 126 listings and sold 12 properties.
A large town house at 417 West 144th Street that consists of a duplex plus eight apartments is on the market for $745,000. "In Midtown, that would be $2.5 million," Ms. Maddox said. Even buildings that look like burned-out shells have prices exceeding $200,000. A boarded-up building on the landmarked and largely renovated Astor Row that has a decrepit front porch, no stairs or floors, and that has been vacant so long that a tree has grown inside recently sold for $219,000.
Town houses make up most of available properties because there are few co-ops or condominiums in Harlem. That, in the eyes of Neil Binder, a principal at the Bellmarc brokerage agency, limits prospects for real-estate brokerage concerns in the area.
"Things may be happening on 125th street, but we don't believe that there is enough activity to warrant an office there, certainly not more than a small number of people," Mr. Binder said. "As we see it, the activity in the Harlem area itself is very sparse."
But his view does not jibe with that of R. Kenyatta Punter, chief executive of a Harlem concern that bears his name and president of the Greater Harlem Real Estate Board, which has 47 members from real-estate and allied fields. Mr. Punter, who has been selling homes in the area for a decade, described the competition as increasingly fierce.
"We are at a point where the supply of real estate to sell on the Upper East and West Sides is very limited and northern Manhattan presents an opportunity for expansion," he said. "None of those firms ventured north of 96th Street in the past, but developers always go where land on which to build is cheapest and right now that is northern Manhattan. There are projects on the table that will produce more than 2,000 home ownership units, including condos, co-ops, town houses and brownstones, by the third quarter of 2001."
Mr. Punter plans to add 15 sales representatives to his present force of 10. "I am looking to hire Hispanic, Asian and white brokers," he said. "I now get as many white as black clients calling and coming to open houses."
Vesta Callender, a psychotherapist who lives in Greenwich, Conn., and who has an office on West 56th Street, is looking for a house in Harlem. She is prepared to pay at least $400,000 for a building and expects to do some renovation.
"Greenwich is very nice, but I want to be involved in the resurgence of Harlem," she said.
Eight years ago, a cousin showed Ms. Callender a house with stained glass windows, a fireplace and other architectural details for $80,000. "I said I wouldn't move there until there was a Starbucks on the corner," she said. "Now, lo and behold, there it is."

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXXIV: RAMS VS. TITANS -- COUNTDOWN TO THE VAGABOND BOWL;
A Pair of Clubs That Routinely Rejected Their Fans Get Set to Tee It Up

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In the star-crossed, luxury-box, revenue-chasing world of professional sports, there is nothing so fitting as this football season's grandest spectacle, Super Bowl XXXIV, which is not sponsored by U-Haul but ought to be.
The teams vying for the National Football League championship, the Tennessee Titans and St. Louis Rams, have each relocated three times, leaving rankled fans and civic leaders in their wake in the pursuit of a publicly funded stadium. Each has an owner who could be described, charitably, as colorful. 
 The Rams' Georgia Frontiere, the only woman who is currently the principal owner of an American professional sports franchise, is a former lounge singer who inherited the team when the sixth of her seven husbands, Carroll Rosenbloom, drowned in 1979.
Asked recently if she felt bad for fans of the old Los Angeles Rams abandoned in Southern California, she replied: "The fans there are still able to watch on television. They watched on TV and didn't come to games anyway."
The Titans' owner, Bud Adams, a Texas oil man and a charter owner in the renegade American Football League, once won three division titles in four years with three different coaches and ended a stalled negotiation with a prized lineman by throwing in a herd of cattle as a signing bonus.
"We'd get them cattle, girls, whatever it took," Adams said today. "Back then, you didn't need a contract."
The Rams, by way of Cleveland and Los Angeles, and the Titans, via Houston and Memphis, meet at 6:25 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday in Atlanta's Georgia Dome. It could become a benchmark of sorts, the crowning of a Super Bowl champion that is the paragon of the modern, vagabond sports enterprise.
As the Rams and Titans have shown, the curious economics of pro football today make it possible that a franchise will flourish by choosing a smaller market, like Nashville or St. Louis, over bigger ones, like Houston and Los Angeles.
Small market teams in Major League Baseball now find it nearly impossible to compete. But in the N.F.L., smaller may be better. A city like Nashville was hungry for the status a professional team can convey, and it happily built a $292 million stadium for Adams with taxpayers' money.
Adelphia Coliseum has 144 luxury suites, the most precious commodity for a franchise owner. With billions of dollars in national television money shared equally by N.F.L. teams and a rigid salary cap restricting teams' payrolls, the rules of the game make small markets equal to their big-market brethren.
This new commercial model in sports was on exhibit last weekend, when Frontiere's Rams earned their Super Bowl berth. They did so with a victory before a sellout crowd inside the Trans World Dome, a $280 million stadium built to lure an N.F.L. franchise back to St. Louis, which had lost its Cardinals to Arizona in 1988.
"We're taking Georgia to Georgia," Rams Coach Dick Vermeil shouted to the crowd in an on-the-field ceremony. Frontiere, honored in St. Louis for bringing pro football back to the area in 1995 and for being active in a variety of philanthropic ventures, was cheered.
"She has done whatever it took to make this franchise a winner and she deserves credit for that," Vermeil said this week in Atlanta, where Frontiere has kept a low profile.
But Frontiere has been vilified in Southern California newspapers for leaving Los Angeles. But many people in Los Angeles said yesterday that they did not care about the Rams' departure.
Albert Eaton, a singer, actor and dancer, said he preferred other sports to football, but would root for the Rams on Sunday anyway.
"I guess it's an instinctive choice rather than the logical choice," he said during an interview on Wilshire Boulevard. "I don't know who the Titans are or where they're from. I guess I'm for the Rams because of the familiarity from them being here."
Asked whether people in Los Angeles were concerned that they have no football team, he said: "If they cared about football, the teams wouldn't have left."
Long before Frontiere owned the Rams, they had established a standard for the carpetbagging sports franchise. In 1946, as league champions, they deserted Cleveland and relocated to Los Angeles, where they became a Hollywood sensation.
Their star running back, Elroy (Crazy Legs) Hirsch, was recruited by movie directors, and a linebacker, Mike Henry, played Tarzan. Their quarterback, Bob Waterfield, married the starlet Jane Russell.
"Our team flights were events by themselves," quarterback Roman Gabriel said of the Rams' halcyon days. "You would just wait to see if Jane was coming."
The Rams became such a hot property that Rosenbloom, who owned the storied Baltimore Colts, swapped them for the Rams in 1972.
On April 2, 1979, the Rams were nine months away from their first Super Bowl appearance when Rosenbloom drowned while swimming in the ocean by himself. Because he was known to be a strong swimmer, there were rumors of foul play and a series of celebrated investigations, but the case was officially designated an accidental drowning.
The Rams moved from Memorial Coliseum in Los Angeles to Anaheim Stadium 35 miles away in 1980 and had several winning playoff seasons. But Frontiere fired most of her husband's football executives and her management style was erratic. She once told a gathering of fans that she consulted an astrologer on player trades.
By 1995, the Rams had lost 10 or more games for five consecutive years. Frontiere took the team to her hometown, St. Louis, where a new domed stadium awaited with a sweetheart lease.
The Rams lost far more often than they won in St. Louis, until this season's magical ride to the Super Bowl.
"It's a lesson in perseverance," Vermeil said of the Rams' saga.
Maybe, but the result in St. Louis is a misplaced mix of traditions.
Inside the Trans World Dome, there is a sort of Football Hall of Fame. But it is half St. Louis and half Rams: Hirsch, who played in Los Angeles, is next to Larry Wilson, the safety who played with the Cardinals in St. Louis. Before last Sunday's playoff game, Lawrence McCutcheon, the former Los Angeles Rams star, was a ceremonial captain on the field with Dan Dierdorf, the ex-Cardinals guard.
Whose team is this anyway?
That's today's N.F.L. You can't know your franchise's history without an atlas.
Adams knows as much. He talked today about his 40 years in pro football, making no apologies for turning his players into gypsies. They jumped from Houston to Memphis in 1997, then to Nashville's Vanderbilt University football stadium in 1998, before settling into Adelphia Coliseum this season.
"It's what we had to do," Adams said. "I didn't want to leave Houston. But we couldn't get the revenue we could with a new stadium."
While the Titans have made it to the Super Bowl -- something the Oilers never did -- Adams almost seemed to bemoan pro football's loss of innocence.
He told a story of how he negotiated with players, baiting them with stacks of money in his desk. He would place $100 bills on the top of several piles of $1 bills to coax players to sign.
Adams also used to take news media relations into his own hands. "I bashed a reporter in the jaw back in '62," he said. "You can't do that these days.
"I've seen the game change. I can't say it's changed for the worse. Because I know where we were. And look where we are now."
In Houston, where Adams's team used to be, fans of the old Oilers said they would be rooting hard for the Titans on Sunday, though not for their owner.
"I love the Oilers," said Marcus Ramirez, a patron at Champs Americana, a popular sports bar. "I hate the owner, Bud Adams. He's the one person I'd want to fire.
"You see people wearing old Oilers jackets. Until we get our own team again in Houston, everyone will be pulling out the stops for the Titans."

HEADLINE: Mayor Giuliani's Election-Year Budget

 BODY:
An ebullient Mayor Rudolph Giuliani took the press and other onlookers through an elaborate slide show of his new four-year financial plan yesterday, missing no opportunity to congratulate himself for saving New York City from the financial mess left by his predecessors. He pointed with pride to this year's $2.2 billion surplus and said his plan would keep spending growing in line with inflation, cut taxes, avoid accounting gimmicks and reform the way the city negotiates with unions.
Some of these contentions are fair. Others exaggerate. Over all, the budget he offered is responsible but flawed, with elements designed for election-year politics. The budget will surely irritate the unions. The City Council, though objecting to some of the details, will embrace many of the tax cuts and other major provisions. 
 The mayor's big news yesterday was a proposal to eliminate the 14 percent personal income tax surcharge starting as early as this year. He also called for cutting a number of business taxes, for a total tax cut that would reach $2 billion a year by 2004. The plan calls for spending more on Medicaid by enrolling more eligible families.
The most controversial provision proposed to replace across-the-board pay increases with a system of merit pay. The idea would be to offer substantial wage increases to good workers and no increases to poor workers. Details of the merit pay plan, including who would control the grading system, would be left to collective bargaining.
The proposal is both unrealistic and nakedly political, designed to appeal to conservatives and union-bashers in the upcoming senatorial campaign. The unions will not accept the proposal, and it is disruptive to introduce it into labor negotiations when the mayor is approaching the end of his time in office one way or another. It would be far better for him, in dealing with public-employee unions, to use wage increases to push for general productivity gains, as he has in the past, instead of singling out a minority of workers for merit raises.
Mr. Giuliani also wants workers to pick up some of their medical costs, as is common in private industry. Additionally, he wants the Board of Education, in return for more money, to turn over some of the city's worst-performing schools and some summer programs to private contractors, and has set aside $6 million for a school voucher program.
The budget's most serious flaw is that it leaves a long-term financial imbalance largely in place. The mayor's own projections show the city running deficits in excess of $2 billion by 2002. By cutting taxes, the plan would make those deficits worse. It proposes to use the current surplus to cover ordinary operating expenses over the next two years -- another fiscally imprudent idea. The surplus is temporary. Sound budget policy would use it to pay off debt or create a "rainy day" fund to offset the revenue loss from a future slide on Wall Street or an economic downturn. The plan does little to bring the city's long-term spending in line with expected revenues. The longer the imbalance is allowed to fester, the steeper and harsher the eventual cuts will be.
The tax cuts and tough stance toward unions will play well in Mr. Giuliani's senatorial campaign. But however well the plan serves the mayor's political ambitions, it will leave his successor with a needlessly deep financial hole.
