HEADLINE: Talks on Biotech Food Turn on a Safety Principle

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: MONTREAL, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Around midnight last night, Juan Mayr, who is chairman of the global biosafety talks here, told delegates after a long day of negotiations to go back to their hotel rooms and "dream about the precautionary approach."
It was a reference to one of the most important issues remaining in the effort to formulate the world's first treaty regulating trade in genetically modified products: Must a nation have scientific proof before it can ban a genetically engineered crop or animal? Or can it act even in the absence of scientific certainty? 
 The "precautionary principle," which allows erring on the side of safety in the absence of scientific certainty, has been enshrined in numerous environmental laws and treaties since the 1970's, but often more as a vague statement of philosophy than as a recipe for action. Depending on the outcome of negotiations here, an agreement on bio safety might contain a strong formulation authorizing the precautionary principle to be used in decision making, setting a precedent for other international agreements.
It could also set a precedent for domestic debates in the United States, where controversy over food made using biotechnology is growing. Virtually no evidence exists that such foods are harmful. But critics say there is not enough information about possible health effects, so the foods should be banned or more tightly regulated.
In negotiations over the biosafety agreement, the United States and several other big agricultural exporting nations say that incorporating the precautionary principle too strongly would allow countries to ban imports of genetically modified corn, soybeans or other crops simply based on fear or protectionism.
"There have been some proposals that we think would redefine the concept," Frank E. Loy, under secretary of state for global affairs, said today. "It would have the effect of justifying restrictions on biotechnology, including import bans, without any scientific basis."
But European countries and the developing countries, which have been pitted against the United States and a handful of its allies all week, say precaution is justified because not enough is known about the environmental effects of genetic engineering. And if a "superweed" or dangerous bacteria were to get loose in the environment, it could not be recalled like a defective car. "Countries must be able to have the freedom, the sovereign right to take precautionary measures," said Christoph Bail, the lead negotiator for the European Union. Once damage occurs, he said, "it would be too late to do anything about it."
European officials say they are not advocating abandoning an approach based on science. "You cannot take action based on just fear," said Margot Wallstrom, the environmental commissioner of the European Union. "You need some evidence, you need some scientific basis for action."
Some officials point out that the United States itself has endorsed the precautionary principle in treaties such as the Kyoto agreement on climate change. Steps are being taken to control gases that contribute to planetary warming, even though it could be argued that the evidence that such warming will occur is not conclusive.
Washington wants to make sure any agreement on biosafety does not take precedence over the World Trade Organization rules. That is because under W.T.O. rules an import can be banned only on the basis of scientific evidence.

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE UNION: THE REACTION;
Before a Word Is Uttered, G.O.P. Pounces on Clinton Speech as a Spendthrift Blueprint

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Republicans tonight criticized the agenda President Clinton outlined for his last year in office as spendthrift, and heralded their party as the true steward of fiscal responsibility, guardian of the elderly and champion of millions of uninsured Americans.
After Mr. Clinton delivered his last State of the Union address this evening, Republicans seized on its details to warn voters that Democrats could not be trusted to oversee the nation's prosperity and the federal budget surpluses that have accompanied it. 
 "The litany of spending programs the President announced tonight proves my point that if you leave a large surplus in Washington, the money will be spent on bigger government," Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican presidential front-runner, said in a statement. "The President's tax cut is too small, and it will not help the economy grow or make the tax code more fair."
Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, expressing amazement at an array of more than 60 proposed new initiatives from a $50 million plan to clean up the Great Lakes to a $20 million proposal to fight infectious diseases, said: "As Washington digs out of the latest winter blizzard, the Congress will dig out of an avalanche of presidential spending initiatives. We will sift through the president's requests and make a determination what is necessary and what is not."
The reaction from Republicans previewed the yearlong battle between the two parties over how best to use the trillions of dollars in projected surpluses, already a core theme on the campaign trail.
Both parties have vowed to protect Social Security and pay down the $3.6 trillion national debt, but Democrats would use much of the non-Social Security surplus to increase spending on domestic programs, while Republicans are eager to plow much of those monies into tax cuts.
For the televised Republican response to Mr. Clinton, party leaders picked Senators Bill Frist of Tennessee and Susan Collins of Maine, experts on health care and education, issues usually associated with Democrats. The choice underscored Republicans' desire to show a moderate face on two issues that have emerged as immensely popular with voters.
The two senators took sharply different approaches. Senator Collins never even mentioned Mr. Clinton or the more than $3 billion in education spending increases he proposed tonight. She indirectly criticized the administration for "dictating to communities how they should run their schools," advocating instead pushing for more control over education decisions to local communities.
"Republicans want what all parents want for their children's schools: more federal help but less federal interference," she said.
By contrast, Senator Frist, a doctor, repeatedly attacked Mr. Clinton's health care proposals.
"The last time he proposed a health plan was seven years ago," Mr. Frist said, referring to the ill-fated effort headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton. "And then it amounted to a federal government takeover of our entire health care system."
But Mr. Frist also edged closer to embracing a version of two Democratic health-care proposals: a patients' bill of rights that allows patients to sue their health care plan under certain conditions, and expanding Medicare to include prescription drug coverage.
"We're going to keep doctors first, lawyers second," Mr. Frist told reporters of the Republican plan to regulate health maintenance organizations.
Republicans lawmakers in tough re-election fights were quick to embrace Mr. Clinton's education and health care goals, while distancing themselves from other increases in domestic spending.
"While I am in agreement with many of his goals -- for example, improving the quality of education for our children and creating some kind of prescription drug benefit for America's seniors -- generally it is important that we restrict increases in spending, lest we seriously slow our economic growth," said Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, who is facing a tough campaign this fall.
Republicans and even many Democrats rolled their eyes at Mr. Clinton's verbosity tonight. ("Long, but strong," Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester, said of the 90-minute speech.) But virtually absent from tonight's Republican reaction was any mention of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, which dominated discussion outside the chamber at the last two State of the Union addresses.
And while most Republicans were not ready to give Bill Clinton a hearty send-off, some lawmakers held out a symbolic olive branch.
Many Republicans, including Representative David Dreier of California, cheered Mr. Clinton's support for bringing China into the World Trade Organization.
"Make no mistake," said Mr. Dreier, who heads the House Rules Committee. "Republicans will work in good faith with this president and every Democrat in Congress who puts ideas ahead of politics."

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE UNION: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Grand Ideas, Little Time

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
With one eye on his own legacy and another on the political aspirations of his vice president, President Clinton claimed credit tonight for leading the nation onto the broad uplands of unparalleled prosperity and laid out an election-year manifesto for his party.
Inevitably, he spoke of successfully crossing his bridge to the 21st century. Inevitably, he spoke at great length. Inevitably, he put some Democratic spots on Republican ideas. Inevitably, too, he set sweeping goals -- no child raised in poverty, affordable health care for everyone, a cleaner and safer planet -- without providing much of a road map toward realizing them. 
 It was Mr. Clinton's last State of the Union address -- his final crack at an annual political ritual that he loves, in part because he is so good at it. Barring some national political crisis, he will have only two more occasions before he leaves office next year to address the nation at length, rather than in the snippets that appear on television and in news articles: at this summer's Democratic National Convention and in a farewell address later.
He summed up his message in a single paragraph, just 60 words.
"We are fortunate to be alive at this moment in history," the President said as soon as the welcoming applause had died. "Never before has our nation enjoyed, at once, so much prosperity and social progress with so little internal crisis and so few external threats. Never before have we had such a blessed opportunity -- and therefore, such a profound obligation -- to build the more perfect union of our founders' dreams."
Then Mr. Clinton listed his economic achievements, as unabashedly as a salesman hawking his wares: rapid growth, low inflation, low unemployment, decreased poverty, "the first back-to-back surpluses in 42 years" and, as of next month, "the longest period of economic growth in our entire history."
Mr. Clinton spoke with all the expansiveness of a man who had hit the lottery or answered Regis Philbin's million-dollar question. With dollars cascading into the Treasury in a profusion that was unimaginable when his second term began, Mr. Clinton proposed several tax cuts -- though no across-the-board reductions of the sort espoused by the Congressional Republicans -- and substantial federal initiatives in more than a dozen fields.
He sounded more like the Bill Clinton who told Congress on Feb. 17, 1993, "Tonight I want to talk to you about what government can do, because I believe government can do more," than the Bill Clinton who declared not once but three times in his State of the Union speech on Jan. 23, 1996, that "the era of big government is over."
Republicans, including Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading contender for his party's presidential nomination, described Mr. Clinton's agenda as that of a spendthrift.
But as always, he restaked his claim to the middle ground, the political terrain where he built his political victories as he led his party back to power after 12 years of Republican control of the White House.
"We restored the vital center," Mr. Clinton said pointedly in a summary of his seven-going-on-eight years in the Oval Office, "replacing outdated ideologies with a new vision anchored in basic, enduring values: opportunity for all, responsibility from all and a community of all Americans."
Mr. Clinton, who knows a parade when he sees one approaching, leaped to the head of another one tonight. He signed on to a Republican proposal, one of several, to ease the so-called marriage penalty in the tax code, just as he had embraced other pet Republican programs -- national missile defense, a scaled-down version of the old "Star Wars" program; the balanced budget; reform of the Internal Revenue Service, and opposition to same-sex marriages.
But like many of his other initiatives, his marriage-penalty proposal had a sharp political twist, because it was aimed squarely at the poor and lower-income families. It would apply only to taxpayers who do not itemize their deductions, a provision that would exclude most mortgage-payers. Other remedies for the problem would have covered more people and cost more.
This was not only Mr. Clinton's last State of the Union address, but he took pains to note that it w as the first of the new millennium. Yet it was more matter-of-fact than some of his past efforts, with fewer rhetorical furbelows. Perhaps scholars are correct when they suggest that this president does best when he is in trouble.
At the height of the confrontation with Congress in 1996, facing what looked like a potentially difficult re-election campaign, he put himself in a commanding position for November by declaring a consensus on a number of issues that the Republicans on Capitol Hill had expected to struggle over. In 1998 and 1999, reeling from the Monica Lewinsky case, he not only delivered fluent speeches, which many had thought beyond his powers in such a fraught situation, but also reframed the budget debate by telling the Republican tax-cutters: Save Social Security first.
A different view is taken by Michael A. Waldman, a former director of speechwriting for the White House, who was involved to some degree in drafting all Mr. Clinton's State of the Union Messages.
"I really think that after the 1994 election you see an effort to reconstruct the presidency and its role through these speeches," Mr. Waldman said. "Not the heroic presidency any more that passes grand programs, but a presidency refocused on what a lot of pundits deride as small issues, but which are in part an effort to bit by bit restore people's confidence that government can do things."
That focus on the possible and the manageable, of course, seems to some a lack of vision, particularly when it comes to foreign policy.
Tonight's speech was devoid of new initiatives in that area. A series of excerpted highlights produced by the White House press office mentioned drugs and education and gun control, but included not a word about foreign affairs. The speech itself urged a new effort to close the gap between the world's have and have-nots, but proposed no new money for aid to poor nations.
Mr. Clinton emphasized the need to work to strengthen democracy in Russia rather than vigorously condemning Russian policy in Chechnya, and he devoted little time to assuaging Russian fears, shared by Western Europe, that the United States had turned its back on efforts to control nuclear arms.
Evidently, the president hopes that his role in bringing a tenuous peace to Northern Ireland and nudging Israel and Syria toward a peace agreement will be seen as his foreign policy legacy. He hoped to add luster to that in his speech tonight, while aiding the campaign of Al Gore, who stood behind him. A Gore victory would of course redound to President Clinton's credit, and it was Mr. Gore's gun control proposal, rather than that of his rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, that the president supported.
But historians increasingly see Mr. Clinton as "a politically talented underachiever" who dealt mainly in "incremental policy departures."
Those phrases come from a new book by Prof. Fred I. Greenstein of Princeton University, to be published in May by The Free Press. Titled "The Presidential Difference: Leadership Style from F.D.R. to Clinton," it sums up this president as follows:
"It is a tribute to Clinton's resiliency and political prowess that he has succeeded in serving two presidential terms. It is a commentary on his weaknesses that this talented political leader has not had more to show for his time in office."

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE UNION: WIDE-RANGING IDEAS;
Marriage-Penalty Proposal Could Ease Way to Tax Cut

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
In proposing tonight to reduce the marriage penalty that the tax code levies on many two-income couples, President Clinton embraced an issue that has been pushed for years by Republicans and so opened the door to a compromise on an election-year tax cut.
The approach set out by Mr. Clinton would help fewer couples than alternative changes preferred by most Republicans, and in particular would do little for couples in higher income brackets. 
 But with Republicans in the House having vowed to make a marriage-penalty bill one of their first priorities this year -- and with Democrats in Congress loath to vote against such legislation at a time of swelling federal budget surpluses -- Mr. Clinton's plan could provide the seeds for a bipartisan compromise.
"It shows that this issue has a lot of political resonance," said Stephen Moore, director of fiscal policy studies at the conservative Cato Institute. "Clinton is very adept at taking politically popular Republican ideas and embracing them as his own. This is a strong signal to me that we will see marriage-penalty relief this year."
The marriage-penalty proposal was one of dozens set out by Mr. Clinton in his State of the Union address, but one of the few that he had not previously announced.
Others included a revised version of a plan he first offered last year to create incentives for retirement savings among low- and middle-income people. They also included initiatives to make health insurance more affordable, provide prescription drug coverage within the Medicare system, increase financing for school construction, expand the tax credit for the working poor and provide more money for medical research.
Many of the proposals -- few of which have much chance of becoming law in their present form -- are intended to channel money toward problems facing low-income people, reflecting Mr. Clinton's emphasis tonight on spreading the benefits of national prosperity.
But the marriage penalty is mostly an issue among middle-to-high-income voters, and one that is more complex than it is often made out to be.
The marriage penalty hits many two-income couples, especially those in which the two partners earn roughly the same amount of money, pushing them into a higher tax bracket than they would face if they could file as single rather than as married.
A study last year by the Treasury Department concluded that 24.8 million couples paid a marriage penalty on their 1999 returns, or 48 percent of the 51.4 million joint returns filed. The average penalty was $1,141.
But the study also found that the same quirk in the tax code that hurts many couples also helps many others, mostly those where only one spouse works or where one spouse earns substantially more than the other. The study found that 21 million couples, or 41 percent of all couples filing jointly, actually received a marriage bonus, which averaged $1,274. About 11 percent of couples paid neither a penalty nor a bonus.
The main component of Mr. Clinton's plan would help 9.1 million two-income couples, those who claim the standard deduction on their federal returns. It would address the marriage penalty by increasing the standard deduction -- $7,200 in 1999 for couples filing jointly -- until it was twice as much as the standard deduction for single filers, currently $4,300. The change would be phased in over five years.
The proposal would do nothing for couples who itemize their deductions, as most higher-income households do.
The proposal would also give a break to single-income couples who do not pay a marriage penalty. It would increase the standard deduction for all couples by an additional $500 in 2005, and by $250 for single filers.
When fully phased in, Mr. Clinton's proposal would increase the standard deduction for two-income couples who file jointly by $2,150. For those in the 15 percent tax bracket, the tax saving would be $322 a year when the proposal was fully phased in.
The White House estimated the cost of the proposal at $45 billion over 10 years.
Republicans have offered a variety of proposals to address the marriage penalty in recent years. Republicans in the Senate last year proposed eliminating the penalty altogether by giving couples the option of filing joint or individual returns. They estimated the cost at $117.7 billion over five years starting in 2005.
Among the Republican presidential candidates, Senator John McCain of Arizona backs a plan similar to what Mr. Clinton proposed. But Gov. George W. Bush of Texas would take a different approach. He would create a deduction for two-earner couples of 10 percent of the lower-earning spouse's income, up to a maximum deduction of $3,000. The cost of Mr. Bush's proposal is estimated at $12.5 billion a year after it is fully phased in.
Republicans in Congress said they were glad to see Mr. Clinton acknowledging the importance of tax cuts in general and of reducing the marriage penalty in particular. But they said they would insist on a bigger and more extensive tax-cutting package than the president offered tonight.
Republicans "think all Americans deserve tax relief, not just the handful the president picks," said Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. Mr. Archer said he would begin work on a marriage-penalty bill next week.
Mr. Clinton also proposed a number of other tax initiatives in his address.
One would provide tax incentives for charitable giving, including allowing taxpayers who do not itemize deductions to claim a 50 percent deduction for charitable contributions above $500 a year.

President Clinton mentioned dozens of proposals in his State of the Union address, from gun control and the environment to medical research and tax cuts. Among his major proposals:
 
ADMINISTRATION'S 10-YEAR COST ESTIMATE
 
PRESCRIPTION DRUGS -- Offer prescription drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries. The Congressional Budget Office says the cost would be much higher than the administration's estimate. $118 BILLION
 
HEALTH INSURANCE -- Help millions of Americans get health insurance by creating new tax breaks and by expanding existing programs. Mr. Clinton would let parents enroll in a children's health program created in 1997. $110 BILLION
 
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS -- Provide for a match of a portion of contributions to a new type of retirement account for couples earning less than $80,000 and individuals earning less than $40,000. A scaled-back version of a plan offered by Mr. Clinton last year. $54 BILLION
 
TAX CREDITS FOR THE WORKING POOR -- Expand the earned-income tax credit, which provides cash payments to families below and just above the poverty line. Expansion would focus on families with three or more children. $21 BILLION
 
COLLEGE EDUCATION -- Offer tax credits and various grants to help families pay for college and graduate school. $30 BILLION
 
SCHOOL MODERNIZATION -- Offer federal subsidies for bond issues to modernize up to 6,000 schools, and interest-free loans and grants to support repair and renovation projects in school districts with the most urgent need. $3.7 BILLION OVER 5 YEARS
 
Chart: "SORTING IT OUT -- Easing the Marriage Penalty"
Details of President Clinton's proposal:
 
THE PROBLEM -- Many two-income couples pay a higher income-tax bill than they would if they were filing as single taxpayers. For some couples, it is because the standard deduction for couples filing jointly is less than twice as much as the deduction for single filers. For others, it is because their combined incomes push them into a higher tax bracket. A Treasury Department study found that 24.8 million couples, or nearly half of all couples filing joint returns, paid a marriage penalty last year.
 
THE PRESIDENT'S PROPOSAL -- President Clinton's plan would help people who suffer from the imbalance in the standard deduction, gradually increasing the deduction for two-income couples filing jointly until it is twice the deduction for single filers. For the 1999 tax year, the deduction for couples filing jointly is $7,200; for single filers, it is $4,300.
 
THE RESULTS -- Including other provisions, the Clinton plan would result in an increase in the standard deduction, after five years, of $2,150 for two-income couples filing jointly. For taxpayers in the 15 percent bracket, that would mean a tax cut of $322. For taxpayers in the 28 percent bracket, it would mean a cut of $602.
 
COMPETING PLANS -- Republicans have offered a variety of competing plans. George W. Bush proposed allowing two-income couples to deduct up to 10 percent of the lower-earning spouse's income, to a maximum of $30,000, for a deduction of up to $3,000. Senate Republicans last year proposed giving couples the option of filing separately, at single rates, if it would reduce their tax bill. John McCain backs an approach similar to Mr. Clinton's.

HEADLINE: Excerpts From the Republican Party's Response to the President's Address

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the Republican reply to President Clinton's State of the Union Address delivered by Senators Susan Collins of Maine and Bill Frist of Tennessee, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
Ms. Collins
As we reflect on our economic health, we should never forget that America's recent success is, above all, a triumph of values. Americans will never let our country become rich in things and poor in spirit. 
 The achievements of the "dot-com" generation rest on the foundation built by our parents and our grandparents. They prevailed through the Depression, defeated the forces of fascism and made personal freedom the hallmark of countries around the globe. . . .
To promote job growth, we'll continue to help our small businesses. That means reducing burdens like the federal "death tax" -- so that when parents work their whole lives to leave their children a family business, it won't have to be sold just to pay the I.R.S.
Taxes, in general, are simply too high. We will continue to fight for tax relief for American families so that they can keep more of what they earn. . . .
As important as all these issues are, there's something else that is vital to securing our future, and that is education. Prior to coming to the Senate, I worked at Husson College in Bangor, Me. I know first-hand the difference that education can make.
We live in a time of unparalleled prosperity. But between Silicon Valley and Wall Street, many Americans still live in the shadows of the new prosperity. New technologies, unimagined a decade ago, provide exciting opportunities for some but pose unsettling challenges to others.
As we enter the 21st century, every young American must be educated to adapt to a changing workplace, and many in our current workforce must be provided with new skills to succeed in the new economy.
A good education is the ladder of opportunity. It turns dreams into reality. That's why education is at the top of the Republican agenda.
Tonight I ask the president to join with Republicans in our commitment to bring a good education to all our children. Our four-point plan for educational excellence will ensure that all children have an equal opportunity to reach their full potential.
First, we will continue to increase federal funds for elementary and secondary education. Last year, Republicans boosted education spending by $500 million more than the president's budget, and we added funds for children with special needs.
Second, rather than Washington dictating to communities how they should run their schools, we should listen to those who know best: our parents, our teachers and local school boards.
The debate in Washington is not about money. It's about who makes the decisions. We need a change of approach -- one that recognizes that local schools, not Washington offices, are the heart and home of education. We will empower states and communities to use federal education dollars in the ways children need most. . . .
Republicans want what all parents want for their children's schools: more federal help but less federal interference. Instead of imposing a one-size-fits-all straitjacket, our plan recognizes that one community may need more math teachers while another may need better reading programs -- and still others, new computers. The point is it should be your community's decision, not Washington's.
In return for that flexibility, the Republican plan requires real accountability -- not more paperwork, but better results. Schools will be held responsible for what is truly important -- improving student achievement.
Third, our plan will strengthen teaching excellence.
America's teachers need our help. About one-third of our new teachers get so discouraged that they leave the profession. Many are prevented from doing their very best because they don't have a chance to get enough training in the subject they teach.
We will increase federal grants to states and communities and give them the freedom to use that money to better prepare, recruit and retain good teachers. The lessons are clear -- we must encourage talented people to choose teaching as a career and keep them in the classroom.
Fourth, our plan will continue the longtime Republican support for higher education. Last year we increased Pell grants and student loans to open the doors to college for more low- and middle-income families. This year we will increase the amount that families can contribute to education savings accounts to make higher education more affordable.
Education today is America's broadband to the fixture -- a powerful conduit for achievement and success. Let us work together to ensure that all Americans have the opportunity for a bright future. . . .
 
Mr. Frist
I'm a senator from the state of Tennessee, but I've spent the better part of my life working in hospitals, caring for people with heart disease.
I've learned a lot by listening to my patients and to the people who work in hospitals.
Earlier tonight we heard the president talk about his latest health care proposals. The last time he proposed a health plan was seven years ago. And then it amounted to a federal government takeover of our entire health system. It would have forced every American into a Washington-run H.M.O. and denied them the right to choose their own doctor.
In the end, thank goodness, it was soundly defeated by Democrats and Republicans alike.
Now tonight, 84 months later, the president has unveiled a similar plan just as bad as the first. It makes government even bigger and more bloated because each new proposal we heard tonight -- and there were about 11 them in health care alone -- comes with its own massive bureaucracy. And each will cost you, the taxpayer, billions more of your tax dollars -- more than $1,000 for every man, woman and child.
During my surgical fellowship, I worked in England for the British National Health Service, and I saw firsthand the rationing, the lack of choice, the long waits and the denial of care for seniors.
I learned that socialized medicine -- whether in England or in Canada, where patients are fleeing to the U.S. for treatment -- just does not work.
In fact, if David Letterman had lived in Canada, he'd still be waiting for his heart surgery. . . .
So a lot is good. A lot is working. But we still have to make it even better.
As Republicans in Congress, we're determined not to be guided by bigger government, but by your freedom to choose your kind of health care and to select the doctor of your choice. Already because of Republican efforts, five million more children now have access to health care; if you change jobs, you can now take your health insurance with you; new mothers can leave the hospital when their doctor, not some bureaucrat, says they're ready. And we're doubling medical research for more and better cures. A great start, but not enough.
As a doctor, I've cared for thousands of seniors. I know Medicare is their lifeline, their security.
But this 35-year-old program, with 130,000 pages of regulations, creates waste and abuse and leaves our seniors with confusing red tape and heartache. Worst of all, Medicare doesn't even include the mainstay of modern medicine -- outpatient prescription drugs.
The answer is NOT government-dictated price controls that stop life-saving research, or forcing the 65 percent of seniors who now have drug coverage to pay more or give up what they have.
Instead, both Republicans and Democrats in Congress have come together with a plan to build on two simple principles: choice and security. It lets people choose the type of medical plan that is best for them, including prescription drugs. No senior citizen, no mother, no person with a disability, will ever be told by a bureaucrat what plan to pick, what doctor to see or what service they can receive.
But just last year the president said "no" to this plan, put forth by the National Bipartisan Medicare Commission -- the very commission the president and Congress appointed to save Medicare.
However, I'm proud to say that I've asked for and received full assurances today from our majority leader, Trent Lott, that he is prepared to bring this needed bipartisan legislation to the Senate floor within two weeks. For this to happen, Mr. President, all we need is for you to tell the American people, "Yes," to this Democrat and Republican plan to fix Medicare. So that people like my fellow Tennesseean, Patricia Brown, whom we honor in the gallery this evening will have the vital prescription drug coverage she needs.
And tonight, to show you and others that we are sincere and that we mean business, Republicans take a first step toward making Medicare stronger. To guarantee that seniors can rely on Medicare forever, we will add it to the Social Security lockbox, which will lock away the surplus for both Social Security and Medicare. We will not let anyone spend your Medicare money. . . .
During the Clinton years, the number of individuals without health insurance has increased by six million people. But with the plan we announced yesterday, we will finally make it easier for low- and middle- income families to buy the coverage of their choice.
I believe we will dramatically improve medical care in America. How could anyone not be hopeful, with what we've seen? Just look at our ability to correct heart defects in children, to halt the progression of osteoporosis and to treat breast and prostate cancer.
Soon we'll see revolutionary new treatments for conditions like Alzheimer's, sickle cell anemia and schizophrenia.
But all of these innovations require freedom, because progress and freedom go hand in hand. . . .
And so tonight, Mr. President, I ask you to put your trust in the American people -- in their creativity, in their resourcefulness, in their ability to achieve -- free of government interference.
Mr. President, please, no more red tape.
Instead, give us a health plan that includes choice and security.
The American people deserve no less. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE UNION: THE VIEWERS;
Family Watching Sees Scandal

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: BOUND BROOK, N.J., Jan. 27

 BODY:
Al Gomolka thinks President Clinton has done a good job managing the economy and gave him credit for requiring background checks on gun purchases and for having a strong foreign policy.
But he cannot buy the president's support for abortion rights. 
 His wife, Shelley Gomolka, agreed with the president on abortion rights and on equal rights issues, particularly for women. And she admitted that the Clinton administration had done a good job managing the economy.
If Mr. Clinton has started thinking about how American families will remember him and his presidency, he could start with the Gomolkas.
Like thousands of other families, the Gomolkas sat down tonight to listen to the president's final State of the Union speech. The Gomolkas let their two older boys, Jacob, 4, and Joshua, 9, stay up late to watch the address. A third son, Isaac, is 2.
In a speech in which the president offered several proposals intended to ensure that the nation's prosperity is shared by all, the Gomolkas found ideas that could help them in the daily lives.
But they also expressed skepticism about whether those proposals would ever become reality.
While the couple often agreed with the president, their views were often tainted by concerns about his moral character.
"His moral character is just pitiful," Mrs. Gomolka, 44, a part-time landscape horticulturist.
"I have to admit that economic issues aren't too bad," she said, "and I agree with him on women's rights, but it bothers me that so many people say, 'Well, he did O.K.,' and then vote for him."
During the speech, the couple expressed a mix of often contradictory feelings and beliefs about politics and the presidency.
They are lifelong Democrats but voted for Ronald Reagan twice, for Ross Perot in 1992 and for Bob Dole in 1996.
Mr. Gomolka, 48, a state parks superintendent, believes he is "on the conservative side," but said he planned to vote for Bill Bradley, if Mr. Bradley wins the Democratic presidential nomination, because of his tenure as a United States senator from New Jersey.
He strongly believes in the right to own firearms, but he nodded approvingly when the president spoke of the success of the Brady gun control measure, which required a five-day waiting period for the purchase of handguns.
"The Brady law was good," Mr. Gomolka said. "It may bother the criminals, but to the person who just wants a recreational gun, it's not going to bother them how long it takes."
The president is charismatic, they agreed, and is persuasive, yet his words tonight were often discounted.
"I think it all sounds great, but it's just hard to believe him," Mrs. Gomolka said, interrupting herself when the president stopped to acknowledge his wife.
"Oh puh-leez, look at him smile," Mrs. Gomolka said.
"It all comes down to truthfulness, and I have to ask, Where does fidelity come into all this?" she said. "It all just comes down to credibility."
As the president ticked off his agenda, the bread-and-butter economic issues hit home in the Gomolka household.
Although they are solidly middle-class, with excellent medical coverage and a generous pension for Mr. Gomolka, they are worried about money and were glad to hear the president offer to help with such things as college tuition credits, prescription drug assistance and care for elderly parents.
"He talks about helping low-income people but if she doesn't work for two days, we're living paycheck to paycheck," Mr. Gomolka said.
And when the president urged a law to guarantee equal pay for women, Mr. Gomolka picked up: his sister, Susie, works at one of New Jersey's big pharmaceutical companies and often complains of earning less than men in equal positions.
Tax credits for college tuition also won praise from the couple, but also a concern that, however, bright the presidents' promises, they might never become law.
"It all sounds good but I'd like to see it in writing," Mrs. Gomolka said. "It doesn't matter how good it sounds if he is not going to be around to make it happen."
Like other growing communities, Bound Brook is experiencing school overcrowding that is straining local budgets and pushing up real estate taxes.
For the president to promise 100,000 new teachers without speaking of new school buildings made no sense, Mrs. Gomolka said.
"We'd have to build new additions on the additions just to have the classrooms," she said.
Yet the president's endorsement of charter schools pleased her: she schooled Joshua at home in kindergarten and first grade and would have kept him at home longer if she had not gone back to work.
"I believe parents should have more options," Mrs. Gomolka said.
Mr. Gomolka nodded in agreement when the president spoke of preserving natural spaces, of letting children grow up next to parks, of saving coastlines and forests, and of supporting public transportation to reduce the time people spend stuck in traffic.
"There you go," he said with the first real enthusiasm he had shown all evening. "That's New Jersey!"
"Where's the money going to come from?" Mrs. Gomolka asked him.
"Our taxes," her husband replied.
"More taxes, or what we've already got?" she asked.
"I would pay higher taxes for all that," Mr. Gomolka said.
As the president drew to a close, Mrs. Gomolka was hardly moved.
"I think over all he had a lot of good proposals, although I'd like to know more about how they all come to fruition," she said. "And I'll never change my mind about his character. I think it puts a shadow on how I see what he has to say."
Mr. Gomolka was also impressed, but not entirely won over.
"I consider it like all the other speeches I've heard him make -- it was a good speech and he has good goals, and it's what the people want to hear," Mr. Gomolka said. "They want him to show some kind of hope for the citizens."

LENGTH: 1710 words

HEADLINE: THE STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Stakes Claim to U.S. Prosperity

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27

 BODY:
Basking in an annual rite for the last time, President Clinton bragged tonight that the state of the union had never been better and proposed using some of the nation's wealth to provide modest tax relief for lower- and middle-income Americans, particularly married ones.
"Our economic revolution has been matched by a revival of the American spirit," Mr. Clinton said, pumping his fist for emphasis. "Crime down by 20 percent, to its lowest level in 25 years. Teen births down seven years in a row, adoptions up by 30 percent. Welfare rolls cut in half to their lowest levels in 30 years. My fellow Americans, the state of our union is the strongest it has ever been." Text, Pages A16-17. 
As Mr. Clinton stepped to the rostrum, the House chamber was crowded, as always, although the entire Supreme Court was puzzlingly absent, some without any stated reason. The drama of his address a year ago, delivered on the eve of his impeachment trial, was gone. Instead, Mr. Clinton's main adversary was the calendar, which shows less than a year to go until his successor's proposals are the ones that matter.
With Vice President Al Gore seated behind his right shoulder and Hillary Rodham Clinton in the balcony above, Mr. Clinton did much to try to help their political fortunes and the effort of other Democrats to take back the House from the Republicans who had impeached him.
So packed full of proposals was the speech that it extended to 89 minutes, breaking the record of the marathon, 81-minute speech that Mr. Clinton gave in 1995. The president also received more than 100 ovations, far more than he received in his other State of the Union speeches.
In one applause-winning proposal, Mr. Clinton, as he has done so often in his tenure, seized an issue dear to the Republicans and made it his own. He announced a proposal to alleviate the part of the tax code that penalizes married couples, forcing them to pay higher rates than if they were single.
That makes such a change likely, since Republicans on Capitol Hill had previously said that ending the so-called marriage penalty was one of their principal goals this year and had appeared to have enough Democratic backing to enact it even before Mr. Clinton embraced the measure tonight. The proposal was one of a series of tax cuts that aides said totaled $350 billion over 10 years, measured against an estimated $2 trillion surplus.
Republicans were taken aback by the sheer number of initiatives. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas called the speech a "litany of spending," and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said "Congress will dig out of an avalanche of presidential spending initiatives." Page 15.
In a surprise announcement held back until just before the speech, Mr. Clinton urged federal legislation to require state licenses for all handgun purchases, one of numerous proposals the president borrowed from Mr. Gore. Saying states now licensed drivers and hunters, Mr. Clinton recommended similar photo identifications for handgun buyers once they passed a background check and completed a gun-safety course.
In his speech Mr. Clinton took credit for the extraordinary health of the American economy -- and shared credit lavishly with Mr. Gore -- while warning that the prosperity should not be squandered.
But while last year's address was built around a pledge to save Social Security before taking any other actions or cutting taxes, this year, Mr. Clinton felt times were good enough to call for both tax cuts, though modest ones, and more social spending.
On foreign policy, an area in which he hopes to be remembered, Mr. Clinton urged lawmakers to give China most-favored-nation trade status on a permanent basis, and he restated his view that the United States must stay engaged in the world, especially with former adversaries still struggling to enact democratic reforms.
As he has in previous speeches, Mr. Clinton devoted far less time to foreign policy and national security issues than to his domestic agenda, quickly surveying the country's role as a mediator in the Middle East and Northern Ireland and as a defender of human rights in Kosovo.
Mr. Clinton said the trend toward globalization was "the central reality of our time." He called for a new consensus on trade, urging Congress to pass legislation easing trade barriers with African and Caribbean nations and to approve the agreement his administration reached with China last year to join the World Trade Organization.
"Open markets and rule-based trade are the best engines we know of for raising living standards, reducing global poverty and environmental destruction, and assuring the free flow of ideas," Mr. Clinton said. "I believe as strongly tonight as I did the first day I got here: there is only one direction for America to go on trade. We must go forward."
He said Russia had been held back from its full potential by economic turmoil and "a cruel and self-defeating war in Chechnya" but said the United States should help "those Russians who are struggling for a democratic, prosperous future."
Most of his points were not new, but he did announce a proposal to offer tax credits to pharmaceutical companies to speed development of vaccines against malaria, tuberculosis and AIDS in poorer nations. He also said his budget would include $150 million to fight disease around the world.
With his speech coming between this week's Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, Mr. Clinton unveiled a legislative shopping list intended to some degree to ensure his relevance as attention shifts to the campaign. Time after time in the speech, Democrats jumped to their feet in applause, while Republicans responded to many proposals with silence.
Election-year Congresses are notoriously unproductive, but tonight Mr. Clinton advanced some proposals designed to win congressional backing this year and other initiatives designed to linger for the Democrats until well beyond Election Day.
"These are great goals, worthy of a great nation," Mr. Clinton said. "The lesson of our history," he said, "and the lesson of the last seven years -- is that great goals are reached step by step, always building on our progress, always gaining ground."
On education, Mr. Clinton borrowed heavily from the campaign platform of Mr. Gore, proposing $3 billion in new spending for the politically popular Head Start program and new after-school initiatives, as well as school construction and enhanced teacher pay. He restated his $31 billion plan to make college more affordable through enhanced federal grants and by making part of tuition tax deductible. He has credited Mrs. Clinton with twisting him arm to make that happen.
"We need a 21st century revolution in education, guided by our faith that every single child can learn," he said. "Because education is more important than ever, more than ever the key to our children's future, we must make sure that all our children have that key. That means universal preschool and after-school, the best trained teachers in the classroom and college opportunities for all our children."
Some of the president's proposals had been suggested before but had never gained traction in Congress. Mr. Clinton urged renewed action on unfinished business, including hate-crimes legislation, a minimum wage increase from $5.15 an hour, a bill of rights to give patients more say with their health maintenance organizations, and gun control.
Tom Mauser, whose son, Daniel, was killed last April at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo., was one of the guests invited to sit beside Mrs. Clinton. The president's speech pushed the gun control measures that Congress had failed to act on last year, along with money to enhance the enforcement of existing gun laws.
The president's licensing proposal stands little chance of passage this year, and raises constitutional issues, but it put Mr. Clinton clearly in Mr. Gore's corner in the presidential campaign, in which former Senator Bill Bradley has promoted his gun control proposals as more effective than the vice president's.
"Crime in America has dropped for the past seven years -- that's the longest decline on record, thanks to a national consensus we helped to forge on community police, sensitive gun control and effective prevention," the president said. "But nobody -- nobody here, nobody in America -- believes America is safe enough. So again I ask you to set a higher goal: let's make this country the safest big country in the world."
The president's tax-relief ideas would supplement working families' retirement savings, assist with child care expenses, encourage charitable giving and make up to $10,000 of college tuition tax deductible. In another helping hand, Mr. Clinton proposed $21 billion to expand the earned income tax credit.
Talk of undoing the marriage penalty is always politically popular. But the president's plan, which would be phased in over a decade and would double the standard deduction for two-income couples to twice the amount of a single filer's deduction, is more limited than various Republican proposals. It would not benefit couples who itemize on their returns.
Addressing one of his biggest legislative defeats last year, Mr. Clinton called for a "bipartisan dialogue" on the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, conciliatory language indicating that the president did not intend to push the matter again. He emphasized the importance of engaging countries like China and Russia, which still maintains nuclear missile arsenals. And he addressed the dangers of biological warfare and "cyberterrorism," without offering any specific solutions to those dangers.
The president pushed again for prescription-drug benefits under Medicare, one of a handful of health care proposals. And he vowed to pay off the debt by 2013, two years ahead of his previous predictions, and resist reckless spending that chips away at Social Security.
In length and breadth, the speech reflected Mr. Clinton's centrist instincts, the advice of many people in the White House and on Capitol Hill -- and the president's desire to savor a moment in the spotlight before the people's attention turns inevitably to the next president, whoever he is.
