HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Swiss Forum Has Its Focus On Memories From Seattle

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 28

 BODY:
World leaders and business executives, gathered for an annual conference beneath the powdery ski slopes of this Alpine resort, have their minds fixed on a rainy American port city 8,000 miles away.
The city is Seattle, where protesters battled police, and trade ministers battled one another under storm clouds last December. The city's name is invoked with such regularity here that its mere mention conjures up fears of a sustained backlash against globalization. 
 The by-invitation-only attendees at the World Economic Forum, an event that caters to a political and business elite and has long championed the march of capitalism and Western values around the world, are treating the surprise collapse of the Seattle talks as the first real crisis to confront globalization since the fall of Communism. Ernesto Zedillo, president of Mexico, lamented today the sudden emergence of "globaphobia," an international force that has singled out global integration as the primary cause of environmental and social problems.
The prime ministers of Britain and Turkey, the head of the World Trade Organization, and the leaders of hedge funds, social research centers, and labor unions echoed that theme in public talks and private conversations here. Sharing goods and ideas across national boundaries still makes economic sense, many said, but it has run into moral and political roadblocks that may prove difficult to overcome. Politicians said repeatedly that global institutions, including the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund and the trade organization, were not up to the task and needed fundamental reform.
"There's no point in pretending that Seattle was not a setback for free trade," Tony Blair, the British prime minister, said in a speech today. "We have an enormous job to do to convince opponents, many of whom I think are wrong, that they can live with globalization."
Mr. Blair proposed that as a first step, leading countries set up a panel to propose how to overhaul the bureaucracy of the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based body that regulates international trade. He also urged that the United States, Japan and Europe drop all remaining barriers to imports from the poorest countries as a gesture of good will to the developing world, which was instrumental in derailing last month's trade negotiations.
President Clinton also plans to address how to restore confidence in trade and globalization when he speaks Saturday at the six-day conference. Mr. Clinton, who will make a half-day visit, is seeking to recover a reputation as an ardent free trader. Some world leaders blamed his administration for failing to contain demonstrators in Seattle and frightening developing nations with his call to impose tougher labor standards.
The leaders are grappling with the reality that in recent months, popular impressions of globalization seems to have shifted. It is now seen less as spreading prosperity around the world and more as the conduit for a long list of ills. Among the many problems cited: growing inequality between rich and poor people and rich and poor nations; the failure of law and ethics to keep pace with advances in science; environmental pollution; and the rapid spread of financial instability from one country to another.
Much of this reflects the views of protesters who converged on Seattle. While government officials have stressed that the failure of trade talks owes more to negotiating positions taken by World Trade Organization members than to the influence of demonstrators, it is clear that the protest message has quickly become a political priority.
"Globalism is the new 'ism' that everyone loves to hate," said Michael Moore, director general of the World Trade Organization, in an interview. "There is nothing that our critics will not blame on globalization and, yes, it is hurting us."
The paradox of this hand-wringing is that the World Economic Forum, a convention of rich and powerful people carefully cultivated by its Swiss founder, Klaus Schwab, more than 30 years, has long viewed itself as the intellectual godfather of globalization. In fact, critics view the forum, in which elected world leaders convene with top business executives in this heavily patrolled resort, as a cabal that shapes the world order without consulting ordinary people.
The forum is actually more of a gabfest. But Mr. Schwab, saying that the goal of this year's meeting is to create a "social consciousness of the global economy," sought to broaden the invitees this year to include representatives of nongovernment organizations and unions, some of which led the Seattle demonstrations. Many accepted.
That did not stop a Swiss group called the Anti-WTO Coalition from announcing plans to block the winding, two-lane road into town Saturday, during Mr. Clinton's visit. The Swiss Army was on call, promising to keep the road open and the who's who list of attendees safe.
"Some of the NGO's that came here did so knowing that they would be criticized," said Peter Armstrong, director of One World International, a private group opposed to globalization, who is attending the meeting. "But there is a certain sense of victory that we are here at all, that we can voice our concerns on the inside."
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and a leader of unions who worked to stop the start of a new round of trade talks in December, also attended the forum, along with a group of international union leaders.
"Seattle is just the beginning," Mr. Sweeney said. "Unless workers are involved, globalization will not work."
Business executives also expressed anxiety about whether globalization was working, and some said they were part of the problem.
George Soros, the hedge fund manager, called for world democracies to establish a new global federation that would set labor and environmental standards more effectively than the United Nations. Louis Schweitzer, chairman and chief executive of the French auto company Renault, said business must take a back seat to politics, accepting limits on political contributions and influence, to help restore public faith in elected leaders.

HEADLINE: Edward Logue, 78, Dies; Fought Urban Decay

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Edward J. Logue, an urban development czar who organized radical renewal programs to combat municipal decay in New Haven, Boston and New York State, died on Thursday at his home in West Tisbury, Mass. He was 78.
In a career spanning three decades, Mr. Logue spent the 1950's renewing New Haven, the 1960's revitalizing Boston and the 1970's running building programs in New York State. Throughout, he said, he was always guided by his humanistic motto of "planning with people." 
 His critics, however, said he was highhanded, confrontational and "another Robert Moses" -- a reference to the imperious New York City master builder.
Mr. Logue's greatest triumph was his development of the Boston waterfront, which he called a "Walkway to the Sea." Officially, it is the Faneuil Hall-Quincy Market restoration.
"It hit a series of themes just right for the time," wrote Bernard J. Frieden and Lynne B. Sagalyn in their book "Downtown, Inc." (MIT Press, 1989). "For a mass public that had discovered gourmet food, the central arcade served it up in volume and with flair. For a public with a fresh interest in history, the market presented authentic 150-year-old buildings and cobbled paths rich with historic associations. For a generation that had discovered sidewalk cafes and bustling piazzas in Europe, the market brought these pleasures home."
Other elements of the "New Boston" that Mr. Logue devised and oversaw were the new Government Center, the completion of the Prudential Center and a broad overhaul of neighborhoods that gave the city a fresh self-image and attracted tourists from around the world.
It became one of the most copied community development projects in the country.
Mr. Logue made his first big splash in the mid-1950s when Mayor Richard C. Lee of New Haven named him development administrator, and Mr. Logue oversaw the rebuilding of the city's downtown. Given broad authority that previously had been parceled out among several agencies, Mr. Logue reshaped much of the city.
"He was one of the first, if not the very first, to figure out how to tap federal funds that were sitting out there waiting to be used for redevelopment projects," said Norman Marcus, who worked with Mr. Logue as general counsel to the New York City Planning Commission from 1963 to 1985.
But Mr. Logue's work in New Haven is not judged a success today. "It's been heavily criticized," Mr. Marcus said.
"Partly that was because it took too long to do -- quite a few years," he said. "By the time it was finished, it was too late. The market was gone. Shopping had shifted from downtown to the malls in the suburbs. The green had become a wasteland."
But that would not be understood for years to come, and consequently Mayor John F. Collins of Boston hired Mr. Logue to head Boston's Redevelopment Authority. From there Mr. Logue went on to New York City.
Sometimes to his detriment and sometimes to great acclaim, Mr. Logue thought big.
"He used to say you've got to think big if you want to get anywhere," Mr. Marcus said. "But his appetite was larger than his ability to digest. He often reached too high.
"He was a force with tremendous energy," Mr. Marcus continued. "Ed wasn't the kind of person who would sit down at the table and negotiate. He intended to run things by himself. In New York City, there were people who resisted that. They didn't want another Robert Moses-type strong man. Ed scared a lot of people."
Mr. Marcus also praised Mr. Logue for his daring and imaginativeness. "When he came to Charlotte Street, a notorious scene of desolation in the South Bronx, he decided not to do the obvious thing and build row houses or six-story apartment buildings there," Mr. Marcus said. "Instead, he built single-family houses with yards and white picket fences. Some people laughed at first. But he was a smart fellow. That redevelopment worked because he was recreating the American dream, and they're still there today."
But apart from the South Bronx, Mr. Logue's efforts in New York City, at the behest of Mayor John V. Lindsay, are widely regarded as failures.
"Although Mayor Lindsay had hired him, he eventually decided to back the constituency that opposed Ed," Mr. Marcus said.
Edward Joseph Logue was born on Feb. 7, 1921, in Philadelphia, one of five children of Edward J. and Resina Fay Logue. He was a graduate of Yale College in 1942 and Yale Law School in 1947.
In World War II, he served in the Air Force, winning the Air Medal with clusters.
After the war, he was legal secretary to Governor Chester Bowles of Connecticut.
Among other jobs, he led Nelson Rockefeller's New York State Urban Development Corporation and his own company, Logue Development, a consulting firm.
Mr. Logue is survived by his wife, Margaret DeVane Logue; a son, William DeVane Logue of West Hartford, Conn.; a daughter, Katherine, of West Tisbury, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Merit vs. Tradition

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
In proposing to scrap across-the-board wage increases in favor of merit pay, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is pushing a daring experiment in labor relations that has enraged the city unions and has rarely been tried elsewhere.
Mr. Giuliani's plan is unusual because while a sizable number of cities and school districts award workers merit pay in addition to general pay increases, it is almost unheard of for a government body to persuade a union to accept merit pay as the sole basis for raises. 
 Despite the rarity of such merit pay plans, Mr. Giuliani is vigorously championing his proposal, calling it the key to bolstering productivity in the city's schools and offices. But leaders of the municipal unions vow to block any pay plan that does not include an across-the-board pay increase, noting that many of their members are still fuming about the two-year wage freeze in their current five-year contract.
Many labor experts say they expect a compromise that would be less radical than the mayor's plan but that could still usher in major changes. Such a compromise might involve a modest across-the-board wage increase with merit pay sprinkled on top.
The school district in Fairfax County, Va., is one of the few governmental entities to adopt a merit plan similar to the one the mayor envisions. For several years, Fairfax's schools embraced merit pay as the sole basis for pay increases, but the school board eventually decided to drop that plan because it created rancor among teachers and because there was little evidence it was improving results for low-performing students.
"The Fairfax County plan created intense bitterness in the schools," said Rick Nelson, president of the Fairfax County Federation of Teachers. "It gave teachers an incentive to compete against each other and not share ideas."
The Denver school system is experimenting with a similar plan, but it has been limited to a two-year pilot program, with only 350 teachers allowed to participate.
Mr. Giuliani's proposal has won considerable support from conservatives because it is tough on labor. But union leaders say it collides with their demands that all city workers deserve a substantial raise to keep up with inflation. The city's union leaders say they feel betrayed that the mayor would talk about denying municipal workers an increase in base pay when the city's economy is booming and the city has a hefty budget surplus.
Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said she would consider merit pay incentives only if the mayor first agreed to substantial wage increases -- probably greater than inflation -- to make teacher salaries, as well as police salaries, more competitive with suburban counterparts.
"Before you even consider the mayor's proposal, everyone has to realize that if we don't get base pay up, how are we going to fill the 54,000 teaching positions that will have to be filled over the next five years?" she said. "There is a nationwide teacher shortage, which just gets worse in New York City when its teacher salaries are so much lower than those in the suburbs."
Ms. Weingarten, who also serves as chairwoman of the Municipal Labor Committee, which coordinates bargaining for unions representing more than 200,000 workers, said she might consider what she called merit incentives or differentials. But her vision of merit is sharply different from the mayor's.
Mr. Giuliani outlined a plan in which a teacher's performance would be rated on a four- or five-part scale. A teacher then might receive merit increases accordingly, perhaps 6 percent for those rated highest down to those on the bottom, who might not receive any raise at all.
Ms. Weingarten said merit plans should not be based on performance, which she said was hard to measure. Instead, she said, teachers should receive merit increases when they reach new skill levels, like being declared "master teachers" by a certifying board.
Labor leaders in New York, as elsewhere, are wary about merit pay, fearing that it will divide union members and be awarded based on subjective rather than objective criteria, with supervisors' favorites getting the bulk of the rewards.
Last year in New Jersey, the main union representing state workers fought bitterly against Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to consider only merit, and not seniority, when deciding which civil servants to lay off. After a lengthy battle, the two sides compromised, agreeing to let seniority continue to play a major role, while allowing merit to be taken into account in a limited way.
In the cities and states where merit increases or bonuses are sprinkled on top of general pay increases, the plans have received mixed reviews. In Maryland, 35,000 unionized state workers can receive $500 bonuses if their work exceeds general standards or $1,000 bonuses if their work is considered outstanding.
"It's a real incentive to employees to be more productive," said Andrea Fulton, executive director of the state's personnel department.
Union officials are less enthusiastic, saying they found the plan acceptable only because it came on top of a sizable wage increase, 8 percent over two years.
"We were concerned that it would lead to favoritism, and our fears are being borne out," said Steven Kreisberg, assistant director for collective bargaining at the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Professor Richard Murnane of the Harvard School of Education, who conducted a lengthy study on merit pay in schools, said he found that it did little to improve the quality of education. "There's not a single instance in which merit pay for individual teachers has been shown to improve the performance of a troubled school district," he said.
He said merit pay appears to achieve better results in schools in wealthier districts, although he added that a major problem with merit pay plans was that they could undermine teamwork.
"When schools really work, it's because teachers work together," he said. "The potential for individuals to behave in a way that reduces the effectiveness of their colleagues is immense."
Sol Stern, a fellow with the Manhattan Institute, a generally conservative research center in New York, insisted that merit pay would go far to improve New York's schools.
"It's absolutely essential that we have a mechanism in the contract for distinguishing between effective teachers and ineffective teachers," he said. "Teaching is the only enterprise I know of where management does not monitor the productivity of the employees."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
MarketsShaken as Economic Statistics Fan Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The American economy grew at a blistering rate of 5.8 percent in the final quarter of last year as it closed in on the record for the longest expansion in United States history.
But inflation also jumped during the quarter and this, along with more evidence of accelerating health costs, make it more certain that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates by at least a quarter of a percentage point when it meets next week, analysts said. 
 The two government reports published today "amount to the 'smoking gun' that the Fed has been warning would eventually appear," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Bank. "The key story is the uptick in inflation."
Stocks, which have been retreating for most of the year, were pummeled heavily throughout the day while the bond market gyrated wildly and finished mostly higher, pushing rates lower.
Gross domestic product, the Commerce Department reported, grew at a blistering 5.8 percent annual pace during the quarter, just slightly higher than the summer's 5.7 percent but well ahead of the 5.2 percent that economists expected.
Consumers, many of them holding large stock gains, spent freely; military and other federal outlays rose sharply; and there was a huge buildup in inventories that apparently reflected precautions against computer failure at the turn of the year.
Spending on food, in fact, climbed 9.3 percent -- representing about one-quarter of the rise in consumer outlays -- as many households stocked up, fearing Year 2000 computer problems that proved largely unfounded.
Business spending on equipment and software, on the other hand, grew more slowly as some companies took a breather after preparing for potential Year 2000 problems, while others deferred such spending until the new year, analysts said.
Since many of the factors affecting the fourth quarter, including exceptionally favorable weather, are unlikely to be repeated, analysts say the economy is certain to cool off in the January-March period.
But it is not at all clear that it will cool enough for the Fed to be able to avoid a series of rate increases as the economy in February sets a record for uninterrupted expansion, 107 months. This would surpass the 106 months of Vietnam-era prosperity from 1961 to 1969.
Stan Shipley, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, "wants it south of 4 percent," referring to growth of the gross domestic product, on the assumption that inflation will break out if the economy keeps exceeding its speed limit. This is set by the sum of population growth, about 1 percent a year, and productivity growth, traditionally thought to be about 1 1/2 percent but now perhaps 2 1/2 percent to as much as 3 1/2 percent.
This report also showed that the savings rate -- personal savings as a percentage of disposable income -- shriveled to 1.9 percent from 2.1 percent in the preceding quarter. The rate was 4.5 percent for 1997, 3.7 percent for 1998 and 2.4 percent for all of 1999.
The inflation number that seemed to upset analysts the most today was the so-called G.D.P. deflator, which jumped to a 2 percent pace in the autumn from 1.1 percent in the summer. But others also advanced, including the price index for gross domestic purchases, up to 2.3 percent from 1.7 percent; without counting food and energy, this index accelerated to 2 percent from 1.2 percent.
But economists also cited the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index, which showed today that while wages and salaries for civilian workers rose the same in the autumn as in the summer, 0.9 percent, the cost of fringe benefits accelerated to 1.3 percent from 0.8 percent.
"The pickup in benefits apparently reflected increased retention bonuses as well as a continued uptrend in health insurance costs," said James F. O'Sullivan, an economist at J. P. Morgan. Wall Street's year-end bonuses, especially hefty for 1999, are expected to have their main impact in the next report.
Pay and benefits of civilian workers advanced 3.4 percent last year, the same as in 1998, as consumer prices advanced 2.7 percent. Benefits include vacations, holidays, sick leave, overtime pay, shift differentials and bonuses, as well as health and life insurance, savings and pension payments and severance pay.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
For Tyson, Drama Starts Before the Bell

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY W. SMITH 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, England, Jan. 28

 BODY:
For 10 days Mike Tyson, America's bad-boy boxer, has captured the attention of this nation. An outpouring of fan support has squashed political opposition to his arrival. He has stimulated the national economy by buying more than $2 million in watches and jewelry. And though he is not even running for mayor of London, he has kissed his share of babies.
Yes, Tyson had been on his best behavior. But today, one day before his heavyweight bout against Julius Francis, Tyson became upset and agitated. Jay Larkin, the senior vice president of programming for Showtime, which is televising the bout, said Tyson went to the Manchester airport instead of staying at his hotel for the weigh-in for his fight Saturday night. 
 The Sun of London and SkyTV, which has pay-per-view broadcast rights in Europe for the fight, reported that Tyson tried to leave Britain and return to the United States. Larkin said: "Tyson was upset. He went to the airport. I don't know what he was upset about. His bodyguard, James Anderson, was with him."
Larkin said he was unsure whether Tyson wanted to leave the country and believed that Anderson talked him into coming back. The Sun reported that members of Tyson's entourage went to the airport, calmed him down and talked him into returning.
Tyson's wife, Monica, and their children did not travel here for the fight, and Tyson was reportedly upset about their absence.
He made the weigh-in an hour late. Reporters who had been told Tyson went to the airport to meet a relative saw Tyson arrive about 4 p.m.
If Tyson was upset, Francis may have added more heat to the fire by keeping Tyson waiting for 10 minutes at the weigh-in. Francis was still in his room when Tyson took a seat on the stage where the scale was and began twirling the small braids on his head. Ten minutes later, Francis arrived. He kept on his black sunglasses for the weigh-in and came in at 244 1/2 pounds. Tyson weighed in at 222 3/4 pounds.
Tyson (46-3) and Francis (21-7), the British heavyweight champion, will meet in the ring at MEN Arena on Saturday night. The 10-round bout will be broadcast on tape delay on Showtime at 10 p.m. Eastern time. On the undercard, Joe Calzaghe (27-0) of Wales will defend his World Boxing Organization supermiddleweight championship against David Starie (22-1) of St. Edmunds, England.
Francis is a heavy underdog in this fight and there isn't much on his resume to suggest that he can beat Tyson. Some reporters here are comparing Francis' situation with that of Buster Douglas, who knocked Tyson out in 1990 and stunned the world of boxing. But Francis is 35 years old, and the speed of his punches can be timed with an hourglass. Plus, he is slow of foot, which means it won't take the 33-year-old Tyson long to track him down.
"The way that Mike has been working in the gym, I can't see anyway that Julius Francis can beat him," Tommy Brooks, Tyson's trainer, said.
A short fight is not what Tyson needs at this point, but it is probably what he will get. Since Tyson was released from prison in 1995, he has had eight fights and has fought only 28 rounds. Take out the 11 rounds he went against Evander Holyfield in their first bout on Nov. 9, 1996, and Tyson has gone 17 rounds in seven fights.
In the last three years, particularly with the two losses to Holyfield (the second fight ended in a disqualification in the third round when Tyson bit Holyfield's ears), Tyson's confidence has eroded. There is a split among those around Tyson. Some feel he needs to step up in competition and get away from the likes of Orlin Norris and Julius Francis. Others believe he needs a couple more nonthreatening opponents to build up his confidence.
"What Mike needs is to be in top condition for his fights, and he needs to fight regularly," Brooks said. "That will build his confidence faster than anything will. When a fighter is in condition he believes he can do anything."
Tyson looks very fit for this fight. By all accounts he has been diligent about training. So, his mind should be clearly focused on Francis.
In his last bout against Norris on Oct. 23 in Las Vegas, Tyson was fit and looked sharper than he had in his bout on Jan. 16 against Francois Botha. But then disaster struck when Tyson clipped Norris on the chin after the bell to end the first round. It was ruled an accidental foul. But the bout was ruled a no contest, because Norris said he couldn't continue fighting.
Norris contended that he injured his knee when he fell from the blow after the bell. And yet another Tyson bout had ended in controversy. Nevada told him to fight elsewhere. So, Tyson crossed the Atlantic Ocean looking for acceptance. He has found it. Now, he has to work to keep it.
If Tyson wants to stay on the track toward a heavyweight championship, he will have to avoid any type of misdeeds in his bout against Francis. Another bizarre ending will undo all the good will he has been able to build in England and derail plans for him to make a European tour, making him a tough sell on two continents. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: In Glow of Speech, Clinton Basks in Public's Warmth

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: QUINCY, Ill., Jan. 28

 BODY:
The last time Bill Clinton came close to this small city along the Mississippi was in his first run for the presidency in 1992, when his campaign bus roared past here on its way to a rally across the river. He returned today as president, seven years later, to relish the aftermath of his final, proposal-packed State of the Union message.
Mr. Clinton always hits the road the morning after his annual addresses to Congress, repeating themes meant as much for the country's heartland as for the chamber full of lawmakers. 
 In Quincy, a once-struggling city now in the midst of a boom, he chose the ideal spot to bask in the post-speech glow. The quaint streets were lined with well-wishers.
At the downtown square where Mr. Clinton spoke -- the same spot where one of the famous Lincoln-Douglas debates took place -- excited residents huddled in the cold for hours before his arrival, many of them schoolchildren given a snow day despite not a single flurry.
"If you saw the speech last night, you know that I quoted President Theodore Roosevelt, one of my favorite predecessors," said Mr. Clinton, who will soon become the youngest ex-president after Roosevelt. "He's the last sitting president to come to Quincy. I don't know what the others were thinking about."
Many in the crowd indicated they had taken in his televised speech, all 89 minutes of it.
"I watched every part of that speech, every minute of it, and I liked everything he said," said Maurice A. Crider, a retired auto worker who wore a knit hat pulled low over his head. He stood in the center square packed tight with more than 10,000 others.
Not everybody there had voted for Mr. Clinton, but it was difficult to find someone who did not find something meant for them in the speech.
"I loved the photo ID's for guns," said Pam Foster, a counselor at Catholic Charities, backing the president's proposal for state identification cards for handgun buyers.
Kay Wood, a Clinton backer whose family runs a 520-acre farm in Alexandria, Mo., said: "We're grain farmers so what I liked was the farm part of his speech. He said things are in bad shape, and we know that."
Debby Birch, an English teacher at a junior high school, voted for President George Bush in 1992 and Bob Dole four years later, but still jockeyed for position along a rope line for a chance to shake Mr. Clinton's hand. She came away excited that he had said some words to her.
"There wasn't anything he said in the speech that I was against," Ms. Birch said, calling it his "last-chance speech" to try to vindicate his presidency before the next president takes over.
She said she supported Mr. Clinton's education agenda, his tax-cut plan and other parts of the speech, indicating its broad appeal. But she still considered herself very much a Republican. "I still ideologically don't agree with everything he says," she said.
Quincy's unemployment was in the double digits when Mr. Clinton took office. The city suffered heavy damage from the floods that soaked the Midwest in 1993. Aides carefully chose this spot to represent the United States, as a whole, much better off than it had been.
"I was unemployed back in the late 80's and now I'm working," said Ken Gibleon, who took the afternoon off from his job at a downtown nursing home to snap a photograph of Mr. Clinton. "This president has turned the economy around. I give him credit for that. My favorite part of the speech was the help with college tuition. I have a daughter in college, and that hit home with me."
Back in 1992, just up the river in Burlington, Iowa, Mr. Clinton had hammered his opponent for claiming an economic recovery that many Americans could not feel.
"My opponent is quoted as saying the recession is over," he had said as governor of Arkansas. "You just don't know it yet. That's what they've been telling you all along. Things are great. You're just too dumb to see it."
Now things really were great, Mr. Clinton said -- although he took pains to repeat his message from Thursday night that too many Americans were still left out of the country's good times.
"One of the things that really bothers me about this astonishing economic recovery of ours is that not everybody has participated in it," the president said. "And I think all Americans will support us in saying that this is the best time we'll ever have -- with unemployment low and growth high -- to go into these inner cities, into these small rural towns, into these Native American reservations, and help turn their economies around."
Mr. Clinton gathered with several hundred supporters at the White House immediately after the speech on Thursday night, a pep rally that lasted until the wee hours of the morning and prompted the president to nap aboard Air Force One today.
This morning at the White House, Mr. Clinton assessed his performance before about 300 mayors and aides. He restated his long list of proposals, like targeted tax cuts and major funding increases for education and health care.
And he took another crack at the line about making communities more livable that he twice bungled as "liberal" on Thursday night in his moment in the spotlight.
"That was weird," the president said. "In my whole life, I've never mispronounced that word before last night."

HEADLINE: Mayor's Capital Plan May Bump Into State Debt Ceiling

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
From new ferry terminals to courthouses, recreational centers, hospitals, museums and schools, the budget Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released this week calls for billions of dollars in new spending on New York City construction projects.
There is just one catch: The city is about to run out of bricks-and-mortar funds. 
 The squeeze is so severe -- the city will probably hit a state-imposed cap on borrowing sometime before July 2001 -- Mr. Giuliani announced this week that he would go to Albany to ask for an amendment to the State Constitution to allow the city to borrow billions more.
The proposal to change the law, details of which are still being formulated, has been welcomed, at least initially, by a broad array of city budget watchers, from the City Council Finance Committee's chairman to the New York City Independent Budget Office's chief economist.
"We are approaching a very desperate situation," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat and the Finance Committee's chairman. "We are limited by law to the amount of money we can borrow. But if we can't borrow, we can't build or improve the city."
Concern is also being raised by Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, among others, that the mayor's push to increase construction spending in 2002 to an all-time high -- twice the level now allowed under the state cap -- may ultimately leave the city in a financial bind. The problem, they say, is that too great a share of the city's tax dollars would have to be dedicated in future years to paying off this mountain of new debt.
The portion of city funds spent to pay off debt has already increased to 16 percent in 1999 from 11 percent in 1990. With the tax cuts and new borrowing the mayor has proposed, it could hit 20 percent within four years, or more than three times the spending on the Fire Department, city officials said. "Whatever we are paying out to cover debt is money we don't have to pay for teachers and police officers and firefighters," Mr. Hevesi said. "It is very, very troubling."
No one, including Mr. Hevesi, disputes that the city's capital spending needs are real. Mr. Giuliani's plan calls for $22 billion in city-financed capital spending during the current fiscal year and the next three years, a increase of nearly 50 percent from the previous four years.
Nearly 33,000 new public school seats would be added within the next five years and air-conditioning would be installed immediately in 8,700 classrooms used for summer school as part of the $6.15 billion in capital spending planned for the school system, an increase of $1 billion from what the mayor had previously proposed. The Williamsburg, Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges would be rebuilt with another $811 million in capital funds. And hundreds of millions more would be spent to build a new sewage treatment plant in Greenpoint and on a project to prevent pollution of Flushing Bay.
Then there is the list of new economic development projects Mr. Giuliani has recently been promoting, including a stadium complex on the West Side rail yards and a recreation and shopping complex at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. New courthouses are proposed for Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. "This is the largest number of new courts and courthouses that have been built in the city probably in a hundred years," Mr. Giuliani said.
The city has a variety of sources of to pay for construction, including state and federal aid. But the most important source is general obligation bonds, the sale of which are limited by the state formula. First established in the 1930's, the cap prohibits the city from borrowing more than 10 percent of the assessed value of taxable city real estate, averaged over the previous five years.
Between 1989 and 1994, the debt limit doubled, as a result of a surge in value in real estate prices. But during later years the debt limit plummeted, making it difficult for the city to manage major spending projects. To keep projects moving, city officials in recent years devised techniques to ensure capital funds were available.
The mayor now wants to revise the formula permanently, perhaps by adding personal income-tax or sales-tax revenues to the calculation, resulting in a broader and more stable tax base upon which to issue debt.
Ronnie Lowenstein, chief economist and deputy director of the New York City Independent Budget Office, agreed that the formula needs to be revised to try to eliminate the unpredictable swings in the cap. But Ms. Lowenstein, Mr. Hevesi and others also cautioned the city must be careful to not take on too much new debt in the process.
Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota and Robert Harding, the mayor's budget director, reject suggestions that the city is planning to borrow too much. All of the projects that Mr. Giuliani has proposed in his four-year plan can be paid for without forcing the city to significantly curtail spending on basic services, or leaving the city with a deficit, they said. "It is a bogus argument," Mr. Lhota said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Airlines Stepping Up Battle For Luxury-Class Travelers
As the battle for the premium-fare passenger intensifies and airlines offer luxury more typical of a cruise ship, Virgin Atlantic has said it will soon introduce the first private cabin in a major carrier equipped with a double bed.
The cabin, which will go for about $18,000 for a couple, is Virgin's attempt to put romance back into flying, said Richard Branson, Virgin's chairman. British Airways and American Airlines also plan to put beds or seats that convert into beds on transatlantic flights. A1. 

Japan Forced to Seek Bank Loans
The Japanese government plans to borrow about $8 trillion yen, $76 billion, directly from banks rather than by issuing bonds in an unusual move that demonstrates the country's precarious financial situation is. A1.
 
Lockheed's Results Meet Forecasts
Lockheed Martin said its fourth-quarter operating earnings totaled $227 million, a 20 percent decline from the period a year earlier, because of higher costs and slowdowns in its aeronautics and space programs. The results met Wall Street's forecasts but its stock price fell 56.25 cents, to $18.875. C2.
 
Brokers in Japan Post Good Results
Japan's three largest brokerage firms -- Nomura Securities, Daiwa Securities and Nippon Securities -- posted their best profits in a decade, illustrating their strong comeback from severe weakness just a few years ago and defying predictions of their demise. C2.
 
Multiple Sclerosis Drug Endorsed
An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended that a cancer chemotherapy drug, mitoxantrone, should be approved as a treatment for multiple sclerosis. The drug is made by the Immunex Corporation of Seattle. A13.
 
F.T.C. Reschedules Amoco Hearing
The Federal Trade Commission rescheduled its hearing to consider whether to block the proposed $30 billion merger of BP Amoco and ARCO. The commissioners had been scheduled to consider a staff recommendation to block the deal Monday but they rescheduled it for Wednesday. Officials said that some commissioners wanted more time to consider a new offer made by the companies this week to sell additional assets. C14.
 
New York Times to Issue New Stock
The New York Times Company announced plans to issue a new class of stock that will track the value of the company's Internet properties, becoming one of the first newspaper companies moving to capitalize on investor enthusiasm for the Internet. C14.
 
Softbank Plans Online Unit Spinoff
Softbank plans to spin off ZDNet, the online unit of the U.S. media company Ziff-Davis, and sell its trade show arm. Softbank, the largest Internet investment company in Japan, owns a 69 percent stake in Ziff-Davis. Shares in ZDNet fell $2.1875, to $27.875; Ziff-Davis fell 93.75 cents, to $17.875. C3.
 
Korean Bank Ownership Restricted
The South Korean government will not allow the nation's major business conglomerates to own banks, a secretary to the president for economic affairs was quoted as saying. C2.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE STRATEGIES;
Negative Campaigning 2000: The Other Guy Did It First

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, N.H., Jan. 28

 BODY:
These days, the candidates see nabobs of negativism everywhere.
At a debate this week, former Senator Bill Bradley said Vice President Al Gore had gone negative on him. Mr. Gore called that accusation a "negative attack" on his integrity. At a town hall meeting in Nashua on Thursday, Senator John McCain rallied the crowd with the wish that in the final week of campaigning here, "We won't be having any negative ads." And in a new commercial on New Hampshire television stations, a Republican group quotes Bob Dole as saying that the attack ads in the 1996 primaries left him "battered, bruised and broke." 
 "Mr. Forbes, stop the negative ads," the commercial's voiceover concludes, referring to the Republican contender, Steve Forbes. "Don't help the Democrats."
All this talk by the candidates of how mean they are being to one another has more than a few New Hampshire voters bewildered. Given the history of truly vituperative primary campaigns here, this year's strikes a lot of people as being closer in tone to high tea than "High Noon."
"It's just a shadow issue," Dave Naughton, a political independent from Nashua who had come to Mr. McCain's meeting, said with a shrug. "I take it for what it's worth: something they talk about."
Suddenly, though, the candidates seem to want to talk about this all the time. It is a fixation that is rooted in the time-honored campaign tradition of spreading bad news about the other guy. The difference is that this year, the bad news they seek to spread is that it is the other guy who is spreading the bad news.
Keenly aware that voters here and across the country say they are tired of the kind of media mudslinging that has come to be known as the politics of personal destruction, strategists are expending large amounts of money and energy to convince the public that their opponents' campaigns are much more negative than they truly are. In commercials and debates, in grip-and-grin events and television interviews, the candidates and their surrogates are branding as negative comments by their foes that in other campaigns might have been dismissed with a yawn.
"It's actually a pretty sophisticated strategy," observed Darrell West, a professor at Brown University who studies political advertising. "It used to be that candidates would go negative to pin negative information on their opponents. Now, what they are trying to do is play the blame game, blaming their opponent for the tenor of the campaign."
What gives this a weird sense of disconnect for voters is that by most measures, Campaign 2000 has been about as raucous as a game of croquet.
"By and large, the candidates have been remarkably issue-based," said Brad Rourke, director of the Project on Campaign Conduct, a nonprofit group in Camden, Me., that seeks to establish guidelines for civility in campaigns. "You read the papers and it sounds as if what they are having are really tough issue debates."
Of course, things could get truly nasty in a hurry. The New Hampshire primary has a not-so-proud tradition of mean-spirited advertising on the last weekend of the campaign; most infamously, there was the advertisement put on the air in 1988 by Vice President George Bush that labeled Mr. Dole "Senator Straddle" for refusing to sign a pledge not to raise taxes, a spot that helped doom Mr. Dole's candidacy here. And in the last couple of days, various campaigns have been playing cat and mouse with one another, threatening to more broadly criticize their opponents and even broadcast the dreaded attack ads -- but only, of course, if their rivals do so first.
"If they say something inappropriate to us," declared William Dal Col, Mr. Forbes's campaign manager, "we've got material prepared to be delivered to level the playing field."
But even Mr. Forbes, whose attacks on Mr. Dole on the airwaves in New Hampshire four years ago were some of the most vicious the state had ever seen, is pulling his punches, running commercials that illustrate his positions on economic issues. The campaign, in fact, has run only one spot that might be viewed as negative, in which an anti-tax advocate from Texas criticizes Governor Bush for his tax policies.
Mr. Dal Col complained that in the current climate, the impact of such spots -- well within the boundaries of fairness, in his view -- is muted by the loud, righteous protests from the other side. "Any time you talk about his record, they spin it as negative," he said. "Here is a constituent who says Bush broke his tax pledge. But they want no debate, so they do the negative thing by accusing us of being negative."
Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for the Bush campaign, scoffed at the idea that Mr. Bush was the aggressor. "I think the voters make a rather informed judgment on who is negative and who is positive," he said." "That's one of the reasons Steve Forbes is having so much difficulty gaining any traction."
Political campaigns are built to take the pulse of public sentiment and play to some popular rhythm, and that may partly account for how voguish it is at the moment to portray the opposition as negative. For negative is highly out of fashion. In a poll of 800 adults across the nation in November by Mr. Rourke's organization, nearly 80 percent said they believed attack-oriented campaigns produced leaders who were "less ethical and less trustworthy."
The poll found, Mr. Rourke said, that while "it's bad to be attacked, it's worse to be perceived as an unfair attacker."
That may help to explain why so many of the harsher commercials that have made it to the airwaves this year have been sponsored by third-party groups. Organizations as diverse as the Sierra Club, the National Abortion Rights Action League and Americans for Tax Reform have run spots here focusing on one candidate or another. The most tactically sophisticated, however, has been a series of spots run by the Republican Leadership Council, including the new advertisement with the words of Mr. Dole, that has been designed to head off any attempt by Mr. Forbes to go negative.
Mark Miller, the council's executive director, said the group began running the spots in November. "I think everyone in the party felt he went way too hard last time and did lasting damage," Mr. Miller explained. "We wanted to tell him in an ad, warning him not to go down that road again."
Of course, such a spot has another function, reminding viewers that this was a candidate prone to go on attack. Voters may simply tune a lot of this out; Mr. McCain, for instance, always gets applause when he mentions his disdain for attack ads, but virtually never a follow-up question. Yet to some monitoring the candidates' behavior closely, even the accusations of negativity have a corrosive effect.
"Frankly, developments in the past week have disturbed me," said the Rev. C. Welton Gaddy, executive director of the Interfaith Alliance, a nonsectarian organization based in Washington that promotes ethical conduct. In December, the group persuaded five candidates -- Messrs. Bush, McCain, Bradley and Gore and Senator Orrin G. Hatch -- to sign what it called the "Framework of Civility for Presidential Candidates," in which they agreed, among other things, to not run commercials that vilified their opponents.
Now, Mr. Gaddy worries that with all the claims of attack, the atmosphere of civility is endangered. "We have moved to the edge of a precipice," he said, "and I hope we take a step back."

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Journal;
Wake Me When It's Almost Over

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
"An exciting time . . . an exciting result!" declared MSNBC's anchor, Brian Williams, on Monday night as he broke the news that "Alan Keyes has rocketed" to third place in the Iowa caucuses.
Talk about excitement! A man who has never been elected to anything, a man whose third-place finish amounted to only 14 percent (some 12,000 votes) of a lower-than-hyped Iowa G.O.P. turnout, a man who is less likely to be elected president than Bill Belichick, is rocketing! What does it matter that his rocket's destination -- unless it's as a permanent talking head at a place like MSNBC -- may be oblivion? This is history in the making. 
 The only problem is, despite the hard sell, the country isn't buying. Even as the caucuses were meeting in Iowa, Harvard's Kennedy School was tabulating its latest polls for its new worrywart project on the Vanishing Voter. The numbers showed that despite weeks of Iowa and New Hampshire headlines, and despite the likelihood the whole nominating process will be over by March 7, only 26 percent of the public is paying attention to the campaign. A mere 6 percent of those polled describe themselves as paying "a great deal of attention" -- which is astounding, given that more than 6 percent of the country is either employed by government or a major media organization and therefore might be thought to have a vested interest in Election 2000. What's more, 66 percent don't support any candidate in any party, and 56 percent pronounce the campaign "boring."
Boring? That's the unkindest cut of all, especially given the competition offered this week by professional show business: Barbra Streisand's numbing State of Her Union filibuster at the Golden Globes. If anything, our political culture has been in overdrive, trying to cook up creative story lines. There were the sagas of George W. Bush's smirks (and alleged snorts), Al Gore's sighs (and alleged tokes), John McCain's tantrums, Bill Bradley's heart flips, Warren Beatty's mind games and, of course, Donald Trump's sex life. There was the Naomi Wolf "alpha male" flap and the spirited debate over the true meaning of the Confederate flag. There have been the fascinating colloquies over the differences between the Democrats' health care plans and the Republicans' tax-cut plans. Not to mention the touching spiritual pageant of candidates publicly embracing Jesus.
Even the fringe acts have been worthy of Barnum & Bailey in their heyday. Gary Bauer, the forward-to-the-past family-values candidate, actually did arouse nostalgia for the sideshow era of the Dionne quintuplets by arranging for his donors to gawk at Iowa's McCaughey septuplets in exchange for a $250 campaign contribution. Nearly as bizarre was Mr. Keyes's accusation that Senator McCain, a man who risked his own young life in war, was in peacetime guilty of "aiding and abetting the cultural murder . . . of our young people" because he made a joke about liking the music of Nine Inch Nails.
Surely, though, the most spectacular geek show is that of Steve Forbes, who has spent $60 million of his own money to act out his delusions on the public stage. No one will say the poignant truth about this guy -- that even if he were a better speaker, or less of a hypocrite (how can the billionaire owner of Forbes magazine inveigh repeatedly against the "media elites"?), there would still be the insurmountable problem of his giggly Peeping Tom grin and pop-eyed spectacles. The most virulent, if least acknowledged, bigotry in this country -- far more widespread than sexism or racism and practiced by all genders and ethnic groups -- is looksism. Even in the pre-HDTV era, no one is going to be elected president who doesn't meet the minimal physical standard required of a game-show host.
That the majority of the public choose to ignore all the year's political players is, professors might tell us, a sorry commentary on the state of both the electorate and American politics. We're lousy citizens. Young voters are selfish, ill-informed slackers. Bill Clinton has made all politicians look like dirt. Everyone hates the media.
But a case could also be made that the people in this country, far from being stupid or unpatriotic, are disengaged for good reason. At a time of boom -- polls show that 73 percent say they are better off than eight years ago, and 81 percent want "steady progress" rather than "big, bold" ideas from the next administration -- Americans recognize that the two Democrats and the two Republicans who actually have a shot at being president will not rock the boat. They may also realize that the four men's quarrels on the issues voters care most about (health care, education, Social Security, Medicare) are mostly modest differences about highly incremental means, not ends. The old, bold ideological polarities -- big government programs from Democrats, big government cutbacks from Republicans -- have been sanded down in the Clinton era. Foreign-policy issues aren't even on the table. No wonder the low-rated debates generate sparks only when they resemble "Saturday Night Live" skits, as witness Mr. Keyes's recounting of his excellent adventure in a mosh pit.
Where there still are violent ideological disputes, mainly on cultural issues involving the boundaries of church and state, they are predictable, since the candidates all conform to party stereotype: every Republican hopeful wants to thwart Roe V. Wade, both Democrats want to protect it. Anyone casting a November vote on the basis of which side gets to appoint Supreme Court justices could skip the rest of the campaign and cast absentee ballots now, without waiting to find out the identity of the nominees.
Given four contenders so eager to hug the center, conventional wisdom has it that this election is a battle over character -- hence the endless dissection of smirks and sighs and the constant lookout for this year's magic balm, authenticity. But none of the big four show any sign whatsoever of being sociopaths or, despite the Bickersons routine of Messrs. Gore and Bradley, compulsive liars. Nor, being politicians, will any of the four prove to be completely authentic or free of smarminess -- including Mr. Bradley, who resuscitated Willie Horton for no logical reason, and Mr. McCain, who suddenly found benign dignity in a rebel flag just 24 hours after he had condemned it as a symbol of slavery.
What all four of these men lack is not decency but the vision thing. Neither Mr. Bradley nor Mr. McCain has so far succeeded in his quixotic efforts to arouse public passion about campaign finance reform or the plight of the 27 percent of the country that is not better off than it was eight years ago. Perhaps they fail to command the moral high ground because they, like their opponents, are so blatantly in thrall to big bucks. (To see which corporations have their hooks into which candidates and parties, check out the new paperback "The Buying of the President 2000" from Charles Lewis and the Center for Public Integrity.) Nor have any of the four candidates kept pace with the fast-advancing issues raised by the new digital economy; if they had, maybe the young people who are being either engaged or turned away by that new world might listen to them.
This is instead a fat and happy election, built on the supposition that rosy surplus estimates are accurate and the boom is forever. It feels less like the first election of a new century than the final election of the old one. It's surely the last to be adjudicated by network TV anchors, perhaps the last without widespread Internet balloting, possibly the last in which the parties' summer infomercials will still be referred to as "conventions."
As such, there's no reason to join the 6 percent of Beltway junkies hanging on every Keyes bounce. Which doesn't mean that it won't get more interesting in the stretch. The increasingly inevitable story line that the political press has feared from the start -- that this might actually be a Bush-Gore horse race -- may be far less boring than the alternative narratives that have been trotted out to try to upend it. If 2000 really is the year of Bush-Gore, at some point the Texas governor will have to stop clinging to his twin mantras of "compassionate conservatism" and states' rights every time he wants to duck a controversial issue, and the vice president is going to have to start talking about Buddhist monks. The earth may not move, but the system may have produced just the tepid managers Americans want in a transitional time.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Markets Shaken as Economic Statistics Fan Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell sharply yesterday as the three major market indexes prepared to post their worst performances for a January in a decade or more.
If the current levels hold through Monday, the technology-heavy Nasdaq index, off 4.5 percent for the year, will chalk up its worst start to a year since 1990, the year that the nation's last recession began. The Dow Jones industrial average, down 6.6 percent, will have its worst January since 1978. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, down 7.4 percent, will have its worst January since 1970. 
 Oddly enough, this disappointing performance occurs just as the nation's economy is setting a record for the longest economic expansion in its history.
The sell-off was caused by rising short-term interest rates and growing fear that the Federal Reserve might have to slam -- rather than just tap -- the brakes to slow the economy.
That concern was heightened yesterday as the government reported that inflation, employer costs and economic growth all rose more than expected in the last three months of 1999.
The Commerce Department said that gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 5.8 percent in the last quarter. The inflation gauge rose 2 percent in the quarter, almost twice the 1.1 percent rise in the third quarter. Meanwhile, the Labor Department said that its employment cost index rose 1.1 percent, powered by the largest increase in health care payments, bonuses and other benefits in six years.
"When the Fed is going to be raising rates, the stock market is going to be going down," said Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers, who is still optimistic about the stock market's outlook for the year. "And I think that is all that is going on here."
But given the strong economy and increasing inflationary pressures, the Fed might now have to raise its short-term interest rate target more than the two quarter-point moves that Lehman Brothers has forecast, Mr. Applegate said. "The equity correction could be longer in duration and deeper in decline than it would have been," he said. "But unless the Fed has to tighten a lot, this still shouldn't be more than a correction."
Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said he did not think there was any sign of a major upswing in inflation. But, he said, "I think we are starting to see cyclical forces pushing inflation higher and the markets are having to deal with that."
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 289.15 points, or 2.62 percent, to 10,738.87 yesterday. The S.& P. 500 dropped 38.40, or 2.75 percent, to 1,360.16. Technology stocks, including Qualcomm and Amazon.com, showed their volatility as the Nasdaq composite finished at 3,887.07, down 152.49, or 3.77 percent.
The performance of the stock market in January has been a reasonably good -- but not sure-fire -- predictor of performance for the entire year. Over time, the stock market has tended to do better the rest of the year after strong Januarys than after weak ones. But remember that in 1987, the Dow rose 13.8 percent, its best January ever, before crashing in the fall of that year. The Dow plunged 508.33 points, or 22.6 percent on Oct. 19,1987.
The Dow is now on the way to recording its biggest January loss since the 7.4 percent decline it posted the first month of 1978, while the S.& P. is approaching the 7.65 percent decline of January 1970. The Nasdaq index's previous worst January was the 8.6 percent decline in 1990.
While stock prices fell yesterday, the bond market convulsed. The fear of rate increases by the Fed sent shorter-term interest rates higher, while a sudden influx of cash as investors sought the safety of government debt, pushed long-term rates lower. The decline in long-term interest rates was surprising given the whiff of inflationary pressure in the government economic reports.
But this may have been explained by special factors, including the Treasury's plan to buy back a lot of longer-term debt as it pays down the nation's debt with growing federal budget surpluses. The expected relative scarcity of 30-year bonds in the future has made them especially attractive.
The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 6.45 percent, from 6.52 percent on Thursday. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 28/32 , to 9525/32 . But in a sign of the fears of rising short-term interest rates, the yield on the Treasury's two-year note jumped to 6.54 percent from 6.51 percent and is higher than the yield on the 30-year bond for the first time since 1990.
In the past, such an inverted yield curve, if it persisted, has signaled that the economy was going to slow or that even a recession was possible. But the special factors that have lowered the yield on the 30-year bond make it a unreliable predictor, according to some economists. In fact, the yield on Treasury's 10-year note, at 6.69 percent, is still higher than the 2-year note.
Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Securities, said that the cash flooded into the Treasury markets after investors sold off Europe's single currency, the euro, the last two days. It fell through the psychologically important $1 level on Thursday and slid even lower yesterday, ending at 97.78 cents, down from 98.86 cents.
Ms. Parker also said that losses from the euro trade appeared to bring about changes in the strategies of investors in other currencies, leading to sell-offs of these currencies against the dollar. The most drastic was the Australian dollar, which plunged 3.7 percent against the American dollar yesterday. The Japanese yen also fell.
There were also rumors that a hedge fund had suffered major losses, triggering some of the turmoil in the currency markets. Ms. Parker said that whether or not this was true, the selling of the Australian dollar was not just from one source. She said it was widespread and done by a lot mainline institutional investors.
Many hot performers of last year have been dropped during the decline in the stock market so far this year. For example, three of the top 10 performers in the Dow last year -- Wal-Mart, Microsoft and Home Depot -- are among the 10 top losers so far this year, all with 14 percent or more declines.
In addition countercyclical stocks like pharmaceuticals and consumer staples, which do well even if the economy is slowing, have performed well. Merck, which rose 2 1/8, to 76 1/4, yesterday, is up almost 14 percent for the year.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1230 words

HEADLINE: Bed Is Latest Weapon in Airline Perk Wars

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
The battle for the premium-fare passenger, in which airlines offer luxury more typical of a cruise ship, has risen to this: One major airline will later this year introduce private cabins equipped with double beds.
The cabins, on Virgin Atlantic, will go for about $9,000 for one -- or about $18,000 for a couple -- on a round-trip trans-Atlantic flight. 
 "We're trying to put the romance back into flying," said Richard Branson, chairman of Virgin Group, the parent of Virgin Atlantic.
In fact, the real target is the business traveler. The airlines have good reason to be concerned about such passengers' comfort. Surveys of business travelers, who buy only 20 percent of all tickets but account for about half of industry profits, find that executives would rather snooze during long flights than dine on cabernet and caviar.
Competition is becoming intense to add more in-flight bunks, although most are spartan affairs. British Airways will begin replacing business-class seats in March on flights between New York and London with single beds that the airline boasts have been tested by a NASA scientist to deliver better sleep. Virgin Atlantic is also introducing a new lounger for business class. By spring of next year, American Airlines will have swapped its first-class lounge chairs for seats that convert into beds on all trans-Atlantic and trans-Pacific flights.
Seats that fold into single beds have long been reserved for first-class passengers. Within the next several months, business travelers will have comparable cots at about half the cost.
Within three years, British Airways and Virgin Atlantic will spend about $800 million between them to improve premium service, beyond a $10 billion plan to buy new jets. British Airways predicts that its new beds will increase its share of business travelers between the United States and London, one of the industry's most profitable routes, by almost 2 percent.
Flat-lying beds are cherished perks, since few business travelers have sampled them. A typical British Airways flight from New York to London has only 14 single beds that are sold as first-class seats. By reconfiguring business class with new beds, which are less private than in first class, an additional 70 passengers can have them.
In-flight beds on routes across the Pacific are almost exclusively reserved for first-class passengers. British Airways said that its business-class beds would be installed on all long-haul flights, including those to Asia, within the next 18 months. "One reason that you are seeing all these improvements among the airlines now is that the environment has become so competitive," said Carl Michel, head of the commercial group for British Airways. "On some routes, passengers can choose between 10 airlines."
The airlines have had a long history with beds, even though some industry executives want to pass them off as new amenities. In the 1930's, the Douglas Sleeper Transport, which was used on long night flights, carried as many as 16 people in sleeping berths that were about three feet wide and almost six and a half feet long. MGM Grand Air, which was controlled by the investor Kirk Kerkorian and operated primarily between Los Angeles and New York, had private compartments in the late 1980's, with seats that folded into double beds.
Over the years, beds disappeared to make room for more seats, lifting airline revenue. The trend to drop amenities has reversed recently, with airlines conjuring up new luxuries to lure passengers. Several major airlines -- including British Airways, Qantas Airways and Singapore Airlines -- have private pods with seats that convert into single beds as part of first-class service. But such service, especially to Asia, has a high price. Qantas, for instance, charges $10,844 for a first-class round-trip ticket between Los Angeles and Sydney.
Such features have begun to drift down into business-class cabins. Passengers who book an upper-class seat, the equivalent of British Airways' business class, on any Virgin Atlantic flight can be buffed up by a masseuse and manicurist.
"The carriers keep raising the bar in terms of their premium cabin product," said Sam Buttrick, an airline analyst at PaineWebber. "The leading-edge business class at its inception was an enhanced coach. But many business classes are now better than what was offered in some first-class cabins five or six years ago." First class these days tends to be the domain of top corporate executives, royalty, entertainers and the super-rich, with other affluent people choosing business class.
The airlines are not neglecting economy-class passengers entirely. Some are adding videos to the backs of seats and making chairs more comfortable.
British Airways and Virgin Atlantic conducted extensive research in developing their beds. Mr. Branson said that passengers appreciate his airlines' luxuries so much that they go out of their way to try them. About half of Virgin's passengers are willing to be awakened just to have a complimentary manicure, Mr. Branson said.
To introduce the double beds, which will be about four and a half feet wide and slightly more than six feet long, Mr. Branson will create a first-class cabin, which will force him to buy larger jets to get the extra space.
Mr. Branson jokes that the private double berths will herald a new era for in-flight sex. "We are legitimizing the mile-high club," he said. But he believes that 90 percent of his double-bed customers will be business travelers.
"Most of these people who buy the bed tickets will be executives trying to get from Point A to Point B," he said.
Within the next few months, Virgin Atlantic will also introduce seats that convert into beds for upper-class passengers. Mr. Branson concedes that the seat does not lie fully flat, which has already earned snickers from executives at British Airways.
While the Virgin Atlantic recliner will remain in straight rows of two within the cabin, British Airways will couple its new business-class beds like lounge chairs. Some will face forward and others backward.
In part of each bed, British Airways will include an electrical outlet for passengers' laptop computers, as well as a phone. After passengers complained about standing in line to get their baggage, British Airways will allow its business travelers to carry on 40 pounds of luggage, double what they were allowed before.
The introduction of in-flight bunks has stoked the rivalry between Virgin Atlantic and British Airways.
"The idea of Virgin's double bed is a marketing gimmick," Mr. Michel said. "Richard Branson has been promising that for years. The real argument against a double bed is that couples rarely travel together on business. What happens when one wants to stay up and the other wants to lie down?"
Affable on most matters, Mr. Branson turns almost icy when talking about his London rival. Noting that British Airways may lose millions of dollars this year -- the airline's earnings have declined in recent quarters -- Mr. Branson said, "That just shows that you get your just deserts when you don't keep your quality up."
More elaborate luxuries are on the way. Airbus Industrie said that its proposed new jumbo jet, which will be able to carry more than 500 passengers, could be equipped to include several lounges and sleeping compartments.

HEADLINE: Lawyers Get A Lecture From Judge In Boy's Case

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN with LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 28

 BODY:
The federal judge hearing the appeal by relatives of Elian Gonzalez to raise him in Miami, away from his father in Cuba, told their legal team today to stop all its "hoopla" and "excesses" in rallying public opinion.
The judge, William M. Hoeveler, moved up the date for them to respond to the Justice Department's contention that no court has authority to override its decision to repatriate the child. Saying the lawyers did not need a month to prepare their response, he moved their deadline to Feb. 14 after having set it at Feb. 24 only Thursday. He also set a hearing for Feb. 22. 
 Elian, 6, who lost his mother at sea more than two months ago as she fled Cuba with him to Florida, is fast becoming an international celebrity, with lawyers and public relations agents trotting him out daily.
But after hearing the lawyers' televised comments saluting the near-month they had been given to respond, Judge Hoeveler called the special hearing today, telling the lead lawyer, Spencer Eig, "I'm concerned about all of the hoopla, all of the demonstrations, all of the excesses that have taken place."
"This case," he said, "will be tried on the law and the facts without all the additional fanfare, and I hope we all understand that."
On Thursday, Mr. Eig had ridiculed the Justice Department's "chutzpah" for the nearly two-inch-thick file it submitted to the court, the United States District Court for the Southern District of Florida.
When he asked the judge today to advise him on responding to the news media, Judge Hoeveler said, "I don't want you to comment about what they're doing, about what you're doing, about how bad the government is."
In Washington, as prospects for making Elian an American citizen bogged down, the Roman Catholic nun who brought the boy together with his Cuban grandmothers on Wednesday -- and who now believes the boy should stay in Miami -- privately appealed today to Attorney General Janet Reno, a longtime friend, to change her mind. Although the meeting proved fruitless, Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin said she impressed upon the attorney general that the boy had already deeply bonded with his Miami relatives.
"Had he gone back to Cuba the first week or second week, the position I feel would be different," Sister Jeanne, president of Barry University in Miami Beach, said after her meeting with Ms. Reno.
But Ms. Reno, in a statement issued after the meeting, said she still saw no legal reason to alter a ruling by the Immigration and Naturalization Service that Elian should be returned to his father.
On Capitol Hill, Sister Jeanne's change of heart, and her visit to their offices, re-energized lawmakers who are pushing to make Elian a citizen. Sister Jeanne has visited Cuba and supports lifting the economic embargo against the island, an unpopular position in Miami, so her words are seen to carry extra weight in Florida.
"Sister Jeanne has a tremendous reputation in Miami, Dade County and South Florida as being a lady of principle," said Senator Connie Mack, the Florida Republican who introduced the citizenship bill in the Senate.
But Senator Mack, who said he hopes to move forward with the bill late next week, acknowledged that it faces a rocky road. Several Democrats have threatened to block it, and even Senate Republicans, who initially seemed to embrace the idea, are divided.
Lobbying to the point of exhaustion, Elian's grandmothers have made several trips to Capitol Hill to try to thwart the legislation. They met with several more lawmakers today but were expected to return to Cuba this weekend.
In the House, the legislation's prospects appear no better. Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, sent the bill to the Judiciary Committee, and the chairman of the panel, Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, decided today to set it aside until the courts make a decision.

HEADLINE: New York Drops Psychic Training Program

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Nine months after New York City began recruiting welfare recipients to work from home as telephone psychics, city officials decided that there was no future in it.
Yesterday, Jason A. Turner, commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, announced the end of the city's arrangement with a company calling itself Psychic Network. 
 "Though H.R.A. believes people should have the freedom to choose their own employment, H.R.A.'s Business Link has decided not to include the Psychic Network as one of its participating employers," Mr. Turner said in a one-paragraph statement issued yesterday.
The decision to part company with the Psychic Network came on the same day that an article on the arrangement was published in The New York Times. Since April, 15 welfare recipients had been trained to read tarot cards and hired by the Psychic Network through Business Link, a division of the city welfare department set up in 1995 as part of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's welfare-to-work effort.
A barrage of brickbats and belly laughs met the revelation of the city's venture into the telepsychic realm.
Stephen DiBrienza, chairman of the City Council's Committee on General Welfare and a vigorous opponent of the mayor's welfare policies, seemed almost gleeful in his outrage.
"It's bizarre," he said. "Remember, this is taxpayer funds. I don't think I could find anything more bizarre and at the same time more disturbing if I tried."
Mr. DiBrienza, who has accused Mr. Turner of failing to answer the committee's questions about the types of jobs the city's welfare-to-work programs provide, added, "It's no wonder they stonewall us if these are the kinds of jobs they're pushing."
Shelley Ackerman, the president of the New York chapter of Astrological Federation of America, was upset for other reasons.
"I'm horrified that this is going on," she said, eager to draw a line between a quickie course in tarot and "astrological studies that have been around for thousands and thousands of years." "That a city agency would do this -- it's unbelievable, it's just unbelievable."
Any business that hires a welfare recipient for at least three months can qualify for thousands of dollars in wage subsidies and state and federal tax credits.
"There's no criteria at all," said Carmen Ortiz, national coordinator of the tax credit program said in a recent interview. Michael Kaufman, a financial economist with the United States Treasury Department, estimated the federal tax credits granted nationwide in the program at $370 million.
According to city figures, Psychic Network was one of 161 businesses that successfully recruited with Business Link, which was set up to connect companies in need of workers with welfare recipients in need of jobs. In his statement, Mr. Turner cited as examples Bell Atlantic, Macy's, Rite Aid, Madison Square Garden and United Airlines.
A collection of city recruitment fliers saved by a welfare recipient included three promoting the Psychic Network jobs. Other fliers included jobs as stock clerks, home health aides and, in an October notice, seasonal Christmas wrappers at Tiffany & Company for $7.50 an hour.
City officials have refused to provide a complete list of participating companies on the ground that they were promised confidentiality, unless they chose to go public.
