HEADLINE: City Hall Accepts Bids to Operate Airports

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, jealous of Newark Airport's trailblazing role in the infant aviation industry back in 1939, wanted New York to have its own bustling airport and decided to build two. But just nine years later, Mayor William O'Dwyer -- chafing under the airports' high costs -- signed a longterm lease ceding their operation to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Every mayor since then has accepted that arrangement, giving up control of a resource in return for freedom from unpredictable expenses and the political perils of dealing with as noisy and intrusive an operation as an airport. 
 At least, that was the case until now.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who maintains that the Port Authority has mismanaged the nation's busiest airport system and favored Newark International Airport over Kennedy and La Guardia, wants to take back the two New York airports and have them run by a private company.
Yesterday, the city took its first step toward that goal, as it accepted proposals from four companies. The company that wins the contract would act as the city's consultant, looking over the shoulder of the Port Authority's airport managers until 2015, when the agency's lease expires and the company begins managing the airports.
City officials said the switch will mean an end to the annual "diversion" of $150 million in airport revenues into Port Authority coffers to subsidize money-losing operations like the PATH trains and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, and a reinvestment of that money into the city's airports. With its greater measure of control, the city can force service improvements and lower fees, and be freed to compete with a thriving Newark Airport for flights, said John S. Dyson, chairman of Mayor Giuliani's Council of Economic Advisers.
For many in the growing airport-management industry, the opportunity to run New York's airports is seen as a real plum, given the tremendous increase expected in the air travel over the next decade and the increasing importance of New York.
But some in the industry say the city's effort to take over from the Port Authority is in many ways counterintuitive. Still others who support the Port Authority's stewardship view the mayor's effort as a vindictive swipe at the agency and a move that may put a company's profits ahead of local or regional interests.
David Z. Plavin, president of the Airports Council International of North America, which represents airport operators, said that few municipalities are seeking to take over airports these days, preferring instead to leave operations to independent authorities.
One reason, he said, is federal laws that prohibit diversion of airport revenues into municipal coffers -- a restriction that does not apply to the Port Authority, which can mix revenues from a host of operations in the region, presumably to benefit them all. Under those conditions, many city officials around the country reason that with managing airports they get all the responsibilities and headaches and few of the perquisites and financial returns.
"It is a recent thing for airports to be seen as profitable by themselves anyway," Mr. Plavin said. "Now the mayor doesn't think he is getting the best management, but most consider the Port Authority as doing a pretty good job."
Adam Whiteman, senior vice president of Moody's Investor Service and an analyst who follows the airport industry, said New York's move to take over the airports was unusual but was not likely to trouble airport-management companies, which want a piece of "the premier air transportation market."
Port Authority officials countered the city's complaint that they divert $150 million a year in airport funds by noting that in any given year they pump as much as $150 million in capital improvements into the New York area airports. The authority has embarked on a $10 billion improvement program that includes train connections between Kennedy, subway and bus lines and the Long Island Rail Road. In addition, Kayla Bergeron, the chief spokeswoman for the Port Authority, pointed out that in recent years the city had rejected the agency's offer to increase its annual lease payments to the city by $50 million.
"The city's Economic Development Corporation wants to pay someone to spend the next 15 years watching the Port Authority rebuild the New York airports while they forfeit $50 million a year in increased rental payments that have been offered by the Port Authority," Ms. Bergeron said. "That seems like a curious way to manage public resources."
The four companies that submitted bids to the city were BAA USA, a publicly held British company that owns Heathrow Airport near London and manages airports in Indianapolis, Harrisburg, Pa., and Melbourne, Australia; Hochtief, a German company that runs the Dusseldorf Airport and other small European operations; Schiphol, the Dutch company that runs the airports in Amsterdam and Brisbane, Australia, and a consortium that includes the managers of the Zurich airport.
Anthony P. Coles, a senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani, said the city expected to establish a selection committee next week to examine the bids closely, and hoped to have a consultant in place "in the next several months."
The Port Authority, which is not playing a role in the selection process, still retains control of the airports and therefore does not have to agree to the arrangement.
Among those who are wary of the city's plan is Elizabeth Braton, chairwoman of Community Board 10, near Kennedy Airport. She said that although she had had her differences with the Port Authority over operations at the airport, its officials were accessible and open to compromise.
"I'm no fan of the Port Authority, but they at least listen, while privatization creates an interest in the bottom line, which can clash with the interests of the people," Ms. Braton said.
Stephen Berger, who was executive director of the Port Authority during the 1980's, said the mayor's plan ignored the regional nature of transportation. "This is the result of an angry and vindictive guy who doesn't like any organization on individual over whom he does not have total control."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS;
Bradley Attacks Gore, but Not on Campaign Finance Issue

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: NEWPORT, N.H., Jan. 28

 BODY:
A day after some of his top aides said he was likely to attack Vice President Al Gore for campaign finance abuses, former Senator Bill Bradley held back his toughest punches today and instead accused Mr. Gore of being dishonest on the issues of abortion and gun control.
But later in the evening, Mr. Bradley talked in general terms about the embarrassment the Democratic Party suffered from the Clinton-Gore campaign's aggressive fund-raising in 1996. He did not mention the vice president by name. 
"We have to face up to the fund-raising scandals of 1996," Mr. Bradley told a gathering of New Hampshire Democrats tonight. "They were disgraceful for both Republicans and Democrats, but they were most embarrassing for Democrats, because we're the party of the little guy. We're the reform party."
Earlier, at an event intended to appeal to New Hampshire's large number of independent voters, Mr. Bradley picked up the endorsement of former Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Connecticut, a Republican turned independent. He then proceeded to attack Mr. Gore's integrity.
"We can do great things if we don't have a politics that drags us down," Mr. Bradley told more than 250 people who gathered in an old opera house here, just four days before New Hampshire's Democratic primary, the first in the nation.
Some of Mr. Bradley's aides had predicted he would directly attack Mr. Gore for his role in the party's fund-raising in the 1996 campaign.Many people consider the issue to be Mr. Gore's greatest political liability, largely because Attorney General Janet Reno has investigated fund-raising phone calls made from the White House by President Clinton and Mr. Gore. She decided there was no evidence of wrongdoing.
The decision to avoid criticizing Mr. Gore about those events reflected disagreements among Mr. Bradley's top advisers over how to approach a potentially potent, and contentious, line of attack against the vice president.
It also suggested that Mr. Bradley's advisers, and Mr. Bradley himself, remain uncertain about how far they want to take their newly aggressive attacks, which began this week.
In discussions that went late into Thursday night, some advisers argued that Mr. Weicker's announcement would be an ideal time to raise the fund-raising issue. But others said it would muddy the message of the event: an appeal by Mr. Weicker to independent voters. Mr. Bradley himself was involved in those discussions, the aides asserted.
While the advisers decided against mentioning Mr. Gore in criticizing the 1996 fund-raising, they said today that Mr. Bradley might yet attack the vice president on the issue this weekend.
For his part, Mr. Gore said today that his campaign would refrain from attacks. Arriving in New Hampshire after a trip to Washington for the State of the Union address, Mr. Gore said, "I'm going to emphasize the positive."
The vice president, who is trying in these final days to win over New Hampshire's independent voters, made almost no reference to the president's address. But he did seek credit for being part of an administration that has overseen a near-record economic expansion.
Mr. Gore was asked in local television interviews about Mr. Bradley's stepped-up aggressiveness in attacking him. But after months of insinuations that Mr. Bradley's proposed economic program would squander the surplus and risk taking the country into recession, he was determined today to stay above the fray.
"See," Mr. Gore said, "I'm not going to get down to that level. I'm going to continue to emphasize a positive agenda."
Mr. Gore said repeatedly that the voters did not want to hear negative attacks.
Throughout the day Mr. Bradley used his New Hampshire campaign appearances to accuse Mr. Gore of being untruthful about three issues of great importance to many Democratic voters: abortion, health care and gun control.
At a morning event in Lebanon, Mr. Bradley asserted that Mr. Gore had used "tricky" words to mislead voters into thinking that he supported the licensing of all owners of handguns, when he had actually called for licensing only new buyers.
And he asserted that Mr. Gore has said he supports universal health care without offering such a plan. Mr. Gore contends that his proposal for expanding health care would cover nearly as many people as Mr. Bradley's plan, and at a lower cost.
"I think when you listen to Al Gore speak, you have to listen very carefully," Mr. Bradley said. "Because old politics uses words in a very tricky manner."
Later, in response to a reporter's question, Mr. Bradley asserted that Mr. Gore had been dishonest about changes in his views on abortion. Mr. Gore says he has always supported a woman's right to an abortion, but Mr. Bradley asserts that the vice president was once an opponent of abortion.
"I'm glad his position evolved," Mr. Bradley said. But, he added, "why does his camp say he's always held this position?"
Mr. Bradley's campaign also began running a television commercial today describing him as the only presidential candidate who has consistently supported a woman's right to an abortion.
The Gore campaign countered by releasing a letter signed by more than 40 Democratic members of Congress vouching for the vice president's support of abortion rights and urging Mr. Bradley not to create "differences that do not exist" between the two Democrats.
But Mr. Gore has a mixed record on abortion, having voted several times while he was in the House against the position favored by abortion-rights advocates. Anita Dunn, an adviser to Mr. Bradley, said tonight that indeed there were differences between the two candidates, in that Mr. Bradley has always supported abortion rights.
The Bradley campaign is hoping to magnify Mr. Gore's claim about having always supported abortion rights into a larger question about his character and his ability to tell the truth.
"We think it's an issue that people are curious about, and coming off of the debate it raises questions about candidates' positions and whether they have been totally truthful in the past," Ms. Dunn said.
The Gore campaign was clearly concerned about the emergence of abortion as an issue in the Democratic primary. The letter that it released tonight tries to divert attention from Mr. Gore's votes against federal funding for abortions for poor women and put the focus on the the fact that the leading Republican contender, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, opposes abortion.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1350 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
In Newark's South Ward, a New Distribution Center

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
MANY of the houses in the neighborhood are vacant and boarded up, and packs of stray dogs wander the streets, but here in the South Ward a new 100,000-square-foot distribution center has been built and was fully leased before construction was completed.
The center, which may eventually employ as many as 100 people, is an attempt by the city and a private, nonprofit development group to take advantage of the area's principal asset: its geography. South Ward is within a few minutes' driving time of the growing Newark Airport and the adjacent container seaports. It is also in the midst of a tangle of highways, including I-78 and I-95, the New Jersey Turnpike. The local Routes 1-9 and 22 are nearby as well. 
 Although it is a distance from Newark's downtown, with its glittering new performing arts center, a minor league baseball stadium and the promise of more sporting events, the project at Bergen Street and Hawthorne Avenue has just what distribution and logistics companies need. In addition to proximity to the ports and highways, the new building has high ceilings, which permit the storage of more goods per rented square foot; 30 docks for unloading and loading; and an expansive paved area on the seven-acre site so tractor-trailer trucks, which have grown longer in recent years, can turn around.
"The area had all the problems of urban blight, but the proximity to I-78 and the ports made it attractive to freight forwarders," said Ronald Sholom, chairman of SBWE, the brokerage that represented the project.
"It's a one-minute drive to I-78 and there are six ways to get there," said Mark Tannen, a vice president of SBWE who was also involved in the South Ward project. "If there is a jam on the highway, you can take local roads to get around it."
A booming economy and the need for distribution facilities close to markets like New York and northern New Jersey have put pressure on the industrial real estate market and helped attract tenants to the South Ward project, despite the appearance of nearby blocks.
"The industrial market is brisk and there is not much product available," said Benjamin Katz, a senior managing director of Insignia/ESG's operations in New Jersey. "The vacancy rate is below 7 percent, and rental rates are up 10 to 15 percent over the last year."
He said the period of free rent, which owners offer tenants in times of slack markets, has all but disappeared and allowances for the cost of interior construction have dwindled as well. He said industrial properties in New Jersey are now leasing before the previous tenants have vacated, a new practice for the area.
"In New Jersey a property usually went vacant for a time before being re-let, but now buildings are starting to lease before they become vacant," Mr. Katz said.
ANOTHER issue affecting the market, brokers said, was that many of the older buildings in the area have low ceilings and are considered unsuitable by distributors, who want the cubic space provided by taller ceilings.
"It's a lot cheaper to go up rather than out," Mr. Sholom said. "It's like using air space."" He said the "shelf life" or time of usefulness of industrial buildings was shrinking as the development of super-flat floors, which make it possible to stack products higher, and new sprinkler fire-fighting systems attracts tenants to more modern properties.
Rental rates in places like the South Ward are under $10 a square foot annually, said Mr. Tannen, while properties immediately adjacent to the airport can demand rents in the mid-teens per square foot a year.
Since it is intended to be the centerpiece of local development that will include new housing, a school and a police station as well as additional warehousing and distribution, South Ward Industrial Park, as the distribution center is known, is not a drab concrete block box. Several towers interrupt the roofline and windows that are set high in the walls of the distribution center to suggest offices on the second floor.
There is no second floor, of course, but the windows add an accent to the building's outer appearance and bring natural light into the building's interior. "We didn't want it to look like an industrial building, that's the reason for all the schmaltz on the outside," said Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the Newark Economic Development Corporation, the nonprofit organization that is working with city government on the South Ward project.
Inside, infrared heaters over the dock entrances keep people and cargo from freezing in cold weather. Because the work is done in hours of darkness, spotlights are trained to beam deeply into cargo trailers.
Since the area had once been largely residential, assembly and preparation of the land was difficult. "Every 25 feet there was an oil tank and a foundation," left over from the housing that once stood on the lot, Mr. Faiella said. In all, he said, close to 600 oil tanks had to be removed.
Assembling the land was simplified because many of the lots had reverted to city ownership because of the nonpayment of taxes. Mr. Faiella said about 15 percent of the land had to be condemned by the city to produce unified sites.
Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, who once represented the South Ward on the city council, described the distribution center as "a start." He said work on a building for a school that has been in temporary quarters for 27 years will begin this year.
He said indecision by state highway authorities about whether to build a section of road in the area had delayed efforts at renewal. "We had a problem with the State Department of Transportation," he said. "They put a freeze on development." But now, he said, the highway issue has been resolved "and we can make our plans."
Another reason for the delay in redeveloping the area was plans by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to develop the area industrially in the early 1980's. The authority could never make the economics of its proposals work out, Mr. Faiella said, but did contribute to the $9 million cost of the South Ward project.
One of the tenants at South Ward Industrial Park is Forward Air, a company that ships cargo collected by some companies that promise overnight delivery ostensibly by air shipment. Instead, much of the cargo is transferred to wholesale shippers like Forward Air who move it by truck on a tight schedule.
"We can move freight on the ground faster than the airlines," said Thomas Keegan, the company's vice president for operations for the northeast region. The company ships freight overnight to locations where the delivery company can collect it for distribution to individual businesses and homes.
"We are wholesalers to the air-freight forwarders and airlines," he said. "We move time-sensitive shipments. If something is picked up at 10 p. m. in Washington, we will have it in Boston by 9 a.m."
Since the air-delivery companies are near airports, it was important for Forward Air to be close by to minimize the time between trips back and forth. "We need to be near our customer base, but we could not find any property to buy," Mr. Keegan said. "This was a godsend."
There are other cleared sites that are slated for industrial development within a few blocks of the new distribution center and opportunities in old, slightly contaminated industrial properties, known as brownfields, Mr. Sholom said. Since the state has relaxed the cleanup rules for properties that will remain in industrial, rather than residential use, he said there were more opportunities to put projects on sites that are already served by highways, water and sewers, electrical power and other parts of the infrastructure.
In the South Ward, he said, the cleared land will support 100,000 square feet of development, which may be developed as two 50,000-square-foot buildings. He said the search for tenants for the first building in the area brought expressions of interest from other companies.
"We are in negotiations with Newark officials on the next phase, which should start to come on within 12 months," he said.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1819 words

HEADLINE: Practical Traveler;
Fewer Barriers For the Disabled

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
A NUMBER of changes making travel more accessible for people with disabilities have unfolded in recent days. Here are some of these developments.
The world's largest economy lodging chain, Days Inns of America, reached an agreement with the federal Government last month that should mean an increase in motel rooms adapted for disabled guests. 
 The agreement between Days Inns of Parsippany, N.J., a division of the Cendant Corporation, and the Justice Department ended a dispute of more than five years. The chain will require that owners who plan to open motels bearing its name must certify the places comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act. It will also pay for a survey to identify problems at places built since 1993 that have already opened, and establish a $4.7 million interest-free loan fund to help franchise holders at these hotels make needed renovations. The chain also paid the United States $50,000 in penalties. Days Inn has 152,000 guest rooms in 1,800 properties in the United States.
John L. Wodatch, head of the department's disability-rights division, said he hoped that the agreement would serve as a model for other franchising companies that play a role in the design of independently operated hotels and motels. Mr. Wodatch said it was a difficult agreement to reach because the company said it was not in the hotel business but in the franchising business.
 
What the Law Calls For
 The disability act, signed by President George W. Bush in 1990, requires that motels built after Jan. 26, 1993, meet particular rules: public areas and a percentage of bedrooms must be accessible by wheelchair; alarms, telephones, bathroom fixtures and the like must accommodate guests with vision or hearing impairments or other disabilities. In 1994, the Justice Department began investigating newly built Days Inns; Mr. Wodatch said then that consumer complaints against the chain outnumbered those against other companies.
In 1996, the department sued five new Days Inns, their architects and contractors as well as Days Inns of America and its parent company, now Cendant, saying that the motels did not provide equal access for disabled guests. A number of other properties originally on the lawsuit list reached settlements before they were sued. The parent company responded that it had no responsibility for individual motels' compliance with the law, that it merely licensed the brand name and provided certain services for a fee.
The department found some problems recurring throughout the chain, among them, insufficient accessible parking, inaccessible entrances and walkways; inadequate signs for those with limited vision; bathroom doors too narrow for wheelchairs.
Last month's settlement, filed in federal court in Kentucky, where one of the five motels was situated, came after 13 months of mediation. Days Inns said it believed the settlement was "good for our customers, the traveling public and the hotel industry." Attorney General Janet Reno said that she hoped other hotels and hotel-franchise companies would make similar changes to assure full accessibility.
The law says that properties built before 1993 need make accessibility alterations only in areas being renovated; this means that landmark properties and other historic hotels that do not renovate can still have lobbies with a lot of steps and no ramps, registration desks too high to reach from wheelchairs and other features that may thwart disabled guests.
London theater will be more accessible for travelers with hearing loss during a tour scheduled for March by the Theater Access Project of the Theater Development Fund. This nonprofit organization, sponsor of the TKTS discount-ticket booths in Manhattan, believes this is the first London theater tour for hearing-impaired Americans. The League for the Hard of Hearing and its affiliated Advocates for Better Communication have joined to sponsor the trip for 25 participants.
The group will take along a screen that displays dialogue in two-inch-high electronic captions. This display was developed by an American, Don DePew, using court-reporting computer programs. It has been used in Broadway and Off Broadway theaters for three years, according to Lisa Carling, the project's director.
The script for "Antony and Cleopatra," as presented by the Royal Shakespeare Company at the Barbican, and for a West End play will be transcribed into the system ahead of time, along with notes on offstage sounds and the like. In the theater, the device is placed at the side of the orchestra and an auditor scrolls three lines at a time as the dialogue is spoken. Although amplification devices are available in London theaters, the Theater Access Project believes that this will be the first use of open captioning there. The London theaters are advertising the performances, and seats may be reserved in the caption-viewing seats.
The seven-night trip, leaving March 25, has other events and tours scheduled. The cost is $1,999 a person with two in a room at the Strand Palace Hotel on the Strand. Air fare on British Airways, departure and hotel taxes and transfer of one piece of baggage are included. A single room costs $430 more. The reservation deadline is Feb. 10. Theater Access Project, (212) 221-0885, extension 257; the TTY (teletypewriter) number is (212) 719-4537; www.tdf.org. The League for the Hard of Hearing is at www.lhh.org.
 
Rights in the Air
In the Denver airport, I encountered a group of wheelchair users waiting to board. I was amazed to learn that they were a team going to play Quad Rugby, a fierce game played by quadriplegics. "It becomes clear that wheels are weapons, and pity should be checked at the door," a Denver Post reporter said in describing a game in November.
The treatment of disabled passengers aboard planes is governed by the Air Carrier Access Act, a law older than the disability-rights act, but it looked complicated to me getting a batch of wheelchair passengers onto one plane. The act anticipates this possibility, requiring that any group of 10 or more with disabilities give the airline 48 hours' notice.
Jennifer Theisen, who works at the Craig Hospital in Englewood, Colo., and is coordinator for the group I met, the Denver Harlequin Rugby Club, said that United Airlines gave her a lot of help in the eight trips her 15-member team made in a season. She avoids connecting flights, and United can get the team nonstop to most tournaments. She orders bulkhead seats for the players and the accompanying people, she said, and generally this works out. The players are boarded ahead of the other passengers, reaching their seats in the airline's narrow aisle wheelchair and getting into them by boosting themselves over any fixed chair arms. Ms. Theisen said that although the players were quadriplegics, they had varying degrees of upper-body mobility and were strong.
The passengers' own wheelchairs are the last things to be checked into the luggage compartment, as the law requires, she said, and they come out first and are ready at the Jetway. Ms. Theisen said that the team usually got off the plane last.
Ms. Theisen, who has dealt with other airlines in the West, and not always so successfully, believes that United's agents are well trained in the legal requirements.
Wheelchair users or their companions often find that they do not have the law's provisions at hand, as Ms. Theisen does, when talking to boarding agents. To assist them, the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association has just published two new pocket cards summarizing the act. These note, for example, that batteries on wheelchairs are not to be drained under any circumstances and that 48 hours' notice is required if an electric wheelchair is going to be transported on a plane with fewer than 60 seats.
A single set of the cards and an air-carrier leaflet are available free from the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, 75-20 Astoria Boulevard, Jackson Heights, N.Y. 11370; (718) 779-8377.
 
Dialysis Cruise
Cruises are feasible vacations for those requiring kidney dialysis, who may otherwise be limited in their ability to go far.
A new vessel, the 513-passenger Deutschland of Peter Deilmann's EuropAmerica Cruises, has a dialysis center aboard to accommodate 12 kidney patients on a cruise.
The liner's itinerary this spring and summer ranges from the Mediterranean to the North Sea and the Baltic, to Scandinavia, across the Atlantic and through the Panama Canal to the Pacific. Many cruises on the Deutschland, which is luxurious, are 7 to 18 nights long. The least expensive 14-night cruise costs $4,040 a person, double occupancy. Dialysis is about $280 a treatment extra (at 1.93 marks to $1), which is paid at the time of treatment. Kidney patients and their doctors must provide medical records in advance to Bauer, a medical firm in Kiel, Germany, that arranges for treatments and medical personnel on board.
Peter Deilmann Ocean Cruises, 1800 Diagonal Road, Suite 170, Alexandria, Va. 22314; (800) 348-8287; on the Web: www.deilmann-cruises .com.
Dialysis Traveller-Dialysis at Sea, a Florida organization in business for 20 years, has arrangements with many cruise lines to provide on-board treatments. Steve Debroux, the president, said that he booked 600 clients a year aboard cruises. There are 100 cruises listed for the coming 15 months in the catalogue; a minimum booking is 8 dialysis passengers and a maximum is 12. The charge per treatment is $425.
The list of cruises by region appears on the Web site, www.dialysis-at-sea.com. Dialysis Traveller-Dialysis at Sea Cruises, 801 West Bay Drive, Largo, Fla., 33770; (800) 544-7604.
 
 Help on the Web
Another resource on accessible travel is found at a Web site maintained by a California couple, Candy B. Harrington and Charles Pannell, who have been gathering information on the subject for three years and who also publish a quarterly newsletter, Emerging Horizons. The site, emerginghorizons.com, recently had a detailed article on San Diego. The newsletter, which carries no advertising, prints lists of motels with roll-in showers that guarantee a reservation for an accessible room. The winter 2000 issue has a list for Las Vegas.
The main article in this issue of the newsletter talks about accessibility in Florence; it tells which entrance to the Uffizi to use, the width of the elevator door at the Palazzo Vecchio museum entrance (29 1/2 inches) and which door to get unlocked to see the Boboli Gardens. The author, Cornelia Danielson, a Florence resident, is described as founder of Barrier Free Travel/Viaggiare Senza Barriere, a nonprofit organization in Tuscany. A year's subscription to the newsletter costs $11.95 in the United States. Checks, Visa and MasterCard are accepted.
Emerging Horizons, Post Office Box 278, Ripon, Calif. 95366; (209) 599-9409.

PUB-DATE: January 30, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 3195 words

HEADLINE: Here A Comic Genius, There A Comic Genius

BYLINE: By FRANZ LIDZ and STEVE RUSHIN; Franz Lidz, the author of "Unstrung Heroes," and Steve Rushin, the author of "Road Swing," are senior writers at Sports Illustrated.

 BODY:
HUMANKIND used to produce two or three geniuses per century. Now, it gives us a couple of dozen per month. Last November's Genius issue of Esquire showcased those men and women "transforming our civilization," including the N.B.A. point guard Allen Iverson and the brilliant Leonardo -- not Da Vinci, but DiCaprio. Today, everyone and his dog is a genius. (Literally: Barnes & Noble shoppers can buy "Caninestein: Awakening the Genius in Your Dog.") The coin of genius is now so frequently minted that it has all the value of the Botswanan pula. 
 Nowhere is this inflation more evident than in current comic cinema. "Comic genius" Jim Carrey (Time magazine) appears as "comic genius" Andy Kaufman (The New Yorker) in "Man on the Moon." Last year's "Bowfinger," starring and written by "comic genius" Steve Martin (The Washington Post) was powered by a dual-character performance by "comic genius" Eddie Murphy (USA Today). The malevolent ventriloquist played by "comic genius" Bill Murray (The New York Observer) menaced multiplexes in "Cradle Will Rock" while the malevolent scientist played by "comic genius" Mike Myers (Chicago Sun-Times) menaced his ventriloquist dummy of a sidekick in "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me."
No C.G. has a longer C.V. than Robin Williams, the android star of "Bicentennial Man." A computer database search of his name turns up three times more published references to Williams as a comic genius than to any other actor.
When every comic actor becomes a genius, it seems, every genius becomes a comic actor: "comic genius" Albert Brooks (The Alberta Report) was born Albert Einstein.
"Genius is an overused superlative in show business," says "comic genius" Woody Allen (The New York Times) in a phone interview. "Lots of very talented comedians can make you laugh, but if you think of Mozart and Picasso and Shakespeare, it's difficult to find a comedian who rises to the level of genius. A genius is like a sudden mutation. It's not that you get very good and very, very good and suddenly you achieve genius. It's not achievable in a gradual or practiced way. Somebody's just born and hit with the magic."
In film, the number of genuine comic geniuses can be counted on one hand, or, at most, on the hand-and-a-half of Harold Lloyd, who lost several fingers to a prop explosive. Even Mr. Lloyd, whose final clock-clinging minutes of "Safety Last" (1923) are the most audaciously funny on film, does not make Mr. Allen's All-Star team: Charlie Chaplin, Buster Keaton, W. C. Fields, Groucho and Harpo Marx and Peter Sellers. Mr. Allen had included Mae West, but called the next day and busted her down to "an enormously gifted performer like Bob Hope and Jack Benny, but not a genius."
John Cleese can think of only one living genius of movie comedy: Woody Allen. "The main thing that makes people laugh now is shock," says Mr. Cleese, the Minister of Silly Walks, from his car phone on the Pacific Coast Highway. "The film 'There's Something About Mary' had funny stuff, but lacked the classical structure, evenness of tone and precision of comic genius. I kind of ache for that."
Mr. Allen does, too. "I don't really want to put the knock on people, but many current comedies that are considered great are not," he says. "I don't find them funny."
They're both right. There are enough "comic geniuses" panhandling for approval in theaters these days to fill the Academy of the Overrated, the purgatory Mr. Allen created for the not-great-enough in "Manhattan" (1979). A performer, after all, can be clever and resourceful without being a genius.
Steve Martin, who excels at playing exaggerated oafs, can't help that an elephant caravan of blather now attends his every artistic endeavor -- in movies, theater and belles lettres. "His humor is more Flaubert than Dreiser," the New Yorker editor David Remnick has hyperventilated about the co-star and co-writer of (cough, cough) "Three Amigos!" But Mr. Martin's humor is also more Jerk than Tramp, more rimshot than Rimbaud. He often seems uncomfortable when not doing shtick.
The same goes for Mr. Brooks, who once told an interviewer that the overwrought exhibitionists he plays are not "insecure," they're "vulnerable"; they're not "whiny," they're "pleading." "Follow your feelings" is the Brooksian mantra -- in "The Muse" his noodge did, probing deep beneath a hardened pseudo-intellectual exterior to expose a gooey pseudo-intellectual interior. There's no there behind Mr. Brooks's despair, as there is with, say, Mr. Allen or Bill Murray, whose swaggering cynicism elevated "Groundhog Day" (1993) from a one-trick "Twilight Zone" episode into a pleasing meditation on mortality and misery. Sadness clings to Mr. Murray like a monkey on a racehorse, and still he wins us over with the sincerity of his world-weary insincerity.
The insincerity of Robin Williams's cloying sincerity -- in films from "Good Morning, Vietnam" (1987) through "Patch Adams" (1998) -- has won him a worldwide audience of enablers. Even President Clinton cannot speak Mr. Williams's name without first conceding his C.G., as if he were a Supreme Court appointee, entitled to the honorific. But then Mr. Clinton, with his I-feel-your-pain sanctimony, is practically Mr. Williams's alter-ego.
The politician in Mr. Williams has won out over the manic Jonathan Winters manque of "Mork and Mindy." "Williams wants to save the world with laughter," wrote the film critic David Denby. "He has tried to free the spiritually imprisoned, loosen our tongues, loosen our bowels -- he's become a purgative of second-rate feelings, a twinkly, husky-voiced leprechaun, funneling counterculture mush through New Age mush." Mr. Williams is free to make his own career choices, but his attendance is not required at the genius ball.
Saving the world with laughter is so powerful a pretension that Mr. Williams, Jerry Lewis and Roberto Benigni have all accepted the ultimate double-dare -- finding comic expression in Nazi oppression. It worked better for Mr. Benigni ("Life Is Beautiful" won him an Oscar) than the others (for sheer chutzpah, the Polish ghetto-blaster Mr. Williams played in "Jakob the Liar" was topped only by -- there is no other phrase for it -- the concentraton camp counselor Mr. Lewis portrayed in "The Day the Clown Cried," a 1972 film so egregious and exploitative that it has never been released). The critic Andrew Sarris has argued that when Mr. Lewis became conscious of his own art -- about the time he became a genie comique in France -- his aspirations exceeded his ability.
This messianic impulse, Mr. Cleese says, is almost always "doomed to failure." (The director Frank Capra on how the silent screen comedian Harry Langdon lost his innocence and his audience: "The trouble was that high-brow critics came around to explain his art to him.") Mr. Myers is eminently aware of his art -- he can recite Da Vinci's "Seven Tenets of Genius" in Italian -- but has so far resisted the impulse to become an artiste. "When a comedian tries to do more significant things, very often he strikes out," agrees Mr. Allen, who has himself sometimes seemed lost in half-baked homages to foreign masters. "The urge to try to do more, is healthy. In comedy, the quickest way to death as an artist is to repeat a successful formula over and over. The other is a slower way to death."
MR. Allen started reaching for significance about the time of "Annie Hall" (1977). "I don't want to make funny movies any more," says the melancholy filmmaker he plays in "Stardust Memories" (1980). "They can't force me to." He became so immersed in the claustrophobic culture of New York that when he attempted an amiable confection like "Manhattan Murder Mystery" (1993), he was like a pitching ace who had lost his rhythm. It was a little painful watching him and Diane Keaton become middle-aged, acting out his favorite old movies. One Ingmar Bergman per century is enough.
All art is the same, said Samuel Beckett: an attempt to fill an empty space. Great art -- say, Beckett's tragicomedy "Waiting For Godot" -- is inherently subversive, shaking us out of our cozy assumptions, forcing upon us fresh perspectives. German funnyman Bertolt Brecht wrote: "Don't be comfortable." But art requires more than discomfiting an audience. No comedian disturbed a crowd more than Andy Kaufman, subject of the current biopic "Man on the Moon." He was less interested in amusing his fans than in abusing them, by turning the conventions of television comedy inside-out. Of course, subverting the traditions of television gag writing is hardly worth the time or energy. One might say Mr. Kaufman staged a devilish coup, elaborately plotted, to oust a third-grade class president. In doing so, he aspired to show, as Mr. Carrey told Newsweek, that comedy "doesn't even have to be funny. It can be weird or ironic." This is preposterous. "If it's not funny," says Mr. Cleese, "I don't think you can call it comedy."
No one is quite sure whether Kaufman was deliriously subversive or merely delirious. "There's a connection between neuroses and great comic talent," says Mr. Cleese. "There's also a difference between comic genius and mental illness."
The director Michael Curtiz once said: "Nobody should try to play comedy unless they have a circus going on inside." By that definition, Mr. Carrey, alone among contemporary comedians, appears possessed of the genius gene. The clinical insanity that seems to afflict him onscreen is itself a form of subversion. A high school dropout with a truly wretched childhood, he is the lone contemporary comedian with a pedigree to match the geniuses in Mr. Allen's pantheon. All six came up from poverty, had little formal schooling and sandpapered their technique in music halls. Mr. Carrey is the only working actor save Mr. Murray who can keep a sinking comedy afloat. Mr. Williams ("Mrs. Doubtfire") and Mr. Martin ("The Out-of-Towners") just punch holes in the hull.
Mr. Carrey exerts his own gravitational pull on the often ordinary films he appears in, defying moviegoers to take their eyes off him. Stanley Kubrick may as well have been speaking of Mr. Carrey when he said, "The quality that distinguishes him from other great comic actors is his ability to transform the horrifying and grotesque into unforgettable comic invention."
In fact, Kubrick was speaking of Peter Sellers, whom he directed in two of the actor's masterworks, "Dr. Strangelove" and "Lolita." His work in the latter was the most richly subversive comic performance in film history, undermining the work of two other geniuses. In the minor role of Clare Quilty, Sellers ignored the script of Vladimir Nabokov, and so seduced Kubrick that he made the movie his own. "He wasn't like you and me," Lolita says of Quilty in the penultimate scene. "He wasn't a normal person. He was a genius."
In assuming three sharply different characters -- playboy playwright, ingratiating cop, and the school psychologist Dr. Zempf riffing on "the irrationality of rationality" -- Sellers seizes the production by its ankles and shakes out all its change. No one is more unsettled than James Mason, who plays Humbert Humbert: faced with Quilty's genius, he is faced with Sellers' genius, which makes both actor and character profoundly uneasy. The audience can fairly feel his flop sweat, for the classically trained Mason spends much of the film looking terrified -- as if, at any moment, he will be ground in the gears of Sellers' diabolical mind.
Playing Chauncey Gardiner in "Being There," Sellers somehow filled the screen with his emptiness. His absence of personality made him a formidable presence. The dichotomy is difficult to deconstruct, but then so is the theory of relativity. "Sellers goes to the deep core of what's funny," says Mr. Allen. "His funniness was the funniness of genius. What he had to offer was clearly gold."
In comedy, of course, one man's gold is another's (Shecky) Greene, which makes isolating the genius gene all the more difficult. "I saw 'Broadway Danny Rose' and sat for 45 minutes waiting for the film to begin," Mr. Cleese says. "It seemed to me an extremely boring movie. Yet it's Steve Martin's favorite Woody Allen film."
Mr. Allen himself is unawed by Laurel and Hardy. "I appreciate Hardy because there's something amusing to me about his constant intolerance of and disgust with and hostility toward his partner," he says. "The other guy, scratching his head and crying, never made me smile."
WHEN Stan Laurel can be dismissed, by one who should know better, as The Other Guy Scratching His Head, what hope have Jacques Tati or Mel Brooks of ever sitting at comedy's grownup table? Mr. Brooks's gift is in mining a genre -- the western, the horror film -- for every mote of comic possibility, just as Mr. Myers's "Austin Powers" movies are a comprehensive package tour of the 60's spy caper. "Mel Brooks is an intellectual gentle giant," offers Mr. Myers. "He uses his intellect to be wonderfully and deliciously stupid."
Certainly -- or should we say, "soitainly" -- there is such a thing as lowbrow brilliance, or what's Curly Howard for? The best dipstick for gauging a comic's depth is involuntary laughter. By that standard, Mr. Myers's Austin Powers is a formidable comic creation, as was the Nutty Professor. "Jerry Lewis has the capability to be very, very funny: physically, charismatically," Mr. Allen concedes. "You see how deeply audiences have responded to him."
Even allowing for a nyuck-nyuck knucklehead like Curly, our candidates for geniushood are all white males, few of them still drawing audiences, and almost none still drawing breath. What's more, they are white American and European males, the only kind that are approved in any great number for worldwide audiences. Surely there is some unknown Cantinflas of comedy out there, the beacon of his or her talent hidden beneath a bumblebee suit on Mexican television. But we have yet to see that C.G., and quite likely never will. This reflects, more than anything, the bigotry of American movies and culture. It has nothing to do with ability, and everything to do with access and opportunity. This unhappy fact was not lost on the actress and screenwriter Mae West, whose saloon singer purrs in "She Done Him Wrong" (1933): "Men's all alike, married or single. It's their game. I just happen to be smart enough to play it their way."
Hollywood's leering overlords let West strut her stuff for only a few films before the Hays Office stepped in and made her an honest (and far less humorous) woman. "Women in general have been kept in a different cage over the years," Mr. Allen says, "and it is only comparatively recently that they've been given the freedom and social acceptance to be comedians. It's the same with blacks."
Richard Pryor -- the profane Jackie Robinson of comic cinema -- was devoured and mainstreamed by Hollywood's makeover machinery. That same machinery was implicated in the industrial accident involving Eddie Murphy, Pryor's protege, whose sharp corners were sheared off by a buzzsaw of buddy flicks.
Mr. Pryor's most memorable work was in standup; his best films are footage of his uncinematic stage act. Which raises another point. There have, undoubtedly, been comic geniuses in other performance fields. But Jonathan Winters, whom Mr. Allen anoints as the peerless genius of standup, "didn't have an ambition to be in movies," Mr. Allen says. "He just never seemed to be interested."
Television's most inspired sketch artists (Sid Caesar, Ernie Kovacs, Butthead) were often dazzling in the fierce run of five minutes, but exhausting and impersonal for much longer. Mr. Cleese claims the only "true" comic genius he ever met was Peter Cook of the satiric revue "Beyond the Fringe." "In stage monologues, Peter could saw it off by the yard," Mr. Cleese says. "To me, genius has something to do with doing it much more easily than others. Peter's problem was that it came too easily." But Cook, who died in 1995, could not transfer his genius to film, the most difficult parlor trick and, for the comic actor, the ultimate test of comic genius.
Mr. Cleese's Monty Python troupe was even more giddily sublime on film than on television. The Flying Circus performed its convention-defying loops and turns in three features, launching aerial assaults on pomposity, gentility and the odd wet fish. "The Pythons were a periodic table of the elements of comedy," says Mr. Myers. "If you distilled almost any of my comic ideas down to its molecular level, you'd be left with something from Python."
Mr. Cleese seems to have distilled his comic ideas down to sub-atomic quarks. He laments that the film "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" was "terrific for the first 40 minutes and the last 30, but soft in the middle." And he reckons structuring a movie that lasts 90 minutes is 30 times harder than plotting a five-minute sketch and 20 times harder than a half-hour sitcom. "It's difficult to be consistently funny," he says. "The great geniuses each only produced two or three movies tops that were classics."
CHAPLIN learned to make comedies when there was no one to learn from. He was comedy's Columbus, discovering new worlds that comedians will still be colonizing for as long as pratfalls are projected on screens. Today, the Little Tramp's influence runs like a shared memory through nearly every film comedic creation, from Ace Ventura to Deuce Bigalow. "I don't believe Chaplin was aware of creating a new vocabulary for film comedy," says Mr. Allen. "He just happened to be that gifted, that superb. Very few have taken that extreme leap into a realm that is undefinable and unexplainable."
The Tramp made his transcendant leap in "City Lights" (1931). "Chaplin tried to do something a little more dimensional than slap-around Mack Sennett comedy," says Mr. Allen. "City Lights was funny and also tragic. Some think it's sentimental, but to me, it's an honest film about love."
"City Lights" is an ostensibly simple tale: the Tramp courts a blind flower girl and tries to impress her by pretending he's a millionaire. At the end of the film, she finally sees the mysterious benefactor who paid for the operation to restore her sight. The flower girl watches in amusement as a newsboy pulls a rag from the tattered trousers of the Tramp, who scolds the kid, blows his nose on the rag, folds it neatly and tucks it into his vest pocket. "She recognizes who he must be by his shy, confident, shining joy as he comes silently toward her," James Agee wrote in 1949. "And he recognizes himself, for the first time, through the terrible changes in her face. The camera just exchanges a few quiet close-ups of the emotions which shift and intensify in each face. It is enough to shrivel the heart to see, and it is the greatest piece of acting and the highest moment in movies."
"City Lights" is, to be sure, a work of comic genius, but even that phrase proves inadequate. With its final close-ups, it sheds the modifier like a baby does its umbilical cord and becomes, alone among film comedies, a work of just-plain genius.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 15; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Film;
In a World With Less Time, Movies That Last a Millennium

BYLINE: By DAVID THOMSON; David Thomson is the author of "A Biographical Dictionary of Film." His book "In Nevada" was published last fall.

 BODY:
EARLY in the third hour of "The Green Mile" (running time 180 minutes), when I had given up on the joke that the title referred to the Tom Hanks character's vexed urinary tract, on considering how the San Francisco 49ers are going to have to rebuild and on making a list of Christmas thank-you notes (I may even have dozed, too), it came to me that a wise god (call him Jack Valenti) should institute a basic-ability test for would-be film directors.
Give them a camera, some film and a few actors, and let them redo the Howard Hawks 1940 film "His Girl Friday" (92 minutes). No one who can't bring it in under 120 minutes gets a picture. 
 This modern lengthiness isn't a trend; it's an incline. Suppose, for the sake of argument, that the nominees for best picture for 1999 are "The Green Mile," "Any Given Sunday" (160 minutes), "The Insider" (155), "The Talented Mr. Ripley" (135) and "American Beauty" (115) -- that's 745 minutes of watching. Go back to 1950, and that year's actual nominees were "Sunset Boulevard" (110), "King Solomon's Mines" (102), "Father of the Bride" (93), "Born Yesterday" (103) and "All About Eve" (138; well, like the lady warned, it was a bumpy night). Total time: 546 minutes. You could have talked to your kids that year, or had a hobby.
What makes this development so egregious is that here in 2000 we're lectured all over the place about how our attention spans have become abbreviated, how our sentences, paragraphs and thoughts are shorter and how the extraordinary burden of media stress, e-mail answerability and getting your data has given us less and less time to have children, let alone message them, and yet somehow the most up-to-date moviemakers are crazy for longer, slower establishing shots, for mood interludes and for letting Al Pacino show us all of an actor's choices instead of making him pick one (one sentence -- 100 words).
I think the "His Girl Friday" test would teach us a lot. For one thing, you'd find that many of the young actors you used (and wouldn't it be marvelous training for them?) would drag the director and the writer into lingering conversations about the Cary Grant character's motivation, the whole back story of his marriage to Rosalind Russell. And you'd get very hurt looks if you told them it was a game, a sort of play for naughty children, a version of squash in which talk was the ball and the other characters were the walls it bounced off, so trust the situation and the language and just learn to talk as fast as you can without dropping or slurring a syllable. Who knows? If you can bring it off, you might end up looking like some of the most intelligent, attractive people who ever existed. I can hear the actors grumbling: "Gee, man, that's not like life. There's no sense memory." Thank God! "Scent of a Woman" (157 minutes) was supposed to be like life?
It's not simply that actors have lost the habit of being quick or economical. At the other end of the production process, editing has given up the handling of film and the direct application of scissors or sharp blades for what I'd call Avid-gazing. The Avid is the standard system for computer editing, and it is a way of working -- some heretics allege -- that encourages moodiness, brooding, felt passages, grace intervals, small talk, luxuriant fades and dissolves. You may not notice the fattening, day by day, but before you know it your film is 25 minutes longer than you thought it was going to be. There's a sort of stagnant, perfumed loveliness just hanging about in your movie. The story takes longer, and as every old-time Hollywood expert knew, with the kinds of stories they were telling, you needed to hurry so no one in the audience had time to wonder about the holes and implausibilities.
I know how easily this might sound like middle-aged bad temper, and the old lament that they did things better, or faster, once upon a time. I am not going to dispute the necessary, glorious, earned length of some films. I don't want parts one and two of "The Godfather" any shorter. Indeed, I rejoiced in the chronological reordering of the two, done for television, that unearthed scenes never shown in theaters -- and that clocked in at 386 minutes, or nearly six and a half hours. If that were playing anywhere tonight, I'd be first in line, and give me a 75-minute intermission for a caprese salad and a nice penne puttanesca.
Nor would I dispute that some directors need not only length but also a sense of duration. Take Jacques Rivette. He works gradually; he is a master of delay, repetition and the ritual of enactment. "Celine and Julie Go Boating" (193 minutes) is one of the greatest films ever made, though I do recall a screening at which the audience was very appreciative of a brief intermission in which sustaining candies were served. I am game for "La Belle Noiseuse" (240 minutes), because you need to see the stealthy process of drawing and painting, and because Emmanuelle Beart has a body that lasts that long.
I will happily accept the principle that, historically, we hardly know how long a film is, or ought to be, or why. For 20 years, more or less, in nickelodeons and storefront theaters, audiences were cheerful with bits and pieces that never ran over 30 minutes and were often far shorter. Those lofty figures, the directors, got ambitious. In hindsight, it was said that they had evolved a "film grammar" (different shots cut together) that permitted far larger, grandiose schemes -- not so much narrative as encyclopedic. And so D. W. Griffith promoted himself and the medium with "Birth of a Nation" (159 minutes) and "Intolerance" (178).
Woodrow Wilson said that "Birth of a Nation" was "history written with lightning." Who ever knew he had such dry humor? That's not lightning; it's the glare of polar summer. Of course, those two Griffith films are helpless landmarks, and the business and the audience were persuaded by the virtues of greater length. But if you want to give students or newcomers a sense of gratitude toward Griffith, show some of his earlier shorts -- "A Corner in Wheat," "The Lonedale Operator," "The Musketeers of Pig Alley" -- where the charm, the sentiment, the picturesque and the blooming of cinematic possibilities are so much more favorably handled in 20 minutes or less.
So the picture business settled on the orthodoxy of 90 minutes -- though for years, the feature film was mixed up with the variety of comedy shorts, serials, newsreels and cartoons. (And if you still think that an important director is cheated by a mere 90 minutes, recollect that Ingmar Bergman's "Persona" is just 81.) Audiences were flexible, and they had stamina.
They did not disdain brief offerings, they were alert to flat or idle patches in films and they liked long evenings in the dark. When David O. Selznick and his chums set out in a car loaded with reels of "Gone With the Wind" one Saturday in September 1939, they were looking for a theater that would permit a sneak preview. They came to the Fox in Riverside, Calif., which was offering a double bill of "Hawaiian Nights" and "Gunga Din." Thus, the four-and-a-half-hour rough cut of "Wind" was smuggled in after "Nights." And when the applause and furor died down after its close, some patrons asked for "Gunga Din."
Was it just habit, or is there some innate justice that makes us feel that a movie -- an entertainment movie -- is worth 90 minutes, or maybe 120? Was it vision, genius and radical temperament that made Erich von Stroheim attempt the 10-hour "Greed"? Or was it a mixture of madness, vanity and gambling? "Greed" is great at two hours. Was it five times greater at 10, or just prolonged, excessive and beyond common sense?
Genius is not a reliable answer. I went to see Oliver Stone's "Any Given Sunday," and, along with a large audience, I had a merry time with its action football. But everyone in the theater instantly recognized the several padding scenes in which characters had lengthy, fatuous discussions about football as a metaphor for life. It was as if we had all dreaded such humbug and hoped that the film would be smart enough to scorn it. Even after a century of movies, we have rear ends that know when to itch.
Equally, at the close of "The Talented Mr. Ripley" (I won't spoil this with details), there is a murder more heard than seen that is delivered with such astringent economy you can easily miss it. In other words, after two hours on screen, "Ripley" is still a very fast film.
With a whole fresh century ahead of us now, and all the forecasts of enhanced home viewing at our own convenience, we have a grand opportunity to reappraise how long a film is, can be, should be, or how quick. And once we consider television as part of the climate of length, we may see how, already, we are responding to very different kinds of scale. Every half-hour "Friends" show, for instance, is one episode -- about 22 minutes each, as nicely contained as Chaplin one-reelers. Yet the years of "Friends" have amounted to an immense, cyclical movie, a mass of small stories or incidents, with only continuity and aging to contain them (see how Chandler has grown fatter) -- just like life, and maybe 75 hours by now.
That there are mysteries and beauties still in the screen's way of passing time becomes clearer every seven years as Michael Apted's astonishing series on growing up, growing older and moving toward death unfolds. He began with 7-year-olds and the vague notion that if audiences liked it, he'd come back in seven years' time and see what had happened to the kids. It has become an international institution. He is at "42 Up" now. Mr. Apted is so modest a man -- and so entirely willing to be caught up with James Bond, too, who never grows up -- that it's easy to miss his achievement, the doggedness and the rare gift he has allowed us all: of being distant or fleeting relatives to his people. So far, we have an epic of around 12 hours, or 35 years. Think what lies ahead as these ordinary souls come to face eternity. Will it be bearable, or any less difficult than escorting our real companions through the last door -- or realizing that they are standing aside, politely, for us? That moment could be great cinema -- a few seconds in time, never forgotten, like the door closing at the end of "The Searchers." But only if we have really inhabited the other 70 years or so, the life sentence. So do not be too taken aback if in this new century there are great films that become as long as us, or as short as our best moments.
 
The Extreams
 There is no doubt about how much we have denied ourselves at the movies in excluding the short film. As illustration, here are 10 great shorts to marvel over:
The Music Box, Laurel and Hardy, 32 minutes.
 Un Chien Andalou, Luis Bunuel and Salvador Dali, 24 minutes.
 Une Partie de Campagne, Jean Renoir, 40 minutes.
 La Jetee, Chris Marker, 29 minutes.
 The Ransom of Red Chief, an episode from "O. Henry's Full House," Howard Hawks, 20 minutes.
 One A.M., Charlie Chaplin, 20 minutes.
 Zero de Conduite, Jean Vigo, 47 minutes.
 The Immortal Story, Orson Welles, 58 minutes.
 Wavelength, Michael Snow, 45 minutes. (Will it never start?)
Detour, Edgar G. Ulmer, 68 minutes. (The minimal feature.)

 At the other extreme, let me propose:
 Out One: Spectre, Jacques Rivette, 270 minutes.
 The Civil War, Ken Burns, 670 minutes.
 Chelsea Girls, Andy Warhol, 195 minutes.
 Crime Story, Michael Mann, every episode, approximately 50 hours.
 Judex, Louis Feuillade, 484 minutes.
 L'Eclisse, Michelangelo Antonioni, 125 minutes.
 Every San Francisco 49er game from the Joe Montana era, approximately 600 hours.
 Wavelength, Michael Snow, 45 minutes. (Will it never end?)
The Big Sleep, Howard Hawks, 114 minutes. (Hawks at his most languid.) DAVID THOMSON
