HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Inside 'Big Box' Project: Threats to 'Little Boxes'

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: ENGLEWOOD

 BODY:
Hank's Hardware is one of those quintessentially American places.
Behind the big glass windows of its storefront on West Palisade Avenue here, 1,200 square feet of hammers and pails, duct tape and touch-up paint, sandpaper and snow shovels recede down the narrow isles and up pegboard-covered walls. It is all the more American that the owner of Hank's -- Hank Jung -- is from South Korea. 
 Hank's is a place where people can set a spell, but it is also a business, competing in the ever-tightening hardware marketplace, and Mr. Jung is worried that his tiny store will be swept away by an orange tide known as Home Depot.
The Atlanta-based chain of home-improvement centers wants to build a 116,000-square-foot "big-box store" -- 100 times the size of Hank's -- on a site now occupied by an auto-parts distributor along Route 4, near Van Brunt Street, in a mostly industrial corner of the city.
An application by Home Depot is pending before the Englewood Planning Board, but Mr. Jung, 43, of Cresskill, may worry a bit less now. On Jan. 18, before a crowd of hundreds of residents opposed to the store, the City Council introduced an amendment to the local zoning ordinance that would bar retail stores from the proposed site, which is in a redevelopment zone.
The ordinance, introduced by a 3-1 vote, is scheduled for a public hearing by the council on Tuesday. Because the ordinance involves a zoning issue, the planning board must comment on it before the council can vote on its adoption. The board's next meeting is Feb. 29; officials said the board would address the ordinance then.
City officials said the ordinance would block Home Depot's plans if it is adopted before the planning board takes final action on the application. The planning board had scheduled a hearing for last Tuesday but it was adjourned at Home Depot's request. Thomas O'Connor, Home Depot's lawyer, declined to comment on the reason.
If the board does address the ordinance next month, the council could adopt it before Home Depot has a chance to return to the planning board, thus rendering the application moot.
Yellow fliers printed by opponents of the plan, who call themselves Concerned Citizens of Englewood, have circulated around the city. "Traffic in Englewood will become insufferable," the flier reads. "The safety of Second Ward residents who walk to their place of worship will be jeopardized," a reference to a community of Orthodox Jews who live near the site.
In response, Home Depot placed a full-page ad in The Record of Hackensack on Tuesday, trumpeting benefits of the store, which would employ 200 full-time and 50 part-time workers, and provide $500,000 a year in local, county and school taxes. The ad also criticized "misinformation" about the company being spread by "a group of citizens."
John Simley, a Northeast regional spokesman for Home Depot, dismissed the opponents' assertions. The reason this site was selected, he said, was to draw traffic from heavily traveled Route 4. Signs would direct traffic along Grand Avenue and Route 93, he said, away from Palisade Avenue, Englewood's heavily congested main street, about a mile away.
The city council has ordered its own traffic study to determine whether the opponents' concerns are legitimate, said Douglas Bern, the council president.
Home Depot, founded in 1978, has opened 38 stores in New Jersey since the late 1980's; more are on the way.
The Englewood store would be open from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m., but closed on Sunday. It would also have a 16,000-square-foot garden center.
"It wouldn't be what I would call a high-traffic store," Mr. Simley said. "It would be a little busier than usual. It will also be open a little bit later than usual."
Mr. Bern the council president, said thatthe council was concerned with the economic well-being of smaller related businesses, which usually cannot match the low prices and wide variety offered by big-box stores.
But Mr. Simley said Home Depot's marketing studies indicated that its stores actually help to recapture some related spending by shoppers outside each store's market. That in turn, he added, is good for smaller stores that develop niches for products or services not offered by Home Depot.
Hank Jung is not so sure. Behind his cramped counter among several loyal customers one chilly Saturday, Mr. Jung said he was far from confident that the council could block the chain. (Indeed, Mr. Simley said Home Depot planned to protect its interests, though he stopped short of threatening a lawsuit.)
Mr. Jung said his chances of selling his store were already nil because of all the talk. And, he said, he will surely be driven out of business if Home Depot moves in.
"I believe I can't do anything about it, because my prices are higher," Mr. Jung said.
James E. Williams, a retired city employee who now lives in Tenafly, stopped into Hank's for a light bulb and stayed for half an hour. "You don't need to put the man out of business," Mr. Williams said. "I was born in Englewood in 1928. I'm 71 years old, I've seen a lot of changes."
But not everyone opposes Home Depot.
Inez Giraldo, 63, of Englewood, who was behind the counter at La Columba restaurant a few doors up from Hank's, said other Home Depot stores were not close enough to be convenient. "Secaucus es muy lejos -- it's very far," said Ms. Giraldo, whose son owns the restaurant.
Councilman Jeffery Drakeford, who represents the Second Ward, where many residents are black or Latino, was the sole vote against eliminating retail operations from the redevelopment zone, because of the jobs and tax revenues such stores provide, Mr. Bern, the council president, said.
The city's Democratic mayor, Paul Fader, who sits on the planning board, has abstained from any action by the board and from taking a public position on Home Depot in order to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest. Mr. Fader, a lawyer, represents TCW, the owner of a shopping center in Holmdel, in a suit against the center's builder and architect. The center is managed by a subsidiary of Trammell Crow, a Dallas-based real estate company that has expressed interest in building an office tower on the site sought by Home Depot.
Mr. Fader said he was referred to TCW by another lawyer, Joseph Ferriero, who is chairman of the Bergen County Democratic Committee. Mr. Ferriero inititially represented the Englewood Chamber of Commerce, which is headed by a former mayor, Donald Aronson, in a lawsuit against the planning board to block Home Depot's application. Another lawyer, Michael Goodman, replaced Mr. Ferriero earlier this month.
Mr. Goodman said the suit accused the board of inconsistent zoning, after the board recommended to the city council last fall that retail stores be permitted in the area and the council agreed.
Following the council vote in November, Home Depot submitted its application. But the council moved to reverse its own approval of retail uses by introducing the ordinance on Jan. 18. The council reversed itself because hundreds of residents opposed the Home Depot application, Mr. Bern said.
Mr. Bern said Mr. Fader's and Mr. Ferriero's connections to Trammell Crow, a potential rival of Home Depot to develop the site, had nothing to do with the council's reversal. Mr. Simley, the Home Depot spokesman, said he did not believe the mayor or county chairman tried to exert any influence, official or otherwise, on the council.
In moving to block Home Depot and to conduct a traffic study of the area, Mr. Bern said, "The council was anxious to cool things down, get maximum input, and come back with a quality decision."

HEADLINE: ON THE WATERFRONT;
Don't Dump on Me

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EATONTOWN

 BODY:
Whether the subject is the ownership of Ellis Island or the constitutionality of the commuter tax, the border wars between New York and New Jersey are always lively and vituperative affairs.
That much was in evidence at a hearing last week at Fort Monmouth, where lurking beneath the scientific debates and cost-benefit analysis surrounding the dumping of harbor dredge material in the ocean off Sandy Hook was the perennial and parochial battle over which state was abusing and shortchanging the other under a four-year-old agreement brokered by Vice President Al Gore. 
 Environmentalists, together with local government officials and residents of shore communities, complained loudly to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, the Environmental Protection Agency and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey about the potential for contamination to the ocean from dumping the soupy, dredged mud from two port terminals in New York City.
But the loudest applause from opponents to the plan came when Representative Frank Pallone, a Democrat from Long Branch, and a spokesman for Senator Robert Torricelli -- with fists raised and clenched -- thundered from the lectern that New Jersey would no longer be the dumping ground for New York's waste. Mr. Pallone said that he and other New Jersey congressmen were prepared to introduce legislation to prohibit the dumping of any dredge material at the site in international waters off the New Jersey coast.
Clearly, the notion that businesses in New York Harbor were benefiting from the proximity of a New Jersey disposal resource was galling to residents from Sandy Hook to Tinton Falls. Worse yet, in the view of Cynthia Zipf, the executive director of the Highlands-based Clean Ocean Action, was that the ocean disposal seemed necessary partly because New York had yet to establish a land-based disposal site of its own for its most contaminated dredge materials, as required by the agreement.
By contrast, New Jersey environmental agencies have spent $49 million to establish such an upland disposal resource in the "brownfields" or old industrial areas around Newark Bay for its most toxic of dredge mud.
"While New Jersey is doing the right things, New York is not, and the federal agencies are enabling New York to continue their sloth-like pace toward progress," said Ms. Zipf, her comments punctuated by cheers from her supporters and jeers from hundreds of longshoremen who showed up by the busload.
The longshoremen contend that dredging opponents are threatening port jobs throughout the region.
Nonetheless, Ms. Zipf continued, "What is needed is a clear message to New York that they must develop alternatives before things get worse."
Lillian C. Borrone, the director of port commerce for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said that although the specter of New York dumping on New Jersey was an aggravating factor, it was essentially a "red herring."
Ms. Borrone maintained that the material being dredged from the Brooklyn Marine Terminal near Red Hook and the Castle Astoria fuel depot in northern Queens was not toxic and met the strict standards set by the dredging agreement for ocean dumping.
"If you are trying to scare people to death, you use the boogie man of New York dumping on New Jersey," she said, speculating that the goal of opponents in mischaracterizing the material was to break the agreement and stop all dumping in the ocean. "It is a specious argument and it places us in an unpredictable situation when it comes to our plans to keep the port competitive with other deep-water ports along the east coast."
Indeed, a spokeswoman for the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, which is working on New York's land-based disposal, was even more dismissive of the notion of one state dumping on the other.
"This is silly partisan politics from people who don't know the facts," the spokeswoman, Jennifer Post, said in a telephone interview. "There is no safety issue here because the material is safe."
Seth Kaye, executive vice president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, stared out at opponents from the lectern and called them "misguided activists using scare tactics and misleading data."
The shouting match aside, New York officials insist that they are working hard to develop land-based disposal alternatives, but insist they do not have as many large brownfields areas close to the ports and accessible by barge as New Jersey. Ms. Post said that in the meantime, the state is spending $20 million on programs to reduce the volume of future contaminants that may find their way into port channels and ship berths.
Other officials familiar with the problems of upland disposal of dredge spoils said that criticism of the dumping coming from New Jerseyans -- whether scientifically justified or not -- was likely to make it more difficult to find a New York site willing to take it.
But even New Jersey officials and others who sided with the dredging supporters said that New York has not lived up to its part of the agreement.
For his part, Vice President Gore, in a letter to opponents of the dredging earlier this month, defended the agreement that bears his name and urged them to it to continue. But at the same time he noted that New Jersey "had demonstrated leadership" in the search of land-based disposal alternatives and expressed hope that "New York will emulate that example".
Ms. Borrone of the Port Authority, speaking at last week's hearings, also noted that "New York has not been as successful as New Jersey" in coming up with alternatives.
Representative Robert Menendez, a Democrat from Union City who supports the dredging and was an architect of the 1996 Agreement, called New York's performance "pathetic.
"This isn't a New York vs. New Jersey issue," Mr. Menendez said. "It is a standards issue that will affect both New York and New Jersey, and New Jersey has just been more agressive."

HEADLINE: On Politics;
The Whitmans Get Around. By the Way, Here's the Tab.

BYLINE: By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
As New Jersey residents dig out from last week's snowstorm, they can rest assured that thanks to their tax dollars, Governor Whitman is also battling the snow and cold this weekend. All week she let people know she would be high in the Alps, in the glorious resort town of Davos, Switzerland.
The occasion is the 30th annual World Economic Forum, the planet's most exclusive networking session, where chief executives, government officials and professional Deep Thinkers are spending six days grappling with the ominous task of promoting "responsible globality." 
 President Clinton is one of 33 heads of state scheduled to attend. The invitees include a bevy of high-octane corporate executives like Bill Gates of Microsoft; Steve Case of America Online; Jack Greenberg of McDonald's; the media baron Rupert Murdoch, and the chairman of Ford Motor Company, William Clay Ford. Secretary General Kofi Anan of the United Nations and an assortment of dignitaries, intellectuals and Nobel laureates will also take part.
Among this lofty group will be exactly one governor, Mrs. Whitman, accompanied by her husband and her commissioner of economic development, Gualberto Medina.
The governor's singular status at the Davos retreat, and the fact that the Forum has also been dubbed the most expensive junket in the world, has made some New Jerseyeans question what, if anything, the state's beleaguered taxpayers are getting in return for their investment.
New Jersey is paying $3,709 in air fare for the governor and her husband, John (they will receive complimentary accommodations). The state will also pay $3,000 for Mr. Medina's air fare and expenses.
The governor's spokesman, Pete McDonough, said the conference was a profitable venture for the state because it served notice that New Jersey was a serious player.
By meeting face-to-face with corporate and government leaders, Mr. McDonough assured, the Whitmans and Mr. Medina could sell the world on the virtues of doing business and creating jobs in New Jersey. He said that most governors did not attend because an invitation to Davos was an honor bestowed only upon the select few who made foreign trade a priority.
"She has meetings with world leaders and C.E.O.'s of the largest companies of the world," Mr. McDonough said. "Dealing at that level, with those kinds of executives, always pays off."
But Democrats said the governor's justification for a publicly financed jaunt to Europe was flimsy at best. And at the very least, they argued that Mr. Whitman, a venture capitalist who would get to spend six days exchanging business cards with Titans of the corporate world, should put his air fare on his company's tab.
"It's certainly legitimate to try to expand New Jersey's business sector, but you don't have to fly the governor and her husband to Switzerland on a junket to do it," said John S. Wisniewski, a Democrat from Middlesex County. "There are so many things we can't afford to do in this state, health care, hospitals, education. We're increasing tolls on the turnpike. It's wasteful for us to spend state money for the governor to go to a resort."
The governor's critics received powerful ammunition last year, when Mrs. Whitman squeezed in a few hours on the fabled Alpine ski slopes and broke her leg. The headlines about the accident, and the recreational aspects of the governor's trip, led to unflattering suggestions that taxpayers were footing the bill for the Whitmans to huddle at some cushy ski lodge, gorging themselves on fondue and fine chocolate with statesmen and chief executives.
Mrs. Whitman's defense of the trip isn't helped by the fact that some other governors don't seem to think that the business-recruiting potential of the Forum is worth the time and expense. Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a fellow Republican, has been invited the last two years, but Mr. Ridge, who only skis occasionally, sent regrets both times, said his spokesman.
Gov. George W. Bush, whose Presidential ambitions might make him particularly inclined to consort with world leaders, has also turned down invitations to Davos. Mr. Bush, an avid bass fisherman who does not ski, was busy campaigning in New Hampshire this year, and was tied up with legislative matters last year, said his spokesman, Scott McClellan.
Mr. McDonough insisted that at this year's meeting, Governor Whitman would be too busy wooing potential businesses to ski, spa or luge. To underscore the rigors of the governor's stay in Davos, her press office last week released an itinerary packed with meetings involving foreign officials, trade ministers and executives who do business in the state. She was also scheduled to give an address about the business climate in the United States, Mr. Medina said.
"The meetings and contacts we've had at Davos in the past have led, directly or indirectly, to hundreds of millions of dollars in prospective sales for New Jersey businesses," Mr. Medina said.
Mrs. Whitman will also take the time to meet with leaders of an assortment of locally based businesses like Merck & Co., Pfizer and Goldman Sachs, which is expanding in New Jersey. Of course, Goldman Sachs, Merck and Pfizer all have headquarters within driving distance of Mrs. Whitman's office in Trenton, which raises the kind of question that probably won't be heard this week in the rarified air over Davos:
Wouldn't it have saved taxpayers money if they had just met in Piscataway?

HEADLINE: Parental Modeling Key to Teenage Drinking

 BODY:
Since the recent arrests of adults stemming from a teenage drinking party in northern Westchester, the media have been buzzing regarding the subject of teenage drinking and what to do about it. "Underage Drinkers Getting Younger and Drinking More," Jan. 16 .
Much of the advice publicly aired from experts has encompassed police enforcement and what I would call the "itinerary" strategy: know where your kids are, who they are with, etc. While these tools are surely part of the prevention arsenal, discussion of the main weapon, parental modeling, has been strangely absent. Simply put, parental alcohol use and parents' attitudes toward drinking influence the decisions their children will make regarding alcohol. 
 As we all know, parents are still the most influential role models for their children. We speak of parental modeling in terms of education, racial or ethnic tolerance and smoking, to name a few examples. Why then, do we not speak of the importance of parents as role models in terms of influencing their children's choices regarding alcohol? I suggest two reasons. First, in order to discuss alcohol issues with their children, parents must first honestly evaluate the use of alcohol in their own lives. Frankly, that is an uncomfortable prospect to many adults. Ask a handful of your friends to discuss the role of alcohol in their lives and how much they drink and watch how fast the subject changes. This does not mean that your friends necessarily have a problem with alcohol, it is just an indication of how sensitive the subject can be.
The second reason stems from our national denial about alcohol. We are so focused on the war on illegal drugs that often we forget that alcohol is by far the most widely used psychoactive drug in America, resulting in enormous costs to both our families and our economy. In 1995, the costs to our economy from alcohol-related problems were $166.5 billion. Alcohol contributes to more than 100,000 deaths a year, making it the third leading cause of preventable mortality. At any given time, 25 percent of all hospital admissions are because of alcohol-related illness or undiagnosed alcoholism. Additionally, it is estimated that alcohol is a factor in 70 percent of all sexual abuse of children, 40 percent of all Family Court actions, 60 percent of all episodes of domestic violence and 25 percent of suicides.
I do not mean to suggest that by enjoying a cocktail or a glass of wine with dinner you will send your child on a descent to the Bowery. Millions of Americans do drink responsibly and sanely (two thirds of the United States population drinks, but only 10 percent of them drink 50 percent of all the alcohol consumed). But the need for strong parental involvement in teenage alcohol prevention is critical because the consequences of early drinking are much greater for our children. Alcohol-related traffic fatalities remain a leading cause of death for teenagers and young adults.
The Centers for Disease Control reports that although alcohol use increases the risk for motor vehicle crashes for all drivers, for young drivers the risk begins to increase at very low blood alcohol content. In young people who drive after drinking, the relative risk for crash involvement is greater at all percentages of blood alcohol contents than for older drivers who drink.
Studies show that people who begin drinking before the age of 15 are four times more likely to develop alcoholism than those who begin at 21.
Furthermore, 64 percent of all high school seniors report that they have been drunk and that nearly one third of all seniors say they have had five or more drinks in a row during the last two weeks.
Additionally, alcohol is a gateway drug for teenagers. That is, it precedes the use of other drugs and lowers one's resistance to the option of using harder drugs. With the young, heavy drinkers tend to be heavy drug users. One study reported that of the students who didn't drink, only 11 percent had tried marijuana and only 1 percent had used it regularly. But of the heavy drinkers surveyed, 85 percent had tried pot and 50 percent used it regularly.
In parenting there is ultimately no greater influence on our children than the role model we as parents provide for them. All of our actions and behavior are stored in their memory and will influence the decisions and choices they make as they navigate the mine field known as adolescence. If we as a society wish to impart the value of teenage abstinence from alcohol and other drugs, we must start in our own homes and provide them with enviable role models.
 
PETER B. HARCKHAM
Katonah 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
For a Family of Builders, the Bronx Is Up

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
FOR years, they have had their offices on East 173rd Street, in the heart of the South Bronx. And during that time they have been in the vanguard of the redevelopment of the community, in neighborhoods like Melrose and Morrisania, where they have built some 800 units of low-income for-sale housing as well as thousands more units of low-income rentals. Even now, with the construction business booming throughout traditionally more profitable areas of the city, they continue to provide housing where many other developers have been unwilling to tread.
But don't tell Mario Procida, 42, that he and the other members of Procida Realty and Construction Corporation, his family's business, are bleeding-heart do-gooders whose choice of projects reflects some sort of philanthropic bent. 
 "We are in business to make money, like everybody else," he said with just a touch too much gruffness, as if unwilling to admit any ulterior, laudable motive. "We just happened to be here."
Perhaps so. But while the firm has had its share of big projects in prosperous areas, including building condominiums in TriBeCa and constructing the luxury Water Club restaurant on East 30th Street in Manhattan, its specialty now seems to be once-blighted neighborhoods in the Bronx. The company builds what is known as "affordable housing" there, as well as commercial developments. And the experience of the Procidas in the Bronx has held them in good stead for similar projects in other places like Poughkeepsie, where they have been selected for a project along the city's depressed riverfront, and in Atlantic City, N.J., where they built an urban renewal development called Madison Landing.
Originally located on East 7th Street in Manhattan, the company was founded in 1928 by Mr. Procida's grandfather, also named Mario, and has always been a family concern. According to Mr. Procida, it moved to the Bronx in the mid-1970's so that his father, Joseph, could be closer to home in New Jersey, and because it was "easy to get from the Bronx to all the other boroughs." Though his father has long since left the day-to-day management of the company to others, he still comes in to help out, Mr. Procida said. The 15 or so employees also include Mr. Procida's mother, Dorothy, the company controller; his sister, Christine Albericci, 34, a senior vice president; and a brother, Joseph, 32, a vice president.
Procida's community involvement began in the 1980's, almost by accident, Mr. Procida said. The family was then primarily building "a lot of fast-food restaurants." But they were also doing a $10 million "high end" residential project near the Throgs Neck Bridge called the White Beach Condominiums, which made the company "one of only a few that were building homes in the Bronx then," Ms. Albericci said.
And so, she said, when redevelopment of the South Bronx became a municipal priority, local groups approached the Procidas and asked them to bid on a subsidized-housing project.
They won the bid, and the result was Salters Square, a group of 130 town houses east of Crotona Park on Intervale Avenue, completed in 1988. The project is in Melrose near Charlotte Street, whose burned-out lots became a national symbol of urban decay in the 1970's.
For its part, Procida received a so-called builder's fee, its profit strictly limited by the terms of its agreement with the project's various public and private sponsors.
Since then, Procida has built many similar developments. For example, Melrose Court is a project of 265 condominiums, all with outside entrances, clustered around three courtyards, that won numerous design awards in the early 1990's. The latest residential project is called Plaza de los Angeles, in the city's Melrose Commons Urban Renewal Zone. Built by Procida together with the architects Magnus Magnusson and Peter Stand, Plaza de los Angeles comprises 35 three-family homes that are scheduled for late winter or early spring occupancy.The homes sell for $220,000 to $230,000; 80 percent are already sold.
Like Melrose Court, Plaza de los Angeles and many of Procida's more recent projects have been sponsored by the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that serves as an intermediary between the city and developers. Officials of that group praise the Procida firm.
"They are really committed to building affordable housing," said Salvatore D'Avola, vice president of the partnership's home ownership program. "They are good builders and they are responsible."
But there have been some bumps in the road for the Procida family. Mario Procida concedes that some problems, such as leaky roofs, surfaced after the construction of Salters Square, the Procidas' first low-income project. When homeowners complained, Procida was obliged to agree to make repairs, although at least one resident declined the repairs and instead sued. Mr. Procida said the case was still pending.
A falling out with another brother, William, led to his departure from the company a few years ago, although Mr. Procida said that family members were all talking to one another now. And a large commercial project in New Jersey that went bad caused the company to file for bankruptcy in late 1996; Mr. Procida said that the company had emerged from that proceeding and was now financially sound, with gross annual revenues of about $12 million.
And while the company remains committed to staying, and building, in the Bronx, it is pursuing projects elsewhere. "There is still a lot of stuff that can go wrong," Mr. Procida said. "And there are limited profit margins. But we are fairly expert in this marketplace now, and in it to stay."
Why, though, if there is more money to be made elsewhere?
Ms. Alberrici points to a plaque that a family gave to her in gratitude for the Procida family's efforts in getting them into their very first home. "There's definitely a warm and fuzzy aspect to it," she said, smiling.
Mr. Procida smiled, too, albeit for only a second. "The fact is that we have rebuilt neighborhoods," he said. "That is gratifying, I admit."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KINGSBRIDGE;
Bronx Residents Take Aim At City Hall's Armory Plan

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Ronn Jordan grew up in the Fordham section of the Bronx. When he was 4 years old, during a bus ride in the northwest part of the borough, he caught his first glimpse of the Kingsbridge Armory, a massive medieval-looking structure at Jerome Avenue and West Kingsbridge Road.
"It was majestic," he remembered. But over the years, Mr. Jordan has seen the building deteriorate. "It has hurt members of the community here to see how bad it looks now," he said. "It has become the world's largest pigeon coop." 
 Last week, Mayor Giuliani announced a $110 million plan to transform the armory into a 475,000-square-foot entertainment, sports and retail complex. But Mr. Jordan is one of many Bronx residents who think the mayor has ignored neighborhood residents by developing a plan that does not meet local needs.
"The community has been left out of the loop," Mr. Jordan said. "It's like the mayor's just sitting in City Hall and saying, 'I'm going to tell them what they need in the northwest Bronx.' "
Mr. Jordan and the Northwest Bronx Community and Clergy Coalition, a neighborhood organization with which he is involved, have long been urging the city to use the armory to alleviate overcrowding in local schools. District 10, in which the armory is situated, is the city's most overcrowded.
Bruce A. Irushalmi, a spokesman for District 10, said the school board had always hoped the site would include an educational component. "There is a very specific need and very identifiable need for additional educational space in the Kingsbridge Road area, because it's the epicenter of our population explosion," Mr. Irushalmi said.
Michael Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said the city had considered adding a school to the site, but rejected the idea.
"At the end of the day, we wanted a project that will be self-sustaining," Mr. Carey said. "A school would not be able to pay for this facility because of the size and cost to keep this project operational."
Instead, the city will work with RD Management, a retail center development company, and Basketball City, a company that runs several recreational efforts, to create a commercial complex that, he says, will become a "massive economic engine for the community." The project would provide 1,100 permanent jobs and 625 construction jobs and take two and a half years to complete.
John M. Reilly, executive director of the Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation, a nonprofit group, said he hoped the city would still consider other options.
"We're happy to see the administration is committed to put some public funds towards it," he said. "But we think the plans the community is talking about need further discussion." NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
EvenS.U.V. Drivers Can Find Ways to Hug a Tree

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FORGET road rage. Though it may seem like the trendy highway vice, environmentalists say millions of American vehicle buyers have committed a different sin, namely gluttony. They went shopping for a family car and came home instead with a sport utility vehicle, a van or a pickup truck.
If you are in this group, and unless you haul bales of hay or entire soccer teams, or commute up and down the Grand Tetons, you may be wantonly contributing more than your share of pollution said to cause global warming. To quote Eldridge Cleaver out of his radical 1960's context, you are part of the problem, not part of the solution. 
 But suppose you recognize the error of your ways. What can you do to atone?
Quite a bit, say environmentalists and energy experts who hope that buyers who picked something bigger than a car will suffer some pangs of conscience. Lately, S.U.V.'s, vans and pickups account for about half the sales of "light duty vehicles," the government's term for the kinds of cars and trucks purchased for household and small-business use.
It's not too late to repent. You can do so from the comfort of your own home, but you may have to face certain hardships, like getting by with only one refrigerator and junking the halogen torchier. Like a dieter compensating for a binge, you have dug yourself in deep, but with a lot of small steps you can still climb out.
First, the scale of the problem. Burning a gallon of gasoline, no matter how cleanly the vehicle does it, creates a little more than 18 pounds of carbon dioxide, the most prevalent of the so-called greenhouse gases. In the process, carbon from the gasoline is combined with oxygen from the air in amounts that scientists can weigh, or calculate.
Add in the energy use required to refine that gallon from crude oil and haul it to your neighborhood gasoline station, and each gallon is worth about 20 pounds of pollution. The number is the same whether that gallon takes you 70 miles in a Honda Insight (the new hybrid that saves gasoline by shutting off the engine at stop signs and turning energy lost in braking into electricity for acceleration) or the four-wheel-drive Range Rover, at about 13 miles a gallon.
Put differently, for each pound of carbon dioxide, the Insight will go 3.8 miles; the Range Rover will go about 1,100 yards, or about six-tenths of a mile.
Most purchase decisions, however, are not between such extremes but between more similar vehicles, like a typical car and a typical S.U.V. The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that the average light truck gets about 15.3 miles a gallon, compared with 22.5 for the car. The truck generates a pound and a half of carbon dioxide for every pound from the car. Or, assuming that they are each driven 14,000 miles a year, the truck generates 5,600 pounds, or nearly three tons, more carbon dioxide.
Many steps to make up the difference are easy, according to Joseph J. Romm, a former assistant secretary of energy for efficiency and renewables and the author of "Cool Companies" (Island Press, 1999), a book on businesses that have reduced greenhouse gas emissions. "Anybody can cut one to two tons," he said.
The main form of energy used in most homes, providing the biggest opportunity for saving, is electricity. Power generated at hydroelectric and nuclear plants produces hardly any carbon dioxide, but the biggest single fuel is coal, which is rich in carbon. Nationally, the average kilowatt-hour, the energy needed to light ten 100-watt bulbs for an hour, produces about 1.5 pounds of carbon dioxide. In the Northeast, with proportionally more nuclear generation, the number is about 1.06 pounds a kilowatt hour, according to the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy.
AT the national average, earning back the 5,600 pounds means saving about 3,700 kilowatt-hours a year -- what a typical home might use in three months. A household could save almost that much by turning off eight 100-watt bulbs that burn 12 hours a day -- if it has that many big bulbs burning that long, and if the residents don't mind going to sleep at sunset.
There are more practical options. "The No. 1 thing I'd recommend is getting rid of halogen torchiers," Dr. Romm said. Replacing a 300-watt model that burns six hours a night with a fixture that has a 75-watt compact fluorescent bulb would provide about the same light -- but produce 750 pounds less carbon dioxide pollution.
The next step is getting rid of the old refrigerator. Not the one in the kitchen, but the one that used to be in the kitchen and is now in the basement playroom or the garage. To the chagrin of efficiency advocates, it seems that nearly everybody who pulled out the avocado-colored 1970's refrigerator and replaced it with a sleek, new, energy-efficient white-on-white model kept the old one, too. If those who want a couple of cases of cold beer can make do by simply running to the store in their S.U.V.'s, they can save about 1,500 pounds of carbon dioxide a year by junking the old fridge. (If you're keeping track, you're up to 2,250 pounds in carbon dioxide savings, or 1,500 kilowatt-hours.)
Further ideas come from "CO2 Diet for a Greenhouse Planet," a paper by John M. DeCicco of the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy and James H. Cook, Dorene Bolze and Jan Beyea of the National Audubon Society.
A low-flow shower head would save 300 pounds of carbon dioxide in a house with an electric water heater -- 80 pounds with a more energy-efficient gas water heater.
Washing four out of five loads of clothes in cold water instead of hot would save about 1,000 pounds of carbon dioxide with an electric water heater. (If the water was heated with gas, the saving would be 350 pounds; with oil, 500 pounds.)
Do all that in a home with an electric water heater, and your savings total 3,550 pounds of carbon dioxide, not enough to compensate for the S.U.V., but enough to make a good dent.
There are ways to go further, of course -- most notably with the home heating system. But such improvements are usually undertaken only when an old system dies. The American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy says that replacing a 25-year-old oil-fired home heating system with a modern one saves 218 gallons of oil in a house that had used 750 gallons a season. Because heating oil produces slightly more carbon dioxide a gallon than does gasoline, the savings from this step alone would be 5,886 pounds, enough to assuage most cases of S.U.V. guilt.
And there is always the back-to-nature approach. Planting a new tree on the property would absorb 26 pounds of carbon dioxide a year. Planted to shade the house in summer and provide a windbreak in winter, the tree could save 300 pounds a year.

Chart: "Relieving Sport-Utility Guilt"
S.U.V. owners with misgivings about burning extra fuel and causing more pollution can compensate, and then some, in their homes.
 
Excess carbon dioxide emissions by a light truck
If both a typical light truck and a typical car go 14,000 miles a year, the truck will produce 5,600 pounds more in carbon dioxide emissions than the car -- a difference of nearly three tons.
 
By taking the following measures at home, a guilt-ridden driver can more than make up the difference.
Washing machine: Use a front-loading clothes washer that saves energy and water. Savings: 500-1,000 lbs. of carbon dioxide a year
Windows: Install new windows with layers of glazing or tinted coatings. Savings: 4,300 lbs.
Lighting: Replace incandescent lighting with compact fluorescent bulbs. Savings: 1,250 lbs.
Oil furnace: Replace an old furnace with a more efficient system. Savings: 5,900 lbs.
Refrigerator: Replace an old refrigerator with a new, energy-efficient model. Savings: 1,500 lbs.
(Source: American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
From the Streets of Seattle To the Table at Davos

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
MEMORIES of Seattle pervade this latest gathering of world leaders and corporate elite. This being their first big get-together since Seattle, there was much bracing for violent street protests drawing attention to the shortcomings of globalization and free trade. But the message from the streets has hit Davos in a different format.
Not that big, riveting demonstrations are really a possibility here. This tiny ski resort, hard to reach even in summer, is not wide-open Seattle. The well-armed Swiss troops at checkpoints along the main roads are not the easier-going Seattle police. And the World Economic Forum is not the World Trade Organization. 
 Rather than excluding opponents, as the W.T.O. did in Seattle, the forum invites its enemies and critics to participate and mingle with the chief executives of the 1,000 companies whose dues and fees pay almost all of the forum's $37 million annual budget. This year, some of the Seattle protesters got invitations and found that their street demonstrations in Seattle added weight to their words in Davos.
"If you are a Shell or a Monsanto or a BP Amoco, you don't want to be blindsided simply because you have not had contact with the leaders of groups that can mobilize opposition to your practices," said Lance Knobel, who planned the 318 discussion sessions. "You listen to their concerns."
Minds are not changed, of course; no one is likely to come away converted when this gathering ends Tuesday night. The world leaders (Bill Clinton and Tony Blair accepted invitations this year) and famous executives (Bill Gates is a regular) will go on insisting that globalization and free trade are good things that raise living standards.
No one said so more clearly than Lewis B. Campbell, chairman of Textron, a multinational company engaged in manufacturing and finance. But Seattle shook him. "I was very unpleasantly surprised by the outcome," he said. "After Seattle, we have to rethink our assumptions" -- not about the benefits of free trade and investment, but its inevitability. "We could lose."
Mr. Campbell shared a platform with John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and Martin Khor, director of the Third World Network, an umbrella group for 80 or so organizations in developing countries that say unrestricted trade hits their nations especially hard.
In Seattle, Mr. Sweeney, Mr. Khor and Brent Blackwelder, president of Friends of the Earth USA, helped organize and lead demonstrations. Here they were participants. Their message: Removing barriers to trade and investment may be inevitable and even a good thing in the right circumstances. But without proper regulation, the cost is considerable: more pollution, destruction of rain forests, frequent financial crises that destroy jobs and savings, cheap imported food that undercuts small farmers in developing countries, and workers without the power to bargain and protect themselves.
The list goes on, and the arguments fall mostly on deaf ears. Why, then, bother to come here?
For one thing, on the issue of pollution and climate, there is some movement. Companies like BP Amoco that have voluntarily limited the emission of damaging gases into the atmosphere were extolled here. So public opinion and debate do sometimes have an effect, however incipient.
But there is a crucial difference for Mr. Sweeney, Mr. Khor and Mr. Blackwelder between Davos and Seattle. The W.T.O., they say, is a governmental body with the power to set binding rules that enforce free trade, and was doing just that in Seattle. Stopping the rule-setting became a consuming goal, justifying the demonstrations that disrupted the meeting. "No deal is better than a bad deal," Mr. Sweeney said.
The World Economic Forum is a different matter. The corporate luminaries who give it life certainly influence the officials who make the W.T.O. rules, but they don't make any rules themselves. Here in Davos they mostly talk, and it pays to talk with them, Mr. Sweeney said. He has been coming here for three years now.
Mr. Khor and Mr. Blackwelder, newly invited this year, agree. "If we can't change their minds," Mr. Blackwelder said, "we are still left with all the demonstration mechanisms that we used so effectively in Seattle."
Even in Davos, Mr. Blackwelder's organization makes that point. One of his colleagues, Andrea Durbin, maintains a presence at a caucus of organizations opposed to unrestricted trade and globalization that have gathered outside the forum. Some of them were invited but declined to take part.
Those who stayed outside said they would feel compromised if they participated in a conference sponsored by a group they consider undemocratic and deeply opposed to their views. But Friends of the Earth took a more flexible stance.
"Our perspective is that it is important to be inside and outside," Ms. Durbin said at a news conference a few blocks from where the forum is holding its meetings. "There are people we are trying to persuade from the inside, but it is also important to maintain pressure from the outside."
In other words, mass demonstrations remain an option, if not for this isolated ski resort, then for the next act in the escalating struggle over trade and globalization.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3005 words

HEADLINE: 107 Months, and Counting;
Expansion Redefines Economy's Limits

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
IN the summer of 1992, a pervasive gloom cast a shadow over the American economy. The unemployment rate rose to 7.8 percent, the worst in years. The Federal Reserve cut interest rates, trying to breathe life into an economy that seemed caught in protracted stagnation. And the federal budget deficit rose to its highest level ever.
A best-selling book by a prominent economist, Lester Thurow, reflected a widely held view that the United States would continue to stumble behind a vigorous Japanese economy and a unified Europe. Even President George Bush, who would soon lose his job over the dismal economy, acknowledged that something was wrong. 
 What almost no one divined was that the American economy had already embarked on a historic expansion, one that took three more years to really bloom. And how rich that bloom now is. The expansion -- an uninterrupted rise in the value of the goods and services that the nation produces -- becomes the longest in history next month.
Gone is the vision of America as an economically weak giant. With the economy growing since 1995 at an average annual rate of 4.2 percent, unemployment has fallen to a 30-year low of 4.1 percent, and consumer prices have risen less than 3 percent a year. Even as its global rivals have faltered, the United States has turned out to be capable of more growth and less inflation than almost anyone had anticipated.
And that is the great gift of the 1990's. However this expansion ends -- whether in a stock market collapse or more gently -- its legacy is a reborn respect for the nation's potential. Limits to economic growth and prosperity still exist at the turn of the century, but they are not the stunted ones of the 70's, 80's and early 90's.
"The last four years really have lifted our hopes about what is possible," said Paul Romer, an economics historian at Stanford University. "We emerged from the 1970's and 1980's with substantially diminished expectations for the performance of the American economy. And now confidence is returning that the economy can grow as fast as it once did in the past without much inflation."
The 1990's expansion turns 107 months old in February, edging it past that of the 1960's as the longest ever. In other words, it has been nearly nine years since the last recession ended in March 1991.
By most measures, of course, the 60's expansion remains the gold standard for the American economy. Then, the economy grew more quickly. Wages and family incomes rose by larger amounts each year. The poverty level and the unemployment rate fell more quickly and to lower levels. The gap between the wealthy and the poor was much smaller.
Still, over the last four years, the current expansion has gained traction, leaving its mark across America. The strong growth has lifted wages and salaries throughout the work force -- although, adjusted for inflation, for the most part they are not back to levels reached in the 1970's.
Where the expansion clearly shows is in family income. Labor shortages have drawn more family members into the work force, and those with jobs are working more. However stressful that may be for family life, median family income rose to a record $46,737 in 1998, adjusted for inflation, decisively past the old high of $44,974 in 1989.
Tracey and Carrie Jones, who live in a Cincinnati suburb, are beneficiaries of this revival. Mr. Jones, 43, assembles and helps to design labeling machines for commercial packages. He has held the same job for four years, a considerable improvement over the early 1990's, when layoffs forced him into hourly work at several companies, without health insurance or a 401(k) pension plan. He now has both.
The long stay at one employer has raised Mr. Jones's confidence in his own skills. He earns $45,000, up from less than $38,000 when he started in 1996. He got a 3.5 percent raise last year and another one this month.
"I wish it had been 5 percent," he said. "I have worked harder for this company than I have ever worked in my life." In March, he expects a $750 bonus, the amount he got last year. That lifts his spirits.
His wife is not complaining. "As the months pass and he still has his job, that makes me feel better," she said. "And when he comes home and complains about being busy, I say, 'Be glad you are busy.' "
She herself has worked two evenings a week -- a total of four hours -- as a bookkeeper for her dentist. At 38, she devotes the rest of her time to raising the couple's two sons. "Every time my husband goes to have his teeth cleaned," she said, "the dentist has asked, 'When is your wife going to work more for me?' " She has finally agreed to add one afternoon, from noon to 3 p.m., while the boys are in school. That will nearly double her $4,500 in annual pay.
Over all, the income gains have been greatest in the upper tier of the work force. Those earning more than $80,000 -- often much more -- have enjoyed steadily rising incomes, as they did in the 1970's and 1980's.
To be sure, these winners, concentrated on Wall Street and in Silicon Valley, are often paid in shares of stock that have skyrocketed, perhaps far beyond their real worth. Given that those euphorically priced shares have been collateral for a huge amount of borrowing by both individuals and corporations, the expansion could come to an abrupt halt in a market sell-off.
But for now, even the poorest regions are enjoying the fruits of economic growth. No region is poorer than a four-county area in the Rio Grande Valley where the unemployment rate two years ago was more than 20 percent; now it is 13 percent. It's not that there are more jobs in the valley; the situation has improved because so many people who lived there have migrated to Houston, Austin or Dallas, where jobs are plentiful.
"When you are a construction electrician and you are earning $6 an hour or less in the valley, and you hear what they are paying in these other cities, you go," said Sister Judy Donovan, a Roman Catholic nun and a community organizer in the valley for the Industrial Areas Foundation.
Nationally, the economy has grown since 1995 at nearly double the rate that most economists and policy makers thought possible without provoking inflation. The all-important productivity growth rate, tracking how much more each worker contributes to output each year for the same hours of work, has risen to an annual average of 2 percent for the 1990's, better than the 1970's and 80's but well short of the 60's.
"The attitude in the 1960's was concentrate on growth and don't worry about inflation, and that attitude may be returning now," Mr. Romer said. "The strong expansion may be demonstrating to us that fast growth and low inflation reinforce each other."
The expansion has changed the political debate, too. Patrick Buchanan and Ross Perot rose to prominence in the late 80's and early 90's on the job anxieties of many voters. This year, those men have been only faint voices, and neither jobs nor the health of the economy is much of an issue.
But will the expansion last? Even the gloomiest forecasters -- economists like A. Gary Shilling, a Wall Street consultant -- have ceased to see a recession just a few months away. "The stock market speculation has carried the economy longer than I anticipated," Mr. Shilling said.
Other economists say new technologies, spilling out one after another, will keep the economy growing robustly not just for months, but for years, ultimately justifying the stock market's lofty level.
Only time will settle the debate.
 
The Causes
Aid From Computers, Markets and the Fed
What accounts for the durability of the expansion? The Internet and the spread of personal computers are high on the list, because they raise productivity. The Intel Corporation, to pick one example out of thousands, has set up special Web sites for customers, mainly computer manufacturers that buy Intel's chips. They place orders on the Web, and computers do the rest, letting Intel employees do other tasks.
"That is a real improvement in our productivity," said Andrew S. Grove, Intel's chairman. Output and revenue have risen faster than labor costs, largely because of the new technologies. Each Intel employee accounted for $436,000 of the company's revenue in 1999, up from $197,000 in 1991. There is more money for profits and wages without raising prices, and the economy grows larger without inflation.
But is every company an Intel? Or is the impact of computers and the Internet likely to be used up in a decade or two?
Many industries are benefiting: Airlines and theaters through ticket sales on the Web, retailers through e-commerce, Wall Street through online trading. The growing list raises the national efficiency for now.
"We have entered a period of rapid and constant innovation, just as we did when electricity and the light bulb spread through the country," said James H. Stock, an economist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government. "But there are limits. I tend to see the computer and the Internet and the technologies related to them like electricity and the light bulb. Once they are widely used, their effect on growth tends to taper off."
Still, new technology is by no means the only reason for the booming economy. Another is that strong profits and low-cost financing, mainly through the stock market, have resulted in record levels of corporate investment in all kinds of machinery, not just computers, and so in increased production. Moreover, Asia and Latin America have become growing sources of manufactured goods, a new supply line that was particularly noticeable during the Asian financial crisis.
The Fed also gets a share of the credit for sustaining the expansion. Rather than sharply raising interest rates in anticipation of higher inflation, a reaction that until the 1990's often dumped the economy into recession, the Fed is now more willing to let a boom run its course, as long as inflation stays reasonably close to 2 percent, roughly its present level.
"The way to describe the change at the Fed is to say the people there are not so trigger-happy," said Robert M. Solow, a Nobel economist. "They keep talking as if they were still trigger-happy about inflation, but they no longer really are."
There are still other changes. The United States has become less dependent on oil, so the latest increase in oil prices has not produced the sort of price shock that was so devastating in the 1970's and 80's. The rise of a service economy has also helped to hold down wages and inflation. Faced with labor shortages, service companies have been quick to relocate or expand in states with pools of inexpensive, unemployed workers.
Manufacturers cannot move their heavy equipment and their more complicated operations so quickly. But that is not a problem for Burrelle's Information Services, which culls newspaper, magazine, video and Internet citations for corporate customers.
Burrelle's, with headquarters in Livingston, N.J., has big operations there and in New York City and Utah. But its growth these days is in Houlton, Me., where unemployment is a couple of percentage points higher than the national average. As a result, educated people can be persuaded to sign on for $6.50 an hour, with a promise of $10 an hour after three or four years.
"We can still get people in Houlton, but the labor market is getting tighter," said Robert Waggoner, Burrelle's chief executive. "We are looking for places where unemployment is higher and they also have good school systems."
Like other busy companies, Burrelle's pushes its workers to keep up with the workload -- a bit of extra pressure that has often added to productivity at the height of an expansion. And employees everywhere, perhaps cowed by past downsizing, are more willing to accept signing bonuses, performance bonuses and profit sharing as their reward rather than insisting on raises, which are harder for employers to absorb without raising prices.
"There is a general understanding in the United States today that companies are not going to compete for workers by raising wages," said David Collander, an economic historian at Middlebury College in Vermont. "And that understanding has become embedded in our social structure."
Rising stock and home prices are high on everyone's list of factors contributing to the expansion's durability. So is growing public confidence, at its highest since the 1960's. "It would be odd if people were not pleased with their job situations and their rising incomes," said Richard Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Consumer Surveys. "What is odd is that they don't expect the good times to end in the next five years."
 
The Rules
Raising the Ceiling On the Economy
A result of this optimism has been an explosion in consumer spending, paid for partly through higher incomes, but also through credit. As stocks and homes have climbed in value, they have become, in effect, the collateral for the rising debt that helps keep the expansion robust.
Nearly 25 percent of the economic growth since 1996 is a result of the stock market and real estate booms, says Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve.
And if those booms had never existed? If the stock market had never become so exuberant? The economy would still have grown substantially faster, without inflation, than Mr. Greenspan thought was possible -- until he saw it happen.
However the expansion is finally explained, an old set of rules, deeply ingrained in economic forecasting and college textbooks, is losing its punch. In the late 1960's, the inflation that had descended on America was attributed to shortages of goods and services. After all, hadn't Lyndon Johnson demonstrated that even the mighty American economy could not produce enough to satisfy a prospering citizenry and also an army in Vietnam?
That idea of the economy's limits gained an iron grip on academic theory and government policy. Unemployment could not fall below 6 percent, the rules had it, or labor shortages would drive up wages, then prices. In the 70's and 80's, that happened just often enough to demonstrate the theory's accuracy. Industry could no longer operate flat out, risking inflationary shortages, which also occurred often enough to be disconcerting.
So the Fed sought to slow the economy whenever it seemed to be expanding by more than 2.25 percent a year or so. That was considered the outer limit, an inflationary trigger point, all right for a few months or even a year, but beyond what the nation could sustain for a significant period.
"There were all sorts of walls that economists put up in their minds that ruled out the possibility of powerful economic growth," Mr. Collander said. "It is these walls that are coming down."
The view of Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers reflects the new consensus. "Three to 3.5 percent," he said in an interview, "is probably not an implausible number right now as a sustainable growth rate for the economy."
The difference may seem small, but the amount of money it represents is considerable in the giant American economy, which produces more than $9 trillion a year in goods and services. Increasing that output by Mr. Summers's new rate means an additional $345 annually for each person in the United States. That has been happening, and then some, since 1996.
 
The Dangers
An Eerie Replay Of a Debt Buildup
But the risks -- the chief one is debt -- embedded in this growth are considerable. Debt is why the 1990's expansion got off to such a slow start. In the euphoria of the 1980's, huge amounts were borrowed against real estate or to finance corporate acquisitions -- always with the promise that office rents or still-rising real estate prices or cash flow from a "restructured" company would more than cover the debt payments. The 1987 stock market crash, and the end of the expansion a little more than two years later, dashed that promise.
In the debt crisis that followed, hundreds of savings and loan associations failed and banks had to write off billions in unpaid debt. With considerable help from the Federal Reserve, the lenders got back on their feet, but until they did Mr. Greenspan spoke of the "head winds" that were holding back the 1990's expansion in its early years.
A similar debt buildup is occurring now. Private-sector debt is as high as it was in 1985, the peak in the 80's. By one measure, total private-sector spending exceeds income and profits by an amount equal to 4.5 percent of the gross domestic product, says Wynne Godley, an economist at the Jerome Levy Economic Institute, a research group in Annandale, N.Y. That figure is a record.
But by another measure -- debt as a percentage of stock values and home prices -- the borrowing is rather mild, roughly 14 percent for households and 52 percent for businesses other than financial institutions. Those percentages are no higher today than at the beginning of the expansion.
Much, then, is riding on the booms on Wall Street and in home values. As long as they stay in place, the expansion should continue.
"If some shock broke the optimism in the financial markets, a lot of people could be in a serious situation," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former economic adviser to President Clinton and now dean of the business school at the University of California at Berkeley. "They have become indebted relative to their wealth rather than their incomes, and that is a built-in vulnerability."
A recession must come. No economist doubts that. The only questions are when, and with how much damage. The answers depend on the extent to which innovation continues to drive growth, and on the stock market's ability to stay afloat.
"I don't even want to talk about a stock market collapse," said Mr. Solow, the Nobel laureate. "What everyone would like to see is the stock market stand still while companies and their profits catch up."

"Four Decades of Economic Gains, Compared"
As in the 1960's -- and in contrast to the 70's and 80's -- the American economy in the 1990's managed to grow and create jobs without setting off inflation. But the expansion in the 90's did not benefit people with modest incomes nearly as much as that of the 60's.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Success Story in Germany Is Not All It Appears to Be

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
AS January winds down, the German stock market's benchmark index is leaving its main European rivals in the dust. The DAX index of 30 stocks is up 1.6 percent in euros, while the other major indexes are down sharply.
But the performance of the DAX is deceiving. It comes on the backs of just six stocks: SAP, Siemens, Munich Re, Mannesmann -- the Vodafone takeover target -- Allianz and Deutsche Telekom. The other 24 in the index are down so far this year. The big loser, Metro, is off 18.9 percent. 
 That is not a new story for American investors, who saw the Dow Jones industrial average rise 25.2 percent last year, while 61.6 percent of the stocks trading on the New York Stock Exchange were down 20 percent or more from their 52-week highs, according to Salomon Smith Barney. But it is just one of the many hurdles that American investors in German stocks face this year.
The worst news of 2000 has been the plunge in the value of the euro, which fell below the $1 level on Thursday and continued its decline on Friday, finishing the week at 97.78 cents. The euro is now down 16.2 percent since its debut on Jan. 1, 1999. So in dollar terms, the DAX is off 1.6 percent this year.
And while a weak euro could spur exports and, in turn, European stocks, its continued decline will eat away quickly at American investors' gains.
The campaign finance scandal that has engulfed the Christian Democratic Union of former German Chancellor Helmut Kohl is mushrooming. It has sent the DAX plunging on some days and is undermining the euro.
"A bigger correction in the German DAX cannot be ruled out, especially if Mr. Kohl were to name the companies involved" in the scandal, according to Marco Kramer, German strategist at Paribas in Frankfurt.
George Hodgson, European strategist at ABN-Amro in London, says an even bigger danger lies in the chance the German scandal will taint other European politicians.
"If global investors start to sense that European politicians are not healthy, the euro zone could attract the type of risk premium that Italy used to attract," Mr. Hodgson said, referring to the Italian corruption scandals that ruined the Christian Democrats in the early 1990's.
Inflation, while still below 2 percent, could head higher, meaning interest rates would rise. The spike in oil prices, the weaker euro (which makes oil and other imports more expensive) and union wage demands are all increasing price pressures.
On the positive side for Germany, the scandal has propped up the current chancellor, Gerhard Schroder of the Social Democratic Party, whose government was on its knees. That should make it easier to get key tax proposals approved this year.
ONE proposal, announced last month, calls for eliminating capital gains taxes on the sale of the large stakes that many German companies, especially banks and insurers, own in other concerns. The tax change would make it easier for German companies to begin the restructuring, acquiring and merging needed to make them leaner, meaner and more competitive. In other words, it would provide an impetus to go through the process of creating shareholder value that many American industries have already completed.
Banks, said Alex Ions, Lehman Brothers European strategist in London, would get cash from the sale of holdings, easing acquisitions abroad. Companies freed of these outside holders would find it easier to merge or would become more attractive acquisition targets.
The takeover fight for Mannesmann, the biggest operator of wireless telephone networks in Europe, illustrates the growing support for restructuring. "There has been no collusion by Mannesmann with the German establishment to fend off the takeover," Mr. Ions said.
But this is a long-term bet. And, unfortunately, the rally from the December tax announcement was immediate. Deutsche Bank shares jumped 14 percent in a day.
Mr. Hodgson said there should be a "second leg" to the capital gains story when the tax is approved and companies act on it. But, he said, over the "next few months, this could recede into the background."
The performance this year of the German stocks in Lehman Brothers' recommended pan-European portfolio also proves that patience is needed. The restructuring theme is at play in all of them -- Bayer, BMW, Continental, Mannesmann and Volkswagen. But except for Mannesmann, the takeover target, all are down 11 percent or more.
The restructuring theme, Mr. Ions said, "has not produced at the bottom line as quickly or as painlessly as some have hoped."
